fields.headline: Shearer spells double trouble
fields.trailText:
Newcastle 2 - 1 Ipswich
Shearer's brace puts young pretender in his place.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at St James' Park
fields.body:
There was a masterclass on Tyneside, but not the one everyone had expected. On the final whistle the young pretender strode up to the man from whom he had learnt so much and warmly shook his hand. Alan Shearer responded by agreeing to swap shirts. The Ipswich goalscorer Marcus Stewart went home happy, "Shearer 9" stuffed into his kit bag.

Meanwhile, the two managers George Burley and Bobby Robson - apprentice and mentor during the most successful period in the Suffolk club's history - quietly arranged to meet up for a drink in the bar afterwards.

"I didn't tactically out-think George to win the game," said Robson, relieved at a first home win and Premiership goal since August. "I'm not that clever."

Shearer was the difference between expectant Newcastle and surprise-package Ipswich. His well-placed left-foot shot past Richard Wright restored parity midway through the first half, and he played for, won and converted the penalty that settled the result. Burley must hope that he made a lasting impression on his own quartet of strikers, all of whom featured on Saturday.

"Just playing against Alan, you learn from his experience," said Stewart, who had prodded the visitors into a deserved early lead after Jermaine Wright had twice seen his angled shots blocked on the United goalline. "There's only one other player in England who can hold the ball up as well as him - Mark Hughes. If you give him the chance, someone like Shearer will score."

Robson agreed: "Shearer was superhuman. The way he held up the ball, his movement off it and his finishing were outstanding. Rob Lee almost matched him, so our two old stagers did us proud."

Ipswich could be chuffed as well. They were the better side in the first half with Jamie Clapham and Herman Hreidarsson menacing down the left flank. With Nolberto Solano hamstrung and substituted before the interval, Newcastle switched to a more balanced 4-4-2 formation at the break and wrested the advantage from their visitors, but were thankful that John McGreal and the substitute James Scowcroft missed presentable late chances.

In truth Ipswich lost only because of the game's sole controversial incident; Shearer ran on to Steve Caldwell's 66th-minute pump forward and was tripped in the area by Mark Venus. "The crowd shouted, Shearer fell down and the referee was 60 yards away and gave a penalty," said the visiting manager.

Shearer naturally disagreed. "I don't quite know how Mr Burley can say that. It was a clear penalty. The defender took my standing leg away as I cut the ball back inside."

Television replays concurred and Shearer deposited the spot-kick into the top corner, his sixth goal in as many games.

fields.headline: Merson magic lights up the gloom
fields.trailText:
Everton 0 - 1 Aston Villa
Merson's magic helps Villa wing it.
fields.body:
Can there be a sorrier sight than two of English football's true giants thrashing around in such an undignified, unedifying fashion? That we had a goal was remarkable: that it was one of such beauty was, in the circumstances, unbelievable.

As a wretched match played in driving rain crawled into its final minute, Paul Merson, an aristocrat amongst artisans, clipped the ball up and over the Everton goalkeeper Paul Gerrard from almost 35 yards and watched it drop into the net.

"The conditions were difficult, truly awful, and that contributed to our goal," said John Gregory, Villa's manager. "The ball must have moved all over the place in the wind and you can't blame their keeper for that. But it was still a special goal. That's something that Paul is always capable of."

It was Villa's only shot on target but it was enough to give them the most undeserved of victories. Everton were poor but they deserved better from a game that ought to be swiftly forgotten.

At least there had been a measure of fun before kick-off. The shivering hordes were treated to a brief firework display, one that left the stadium cloaked in impenetrable smoke. Unfortunately, shortly before the referee Stephen Lodge raised whistle to his lips for the first time, it cleared.

Long before an interval that could not come a moment too soon, those present were looking back fondly on that pyrotechnic display. It was no longer smoke hanging in the early-evening air, rather a sense of gloom.

With Everton willing to chase a goal but lacking the guile to create an opening despite Aston Villa's timidity, this was always a poor game.

For all Merson's selfless running between Villa's midfield and forward line, for all Thomas Gravesen's endeavour, for all Paul Gascoigne's delicate promptings, there was little to fuel the belief that here was a game that would entertain the faithful.

Sadly for Everton, Gascoigne, the one man who seemed capable of taking on the mantle of matchwinner, did not make it to half-time, departing disconsolately with a leg injury. "It's his thigh. We don't know how bad it is yet but he will see a specialist," said Walter Smith, the Everton manager.

It was not until the 43rd minute that the first corner was won. It was lifted into the box by Gravesen and met powerfully by David Weir, but David James did well to tip over the Scot's header.

At least the referee saw fit to introduce a dash of controversy to proceedings. After 45 minutes Merson sprinted into the area but as he shaped to cross, Weir clattered him from behind. It looked a penalty but Lodge was having none of it.

It was only the deterioration in conditions that precipitated an upturn in the entertainment value after the break, for as the surface became increasingly treacherous, even the most cultured of feet began to make errors of judgment.

Everton did almost fashion a breakthrough before the hour but after doing well to reach Mark Pembridge's cross at the far post Gary Naysmith was horrified to see James, who finished with a bloody nose after a clash with Kevin Campbell, turn his header on to a post.

Thereafter Everton's David Unsworth did his level best to get sent off as it rained and rained. "It wasn't a very pretty match," Gregory said, "but Merson can always do something to win them for us."

webTitle: Bradford grope in blind man's bluff

fields.headline: Bradford grope in blind man's bluff
fields.trailText:
Charlton 2 - 0 Bradford
Early strikes give Bradford that sinking feeling.
fields.body:
Football's most exciting action tends to happen off-field these days and it was easy to see why as Saturday's game disintegrated into simultaneous blind man's buff. Charlton were soon two up. Bradford had had one away goal this season. It was all over with 75 minutes to grope.

Elsewhere Charlton's chief executive Peter Varney listed keener issues - threat to transfer system, distribution of Premier League TV money, NTL withdrawal from pay-per-view contract - affecting the economic wisdom of redeveloping the north stand to create a 26,000-seat stadium, not to mention refusal by Greenwich Council of consent to beam back 10 away matches.

Charlton look after fans and finances alike with exemplary responsibility. But revenue uncertainty, not wholly dependent on status, hangs over the new stand. Varney says the European Commission is leaning towards a salary-based compensation structure; wages could go through the roof - which is what a poplar did to the south stand last week.

Stan Collymore might have raised it again but he was missing. At first it was thought that Bradford, having got their wonder goal at the first go, had transferred him to the Dome. In fact it was wisdom teeth; everyone has them.

For 45 minutes the wit was all Charlton's. They reverted to 4-4-2 as Bradford converted from four to three at the back to match Charlton's most recent formation. Six were needed. Charlton's angled runs and use of width scattered and sliced through the defence, who wobbled like penguins under aerial traffic. Graham Stuart was superb in midfield. He and Jonatan Johansson set up each other's goals.

After the interval Charlton lost their way; Bradford never found theirs. Alan Curbishley blamed "apprehension"; City's Chris Hutchings is entitled to it. One half-expected only his head to arrive, borne on a platter by his chairman. Hutchings said: "We've all got to row together in the same direction." Steve Redgrave is available. But oarsmen, of course, go backwards if not down.

webTitle: Pale Dynamos who shone a brilliant light in postwar Britain

fields.headline: Pale Dynamos who shone a brilliant light in postwar Britain
fields.trailText: When the Moscow Dynamo team visited in 1945 they caused a luminous sensation in grey, austere, war-ravaged Britain.
fields.body:
On the afternoon of Saturday October 13 1945, next to each other in the directors' box at Stamford Bridge, sat the statesmanlike secretary of the Football Association, Stanley Rous, and Comrade Ravenko, the Soviet sports minister's chief emissary, newly flown in from Moscow. They watched Chelsea play West Ham United, and for much of the match the two men (plus two interpreters) were deep in whispered conversation.

Only six months had passed since the death of Hitler, five since VE Day, four since the atom bombing of Hiroshima, and three since Clement Attlee's landslide victory over Winston Churchill in the general election. After the match, in the directors' room, Rous and Ravenko shook hands on their deal before chauffeurs drove them separately away through the bombed-out streets of west London.

Three weeks later, on Sunday November 4, an aircraft touched down at Croydon airport, a US-built lend-lease Dakota with a scarlet star motif on the tailfin and each wingtip. Rous of the FA and a bemedalled phalanx of uniformed personnel from the Soviet embassy greeted the disembarking passengers in the hut which served as the arrivals' lounge.

They comprised 39 men - 20 footballers and 19 trainers, coaches, journalists or general "minders" - and one woman, the interpreter Alex Elliseyeva, whom, in no time, Fleet Street was to dub "Alexandra the Silent".

It was the Moscow Dynamo football team and through that month, 55 Novembers ago, they were to cause a luminous sensation in grey, austere, war-ravaged Britain.

Rous at once had to apologise. He said he had personally telephoned more than 100 London hotels and none could (or would) put up the exotic party en bloc. So their first night was spent bleakly at the Coldstream Guards' Wellington barracks in St James's. They threatened to go home. The next night the party was dispersed in twos or threes around any number of dingy west London hotels. Double the complaints.

On the third day, a desperate Rous persuaded the Imperial Hotel in Russell Square to lease him whole floor - "Do Russians need sheets?" the manager asked him - but accommodation only. All meals (including breakfast) thereafter were taken at the Soviet Embassy in Kensington.

First opponents would be Chelsea on Tuesday November 13. At once, for a whopping £14,000, Chelsea signed the demon Everton and England centre-forward Tommy Lawton, which news doubled the frenzy of anticipation in the capital. Five-shilling tickets (25p today) were already being offered by London spivs for more than £5, which was then the average weekly wage.

The Russians said the press could only watch them practise by invitation. Having done so, Fleet Street's finest were dismissively unimpressed. Paul Irwin in the Sunday Express found the Dynamo players "completely ordinary ... all their work is done standing still. Do not expect much from this bunch of factory workers, Tommy [Lawton] will bag a hatful."

In the People, Tom Morgan concurred: "Chelsea will easily uphold the football supremacy of its fatherland with a ringing victory. Dynamos? These pale boys are far too slow for the top drawer."

Harold Palmer in the Evening Standard predicted that "Chelsea will sweep them off their feet", although Stanley Walton in the Sunday Dispatch did warn: "They all have slightly in-turning toes which, in my youthful days in Scotland, was the hallmark of a useful shot."

By Tuesday at noon, west London was at a standstill. An hour before the start, the Stamford Bridge gates were closed on an over-capacity crowd of 74,496, but with thousands more breaking through smashed-down gates, it was reckoned next day that the actual attendance was more than 100,000.

The Dynamo players warmed up for 15 minutes before kick-off - to the mesmerised delight of the throng that spilled over the greyhound track and right up to the touchlines. No English team had ever "warmed up". The Russians then took off their heavy serge "sweatsuits" (something else a British crowd had never seen) and to a collective gasp the Dynamo "strip" was revealed - dark blue shirts decorated with a pink letter "D" at the breast, long powder blue shorts hemmed with white, and emerald-green stockings with white turnovers.

Immediately before kick-off, each Russian presented a bouquet of flowers to his opponent. The Chelsea players did not know where to look; the vast crowd fell silent at such a uniquely titillating wonder on an English football field. And it remained dumbfounded once the contest began as the Russians' inch-perfect passes, positional switches and fluent speed made monkeys of the back-pedalling English players. The chivalrous Lawton said afterwards: "It was brilliant teamwork, speed and ball control. To be honest, the Russians should have been four goals ahead after only 20 minutes except for their poor shooting."

It ended 3-3. The following Saturday, Dynamo annihilated Cardiff City by 10-0 at Ninian Park (40,000) - "This is an awesome, greased machine, not a football team," said the Cardiff manager Cyril Spiers. On Wednesday, Dynamo beat Arsenal (who had hastily recruited Stanley Matthews) by 4-3 in obliterating fog at Highbury (54,600), and a week later drew 2-2 with Rangers at Ibrox (90,000).

They returned to London for shopping, a banquet with the Lord Mayor, and a visit to Karl Marx's grave at Highgate - and left, in a scarlet-starred Dakota from Northolt airport, as surreptitiously as they had come, leaving a bereft Aston Villa with 70,000 printed but unused tickets for a farewell match the Birmingham club mistakenly thought it had arranged.

On Sunday December 2, in his column in the Graphic, Stanley Matthews wrote of "the finest team ever to visit these islands - we have certainly learned a thing or two from these Dynamos".

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Eriksson resumes a double life
fields.trailText: The better Lazio do this season, the less likely are England to see their new manager arrive early. But that's no bad thing.
fields.body:
"Good evening!"

Thick with irony as well as accent, an Italian voice emerged from the throng to greet the Lazio coach as he entered the post-match press conference in the Olympic stadium on Saturday night.

"Buona sera," Sven-Goran Eriksson replied, trumping the joke with a nod, a wry smile and immaculate courtesy. Then he settled down to talk about a victory which reassured his club and its fans that, although the heart of their "mister" may be pledged to England and its national side, his current attention is focused on consolidating his achievements with Italy's champion club.

By a further irony, not for much longer will Eriksson hear himself referred to as "mister", which is how players and journalists in Latin countries have addressed their coaches since the days when the British spread the game around the world, organising teams and providing the first generation of managers. But the way Lazio cruised to a 2-0 home victory over Bologna silenced, at least temporarily, local speculation that he would be on his way out of Rome long before his contract ends on the last day of June.

Goals from Pavel Nedved and Hernan Crespo, one in each half, were the statistical expression of a total superiority which prompted Eriksson to remark that he had "rediscovered the Lazio of last season". After an uncertain start to the campaign, this was their third win in a row. "It was a fine victory," he said. "I was very pleased. We showed enormous spirit. Physically, mentally and tactically, the team was solid. We gave Bologna very few chances."

In fact they gave Bologna no chances at all. The visitors failed to muster a single shot. A last-minute fitness test had deprived them of the presence of the little veteran Beppe Signori, whose scoring feats during a long spell with Lazio brought him the unofficial title of the King of Rome before Eriksson arrived three years ago, quickly decided that his reign was over, and sold him. Eriksson seems to have upset remarkably few people during his 25 years in football management, but Signori is definitely among them.

When the fans on the Curva Nord caught a glimpse of their once-beloved striker on the big screen before the match, they gave him a warm round of applause. They extended the same courtesy to Eriksson, whose decision last week has clearly not damaged their respect for the man who brought them the championship. Just so long, that is, as he keeps on winning.

"As always, when the results are good, everything is tranquillo," he said on Saturday night. "At the first defeat, the critics will start again. But the team is growing, and we can grow still more in the coming weeks. I believe that this cycle of success for Lazio isn't at an end. It will continue next year and the year after that. This club has learnt how to win, and that will carry on even when I'm no longer on the bench."

His diplomacy extends to a refusal to discuss England while he is about Lazio's business. "Until I finish working with Lazio, I'll speak only of Lazio," he said. But in the medium term that is simply unrealistic, although there is no indication yet of how great a role Lazio's president, Sergio Cragnotti, will allow him to play in England's two World Cup qualifying matches in the spring. At this early stage, there seems to be no bad feeling. "Eriksson's head may be in England," a writer for the Gazzetta dello Sport noted in his reflections on Saturday's victory, "but he read the tactics of this match much better than his opposite number." As for Cragnotti, he contented himself by saying that "the players are professionals, and I was certain that they wouldn't let Eriksson's decision affect their performance".

The better things go in Rome, however, the more unrest there is likely to be in England. And it was an Italian, the Marxist philosopher Antonio Gramsci, who best summed up the present position of Eriksson's next employers. "The old is dying and the new cannot be born," he wrote. "In the interim, a variety of morbid symptoms appears." Or, to put it another way, nature abhors a vacuum. Hence the wild speculation that Eriksson has already invited Alan Shearer to return to the squad, and that Cragnotti has persuaded him to stay on as Lazio's director of football at the same time as fulfilling his obligations to England.

"It's just not true," he said on Saturday of the latter suggestion. "Young players are the future," he had said last Thursday morning, during the introductory press conference organised by his next employers. fields.headline: First Division  round-up
fields.trailText: Four days after being thumped by Manchester United in the Worthington Cup, Watford had far too much ammunition for Grimsby and ran out 4-0 winners at Vicarage Road.
fields.body:
Four days after being thumped by Manchester United in the Worthington Cup, Watford had far too much ammunition for Grimsby and ran out 4-0 winners at Vicarage Road.

It all left them a point clear and Graham Taylor, the Watford manager, heaping praise on Allan Nielsen, the Dane who capped his day's work by getting on the scoresheet along with Tommy Mooney, twice, and Gifton Noel-Williams. "I don't usually like to single out individuals but I thought he was superb," Taylor said.

"Watford gave us a lesson in how to finish and defend, but I was not that disappointed with our display," was the response of Grimsby's manager Lennie Lawrence.

Nottingham Forest beat Preston 3-1 to make it three wins out of three, take them up to ninth and leave their manager David Platt believing they can make a play-off place. But Preston had Graham Alexander and Rob Edwards sent off and conceded two penalties. Chris Bart-Williams scored them both.

Blackburn made it five consecutive league wins thanks to Craig Hignett's injury-time winner against Stockport. "It was justice," opined the manager, Graeme Souness. "We played some great football and were full value for the win."

Gary Megson, West Bromwich's manager, was unhappy that Burnley's Graham Branch was allowed to run through three defenders before slotting the ball under his goalkeeper. "Our defending was so powder puff it was not true," he said. But Jason Roberts saved Albion's day with an injury-time goal.

Wolves' manager Colin Lee was furious after a 2-0 loss at Crewe. "I told my players exactly what I thought of them, but in a controlled way," he said. "I can't understand how we can play so well against teams like Watford and then so badly against lesser teams we should be beating."

fields.headline: Second Division  round-up
fields.trailText: Tony Thorpe's 100th goal helped Bristol City make it 11 games unbeaten with a 4-0 demolition of Notts County. Simon Clist, with his first ever goal, Scott Murray and Lee Peacock were also on the scoresheet as Danny Wilson's teams registered their fourth win in five matches.
fields.body:
Tony Thorpe's 100th goal helped Bristol City make it 11 games unbeaten with a 4-0 demolition of Notts County. Simon Clist, with his first ever goal, Scott Murray and Lee Peacock were also on the scoresheet as Danny Wilson's teams registered their fourth win in five matches.

The clash between the sides lying in third and fourth place ended all square at Millmoor, Gareth Griffiths scoring for Wigan after 76 minutes and Rotherham's Mark Robins making it 1-1 with 10 minutes left. The Wigan goalkeeper Roy Carroll was sent off a minute later for a professional foul.

Millwall were unable to make up ground, held 1-1 at Port Vale, where David Brammer cancelled out Dave Livermore's opener for the Lions.

It was a similar story for Wycombe, held 1-1 at Swindon after leading through Andy Rammell's ninth-minute goal. Bart Griemink was sent off after 62 minutes for handball but the Wanderers were unable to take advantage against 10 men until Alan Reeves netted in the last minute.

Stoke moved up two places after a 2-1 win at Wrexham, where they led through Peter Thorne's 16th-minute goal and Stefan Thordarson's 27th-minute penalty. Darren Ferguson pulled one back with another spot-kick on 66 minutes.

Bury ended a five-match losing streak with a 1-1 draw at home to Luton. Adrian Littlejohn put the Shakers in front after 47 minutes only for Petri Helin to level for the Hatters nine minutes later.

Cambridge ended a four-match losing run with a 1-1 draw with Brentford, who had Andy Scott to thank for a last-gasp equaliser after John Taylor gave the Light Blues the lead after 33 minutes.

Oxford United stay rooted to the bottom after a fourth successive defeat, 1-0 at home to Bristol Rovers, who kept their first clean sheet in 10 games. Stephen Foster was the hero for the Pirates.

fields.headline: Third Division  round-up
fields.trailText: Brighton closed the gap on the leaders Chesterfield to three points with a 4-1 thrashing of Carlisle, who dropped to the bottom after 13 games without a win.
fields.body:
Brighton closed the gap on the leaders Chesterfield to three points with a 4-1 thrashing of Carlisle, who dropped to the bottom after 13 games without a win.

Two goals from Paul Watson and others from Bobby Zamora and Lee Steele put paid to United - who replied only through an own-goal from Kerry Mayo.

Chesterfield were held at Lincoln, who led through a penalty from Steve Holmes in the 56th minute. Luke Beckett's sixth goal of the season made it 1-1 at Sincil Bank.

Halifax climbed off the bottom with their first win under their new manager Paul Bracewell, their 3-1 victory over Exeter leaving the Grecians eight games without a win.

Kidderminster scored their first home goal in 287 minutes when Adrian Smith put them in front against Cheltenham but Chris Banks broke Town's goal famine with their first in 395 minutes when he made it 1-1.

In the west country derby Torquay and Plymouth ended all square at 1-1. Sean McCarthy scored for the Pilgrims and Eifion Williams for the Gulls, who have gone 10 games without a clean sheet.

fields.headline: Thompson banishes Bhoys' terror of Rugby
fields.trailText:
Kilmarnock 0 - 1 Celtic
Celtic show their mettle against Ayrshire bogeymen.
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill's Celtic look remorseless. The Irishman has given his team something that this club has craved for years - the wit and durability to visit grounds such as Kilmarnock's and come away victorious. Jozef Venglos and John Barnes, O'Neill's predecessors, foundered here, but no one in green and white now can talk of the graveyard that is Ayrshire.

If Celtic do win the championship this season it will arrive on such feats as this thorough job. Kilmarnock, currently third, have been nobody's fools. Celtic, though, played the unwelcome and uncompromising visitor, eking out chances. On top of this, O'Neill is amassing impressive statistics. This was Celtic's 14th unbeaten league match, of which they have won 12.

Celtic should have won this more comfortably had Henrik Larsson, their talismanic Swede, not indulged himself ludicrously. Larsson's skills can be thrilling, but in the 66th minute, with his side guarding their lead, he rounded Gordon Marshall before opting to toy with the empty net. Instead of scoring, Larsson became a circus act. A posse of defenders enveloped him before punting the ball clear.

"In 99 cases out of 100 you would put money on Larsson to score that," said O'Neill later. "But we won, so I'll forgive him."

Scotland remains an unwelcoming place to Chris Sutton. Scarcely had the Englishman stepped foot north of the border and a red card was received with a flurry of yellows soon following. Yesterday it took around 50 seconds to elapse before the referee Willie Young, a man who wears his contempt with pride, summoned Sutton to book him.

The striker may be tempted by now to claim racism in these parts - in truth the Scots cannot convincingly claim that anglophobia does not exist. Yet the studs that Sutton planted into Ian Durrant's ankles looked painful enough to warrant his reprimand. The moment caught the mood of a physically bruising match.

Sutton, though, was instrumental in Celtic's goal after 60 minutes. It was the Englishman's persistence near the touchline and dribble past Gary Hay that preserved momentum. When Didier Agathe's cross was dispatched, taking a big deflection on the way, it evaded everyone, including Larsson and Sutton himself, before Alan Thompson arrived to prod past Marshall.

Kilmarnock are blessed with a goalkeeper of eccentric foibles - one moment clutching the ball bravely and cleanly, the next fumbling around with it. Four years ago Marshall was tossed out of Celtic Park and from this performance you could see why - his brilliance is always partial.

The way he blocked efforts from Sutton and Stilian Petrov, both from deadly range, was marvellous. Yet Marshall had also flapped badly at Petrov's earlier effort, nearly allowing Larsson to hare in and steal an earlier lead. With Celtic's Jonathan Gould refusing to be upstaged, this match was captivating partly for its entertaining goalkeepers.

Kilmarnock can live with this setback. Bobby Williamson's team had youngsters strewn throughout it, though they failed to threaten Celtic enough to warrant a point.

fields.headline: Savage helps Taylor get back to the day job
fields.trailText:
Man City 0 - 1 Leicester
Taylor gets back to the day job as Leicester go third.
fields.body:
Towards the end of his playing days Peter Taylor had a loan spell with Joe Royle's workmanlike Oldham side so it must have been that much sweeter for the Leicester manager to take three points from his old boss after what has been a difficult week at the coal-face.

Wearing two hats cannot be easy for England's caretaker manager, particularly after seeing Leicester's defence of the Worthington Cup undermined by Crystal Palace in midweek. But after his team responded with this win, which took them up to third place, Taylor took the opportunity to play down the demands of his dual role. He did it as comfortably as his defence coped with City's redundant attack.

"It's been very easy; I have not thought about England at all," he said. "But after what some of the papers had to say on Friday, I'm sure you can appreciate I would rather talk about Leicester City." Taylor is angry at reports suggesting that he had been discourteous to England's manager-elect Sven-Goran Eriksson, from whom, he added, he is expecting to hear in the near future.

The match was a tedious spectacle, as Royle opted to match Leicester's five-man midfield with one of his own. It would have needed something special to beat a team who have conceded only one goal on their travels, but City were not equipped for inspiration. Instead Robbie Savage settled it with a left-foot shot from the edge of the area after his first effort was blocked. "Robbie's a lot more skilful than I thought he was before I came here," Taylor said.

Only then did Royle introduce his most creative players, Ian Bishop and Mark Kennedy, and they soon offered more scope for their team-mates. Though Dickov, who had a low shot well saved by Tim Flowers in the first half, had a couple of half-chances, it was Paulo Wanchope who came closest, but his effort was turned over by the substitute Simon Royce.

Leicester would have added to their 10 league goals if Arnar Gunnlaugsson had taken a late opportunity as Royle's side pushed forward for an equaliser, but he was stopped in his tracks by a superb tackle from Steve Howey, who if Taylor's mind wanders may just earn an England recall this week.

Flowers, who must be hopeful of a call-up too, was withdrawn at half-time with a "stiff back" that required manipulation during the game while Nicky Weaver barely distinguished himself at the other end, and was particularly lucky to get away with handling outside his area.

"Of all our defeats so far that was the least disappointing," opined Royle, who is actively looking for a striker. "They didn't cause us problems in open play but I can see how they keep clean sheets. We've got to find that balance."

fields.headline: Robson's 10 men stave off fans' fury
fields.trailText:
Middlesbrough 0 - 1 Arsenal
Robson's 10 men stave off fans' fury despite Henry's winner.
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor at the Riverside stadium
fields.body:
For the time being the anti-Bryan Robson faction at Middlesbrough has been muzzled, although how long before it bares its teeth again will remain open to debate.

The likelihood is that things will get worse before they get better. Robson's return to Manchester United on Saturday promises to be a degrading experience but the following two weeks promise to be more testing.

If Middlesbrough have clambered out of the quicksand after successive home games against Leicester and Bradford, Robson will get another chance to prove that Steve Gibson's assertion that "Bryan's the diamond in our crown" was not merely the sound of a chairman living in denial. Should their slump continue, even Gibson might have to concede his diamond is actually a dud.

Perhaps it is a measure of Middlesbrough's predicament that so many people felt that their fifth consecutive defeat merited something between sympathetic applause and a condescending pat on the back.

Their supporters just seemed happy that Operation Damage Limitation had succeeded and Robson attempted to talk up his over-30s club as having conjured up some kind of superhuman effort. "The commitment and work rate were excellent," he repeated over and over again. Yet, against that, his teeth must have ached from the lack of quality.

Devoid of width or penetration, Middlesbrough shuffled through more than an hour of muddle and mishap before managing anything approaching a moment of creativity. So it was a pity for Noel Whelan that his defence-splitting flick only flummoxed his own back line, Thierry Henry's skew-whiff shot encapsulating Arsenal's finishing.

Had Arsène Wenger's side displayed any sort of ruthlessness their goal difference might not look quite so inferior to Manchester United's this morning. As it was, they teased and tormented their opponents before ultimately getting what they wanted, rather like a cat toying with its prey.

There were times when Arsenal's lackadaisical approach threatened to backfire, particularly with John Lukic in goal displaying a bandy-legged uncertainty. But in truth the outcome was a foregone conclusion from the midpoint of the first half, when Gary Pallister overhit a pass for Steve Vickers and Fredrik Ljungberg was left clear on goal.

There was no disputing that Mark Crossley poleaxed Ljungberg and, even though Pallister had lolloped into the six-yard area as Middlesbrough's last man, the referee Andy D'Urso was theoretically correct to send the goalkeeper off for denying "a clear scoring opportunity". Henry tucked the penalty beyond the substitute goalkeeper Marlon Beresford and, as a contest, that was pretty much it.

Many of D'Urso's colleagues would probably have opted for a yellow card rather than red and, looking at the bigger picture, why should a goalkeeper who has given away a penalty while making a legitimate attempt to win the ball be punished more than that anyway? "Once you send a goalkeeper off, it completely ruins the game. We need some common sense," said Crossley.

There is also an argument that the sending-off may have saved Robson from another voluble level of dissent. Having spent £78m on players, Robson has not seen his team record a clean sheet all season or a win at home since March.

So where does Robson go now? Old Trafford, alas, and the likelihood of public humiliation from his old employers. "We were the last team to win there in the league, so why not be the next as well?" he said. And if wishes were horses, beggars would ride.

fields.headline: Graham earns some Spurs plaudits
fields.trailText:
Tottenham 2 - 1 Sunderland
Graham enjoys the silence of the fans.
fields.byline: Martin Thorpe  at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Their entrance fee is no longer crucial to the financial health of the top clubs but, en masse, supporters still wield a lot of power. They can make or break a manager or a chairman.

So when booing broke out at Tottenham recently everyone assumed it was only a matter of time before George Graham or Alan Sugar would be seeking alternative employment.

Critical mass appeared to be reached on Tuesday, when a 3-1 home defeat to Birmingham left Spurs with only one win in five games, and major protests were called for at Saturday's game with Sunderland.

But what do you know? The team won and received a standing ovation. "Spurs silence the boo boys", trumpeted Sunday's headlines.

Victory remains the greatest mood-altering drug in football. Something else was going on here, however, because Tottenham received a rousing reception when they took the field before the game had even started.

Here, it seemed, was proof of Graham's assertion that those booing are a small minority. Here was the majority heeding the manager's call to be patient and get behind the team.

What further knocked the wind out of the sails of the booing romantics was the fact that the end-of-match applause came in recognition not of cavalier football, but of the supposed Spurs anathemas - graft and team spirit. Reports of the imminent demise of Graham and Sugar appear greatly exaggerated.

The players had worked hard after the Birmingham defeat and emerged with a new 3-5-2 formation. Even so, their limitations were obvious. After an opening burst in which Thomas Sorensen turned contortionist to keep out Les Ferdinand's deflected header, Tottenham too often lacked the guile to break free of Sunderland's determined pressing game. And when, on 36 minutes, Ramon Vega repeated his feat at Chelsea by giving away a penalty for handball, it looked as though they would pay the price.

But Kevin Phillips is suffering a dry spell and blasted the ball over the bar. So Tottenham dug in and hit back. Sorensen had again denied Ferdinand when Tottenham took the lead just before the break with Tim Sherwood's first goal of the season, scrambled over from close range.

Eighteen minutes into the second half, though, Spurs' defensive frailties in the air were exposed when Don Hutchison found space at the far post to head in a cross.

Suddenly the visitors were eyeing their first away win, but they pushed forward too much and Sherwood's astute pass from just inside the Sunderland half set Chris Armstrong free on goal. Despite being out all season with injury, the striker coolly slotted the ball through Sorensen's legs.

The new Spurs qualities of resolve and tenacity helped withstand a late Sunderland surge, though Ben Thatcher was sent off for a second bookable offence. Their challenge now is to translate their home form - 16 points out of 18 - to away games. Sunderland, meanwhile, need to start scoring. Ten goals in 12 games is a worrying return.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Palace respond to Smith's revolution
fields.trailText:
Crystal Palace 4 - 1 Sheff Wed
Palace respond to Smith's revolution
fields.body:
Alan Smith's motivational strategy may have been heavily criticised by Crystal Palace's chairman and the players' union but no one can be in any doubt that the very public roasting he dished out to his side after their sixth straight defeat has worked.

Smith's questioning of the attitude and commitment of his side seems to have hit home and the players have responded with two wins and a draw in their last three matches.

Smith has added steely experience - in the shape of Steve Staunton and Jamie Pollock - to a squad full of youthful promise. Yet, before last Saturday's trip to Bolton, Palace had failed to bridge the age gap and had dropped to second bottom in the league.

A draw at the Reebok stadium, followed by the 3-0 Worthington Cup defeat of the holders Leicester in midweek and Saturday's stroll against Sheffield Wednesday, have lifted Palace above Paul Jewell's side and left Smith vindicated.

"There's 21 players who have taken part in this week from the Bolton game to this game and all 21 have contributed," he said.

Jewell, after enjoying a resurgence of sorts from his side, may need to take a leaf out of Smith's motivational handbook. After Saturday's capitulation he was left in the position of again having to give more praise to the side's fans than his players.

"The supporters were brilliant," he said. "It's embarrassing when they are giving more effort than the players. They deserve better."

An all-singing, all-dancing section of the away support was kitted out in fancy dress, Postman Pat, Bart Simpson, Ali G and Bugs Bunny among those lending their encouragement.

Mickey Mouse was not there, although Wednesday's defenders did a passable impression with an error-prone first-half display. Three times within 36 minutes Palace were given the freedom of the visitors' six-yard box, Dougie Freedman, Clinton Morrison and Pollock all latching on to flick-ons from corners to score.

Pollock fired home from 20 yards two minutes into the second half to extend Palace's lead and Gerald Sibon's late penalty could not disguise Wednesday's shortcomings.

Jewell, whose side face Watford tomorrow, hopes the mauling will act as a "kick up the backside" to his players. Otherwise it may be time for the Smith technique.

fields.headline: Online shopping won't be a turkey this Xmas
fields.trailText: 8am: Online shopping was a disaster last Christmas, but this year e-retailers are keeping their fingers crossed for a bumper holiday shopping season, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Last Christmas, online shopping was a disaster.

The sector was plagued by broken promises, websites that crashed and presents - even turkeys - that weren't delivered in time for Christmas Day.

But after pumping millions of pounds all year into foolproof transactional websites, e-retailers are keeping fingers crossed that they'll make it through the coming holiday shopping season and reap grand rewards.

A flurry of e-Christmas activity will kick off in the next few weeks.

Already, gardening website e-garden.co.uk has thrown its hand into the ring by taking orders for Christmas trees and decorations online. Portals are starting to talk about their Christmas schedules. Freeserve plans to run The Twelve Days of Christmas promotion, kicking off on December 1, with 12 retail partners over 12 days, giving away Christmas prizes every day.

Boys toys website Firebox - one of the retailers involved in the Freeserve promotion - expects sales to rise by five times normal levels over the Christmas period. It is running other promotions with Maxim and LineOne and Blue Carrots, and giving away a free Zap Cap (a bottle opener) for orders over £50.

This year, more than any before, much is being wagered on a good e-Christmas. For some retailers a bumper Christmas could mean the difference between survival or liquidation, with those that fail to make a profit during the season the unfortunate ones facing closure in the new year.

Despite the unavoidable shake-out of dot.com retailers in the new year, the odds are in favour of consumers flocking to the internet to do their Christmas shopping.

Jo Tucker, managing director at the Interactive Media in Retail Group thinks this year will be a successful e-Christmas and expects online shopping revenues to soar to £500m, half that the IMRG says has been made in all the first ten months of this year.

"We're all time-poor at the moment and the thought of going to a busy high street to do Christmas shopping is a nightmare," says Ms Tucker.

Part of the reason why it will work this year, adds Ms Tucker, is that all the important factors are now in place, such as fulfilment and choice.

The fact that all the big high-street retailers, including Debenhams, Argos, Marks & Spencer, Kingfisher, Next, WHSmith, Arcadia and Boots, are now heavily involved in e-commerce should go some way to eroding consumer security fears about shopping online.

But unless retailers start breaking clever marketing campaigns in the next few weeks, they may not have the time to prove their mettle in the e-Christmas rush.

E-commerce may no longer be in its infancy, but few retailers have had much success with selling over the web.

The first e-Christmas in 1998 is now just a bad memory for those involved, especially Microsoft, that sunk millions into the project to get people buying Christmas presents online.

And last year not only were retailers far too concerned by the y2k bug to invest too much in e-commerce systems but, by and large, they rushed to market too quickly and were simply unable to cope with demand.

According to Continental Research, UK consumers, in the last year, spent a grand total of £175m on buying Christmas presents online - an average of £97 each - with 69% saying they were satisfied with the process.

Retailers that failed consumers back then, have now spent millions trying to win them back this year. That's why this year - the next 56 days - will be a crucial period for everyone in the online retail game.

fields.headline: Macari's dream team runs out of gas
fields.trailText:
Fulham 3 - 0 Huddersfield
Macari's dream team runs out of gas
fields.body:
The dream team - that's Macari, Jordan and Deehan - are looking for almost as many new players as Huddersfield have points. Fulham, upwardly mobile and haughty with it, should not snigger because they too should reopen their much fatter chequebook.

Lou Macari hopes to recruit a striker from abroad and in this search Huddersfield's new manager has something in common with Jean Tigana, who is reportedly thinking big about Anderlecht's Czech giant Jan Koller, all of 6ft 7in and worth about £6m.

It seems a fanciful notion but so too does that of Fulham flowing away from the rest of the division. This contest demonstrated exactly why resolute Watford have taken over at the top. For almost an hour, until Louis Saha thunderously headed home his 15th goal in 16 appearances, Huddersfield hung in there and hoped.

Until then, with neither goalkeeper seriously examined, neutrals did their addition; such as just how many passes Fulham needed to progress from one penalty area to the other and how much worse Huddersfield's hellish statistics could become by teatime. Neither was the fussy Steve Bennett to be left out.

Bennett flourished nine cards, two yellows and the obligatory red being dispensed to Scott Sellars after 69 minutes, at which point the dream team's hopes of a dream start died. Well, not quite, because soon Macari, attempting to even up the numbers, trapped the ball just inside the touchline in anticipation of a quick Huddersfield throw-in. Macari escaped without censure as Bennett ordered a bounce-up.

Then Saha, admittedly fouled for almost all Huddersfield's six cautions, escaped with yellow for a high challenge on Rob Kozluk after some verbals shortly before.

"It was the worst tackle I've ever had," said the 23-year-old defender afterwards. "He caught me knee-high from the side and with his full force in the tackle. I thought at the time he'd broken my leg. He should definitely have been sent off. Saha doesn't need to do it because he's so talented."

Macari had much else to ponder, not least that Huddersfield have gone 16 league and cup games without a win and have not scored in more than nine hours. They could do with a younger Macari, Jordan and Deehan up front.

Fulham struck two late goals, Lee Clark setting up both. Bjarne Goldbaek mishit past Nico Vaesen and the forceful Steve Finnan scored cleverly with the outside of his foot.

For Tigana's team, three more points to fuel the drive towards the promised land; for Macari's men, another empty afternoon and a long haul with the tank dangerously low.

Bennett flourished nine cards, two yellows and the obligatory red being dispensed to Scott Sellars after 69 minutes, at which point the dream team's hopes of a dream start died. Well, not quite, because soon Macari, attempting to even up the numbers, trapped the ball just inside the touchline in anticipation of a quick Huddersfield throw-in. Macari escaped without censure as Bennett ordered a bounce-up. Then Saha, admittedly fouled for almost all Huddersfield's six cautions, escaped with yellow for a high challenge on Rob Kozluk after some verbals shortly before. "It was the worst tackle I've ever had," said the 23-year-old defender afterwards. "He caught me knee-high from the side and with his full force in the tackle. fields.headline: Dons enjoy home from home
fields.standfirst: First Division
fields.trailText:
Barnsley 0 - 1 Wimbledon
Victory in Yorkshire again for the Dons.
fields.body:
Wimbledon are used to a nomadic existence after nine years without their own stadium, but they appear to be finding a home from home at last. The only problem for their fans is that it is some 200 miles from south London.

Yesterday's win was their third in Yorkshire this season. After romping to success at Sheffield Wednesday and Huddersfield, this victory, courtesy of a late Damien Francis goal, took their points haul in the white rose county above that yielded from Selhurst Park this term.

"It's another clean sheet and another win in Yorkshire," said the visiting manager Terry Burton. "I don't know how much space there is up here, but if there any room for Wimbledon we should be looking."

The Londoners may not always benefit from such hospitable refereeing. After only 11 minutes Kevin Miller's long punt bounced over the Wimbledon back line for Lee Jones to chase. The former Tranmere striker was felled from behind by Robert Gier with little cover in attendance but Phil Dowd produced yellow while the Oakwell crowd bayed for red.

"It doesn't matter what I make of it," said the Barnsley manager Dave Bassett. "He stayed on and it's no good talking about hypotheticals."

Gier was luckier still to avoid dismissal when he scythed down Mateo Corbo just before half-time. The referee, well behind play, took no action at all this time. "If you're not sure you don't send him to jail, do you?" added Burton, who wisely substituted the young centre-back at the break.

Barnsley, ravaged by injuries, had only themselves to blame for this latest home setback. Neil Maddison, on loan from Middlesbrough, could have set them on their way to a first league win at Oakwell since September early in the second half, but the midfielder deflected Corbo's cross on to the bar with the goal gaping.

Kelvin Davis then saved smartly from the Uruguayan and Robbie van der Laan saw his low shot deflected over the bar. After a first half that was about as exciting as the chilling Yorkshire fog, the flurry of chances warmed the crowd of 13,641.

For a while the Dons seemed to be vying with each other for miss of the season. Francis blazed over an open goal after good work from John Hartson; Per Karlsson did likewise from Francis's cross.

Then, in the dying moments, Mike Sheron fouled Jon Harley, Alan Kimble swung in the free-kick and Steve Chettle, stumbling awkwardly as the ball veered at him, could only half-clear. Francis, unmarked on the edge of the area, twisted his body to keep himself above the ball and dispatched his volley emphatically beyond the static Miller.

fields.headline: Cole right on cue in Ferguson's dress rehearsal
fields.trailText:
Coventry 1 - 2 Man Utd
Cole puts United in the mood for Dynamo Kiev.
fields.body:
This is a pivotal week for Manchester United, who must beat Dynamo Kiev at Old Trafford on Wednesday to ensure a continued presence in the Champions League. Should they fail, even the prospect of a Premier League hat-trick would be a poor consolation, and the idea of slumming it in the Uefa Cup is patently unappealing.

Understandably, therefore, Sir Alex Ferguson chose to give his leading players not a rest on Saturday but a rehearsal against Dynamo Cov - or rather Coventry City, whose dynamism depends in part on how many AA batteries they can muster at any one time.

United won, of course, as they had done in 14 of the previous 16 encounters with Coventry. And they would probably still have won had Ferguson chosen to rotate his team as he had done in winning 3-0 at Leicester City, then the Premiership leaders, three weeks earlier.

But having fielded an Extra A XI at Watford in the Worthington Cup, where needless to say United beat the Nationwide leaders 3-0, Ferguson thought that his first team could do with some match practice. "I could have made changes and rested one or two but I felt they needed a game today," he explained.

As a result Gordon Strachan's side found themselves facing the strongest opposition Ferguson could muster. This was the definitive United team with the exception of the centre-back positions, where Gary Neville and Wes Brown filled in for Jaap Stam and Ronny Johnsen.

Stam is expected to be out until the new year after an Achilles operation but Johnsen, now recovered from an ankle injury, should be back against Kiev. This could see Brown switching to right-back, replacing Phil Neville, and Nicky Butt is set to replace the suspended Paul Scholes in midfield.

Without Stam's power and authority United are vulnerable at the back, and on Saturday Coventry eventually exploited a weakness in the air when Gary Breen met Paul Telfer's corner with a strong header which the Peruvian Ysrael Zuniga, standing almost on the goalline, nodded into the net.

It was Coventry's misfortune that injuries to Cedric Roussel and John Aloisi deprived them of the combination of aerial strength and ground strategy that might have enabled them to press home this advantage to greater effect. As it was, the introduction of John Eustace just before the hour added sufficient aggression to their football to bring a sweat to United's brow and briefly rile Roy Keane.

Coventry are not a bad team. They may lie 17th at present but they are as much of a muchness as most of the mid-table pack.

The Moroccan pair Moustapha Hadji and Youssef Chippo continue to provide skilful, imaginative touches and the presence in Strachan's attack of the teenaged Jay Bothroyd, a member of the Arsenal team that beat Coventry in last season's FA Youth Cup final, was encouraging for the longer term.

Coventry's problem on Saturday was that up to half-time a number of their players appeared to believe that they should not be sharing the same pitch as the champions. After the game the feeling was confirmed by Strachan when he said : "In the first half we were playing the reputation of Manchester United. Roy Keane only got his first tackle when John Eustace came on."

That said, the quality of United's opening goal shortly before the half-hour would have commanded respect from more vaunted opponents than Coventry. In a counterattack of bewildering pace and precision Scholes volleyed a long pass out to David Beckham on the right and he sprinted almost to the byline before crossing low for Andrew Cole to turn the ball in first time at the near post.

For smoothness of movement and speed of delivery the goal would not have discredited a game of ice hockey. Ferguson was not exaggerating when he declared that "you won't get many better goals than that this season". Even one would be a surprise.

In contrast United's second goal, 10 minutes later, was all about Beckham's reputation at free-kicks. Paul Williams is Coventry's steadiest defender but needlessly fouled Ryan Giggs within scoring range, exposing his goalkeeper Chris Kirkland to Beckham's powers.

Kirkland lined up the defenders and prepared himself for the usual mortar attack over their heads. Instead Beckham's kick surprised him by bouncing tamely through the wall and through the goalkeeper's hands.

After Zuniga had scored United tightened up their game and made sure Coventry never smiled again. Late on Dwight Yorke came off the bench to hit a post, enough to have Ferguson reflecting that "we missed chances and might have regretted it".

This is as nothing, however, to the regrets that will ensue if United's chance in the Champions League is thrown away on Wednesday.

webTitle: Byfield skates through his Reading test

fields.headline: Byfield skates through his Reading test
fields.trailText:
Walsall 2 - 1 Reading
All change as Walsall take top spot in Division Two.
fields.body:
Ray Graydon's decision to take his Walsall squad on a Halloween training break to the Peak District proved apt as the west midlanders fashioned a win that saw them clamber above Reading to the Second Division summit.

Reading were unfortunate not to be ahead after they had what seemed a perfectly valid effort by Keith Jones disallowed during a turgid opening period in which they had threatened to overrun Walsall.

However, inspired by the promptings of Jorge Leitao and the pace of Darren Byfield, the hosts found a new lease of life after the break and took command of the game with goals from Pedro Matias, on 58 minutes, and Byfield, four minutes from time.

Although Reading hit back with a stunning injury-time strike from Jimmy McIntyre it was scant consolation for the big-spending Berkshire club.

In Byfield, who proved to be the match winner in this scrappy encounter, Graydon has unearthed a precocious and gifted striker.

The former Walsall centre-half and captain Adrian Viveash, who moved to Reading on a free transfer in the summer, was given a torrid time by Byfield for much of the afternoon. "He's a very confident lad and obviously he'll feel he got the better of me because he scored. But good luck to him. I hope he does well."

Not too well, Reading will be hoping, as it might just cost them promotion.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Bennett's clanger leaves Francis blue
fields.trailText:
Birmingham 1 - 1 Bolton
Goalkeeping clanger leaves Francis feeling blue.
fields.body:
It must be something in the second city's water. Only days after David James added to his burgeoning list of goalkeeping calamities by conceding the penalty that cost Aston Villa their place in the League Cup, his Birmingham City counterpart Ian Bennett was in ricket-dropping mood at St Andrews.

That Bennett's reckless but ultimately futile charge to intercept a ballooning Bolton clearance which bounced over his head should result in the equaliser being side-footed home by Michael Ricketts was wholly appropriate.

Trevor Francis failed to see the humour. "It was an unbelievable error when I thought we were looking good for a two- or three-goal win," he moaned.

This never looked likely in a sterile first half that made a mockery of Francis's criticisms of the Football Association for not considering English-born coaches at Nationwide League clubs as candidates to succeed Kevin Keegan.

Francis was speaking from a position of strength after the Blues had outplayed and outwitted Tottenham in the League Cup; within minutes of the third- and fourth-placed clubs in the Nationwide League squaring up to one another, the notion looked risible.

Bolton, five men strewn across the midfield, made it clear that a draw was the extent of their ambitions; just as apparent was that City lacked the guile to record their eighth successive home win.

The on-loan striker Mark Burchill did not reproduce the skills that helped undo Spurs but at least that might dissuade the watching John Gregory from attempting to sign the Scottish international.

With Burchill and Dele Adebola making little headway, Francis at least had the tactical nous to counter Bolton's game plan in the second half by giving Stan Lazaridis a free rein to run at the visitors.

Lazaridis obliged within five minutes when his run was ended illegally by Robbie Elliott and Martin Grainger converted the consequent penalty. Elliott escaped a booking but for the Bolton manager Sam Allardyce the only offence had been committed by Lazaridis, who, he said, "should have been booked for his dive that was worth at least 5.9 marks".

Bolton were fully compensated by Bennett's clanger, which, as well as leaving Francis fuming, had him reminiscing. "I haven't seen anything like it since Pat Jennings scored direct from his own area when the ball bounced over Manchester United's Alex Stepney in the Charity Shield back in the 60s."

He will be more than happy to wait another 33 years to see a repeat, especially if his goalkeeper is involved.

webTitle: Beattie's belter makes fools of Chelsea

fields.headline: Beattie's belter makes fools of Chelsea
fields.trailText:
Southampton 3 - 2 Chelsea
Beattie's belter makes fools of Chelsea.
fields.body:
Claudio Ranieri suggested after this injury-time defeat that the outcome must have been written in the stars. More to the point is the tendency of his stellar collection to crash to earth away from home. Even England's gambling school might be reluctant to back Chelsea on their travels.

Despite an unblemished home record under Ranieri, Chelsea have picked up only a single away point since the Italian arrived - typically at Old Trafford.

The fact that the team have not won away since April 1 must amuse Ken Bates as much as the thought of someone removing all the windows from the Chelsea Village hotels next April Fools' Day.

When the Champions League is your ambition such a run is no laughing matter. And excellently as Southampton played in building a 2-0 lead by half-time, this was the sort of game that Chelsea should be winning. When they belatedly roused themselves and dropped Gianfranco Zola deeper, their superiority for long periods was marked.

"In the second half for 20 minutes, or possibly longer, we were chasing shadows," admitted the Southampton midfielder Chris Marsden. "That's the quality they've got. At one time I thought they had 15 players on the pitch."

Chelsea's problem was that initially they seemed to have only five. Lacking urgency and short of solidity and leadership in defence they were outfought and outplayed by opponents who had suffered three successive home defeats. Ranieri will not have needed a translator at the interval to make his feelings known.

"If we play like we did in the first half then it's going to be really difficult to win an away game," admitted Gus Poyet. Paul Jones was not forced into a single save. The challenge for Ranieri is to ensure the second-half showing becomes the norm, though he will know better than most that Rome was not built in a day.

The one-time Fiorentina coach said he was still trying to fathom why his team have not reproduced their home form on their travels. It certainly should not be over-confidence or arrogance after those defeats at Bradford and St Gallen.

Clearly Chelsea were shaken by Southampton's aggression and relentless harrying early on, and struggled to contain James Beattie in the unexplained absence of Marcel Desailly. But for the post that denied Marsden and a wasted chance by Beattie the game could have been over at half-time. It was to Chelsea's credit that they fought back.

Victory ultimately flattered Southampton a touch but they began so impressively that it was hard to begrudge them. The exciting 20-year-old left-back Wayne Bridge crossed for Beattie to finish at the far post and then supplied the free-kick that Jo Tessem turned in as the Chelsea defence dallied.

Dennis Wise had signalled Chelsea's fighting qualities rather too literally by engaging in a scrap with Marsden ("he stood on my feet, grabbed me round the throat," Marsden said, "but the plus side is he takes it as well") and began the response by bundling in a Poyet effort not long after the Uruguayan had hit the bar.

With Zola drifting to provide the craft and width that had been lacking, it was no surprise when Poyet headed in a cross by the Sardinian. But Southampton, for whom Dean Richards was outstanding at the back, had the final say to move out of the relegation zone. Whereas Zola and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink had earlier engaged in a bizarre argument over who should take a free-kick, Beattie curled his effort past Ed de Goey from 25 yards in the third minute of stoppage time for his second goal of the afternoon.

The striker, who was wanted by Crystal Palace earlier this season, had not previously scored for 18 months. Chelsea must hope they do not have to wait as long for an away win.

webTitle: Addison puts a dent in the Diamonds

fields.headline: Addison puts a dent in the Diamonds
fields.trailText:
Rushden and Diamonds 1 - 2 Yeovil Town
Yoevil bring promotion one step closer.
fields.body:
For Colin Addison the wheel has turned full circle. His first act in club management was to take a team into the Football League and now, 28 years later, he has seen the clearest sign yet that his new Yeovil charges will be moving in higher circles next August.

The path from Hereford United in 1972 to Yeovil Town has taken him via Derby, Atletico Madrid and Al Arabi in Kuwait, but Addison clearly relishes rolling up his sleeves for non-league management.

Four weeks after replacing Dave Webb, who left to take over at Southend, Addison looked on with satisfaction as his side opened up a four-point gap with a game in hand over their opponents at the top.

"We knew it was going to be a competitive game," said Addison. "We showed a lot of character and resilience. Today was an examination. Rushden are the team to beat; they've been there for the last few seasons in the top two. They show a very high degree of consistency and that's what we're looking to achieve."

But he remained cautious. "We must not get too carried away. This game won't decide anything at all, but it's nice to have a great victory."

Nene Park had the passionate feel of a wintry cup tie; well over 5,000 turned out to see the Conference fireworks go off. Yeovil almost went ahead on the half-hour, when Warren Patmore's shot cracked off the crossbar, and they were slicker throughout the first half.

Barrington Belgrave twisted and turned to torment Rushden and, as half-time neared, he started a surging upfield move that ended with Patmore, whom Rushden tried to sign last season, sending a looping header into the net.

Justin Jackson, jockeying with Patmore at the top of the Conference scoring charts, levelled things up after Tony Pennock had parried Jean-Michel Sigère's fierce shot into his path but when Jon Brady handled on the line after another Patmore header with seven minutes left, the referee flourished a red card and awarded a decisive penalty.

Darren Way duly crowned Addison's day and the visiting fans and players alike celebrated as though promotion was in the bag.

The Rushden manager Brian Talbot, whose team has been edged out at the top by Halifax, Cheltenham and Kidderminster in the past three seasons, tried to stay reflective.

"Every year we seem to hit this problem that another team is up there with us. We just have to accept that," he said. "I would say we had 65-70% of the play in the second half but it wasn't to be.

"Obviously it's a kick in the teeth: it's the first game we've lost at home all season but I'm sure that Yeovil will lose some games. We've got to make sure that we don't drop our heads."

For Addison though, the memories are flooding back. "I see similarities with Hereford: the stadium, the crowd potential, the great FA Cup tradition. It reminds me a lot of all those years ago."

Talbot and Max Griggs, whose investment has got Rushden this far, should be worried.

fields.headline: In sickness and in wealth
fields.standfirst: We already spend billions of pounds every year on private healthcare. So what does the recently announced 'concordat' really mean?
fields.trailText: Has the government really thought through its policy on private health care? By their own logic, ministers should abolish prescription and other charges, argues Justin Keen.
fields.body:
Last week the government proudly announced a new "concordat" between the National Health Service and the private sector - interpreted by cynics as a way of ensuring there will be spare beds about this winter. The phrase "private health" conjures up pay beds and Bupa but in fact the non-NHS sector - what people pay for out of their own pockets - is a lot bigger than that. In 1997 non-NHS healthcare spending was just over £8bn. Paid for by taxes, the NHS spent £40bn in 1997-98 so "private health" comes to around 17% of total UK health spending.

Some £2.1bn was spent on insurance, by private individuals and by companies on behalf of their employees. Just under £2.5bn was spent on pharmaceuticals. This figure rises to around £4bn if we add other over-the-counter healthcare products.

Payments made by private individuals for health fall into three broad categories. The first is cash outlays on drugs and patent medicines, dentistry (more than £300m a year) and glasses, contact lenses, eye tests and other optical services (more than £500m). Payment for complementary therapies such as osteopathy and acupuncture is at least £450m a year according to research by Kate Thomas of Sheffield University. Private individuals pay £500m each year directly out of their pocket on hospital treatment. Self-payment has been growing in recent years, and some 20% of operations and treatments are now paid for directly rather than through insurance.

Perhaps long-term care for the elderly or disabled should be added in. Spending on personal healthcare by people living in their own homes or in nursing or residential homes is hard to assess but it is likely to run into the hundreds of millions. Private expenditure on chiropody alone is some £70m a year.

A second category of payments are those made to third parties, the largest of which buys private medical insurance for individuals and families. This is worth about £1.1bn a year. Some 2.8m people are covered, which is 3.8% of the population. Some 6m people have health cash plans, which are a cross between low-cost insurance and savings products, designed mainly to help pay for lower cost items such as dental charges, and modest lump sums for hospital stays (whether in private or NHS hospitals). Total contributions to these plans are relatively modest, at around £200m a year. There are two additional types of private payment in this category: the first is gifts to charities which end up helping the NHS - they total over £150m a year, according to a recent National Audit Office report; people buy lottery tickets and the National Lottery contributes some £50m a year to the NHS; the third is money paid over directly to the NHS. The great slogan coined for Labour's invention in the 40s was that the health service was free "at the point of delivery". It was never entirely accurate even then and since 1951 patients have had to pay explicit user charges. Today the bulk of charges are for prescriptions, dentistry and ophthalmic services, and totalled £800m in 1997-98.

"Private health" turns out to be a lot more complicated than pronouncements such as Mr Milburn's would imply. He was really only talking about private hospitals and they account for only about a quarter of personal private expenditure on healthcare. Most private health spending is in retail markets, for a wide range of goods and services. The chart shows how the spending divides up.

Perhaps the government would rather not think about it. In its National Plan for the NHS in July, the government argued that private medical insurance is a major cause of inequitable access to health care. This is right but the government omitted to mention that user charges for core health services are if anything more inequitable. By their own logic they should have abolished prescription and other charges. Labour has reintroduced free eye tests for people aged 60 years and over but has also actually increased prescription charges. For a government that has restored equity to the political lexicon, and pledged so much new money to the NHS, this is an opportunity missed.

To a large extent primary healthcare is private. That is uncontroversial in the sense that people buy pain relief, athlete's foot powder and so on from chemist shops: it is difficult to imagine nationalising over-the-counter pharmacy services. But dental and optical services have been turned into mixed economies. The Tories started the ball rolling by increasing charges and Labour has only tinkered with its inheritance rather than reversed policy - it presumably is relaxed about the role of the private sector in health care.

Add to all that the private finance initiative (PFI) for building and in some cases maintaining hospitals and now Mr Milburn's concordat, and it is hard to avoid concluding that major changes in the structure and financing of healthcare have already taken place. More are in the pipeline. It is a pity, then, that the concordat focuses mainly on hospital and the new way-station services located between a hospital stay and return home. If a concordat is needed anywhere at the moment it is in general dentistry, where the government now needs the private sector to help solve problems of access. A better appreciation of the nature of private healthcare expenditure and consumption is the starting point for better policies to engage with it.

Justin Keen is fellow in health systems at the King's Fund.

webTitle: Crewe and Floud for university president

fields.headline: Crewe and Floud for university president
fields.trailText: Professor Ivor Crewe, vice-chancellor of Essex university, and Professor Roderick Floud, vice-chancellor of London Guildhall university, have been nominated as candidates to become the next president of UK university heads
fields.body:
Professor Ivor Crewe, vice-chancellor of Essex university, and Professor Roderick Floud, vice-chancellor of London Guildhall university, have been nominated as candidates to become the next president of UK university heads

The Committee of Vice-chancellors and Principals, which is shortly to rebrand itself as Universities UK, says that the election result for the president will be announced on 1 December. The new president will hold office from 1 August 2001, after the current president, Sir Howard Newby vice-chancellor of Southampton university, stands down, to 31 July 2003.

Professor John Bull, vice-chancellor of the University of Plymouth has been re-elected as Treasurer of the CVCP unopposed.

Crewe is a political scientist, while Floud is an economic historian. If Floud was appointed, he would become the first leader of UK academic heads to come from a former polytechnic.

webTitle: Online public debate on biotechnology research

fields.headline: Online public debate on biotechnology research
fields.trailText: The main government agency funding research in the biotechnological and biological sciences is for the first time undertaking an online consultation inviting the public to comment on the future direction of its research programme.
fields.body:
The main government agency funding research in the biotechnological and biological sciences is for the first time undertaking an online consultation inviting the public to comment on the future direction of its research programme.

As part of attempts to promote public debate about controversial aspects of biological research such as GM crops, and public input into its research funding plans, the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council is seeking comments on the scope, content and implications of its new research initiatives.

The council, which spends £200m every year, wants feedback on plans for new research into the role of genes in contributing to the way plants, animals and microbes develop. Comments are also invited on the council's science programme in general.

The results of a consultation on a research programme into the way genes flow in plants and micro-organisms are also available. In one comment received on this topic, Mark Pallen, Professor of Microbiology, from Queen's University of Belfast, argued that more research needs to be done on the organisms and resistance genes poured into sewers from hospitals "to potentially wreck havoc in the external environment".

Views can be expressed at: http://www.bbsrc.ac.uk/society/consult/Welcome.html
