webTitle: A less than happy epitaph for the Clinton years

fields.headline: A less than happy epitaph for the Clinton years
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: America hates a loser, and should Al Gore squander Bill Clinton's golden economic legacy by losing to George W Bush tomorrow he will go down in history as one of the losers of all time.
fields.body:
America hates a loser, and should Al Gore squander Bill Clinton's golden economic legacy by losing to George W Bush tomorrow he will go down in history as one of the losers of all time.

Unemployment is low, inflation is low, real incomes are rising, the dollar is strong, Silicon Valley has transformed the global industrial landscape. Put simply, Gore should be cruising it. Should the Republicans win back the White House after eight years, the pundits will say the vice-president was wooden, lacked warmth, told little white lies, came across like an arrogant know-all - all of which is true. Maybe they will even think up a new catchphrase - "It's not the economy, stupid".

The economy is not working in Gore's favour. That may be because after such a prolonged period of growth, voters take the good times for granted. Alternatively, they may think the credit for the longest economic expansion in the US since records began has rather more to do with the policies of Al Greenspan than those of Al Gore. Finally, it may be that life under the Democrats these past eight years has not been quite the stroll in the Elysian Fields for ordinary working class Americans that commentators assume.

A recent analysis of Clinton administration's record by the American economist Robert Pollin in the New Left Review concluded that it had "done virtually nothing to advance the interests of organised labour or working people more generally". To be sure, the minimum wage has been raised, but its purchasing power has fallen by 40% since the late 60s. To be sure, real wages have been rising for the last couple of years, but this follows a period of falling wages stretching back two decades. Wage inequality has widened, with the gains for ordinary workers far lower than in previous economic expansions. If Gore needs to know why he is having trouble getting his core vote out, he should mull over the fact that average wages for non-supervisory workers are lower than they were under Ronald Reagan.

Gore may still win. When it comes to it, there may be a temptation to hold on to nurse for fear of something worse. However, there does not seem to be too much fear about and Bush could find himself in the same position as Tony Blair in 1997 - about to inherit an economy that has been growing for nine years without a break - the longest expansion since records began in the 1850s. Almost without exception, the gurus of Wall Street believe that the US economy is heading for a soft landing and, with the budget in surplus, Bush can afford to get straight down to doing what Republican presidents enjoy most - cutting taxes for the rich.

But it is far to early to conclude that there will be a soft landing. Neither Bush nor Gore has dared to mention the fact that America's boom could come crashing down at any moment, even though they must be aware of the risks.

On the web, there is a wonderful site called iTulip.com, which specialises in warning stupid and greedy investors of the dangers ahead. It argues that there will be a point at which even the most stubborn bull of Wall Street realises that the game is up and starts to yell at his broker: "Stop arguing with me! Sell, you bastard." This, charmingly, is known as the puke point, and when enough investors reach the PP at the same time panic sets in; iTulip believes this could be November, other analysts think it could be January.

There is little doubt that the US has witnessed an industrial renaissance over the past decade and a half. In part this has been due to the remarkable vigour and innovative zeal of Americans themselves, but it has also been due to the pump priming provided by massive defence spending in the 80s, the weakness of the dollar until the mid-90s and the squeeze on wages. The beneficiaries of the pay cuts imposed on workers have been the profits of corporations and the pay packets of better-off; this transfer of resources has been recycled into higher investment and the stock-market boom.

So we have had a situation where there has been no shortage of cash to fund new ventures, even those with little chance of commercial success, and no shortage of money to drive shares in these companies to unprecedented levels. Although the pace of expansion under Clinton has been unremarkable when set against those of the 50s and 60s, stock market valuations went crazy. To take one example, the price-earnings ratio for Xerox peaked at 123 in 1961; the peak for the online auction company eBay was 9,571.

Wealth effect

In the next phase of the cycle, the boom in the stock market created a wealth effect, which in turn fuelled increases in consumption and gave individuals the confidence to take on more debt and companies the confidence to invest in even more marginal projects. Investors in other parts of the world looked on enviously as Wall Street reached dizzy heights. Desperate for a slice of the action, they bought US assets at overblown prices, driving up the value of the dollar and helping to dampen down American inflation.

That this position is precarious in the extreme should be immediately apparent. Financing consumption via stock market gains only holds good while the stock market is going up, and Wall Street has moved sideways this year. Why has it moved sideways? Simple. There has been colossal overinvestment, profits are starting to come under pressure, and the cannier investors are starting to lose their faith in the ability of the hi-technology sector to deliver the earnings that would justify their absurd share prices. Actually, the really canny investors banked their winnings a long time ago.

As Graham Turner, of GFC Economics, points out, there are plenty of signs that the economy is slowing. Manufacturing production is slipping back, consumer spending on durable goods and cars has turned down sharply during 2000 and the labour market has started to turn down. With demand slackening but capacity over-abundant, the inevitable is happening. Investment is being cut back and prices are falling. The price of phone calls is falling by 6% a year, with long distance calls falling at an annualised rate of 14.5% in the past six months. This is not good news for AT&T.

Yet even now there is a sense of denial - and this could prove costly. Share prices have perked up, belying what is going on in the corporate bond market , where rising yields indicate that a credit squeeze is well under way. If there is borrowing going on at the moment, it is probably distress borrowing.

All of which suggests that a hard landing is a much more plausible scenario than the many followers of Dr Pangloss would have us believe. Early cuts in interest rates might just do the trick, but having underwritten the stupidity of investors once, Greenspan will be reluctant to do the same a second time. The economists at Goldman Sachs believe that rates will be kept on hold for the whole of next year, and if they are right the consequence may be a very sharp slowdown indeed, with a plunge in the dollar acting as a further deterrent to easing monetary policy.

If this happens, it will provide a suitable epitaph to the Clinton years. As Pollin notes: "The core of Clinton's programme has been global economic integration, with minimum interventions to promote equity in labour markets or stability in financial markets. Gestures to the least well-off have been slight and backhanded, while wages for the majority have either stagnated or declined. Wealth at the top, meanwhile, has exploded. But a stratospheric rise in stock prices and debt-financed consumption spree make a mortgaged legacy. Clinton will hand over to his successor the most precarious financial pyramid of the post-war period." It could be a good election to lose.

Larry.elliott@theguardian.com

With demand slackening but capacity over-abundant, the inevitable is happening. Investment is being cut back and prices are falling. The price of phone calls is falling by 6% a year, with long distance calls falling at an annualised rate of 14.5% in the past six months. This is not good news for AT&T. Yet even now there is a sense of denial - and this could prove costly. Share prices have perked up, belying what is going on in the corporate bond market , where rising yields indicate that a credit squeeze is well under way. If there is borrowing going on at the moment, it is probably distress borrowing. All of which suggests that a hard landing is a much more plausible scenario than the many followers of Dr Pangloss would have us believe. Early cuts in interest rates might just do the trick, but having underwritten the stupidity of investors once, Greenspan will be reluctant to do the same a second time. The economists at Goldman Sachs believe that rates will be kept on hold for the whole of next year, and if they are right the consequence may be a very sharp slowdown indeed, with a plunge in the dollar acting as a further deterrent to easing monetary policy. If this happens, it will provide a suitable epitaph to the Clinton years. As Pollin notes: "The core of Clinton's programme has been global economic integration, with minimum interventions to promote equity in labour markets or stability in financial markets. Gestures to the least well-off have been slight and backhanded, while wages for the majority have either stagnated or declined. Wealth at the top, meanwhile, has exploded. But a stratospheric rise in stock prices and debt-financed consumption spree make a mortgaged legacy. Clinton will hand over to his successor the most precarious financial pyramid of the post-war period." It could be a good election to lose. Larry.elliott@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Ministers favour Woodhead peerage
fields.standfirst:
Hague wishes to reward inspector for key Tory education policies
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Hague wishes to reward inspector for key Tory education policies.
fields.body:
The government last night welcomed Tory proposals to give the soon-to-depart chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, a peerage.

Reports that William Hague was intending to offer Mr Woodhead a place on the Tory benches in the Lords were confirmed by Labour, which said it was aware of the plan.

Although no formal offer has been made to Mr Woodhead, who resigned his post on Thursday, it was made clear yesterday that the Conservative leader wants to reward the man whose views have recently embraced many key Tory education policies.

The Conservatives believe that it would be a major advantage to have Mr Woodhead as a fierce government critic in the Lords.

But yesterday one senior minister said: "We picked up about a month ago that this was something the Tories wanted to do, and we are perfectly relaxed about it.

"In fact, we see it as far better to have Mr Woodhead making statements within a formalised political context. At least that way he would be fully accountable for his views and distant from Labour."

Mr Woodhead announced his resignation after David Blunkett, the education secretary, learned that he was negotiating his departure from the high-profile post for a new job in the media and public relations. He will stand down at the end of the month to join the Daily Telegraph and Bell Pottinger Public Affairs in the spring.

In subsequent interviews, Mr Woodhead gave notice that he would become a persistent thorn in Mr Blunkett's side next year, and that he had found it increasingly difficult to defend some aspects of Labour's education policy.

Despite apparent sympathy with Conservative education policies, Mr Woodhead insisted last week that he was "not a Tory" and that he did not understand "the rightwing, leftwing polarisation with regard to education".

But Mr Woodhead has confirmed that despite Mr Hague's plans to reward him with a peerage, no offer has yet been made.

Mr Woodhead, who was originally appointed when John Major was prime minister, told the Guardian: "It's news to me if there is any proposal of that kind. I have had no proposition of that sort and haven't been involved in any discussion. If anybody approached me, I'd give it consideration, but nobody has approached me."

Speaking further about the growing frustrations in the latter days of his job, he said in the News of the World yesterday: "The way in which the chief inspector of schools and secretary of state operate doesn't lead to a cosy relationship - I would certainly not say it was warm."

Mr Blunkett has ordered that Mr Woodhead's deputy, Mike Tomlinson, should act as a caretaker head of Ofsted until the general election in order to ensure continuity. Yesterday the Department for Education and Employment made it clear that there would be no hurry to advertise the Ofsted job.

But Mr Woodhead also said in the News of the World interview that, following Mr Blunkett's call for a "more conciliatory figure", he must not be replaced by a "yes man".

He added: "But my successor has got to have a thick skin. Being chief inspector of schools cannot be an easy job."

fields.headline: Net pornographers face harsher sentences
fields.trailText: Internet pornographers face hasher sentences, a judge said today as he jailed one for 30 months.
fields.body:
Internet pornographers face hasher sentences, a judge said today as he jailed one for 30 months.

Judge Stephen Robins said that longer prison sentences might be needed to wipe out the "channels to depravity" that were now available, London's Southwark crown court was told.

He told Stephane Perrin, a 29-year-old French national from Hove, East Sussex, that the sentence he would have to serve was just six months short of the maximum the law currently provided for this type of offence.

But he said that the tariff was set before internet porn became a serious issue and "that things have moved on".

Judge Robins said that documents found in his home showed the profits from the online porn business were substantial and may be far greater than courts have had to deal with up until now.

"This may be one of the early cases where the court has to determine the appropriate tariff of sentence for internet porn ... it may be that the court of appeal may see fit to give further guidance to sentences for internet porn," he said.

"But in the meantime the message must go out that those responsible for the publication of internet porn can expect to be dealt with severely by the courts in this country," he added.

Perrin's operation came to light after a detective found the site, hosted in US, while surfing the internet in October last year.

When his home was searched, documents were recovered revealing the identity and addresses of hundreds of customers from "all corners of the world", said Gareth Patterson, prosecuting.

Detectives also travelled to the US as part of their investigation. Outside court, case officer Constable Jim Pearce said: "Although this site was hosted in the United States, operators need not think they are safe because we have the power to go there, serve subpoenas on the web hosts and seize their records for use in proceedings in this country."

Police financial investigator Detective Constable Gerry Panter said that, while he was happy with the sentence, it was "unfortunate" that as the law currently stood Perrin could keep the £26,000 he had made from his operation.

"We need a minimum of two convictions before this money could be confiscated," he explained.

However, while Perrin's internet operation is still running and making him money, it will be some time before he can enjoy any of it.

webTitle: Brown says he won't bow to fuel pressure

fields.headline: Brown says he won't bow to fuel pressure
fields.trailText:
Gordon Brown says he will not bow to "unaffordable" demands for big cuts in fuel tax that would put at risk economic stability. 
 
Addressing the CBI annual conference in Birmingham, ahead of Wednesday's pre-budget report, he said that there must be no return to the "short-termist" economics which led to the "boom and bust" of the 1980s.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown says he will not bow to "unaffordable" demands for big cuts in fuel tax that would put at risk economic stability. Addressing the CBI annual conference in Birmingham, ahead of Wednesday's pre-budget report, he said that there must be no return to the "short-termist" economics which led to the "boom and bust" of the 1980s.

"With our prudence matched by higher productivity, Britain can grasp the great interest rate prize that has eluded us for a generation - a long-term future of low and stable interest and mortgage rates upon which people can rely and business can plan ahead," he said.

"But this would all be put at risk if unaffordable demands, such as for cuts in fuel duties of up to 26p, were met on Wednesday, with interest rates rising soon after."

Mr Brown's speech will be seen as the latest shot in the high stakes war between the government and fuel protesters in the run-up to their November 13 deadline.

He said that the average mortgage holder was around £1,000-a-year better off because the cost of borrowing, over the past three years, had been on average 4% lower than it had been over the previous two decades, all of which would be jeopardised by big tax cuts.

The chancellor acknowledged that it was an "important week" for the economy and hinted that he would use his pre-budget report to address the "genuine concerns" of hauliers and farmers with a targeted package of measures.

These could include assistance for hauliers investing in modern vehicles and training for staff, and help for farmers seeking to diversify into different agricultural sectors.

The chancellor signalled that the pre-budget report would include incentives to enhance business competitiveness, with further tax breaks for employee share ownership and simplification of the VAT system.

His speech was warmly welcomed by CBI director general Digby Jones, who said that Mr Brown appeared to be addressing the key concerns of industry.

"The chancellor gave some promising hints that he wants to tackle our long-term business challenges.

"We were particularly pleased by his suggested support for structural reform in the farming and road haulage sectors," Mr Jones said.

fields.headline: Unnatural rate of growth
fields.trailText: In recent years, both the British and US economies have grown at a rate far exceeding what was regarded as their rate of growth of productive potential, but with minimal inflation.
fields.body:
In recent years, both the British and US economies have grown at a rate far exceeding what was regarded as their rate of growth of productive potential, but with minimal inflation.

How is that possible, and can it last?

On an orthodox view of the world, such a happy combination of circumstances is not possible because the growth of productive potential is taken as rigid, as if given by God, and inflation is assumed to result from actual output growth in excess of potential output growth.

The growth of productive potential is often referred to by economists as the natural rate of growth. The term was coined by the Oxford economist Sir Roy Harrod.

What has become apparent from the experience of the last few years, however, particularly in the US, is that there is nothing natural about the natural rate of growth (just as there is nothing natural about the natural rate of unemployment), and that the underlying growth rate of an economy is very responsive to the pressure of demand (or actual output growth).

If wage inflation is moderate as the economy expands and unemployment falls, it is possible to sustain high growth rates for long periods without inflation. This is basically because demand creates its own supply and there is no pressure on costs.

There are a number of ways in which the growth potential of an economy responds to demand. First, the labour force is extremely elastic. The unemployed are drawn into work, participation rates rise, hours worked increase, part-timers work longer, and countries often draw on migrant labour.

Secondly, the growth of labour productivity responds to the growth of output itself. Growth encourages capital accumulation which embodies technical progress; higher output brings scale economies, and the higher the level of output the more adept workers become (learning by doing).

Miguel Leon Ledesma and I show in a forthcoming paper* that in all OECD countries in the past 35 years, the underlying growth of economies has expanded by roughly 60% of the increase in the actual growth of output, and by more in countries with higher labour reserves such as Greece and Italy.

Two major factors constrain output growth and therefore put a brake on the real growth of living standards; one is inflation and the other is the balance of payments.

The conventional wisdom in the US and Britain used to be that the inflation rate would take off if output growth exceeded 2.5%-3% because this would push unemployment below some natural rate leading to a wage-price spiral.

Experience has shown that the concept of a natural rate of unemployment is a theoretical construct with no empirical counterpart that can be identified.

It all depends on wage behaviour. Not so long ago, the natural rate of unemployment in the US was said to be 8%. When unemployment came down to 7% without accelerating inflation, the natural rate was redefined as 7%.

When unemployment came down to 6%, the natural rate was redefined again. Unemployment is now less than 4% and there is still no sign of accelerating inflation.

The same story can be told for the UK. What both economies have demonstrated is the simple Keynesian point that sustained demand expansion can lead to sustained higher output growth without infla tion as long as supply responds and costs don't rise. Euroland would do well to take a leaf out of the Anglo-Saxon book and try the same medicine.

In the present benign climate of wage negotiations - a far cry from the turbulent years of the 1970s when the golden age of growth without inflation of the 1950s and 1960s was brought to a sticky end - the most likely check on the growth of output will be the balance of payments.

In Britain the deficit to GDP ratio is approximately 2%, while in the US it is 4%. Not even the US can go on borrowing indefinitely, although it is not easy to predict when the world's investors will at long last lose confidence in the strength of the almighty dollar.

Until then, faster growth than experienced in the 1970s and 1980s, but perhaps not as fast as the 1990s, should be sustainable provided wage demands do not accelerate.

The elasticity of productivity to output growth is not something temporary, and reserves of labour still exist to be tapped.

 The Endogeneity of the Natural Rate of Growth, published in the forthcoming Cambridge Journal of Economics.

Tony Thirlwall is professor of applied economics at the University of Kent at Canterbury

fields.headline: Swotting and painting
fields.standfirst: Our series on what cricketers get up to in the off season continues with the  Lancashire and England swing bowler Peter Martin.
fields.trailText: Peter Martin, 32 on Nov 15, has taken over 400 wickets as an opening bowler for Lancashire. He won his county cap in 1994 and made his Test debut a year later, in the first Test against West Indies. He has played in eight Tests and 19 one-day internationals. Six foot five inches tall, he is generally known as Digger.
fields.body:
Peter Martin, 32 on Nov 15, has taken over 400 wickets as an opening bowler for Lancashire. He won his county cap in 1994 and made his Test debut a year later, in the first Test against West Indies. He has played in eight Tests and 19 one-day internationals. Six foot five inches tall, he is generally known as Digger.

"I'm doing a post-graduate certificate in management at the University of Central Lancashire in Preston and it takes up about one day a week. It's not particularly preparation for anything - but it's a broad-based management course and I hope that it will be an extremely useful base to kick on from in the future.

"One thing which was quite frightening though was the induction course. All the other students looked about 12. A few of the lads recognised me but they soon got past treating me as an alien. Probably half of them didn't realise who I was anyway. Anyway, once I got cracking all my fears were allayed. I'm going to be struggling to finish the last dissertation in April because of my cricket commitments but the course teachers have been very sympathetic.

"Apart from that I've been doing a bit of painting for people. I do quite a bit of diverse stuff, whatever people ask for really. I've got two horses, two houses and two cricket pitches to do. I started doing it a few years ago but and I prefer doing stuff relative to me really, places I've been.

"Most of my commissions tend to be based around cricket. Do my team-mates commission me? Do they heck. No chance. Though I have done a couple of little thank yous for them. I'd feel a bit of a prat asking for money anyway from people I work so closely with. Painting is a hobby, pure and simple, not a money-making exercise.

I don't really let myself go during the winter. As I've got older I've eaten and drunk less crap because it's more difficult to stay in shape. But I have had problems with injuries.

I broke both thumbs last season. I broke one batting against Derby in June. It wasn't just a break, but a compound fracture dislocation. That got screwed by my doctor, Mr Paul, who is very nice. It was pretty miraculous that I managed to play again. I took five wickets and then broke my other thumb during a warm-up. I think someone was telling me just to sit down. My first break was my right thumb and that wasn't so bad but after my left thumb went (I'm left-handed) I felt impotent. The left one is fine now but the right is still not moving much.

I moved to Knutsford in February so I can't really afford many holidays. I went to Madrid for two days with my wife Bethan in the summer. And then we go to Amsterdam with Lancashire in February with easyJet. Cheap and cheerful.

To be honest last year was going to be a really big year for me and it was a real shame to miss out. I haven't given up hopes of playing for England and the injuries were a bit of a kick in the nuts as far as that was concerned. I really want to maintain my standards for Lancashire next year.

Realistically I'm not likely to play for England again but never say never. I'm a far better bowler now than I was when I first played for England but that's the way it goes."

Peter Martin was talking to Tanya Aldred who is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

Worcestershire groundsman Roy McLaren on October 23

Sussex seam bowler James Kirtley on October 16

Essex offspinner Peter Such on October 9

Warwickshire captain Mark Wagh on October 2

Cambridge scorer Reg May on September 25

fields.headline: Roma keep candle burning
fields.standfirst: Serie A: The eternal also-rans came good with a second-half hat-trick from Gabriel Batistuta, but they still trail Udinese.
fields.trailText: When Roma last won the scudetto in 1983, long hair was the fashion and the samba skills of Falcão, the crosses of Conti and the goalscoring exploits of Pruzzo sent the red half of the Eternal City wild.
fields.body:
When Roma last won the scudetto in 1983, long hair was the fashion and the samba skills of Falcão, the crosses of Conti and the goalscoring exploits of Pruzzo sent the red half of the Eternal City wild.

Since then the Lupi have struggled in the shadow of Juventus, Internazionale, Milan and even their hated city rivals Lazio. But 17 years after their last Serie A triumph Roma have returned. And with Totti's trickery, Cafu's incisions, and Gabriel Omar Batistuta's goals (and hair) reviving memories of the 1983 side, they are - for the first time in a decade - being talked up as serious title contenders.

Yesterday Roma's ripe start to the season continued with a 4-2 victory away at Brescia. After somehow falling 2-1 behind at half-time, they turned things around with a brilliant second-half hat-trick from Batistuta (he has now scored a phenomenal 158 goals in 249 Serie A matches), leaving the Brescia coach Carlo Mazzone - the Big Ron of Italian football - mightily impressed.

"If Roma don't win the league this season I don't know when they ever will," the ex-coach of Roma gushed, before quickly recovering himself. "I say that like a Roma fan but it must be made clear that we didn't gift them the win today."

Roma's coach Fabio Capello, however, was much more downbeat. "Today we must not boast," he insisted. "We must remain calm and keep our concentration."

Despite their impressive victory, Roma stay behind the shock Serie A leaders Udinese, who were much too strong for Lecce. After a drab first half, Italian international Stefano Fiore began to strut his stuff, and two goals within five minutes from Paulo Sosa and Massimo Margiotta sealed a comfortable 2-0 win.

After the game the Udinese coach Luigi De Canio - like Capello - refused to get carried away. "It was very difficult today because Lecce are a good team and we didn't play well for the first half an hour," he admitted. "We have to stay humble and keep concentrating."

Meanwhile another of this season's surprise packages - newly promoted Atalanta - continued their excellent start with a 3-3 draw at Milan. But Atalanta's two-goal hero Christiano Doni - who is facing a five-year suspension for match-fixing - wasn't satisfied, claiming his side should never have thrown away their 3-1 half-time lead.

"I am actually not that happy with the result because I believed right up until the final whistle that we could get the three points," he insisted. Even so, fans of newly promoted Atalanta will not be too disappointed to find themselves in third place.

The same cannot be said about the attitude of ever-volatile Napoli supporters, however. Yesterday one particularly irate supporter followed the Azzurri's 2-1 home defeat by Vincenza by hurling a Molotov cocktail into the villa of co-owner Corrado Ferlaino.

The home-made device bounced off the wall of the house and exploded in the garden, setting fire to two cars (a Renault and a Nissan if you're interested) that were parked outside. Fortunately a policeman on duty at the house extinguished the blaze - although the cars were destroyed.

But Ferlaino couldn't say he wasn't warned. He later told police that he had received an anonymous call on Sunday morning telling him that his villa would be set alight if Napoli failed to win. Worse still, later that morning, two men had warned one of Ferlaino's cleaners: "Watch out. There's going to be one hell of a fire here tonight."

Despite the result - and the fire-bombing - the Napoli coach Zdenek Zemen today survived a board meeting - and so keeps his job, for now at least.

Elsewhere Juventus moved into fourth place after David Trezeguet scored twice in their 2-0 win away at Massimo Tiabi's Reggina. Parma won 1-0 at Bari with an 87th-minute Patrick Mboma goal. And Hakan Sukur - rumoured to be going back to Turkey last month - scored his second goal in as many games as Internazionale scrambled a late draw at Verona.

But spare a thought for the plucky home side - they were forced to play the whole of the second half with 10 men after Vincenzo Italiano was given a second yellow card for an over-the-top goal celebration after he put Verona 2-1 ahead.

It could have been worse, though. With seven minutes to go (and with Inter throwing four forwards into the attack: Pirlo, Vieri, Sukur and Recoba) the Turkish striker was presented with an inch-perfect Recoba cross only three yards out but sliced it over the bar.

webTitle: Officers angry as murder report is withheld

fields.headline: Officers angry as murder report is withheld
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The prison officers' representative for Feltham young offenders institution in south-west London has criticised a decision by the prison service not to reveal to officers the findings of an internal inquiry into the racist murder of an Asian inmate.
fields.body:
The prison officers' representative for Feltham young offenders institution in south-west London has criticised a decision by the prison service not to reveal to officers the findings of an internal inquiry into the racist murder of an Asian inmate.

The Prison Officers Association committee at the institution asked on more than one occasion to see the report into the murder of Zahid Mubarek by Robert Stewart, a psychopath with whom he was sharing a cell, but the requests were denied.

Last week Stewart was jailed for life for Mr Mubarek's murder, prompting calls for a full independent inquiry into the incident.

The decision to withhold the report was taken by Martin Narey, director general of the prison service, who wanted to limit circulation until Mr Mubarek's family had the chance to read and consider its findings.

The family was given a copy of the report at a meeting with Mr Narey and Paul Boateng, the prisons minister, last week.

But Stephen Gough, an executive committee member of the POA, and the area representative for Feltham, criticised the lack of access.

Mr Gough added: "To exclude us from the loop means that officers cannot be proactive."

"It is absolutely right that the family should see the report but if something has gone wrong and needs putting right, then prison officers should see it."

Mr Gough said that officers at the institution regretted what had happened to Mr Mubarek. But he added that the decision to allow the two men to share a cell was not a "ground floor decision" and would have been taken at management level.

He said that morale was low among staff at Feltham, and uncertainty over management - there have been four governors in six months - had left officers in a state of limbo.

Mr Gough said that prison officers were "the forgotten service".

fields.headline: Christmas delays on the cards
fields.standfirst:
Crisis hits postal deliveries

Special report: the weather
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The rail crisis is causing a backlog of 10m letters a day and tens of millions of greeting cards may not arrive by Christmas Day if the chaos continues, the Post Office warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The rail crisis is causing a backlog of 10m letters a day and tens of millions of greeting cards may not arrive by Christmas Day if the chaos continues, the Post Office warned yesterday.

Last night the organisation was reviewing whether to bring forward last posting dates for Christmas in an effort to overcome massive delays caused by rail repairs and speed restrictions. If the situation continues, the Post Office will struggle to cope with the Christmas rush, a spokesman admitted.

"The difficulties we have experienced over the past two weeks have been horrendous and there have been unprecedented delays in mail delivery," he said. "If we get these sort of delays running up to Christmas there is inevitably going to be an impact on delivery."

He added the Post Office was considering whether to ask people to post Christmas cards earlier than usual to ensure they arrive in time.

The Post Office is transporting more mail by road and air in response to the rail disruption but this could also be affected by threatened fuel protests.

Last night Railtrack warned that urgent maintenance work on the railways could be derailed by more bad weather. As the new storm swept in, Railtrack said a planned "huge programme of re-railing and inspection" due to start yesterday may face delays.

Flooding in the Midlands and the west of England, together with post-Hatfield Railtrack speed restrictions, meant some train companies were able to offer only about half the normal number of weekend trains.

Some companies warned passengers that journeys could take up to 75 minutes longer than normal.

Railtrack has said the amount of work needed to repair flood damage would not be evident until the waters subsided.

webTitle: Macca returns to a Real dive

fields.headline: Macca returns to a Real dive
fields.trailText: Steve McManaman is back. Exactly 164 days after last year's Champions League final, Vicente del Bosque returned the scouser to his starting line-up for the trip to Numancia on Saturday night. Not that the Man in the Moustache seemed altogether convinced. Launching an audacious challenge on John Gregory's position as undisputed King of Man-Management, Del Bosque claimed that due to injuries "someone had to play".
fields.body:
Steve McManaman is back. Exactly 164 days after last year's Champions League final, Vicente del Bosque returned the scouser to his starting line-up for the trip to Numancia on Saturday night. Not that the Man in the Moustache seemed altogether convinced. Launching an audacious challenge on John Gregory's position as undisputed King of Man-Management, Del Bosque claimed that due to injuries "someone had to play".

And that man was Macca. Surprisingly after such a ringing endorsement, it wasn't a huge shock that his return wasn't enough to rescue a Real side in dire straits. Del Bosque's men have now lost three out of four after falling at home to Mallorca in midweek (2-0) and away to Numancia on Saturday night.

Real were poor throughout their trip to Numancia's Los Pajaritos ("The Little Birds"), and although Raúl - dreadful in recent weeks - finally managed to find the net, it was not enough to prevent a shock Numancia victory. Romanian midfielder Larentiu Rosu hit a hat-trick as the side from Soria ran out worthy 3-1 winners.

Luckily for Real, none of the major challengers managed to take full advantage. In fact, with a full round of matches in midweek as well the normal weekend games, Zaragoza and Mallorca were the only sides that picked up six points.

Valencia blew the chance to extend their lead at the top of the table at Montjuic this weekend, falling to resurgent Espanyol after a late goal from Manuel Serrano. Missing the pace and movement provided by Piojo López, Farinós, Gerard and Angulo (currently on the bench), Valencia have been unconvincing in recent weeks, even though they kept on winning by the odd goal. When you rely on John Carew for goals you court disaster, though. And so it proved.

While Valencia have been dull, champions Deportivo la Coruña and Radi Antic's Real Oviedo are the sides to watch, with goals galore - at both ends.

Diego Tristán's hat-trick for Depor saw off Las Palmas in midweek, with injury-returnee Roy Makaay getting the other in a 4-0 win. Javier Irueta's side then travelled to Villarreal on Saturday and went 1-0 and 2-1 up, only to concede two in the last ten minutes to finish up losing 3-2. Víctor, who always seems to score against Depor, was Villarreal's star man - he scored two himself before superbly setting up Moisés for the winner.

Oviedo, meanwhile, stuck four past Rayo keeper Kasey Keller in midweek (4-1), only to let in the same amount at Alavés on Sunday. With that victory Alavés lie second despite having fallen to a surprise - and bad-tempered - home defeat, 1-0, against neighbours Real Sociedad on Wednesday night.

With all the championship contenders struggling to collect maximum points, Barça's failure to beat Numancia at home on Wednesday suddenly doesn't look so bad. The culés remain concerned about their side's dependence on Rivaldo, though. Luckily, the Brazilian is rather good. He opened the scoring from the penalty spot against Numancia - only for the visitors to find a late equaliser - and he was on target again against Las Palmas on Saturday, coolly leaving the islanders' goalkeeper Nacho (hmmmm, Nachos) González on the floor before rolling the ball into an empty net. This time a single Rivaldo goal was enough.

Barcelona's major problems are at the other end. Lorenzo Serra Ferrer dropped comedy keeper Dutruel for the visit of Numancia in midweek. Luckily, Francesc Arnau proved a worthy replacement, palming Pacheta's 89th-minute free-kick straight into the path of Rubén Navarro to level the match at 1-1.

This dodgy keeper business seems to be becoming something of a habit. Whatever next? Mark Crossley? Rumours in the Spanish press suggest that Barça are after two teenage goalies: Iker Casillas of Real Madrid and Paul Robinson from Leeds. Well, if you can't beat 'em, buy 'em. Perhaps they should look to buy Real Oviedo's Ivan Anía. He made a fine two-handed save to deny Alavés a certain goal 20 minutes into his side's visit to the Mendizorroza ground on Sunday. Just one problem - he's a midfielder (and he was sent off).

The other two sides in the top six, Celta Vigo and Rayo Vallecano, both won this weekend despite disappointing defeats earlier in the week. Alexandr Mostovoi's return was the key for Celta as they saw off Málaga on Saturday. Valeri Karpin's deflected shot fell kindly for the Russian, who scored the game's only goal from a position that looked suspiciously offside.

Meanwhile, Rayo won 2-1 at home to Valladolid. Josep Setvalls set the home side on the way on the stroke of half-time and Elvir Bolic got the winner five minutes from time after Heinze had looked like getting yet another draw for Valladolid - it would have been their seventh in nine games.

Elsewhere this weekend, Osasuna and Athletic Bilbao drew 1-1, while Racing Santander lost 2-0 at improving Zaragoza. Real Sociedad were beaten by Spain's on-form side Real Mallorca (three wins on the trot including Real Madrid and Barcelona), with ex-Barça defender Miguel Ángel Nadal the hero with a last minute winner.

Finally, it seems that the Atlético Madrid fans' patience with the world's dodgiest chairman, president Jesús Gil y Gil, has finally worn out. Atléti, 1996 double-winners and relegated from the top flight last season, capped a miserable run at the weekend with a dreadful performance, losing 2-1 at home to Tenerife.

That defeat leaves the side in the relegation zone, fourth from bottom. Gil's prediction that this would be "a year in hell" is looking hopelessly optimistic. And if they go down again - well, what comes below hell for the Atléti players? Maybe they'll all be packed off to Middlesbrough.

Atlético's fans booed their team from the field at the end, but reserved their real fury for the president himself, whom they ever so politely asked to leave. Trouble is, with Gil owning 95% of the shares, a boardroom coup is hardly on the cards.

webTitle: US papers say election result too close to call

fields.headline: US presidential race too close to call
fields.standfirst: The outcome of the presidential election is impossible to predict, with Al Gore and George W Bush neck and neck in the polls and using similar tactics to attract undecided voters, writes Derek Brown
fields.trailText: What the US papers say: The outcome of the presidential election is impossible to predict, with Al Gore and George W Bush neck and neck in the polls and using similar tactics to attract undecided voters, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
They may back different candidates or none at all, but the main US papers are as one in believing that the presidential race is simply too close to call. Certainly, the commentators are placing no bets.

Michael Tackett, political editor of the Chicago Tribune, admits he hasn't a clue about the likely outcome: "For all the speeches delivered and miles logged, attacks levelled and promises made, the long, costly race for the White House remains in the final weekend as ill-defined as it is close.

"It's a big race about relatively small things. Not war or recession. Not a hostage crisis or long gasoline lines. Not a missile gap or civil rights. Instead, it has been a battle waged largely at the midfield of American politics with the seemingly dominant issues being the cost of seniors' prescriptions and the government's stewardship of Social Security."

The Los Angeles Times says the presidential contest is now "down to the wire" - a phrase much used on the front pages - and offers a vivid account of Al Gore's breakneck progress from state to state: "With the race closer than any in decades, turnout is crucial for both sides. And it's most important in the tossup states where Gore and Bush appeared just hours apart over the campaign's final weekend.

"In their struggle for the 270 electoral votes needed to win, the campaigns have targeted swing areas of swing states so precisely that Gore stopped Sunday in the same Detroit suburb of Dearborn that Bush visited on Saturday. And here, as at every other stop, Gore told people their state was the one that could push him over the top."

Rather cruelly, the paper also offers some reflections on losing the presidential contest, by some who have done just that: "George S. McGovern, who lost resoundingly to Richard Nixon in 1972, recalls the silence, the loneliness. 'Where did all those voters go? Where were those huge crowds on election day?' he asks. 'You have a huge sense that the country deserted you and left you alone.'"

The San Francisco Chronicle offers hard evidence of the closeness of the race, reporting the latest poll in the vital state of California. It shows Mr Gore ahead of Mr Bush by five points, 46 to 41, with four points for Green Party candidate Ralph Nader, two points for Reform Party candidate Pat Buchanan and others, and seven points going to undecided voters. The poll, with a 3.3 percent margin of error, showed a two point slide for Mr Gore from a similar poll released last Thursday.

The paper quotes poll director Mark DiCamillo: "With each passing day over the past week and a half, Bush has gotten closer and closer in California. Where once California was seen as a safe Gore state...now it's more of a lean for Gore."

The Dallas Morning News reports the staggering amounts of cash which has been poured into both campaigns: " Add the sums raised by presidential campaigns, House and Senate candidates and the parties themselves, and the tab this year has already reached about $1.9bn - by far the most ever spent during a campaign and more than double that of 1992. Throw in the money spent by interest groups such as the National Rifle Association, pharmaceutical companies and Planned Parenthood, and the total swells to nearly $3bn, according to estimates."

The Miami Herald is understandably focused on the surprisingly close race in Florida, where Mr Bush is struggling to maintain his early lead, in spite of his brother Jeb being the popular state governor. "Bush's trip to Florida in the final days of the closest presidential contest in four decades and Gore's midnight rally in South Beach tonight are a measure of how critical the state and its 25 electoral [college] votes have become to the victory of either candidate on Tuesday. Vice-president Gore has also included Florida in his final 30-hour, seven-state, non-stop frenzy of campaigning."

The New York Times reports the other frantic last-gasp campaign on its doorstep, between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick Lazio for the US Senate. It has a colourful account of the first lady's Sunday dash round churches to encourage the overwhelmingly Democrat black vote: "The same striking scene was replayed again and again throughout the day: the wife of the president of the United States sweeping into Baptist churches in some of the most impoverished neighbourhoods of New York, to a rustle of excitement and raised hands and a swell of organ music and gospel song."

Amid the frenzied claims and counterclaims, there is still space for humour, albeit of a caustic kind. The Detroit Free Press features a cartoon in which a television interviewer asks a man on the street which candidate he prefers. He answers: "Drew Barrymore - she's easily the best of the new Charlie's Angels."

The paper also conducted a straw poll of 20 people to find how much they knew about the electoral college; the 540-member body which will choose the new president. Only two of the respondents had a clue. A waitress and customer at the nearby Clique restaurant shook their heads in puzzlement. "I have no idea," said the customer, whose first name was Vera. "Did you try the Yellow Pages?"

fields.headline: Bradford sack Hutchings
fields.trailText: Bradford City have sacked their manager Chris Hutchings and first-team coach Malcolm Shotton.
fields.body:
Bradford City have sacked their manager Chris Hutchings and first-team coach Malcolm Shotton.

Hutchings had been in charge at Valley Parade for only the past four months but had come under increasing pressure from the chairman Geoffrey Richmond after 10 games without a win.

The final straw came with Bradford's 2-0 defeat at Charlton on Saturday, a game Richmond did not attend after being taken ill during the Worthington Cup defeat at Newcastle last week.

Richmond called an emergency board meeting last night and announced the decision this afternoon with a familiar euphemism: Hutchings and Shotton, he said, had been "relieved of their duties".

Richmond thanked Hutchings for working "tirelessly on behalf of the club" during his four years as coach and youth development officer and four months as manager. "The board felt that the time for a change had now come to give the future manager as long as possible to change the fortunes on the field," the chairman explained.

Bradford spent heavily on new players this summer and gained an immediate dividend when they beat Chelsea 2-0 on August 22. But they have not won a Premiership game since.

After a 2-0 defeat at home to Ipswich on October 21, Richmond held a two-hour meeting with Hutchings and issued him with an ultimatum: "Improve results or pay the price."

"Obviously it's a great disappointment to be relieved of my duties," Hutchings said yesterday. "However I recognise the club's future prospects are the most important thing to the board and they feel change is the best way to do this."

Stuart McCall, who was sent off on Saturday, has been named as caretaker, and the club is inviting applications for the vacancy.

Hutchings is 43. He was a late arrival in professional football, playing for Southall and Harrow Borough before signing for Chelsea in 1980. He went on to play for Brighton, Huddersfield, Walsall and Rotherham.

"I still feel I have got a lot to offer the world of football," he said yesterday. "I hope to get back and be involved in the game as quickly as possible."

webTitle: Prescott's £51m to beat floods 'a drop in the ocean'

fields.headline: Prescott's £51m to beat floods 'a drop in the ocean'
fields.standfirst:
Adequate defences could cost billions

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Adequate defences could cost billions.
fields.body:
John Prescott's offer of £51m over four years to prevent the sort of floods seen in the past month is a drop in the ocean of what may be needed, say the environment agency and green organisations.

Geoff Spence, head of water management at the environment agency, yesterday welcomed the extra one-off cash payment but said he would be "amazed" if a review of Britain's inland flood defences did not reveal the need for far more money to be spent.

"It will certainly be far more than £51m," said Mr Spence. The agency argued for £100m a year in last year's spending review but was given £30m extra, despite conservative estimates from the Department of Environment that global warming would require an extra £4.5bn to be spent on flood defences in the next 50 years.

Only £2m (4%) of the new money promised by the government at the weekend can be spent in the next 12 months. Most is expected to go on "running repairs" to the failing inland defence systems and to accelerate existing studies of what work needs to be done to protect towns such as Shrewsbury, Bewdley, Lewes, York, Gloucester and Uckfield, which have repeatedly been hit in the past few years.

Yesterday, the new money was criticised for being too little too late by green groups and communities affected by some of the worst flooding on record. "The sums Mr Prescott is talking about are finger-in-the-dyke stuff. We'll never keep climate change at bay by spending a few million. It will cost billions, the problems are that serious," said Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth.

The priority, said the environment agency, would be to repair defences which have been damaged or destroyed in the past 10 days. The agency will begin a review of inland defences when the floods have gone, but this is not expected to be published until February.

One problem the authorities face is that even relatively small new defences can take up to four years to evaluate, design and build.

There is no simple way of defending all towns and villages. No one is in favour of building high flood walls around all vulnerable places. Experience abroad has shown that investments of this kind which may involve huge earthworks, raising river banks, building sluices and canalising rivers to divert water, often fail and lead to problems elsewhere.

The reality is that if, as expected, climate change kicks in with more frequent extreme weather, government, the business community and individuals, must be prepared to spend billions of extra pounds a year unless far greater emphasis is given to keeping the water on the land, and preventing it from reaching the rivers too quickly.

The quandary is that to do anything serious will cost billions, but to do nothing may cost much more. A recent EU report on the adaptions required for climate change in Europe noted the increasing pressure of floods and extreme weather on water resources, agriculture, transport, health, and coastal zones.

So far Britain has seen little damage compared to what is forecast to happen.

The Association of British Insurers estimates it could cost at least £10bn in insurance losses if the Thames catchment region were massively flooded. A prolonged storm over the upper half of the river Trent and Severn catchments, it said, could cost about £5bn.

"It's vital that flood defences are adequate. It could take very high investment to bring internal defences up to scratch. Coastal defences, too, are inadequate in certain areas," said an ABI spokesman yesterday.

webTitle: Gore and Bush charge for the line

fields.headline: Gore and Bush charge for the line
fields.standfirst:
With less than a day to go, the US presidential candidates are chasing each other to the wire
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText:
With less than a day to go, the US presidential candidates are chasing each other to the wire.
Special report: the US elections
fields.body:
With the presidential contest still neck and neck, less than 24 hours before the United States votes, Al Gore and George W Bush are making a final push through battleground states.

The Republican candidate promised "a sprint to the finish," while his Democratic rival told audiences that it was time "to move your feet."

Both candidates emphasised the need to energise their core supporters and reach still-undecided voters. "We've laid the groundwork for victory, now it's up (to us) to get people to the polls," said Mr Bush, leaving Florida - a state both candidates are desperate to win - for the last time before the election.

A Bush strategist, Karl Rove, said that Republicans had concentrated on get-out-the-vote efforts in the campaign's final days, placing 70m phone calls to voters, sending out 110m items of mail and mobilising 243,000 volunteers in 28 battleground states.

While both candidates have full schedules, Mr Gore went a step further, campaigning around the clock. Well past midnight, in a wind-blown cold rain, he hustled across airport tarmac to greet some 700 flag-waving supporters in Iowa.

"I'm going to be brief," he promised. "I want you to save some energy to take your neighbours to the polls and I want you to convince all of the undecided voters you encounter over the next 24 hours and more, because this race is close."

Mr Gore stood under a black umbrella meeting workers as they reported for work at a tractor plant. He grinned when a red pickup truck slowed in the street and its driver shouted, "Give George Bush hell tomorrow!"

After appearing on a string of TV talk shows, he flew off to campaign in Missouri, Michigan and Florida. Tomorrow morning he plans to hold a dawn election day gathering in Tampa, Florida.

"The last formal campaign stop of campaign 2000, after my opponent's gone to bed, is going to be in central Florida, because that's where the future is going to be written," he insisted.

George Bush spent the night in Orlando after a five-city blitz through Florida, the most populous swing state. Earlier, the Texas governor campaigned in Tennessee, Wisconsin, Iowa and Arkansas before returning to his home in Austin, Texas.

The Republican presidential nominee drew large, enthusiastic crowds at each of his Florida stops. National polls give him a narrow edge in the presidential race, but Gore's support in large battleground states has led to an unpredictable race to 270 electoral votes and victory.

webTitle: Borrowed Time, Mind Games, and Crippled Inside

fields.headline: Borrowed Time, Mind Games, and Crippled Inside
fields.trailText: SOFT HUTCH
fields.body:
SOFT HUTCH

"Without a doubt we are looking at doing more than just staying up," said Chris Hutchings on his appointment as manager of Bradford City back in August. He then claimed his managerial style would combine a dash of Bill Shankly, a drop of Brian Clough and a hint of Bill Nicholson. "They were great managers whose teams always played fantastic football and that's what I want to instil here," he said, three months before getting the sack.

When the Fiver asked Bradford for confirmation of Hutchings' sacking this afternoon, we were told that "the phrase we are using is 'relieved of his responsibilities'". So, the relieving of the responsibilities must have come as no surprise to Bantams fans, who have gone ten games without a win, are in the bottom three, out of the Worthington Cup, and have Stanley Victor Collymore up front (when he's not having his wisdom teeth removed - and surely he needs as many as he can get his jaws on?). Indeed, it was only three defeats ago that publicity-aware chairman Geoffrey Richmond told Hutchings he was living on "borrowed time".

The club are holding a press conference at 5.45pm today (about 13 hours before most of you receive this mail). It is to be expected that Mr Richmond will make lots of noises about securing the club's Premiership status and finding the right man for the job. But perhaps if the club had done something about that in the summer, instead of trying to get as many big names (remember Benito Carbone?) into the club as possible, they might not already be half-way to the First Division.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IN THE HOLE

Last night, the Fiver stayed up until the small hours trying to lay bare the menace that is organised card games. But no matter how hard we tried we could not recreate the moral havoc that single-handedly brought about the collapse of the England team during Euro 2000. Until we summoned the demon Astaroth that is.

No, for some reason, over the course of the weekend cards have become football's new bet noir (geddit??). Tabloids have raged about Kelvin Koogan's card school (two pages after offering readers expert tips on the horses). Paul Merson, gambling expert, has warned of the mental changes playing a quick hand of whist can bring about ("It is so mentally draining. It's on your mind all the time"). And Kevin Phillips has found it a useful new peg on which to hang his international bitterness ("If you were not a card player or a racing fan, going away with England could be a bit boring. I used to spend my free time just stuck in my room.").

But who will stand up for the benefits of sitting on a pair of cowboys with a naked ace and a jack in the river? Not to mention having a good hand at poker? Why it's Arsene's Arsenal Wenger. "When I arrived at Arsenal I changed a number of things but I did not do anything about gambling because I did not see it causing any difficulties," said the footballing professor turned moral transgressor. "I banned alcohol before and after games and I introduced a new dietary system but I did not and do not perceive gambling as a problem." Treble aces all around!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Last season there was a bit of a problem in defence early on and we weren't comfortable. The trouble this time isn't just a defensive thing, it is the whole team" - Yes, that's right Mikael Silvestre. It's the whole team's fault, not yours.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

PADDY'S WHACKED

When the Fiver heard that a Liverpool player is to miss the rest of the season after picking up a serious injury against Leeds this weekend, we assumed a slapstick mishap had befallen one of their hapless defenders. Perhaps Sami Hyypia had torn several muscles upon violently mis-kicking at thin air. Had Markus Babbel seriously injured his buttocks after bouncing around on them all afternoon? Or maybe an exasperated Gerard Houllier had stoved Christian Ziege's face in with a cricket bat.

But in fact the injured party was Patrick Berger, who badly twisted his knee in a challenge with the otherwise anonymous Mark Viduka. "I did it when I was trying to tackle Viduka as he was about to score Leeds' third goal," explained the midfielder with the air of a man for whom hope and happiness have become alien concepts. "I was covering as a left-back. I know I could have got to the ball, but suddenly I twisted my knee and I was powerless to do anything."

As this is the second time this season Berger has knackered his knee, Liverpool have decided to send him to Dr Richard Steadman, an expert who has already tinkered with Jamie Redknapp and PSV Manchester striker Greg van Rusedski. "I don't know how long I'll be out for," moped Berger, "but once Dr Steadman has opened up my knee and had a look inside he'll decide what I need to do to get fit." Sadly, this means the Czech international won't get home to see his family for Christmas - "that's not looking possible now" - but he should look on the bright side: at least he won't be blamed the next 26 times his team capitulate.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Manchester United are set to sign Canadian defender Kevin McKenna from German club Energie Cottbus. Twenty-year-old McKenna, who has failed to hold down a first-team place in the Bundesliga this season, could complete a move to Old Trafford this week. Cottbus manager Klaus Stabach said: "All we have to do now is agree on the transfer fee. Manchester United know what we would like to receive."

Fulham's £6m bid for giant Czech striker Jan Koller looks almost certain to fail after Anderlecht general manager Michel Vershueren accused Jean Tigana of trying to get Koller on the cheap. "Firstly, Fulham aren't valuing Jan Koller at his true worth. We'll never let him go for so little," Vershueren told La Derniere Heure. "Apart from that, our Czech deserves better than to develop in that division."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Wembley's twin towers will be demolished with the rest of the stadium, Wembley chief executive Bob Stubbs confirmed today. He said that a bid by Halton Council in Widnes to save the towers had failed because it was too expensive to relocate the structure.

Scotland have agreed to play a friendly in Poland next April.

Charlton have revealed they lost more than £3m last year - after gambling on an immediate return to the Premiership. "It is true to say that we took a carefully calculated financial risk by maintaining and then improving the first-team squad in order to gain promotion," admitted chairman Richard Murray. "Consequently I am proud of the fact we celebrate the new Millennium as a Premiership club.

" * * * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Uefa Big Cup Weekly (11.30pm) Why the whole country wants Manchester United to stay in the tournament, by Clive Tyldesley.

Nationwide League Football Extra (12.30am) Steve Claridge's Portsmouth have gone eight league games unbeaten. Who'd have put money on that?

Channel 5: Dutch Football (4.30am) Stop hogging that ball and pass it round.

Sky Sports 1: Live Monday Night Football (7pm, 12.30am) Now listen here, Mr Keys. If you don't drop that pompous introductory nonsense, we'll stick your 'Sky Sports presentation in widescreen and Dolby surround with interactive coverage on channel 404' where the sun don't shine.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.30pm, 3am) Rodney Marsh: "That's a great point." The Fiver: "That's a piss-poor catchphrase."

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 12midnight SS1) Watch Oxford sail into the distance.

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm) Coventry City's Wille Carr. See if more than a minute goes by without mention of the donkey kick.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (8pm) Better get into your stride quickly, Alan, lad. It's started.

Perhaps Sami Hyypia had torn several muscles upon violently mis-kicking at thin air. Had Markus Babbel seriously injured his buttocks after bouncing around on them all afternoon? Or maybe an exasperated Gerard Houllier had stoved Christian Ziege's face in with a cricket bat. But in fact the injured party was Patrick Berger, who badly twisted his knee in a challenge with the otherwise anonymous Mark Viduka. "I did it when I was trying to tackle Viduka as he was about to score Leeds' third goal," explained the midfielder with the air of a man for whom hope and happiness have become alien concepts. Cottbus manager Klaus Stabach said: "All we have to do now is agree on the transfer fee. Manchester United know what we would like to receive." "Firstly, Fulham aren't valuing Jan Koller at his true worth. We'll never let him go for so little," Vershueren told La Derniere Heure. "Apart from that, our Czech deserves better than to develop in that division." * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Wembley's twin towers will be demolished with the rest of the stadium, Wembley chief executive Bob Stubbs confirmed today. He said that a bid by Halton Council in Widnes to save the towers had failed because it was too expensive to relocate the structure. Scotland have agreed to play a friendly in Poland next April. Charlton have revealed they lost more than £3m last year - after gambling on an immediate return to the Premiership. "It is true to say that we took a carefully calculated financial risk by maintaining and then improving the first-team squad in order to gain promotion," admitted chairman Richard Murray. "Consequently I am proud of the fact we celebrate the new Millennium as a Premiership club. " * * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO ITV: Uefa Big Cup Weekly (11.30pm) Why the whole country wants Manchester United to stay in the tournament, by Clive Tyldesley. Nationwide League Football Extra (12.30am) Steve Claridge's Portsmouth have gone eight league games unbeaten. Who'd have put money on that? Channel 5: Dutch Football (4.30am) Stop hogging that ball and pass it round. Sky Sports 1: Live Monday Night Football (7pm, 12.30am) Now listen here, Mr Keys. If you don't drop that pompous introductory nonsense, we'll stick your 'Sky Sports presentation in widescreen and Dolby surround with interactive coverage on channel 404' where the sun don't shine. You're On Sky Sports! (10.30pm, 3am) Rodney Marsh: "That's a great point." The Fiver: "That's a piss-poor catchphrase." Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 12midnight SS1) Watch Oxford sail into the distance. Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm) Coventry City's Wille Carr. See if more than a minute goes by without mention of the donkey kick. Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (8pm) Better get into your stride quickly, Alan, lad. It's started.

fields.headline: Mowlam queries pot 'gateway'
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam, yesterday denied cannabis was a "gateway" drug which could lead to heroin abuse and claimed alcohol was potentially far more damaging.
fields.body:
The Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam, yesterday denied cannabis was a "gateway" drug which could lead to heroin abuse and claimed alcohol was potentially far more damaging.

Ms Mowlam, who is responsible for the government's drug policy coordination, said there was no scientific evidence that proved the gateway theory.

Her views clash with the home secretary, Jack Straw, who has said cannabis is in itself harmful and leads to use of harder drugs.

Ms Mowlam - who is known to hold more liberal views on cannabis legislation - also praised the recent Runciman report which called for the depenalisation of cannabis possession.

She also urged greater consistency between forces in the handling of cases of possession of cannabis, suggesting the uneven rate of prosecutions was unhelpful. Last year 2,838 people went to prison for cannabis possession.

She was speaking on BBC TV's On The Record in advance of Wednesday's publication of the government's annual drugs report.

She intends to use the publication to highlight the success of the government's drug testing and treatment orders (DTTOs), a scheme which requires criminals to undertake drug treatment as an alternative to a custodial sentence.

The use of orders, now going nationwide, appears to be reducing offenders' reliance on drugs.

Research published last week shows that of the 288 offenders in three pilot areas made subject to a DTTO, the average weekly spend on drugs showed a 94% fall from £400 in the month before the arrest to £34 in the first few weeks of the order.

In total 210 offenders were sentenced to a DTTO, nearly three quarters of offenders recommended to the court for an order.

The orders are available to offenders aged 16 and over found guilty of offences leading to custodial sentences ranging between six months and three years.

webTitle: Jay states Dyke happy with BBC's business coverage

fields.headline: Jay says Dyke happy with BBC coverage
fields.trailText: 2.45pm update: Peter Jay, economics and business editor of the BBC, has sidestepped Dyke's criticisms of the corporation's business coverage, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
Peter Jay, economics and business editor of the BBC, has sidestepped the stinging criticisms made by director general Greg Dyke of the corporation's track record in business coverage.

Jay said both he and the business team at the corporation were pleased by the added commitment from Dyke, which includes a number of new programmes devoted to business and a near doubling of correspondents.

"We are very excited about the extra resources, impetus and priority being given to this area," he said.

Jay will become purely economics editor and will work alongside Jeff Randall, the editor of Sunday Business, who was this morning announced as the corporation's business editor.

Jay dismissed suggestion that Dyke's comments were a criticism of his role which he said was chiefly about macro economics and not the business community. "As far as I am aware Greg is pleased with what I have done," he said.

He added: "I don't think it's for me to judge what the business coverage has been like in retrospect. Its much more for me to welcome the support and confidence being given to this area of broadcasting."

fields.headline: The cat's whiskers
fields.trailText:
Bowl of cream required
The handbag award for bitchiest comment by a media type goes to one M. Jackson of Horseferry Road. Channel 4 boss Jacko unsheathed his claws while banging on about his strategy for further pay-TV ventures at the whizz-bang press launch for new entertainment service E4. "We don't see any point launching channels for the sake of it," pronounced the Jackster solemnly, "that's known as the Carlton strategy". Miaow!
fields.body:
Bowl of cream required
The handbag award for bitchiest comment by a media type goes to one M. Jackson of Horseferry Road. Channel 4 boss Jacko unsheathed his claws while banging on about his strategy for further pay-TV ventures at the whizz-bang press launch for new entertainment service E4. "We don't see any point launching channels for the sake of it," pronounced the Jackster solemnly, "that's known as the Carlton strategy". Miaow!

Low-profile media appearance for Birt
Since he quit the BBC to don ermine in the upper house, Lord Birt has been religious about keeping a low profile. So Monkey was privileged to witness his re-entry to the world of media - at the opening of an bustling young marketing firm's new offices last night. Before you commiserate with Circus, Monkey can explain - his daughter apparently works there.

Mail hacks defect to Mirror
Oh dear, the Daily Mail's well of love just isn't deep enough. Maggie O'Riordan, one of its newsroom stars, is quitting to join the Sunday Mirror as a senior feature writer after a foul-mouthed bust up with an executive. And Alun Palmer former showbiz reporter has been offered a top job at the Mirror - as deputy showbiz editor.

No Go Yo Yo
Top marks to Flextech Telewest, which is making a stand against the increasing trend for silly names. The newly-merged company commissioned branding consultancy Wolff Olins, the company behind Orange and Go, to come up with a slightly catchier moniker. But Wolff Olins' suggestions - understood to include Circus and Yo Yo -- have all been rejected, leaving Flextech Telewest just months to come up with a new name before the merger is complete.

Image consultant
The ad industry's most notorious workaholic can kiss his hard-earned reputation goodbye. Images of McCann-Erickson's industrious chief executive, Ben Langdon, sunning himself in St Lucia were beamed into the nation's living rooms at the weekend after he was caught on camera for the BBC's Holiday Guide. Rumours that Mr Langdon engineered the TV appearance himself to show off his newly-trim physique are entirely unsubstantiated.

Be afraid...
Scarlet fever is alive and well, and sweeping through new weekly mobile magazine Mobile. Editor Glenn Tompkins has been quarantined after contracting the nineteenth-century disease and hypochondriac staff are now fearing for their lives. Could this be the first signs of a plague sweeping the media industry? Trust media to bring back a disease that hasn't been seen for decades. Symptoms to look out for are sore throat, fever, headache, a red rash, delirium and agitation - not much to go on, given that this could apply to just about any old media exec.

Signs of a man desperately clinging to his youth, part 1
You are a charming media type, with a sharp dress sense and a beautiful new woman from the telly in your life. So when it comes your leaving bash you need somewhere impressive to entertain your friends and contacts. So can anyone explain just why BBC1 controller Peter Salmon chose The Limelight club (trendy circa 1985) to bid farewell to his chums?

Editing life's bowl of cherries
Lis Howell, the woman who launched UK Living, is back, and not a day too late. Howell has launched a portal for the over-35s, called bowlofcherrries.com (no, not bowelofcherries.com, which, incidentally, has not yet been registered), and roped in 50 of her celebrity pals to add kudos to the site. Monkey was bemused by a glaring omission in the press release for the site - absolutely no mention of GMTV where Howell spent two years of her life. Could this be a new F-factor in her career - F for forgettability?


Email the Media Monkey at monkey@mediatheguardian.com

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip surrounded by sandbags and whistlin' about the end of the world
fields.trailText: Fulham's £6m bid for giant Czech striker Jan Koller looks almost certain to fail after Anderlecht general manager Michel Vershueren accused Jean Tigana of trying to get Koller on the cheap.
fields.body:
Fulham's £6m bid for giant Czech striker Jan Koller looks almost certain to fail after Anderlecht general manager Michel Vershueren accused Jean Tigana of trying to get Koller on the cheap.

"Firstly, Fulham aren't valuing Jan Koller at his true worth. We'll never let him go for so little," Vershueren told La Derniere Heure. "Apart from that, our Czech deserves better than to develop in that division. Of course Fulham are right up the top of the league but all the same.

"Finally, we need him. Anderlecht are on the point of qualifying for the Champions League. It would be suicide to weaken ourselves by selling him."

John Gregory has watched Birmingham's on-loan striker Mark Burchill twice in the past week, reports Teamtalk. However Burchill is unlikely to move to Villa because Birmingham have first option on the Celtic striker.

Meanwhile Fulham striker Paul Peschisolido is having talks with QPR about making his loan move to Loftus Road permanent. "I would like to move here permanently if something can be agreed," admitted Peschisolido. "I don't think I can go back to Fulham because I don't see a future there, and I don't know why because Tigana didn't speak to me. In fact he doesn't speak to anybody at all."

Portsmouth are hoping to sign West Ham striker Paul Kitson on loan.
