webTitle: Paris left behind by racing Sedan

fields.headline: Paris left behind by racing Sedan
fields.standfirst: The car that ate Paris and other major features of the weekend.
fields.trailText: Who are these people? A bunch of unfamiliar clubs are enjoying their time in the Sundance this season and may yet be seen in the Champions League next season. Learn to pronounce these names now: Alaves, Sedan, Udinese, Anji Makhachkala, Leicester City.
fields.body:
Who are these people? A bunch of unfamiliar clubs are enjoying their time in the Sundance this season and may yet be seen in the Champions League next season. Learn to pronounce these names now: Alaves, Sedan, Udinese, Anji Makhachkala, Leicester City.

Udinese moved to the top in Italy. Sedan have taken the lead in France. Alaves have moved up to second in the Spanish League. Anji Makhachkala can finish third in Russia. And Leicester, some of you may have noticed, are third in England.

With Monaco struggling and Marseille in deep caca, Sedan have come up on the outside. They won 3-0 in Guingamp on Saturday with two goals from their Belgian international striker Toni Brogno to overtake Paris St-Germain, who lost 1-0 at Auxerre.

Sedan have a long tradition of professional football, but they have hardly distinguished themselves in recent years. For a while they were merged with Racing Club of France, which briefly made them Racing Sedan, an awkward and unlikely alliance between the Parisiens and a scruffy little town in the Ardennes.

Small-town teams have thrived in the French League -- Guingamp, Auxerre and Monaco, with a combined population of under 100,000, are the most prominent recent examples -- but until recently Sedan appeared unlikely to join their number. Five years ago they were relegated to the regionalised third level of French football. Now they can look down on the Parisiens.

Meanwhile mighty Marseille have dropped into the relegation zone -- on Saturday they lost 1-0 at home to Rennes -- and Monaco, who went down 2-0 at home to Lyon on Friday, have fallen to 11th and are in danger of going out of the Champions League.

Marco Simone, an Italian striker who has never shirked off-the-ball work, gave his team-mates a rocket on Sunday, two days before their must-win visit to Ibrox in the Champions League. "If anyone is not (motivated) I hope he will have the courage to stay at home," he said, "because we don't need people who bring nothing to the team.

"I'm very angry because I've had enough of people who think it's enough to be here with the sun and all the advantages. I did not come here on holiday or as a pensioner. I can quit, tomorrow even, if there is no possibility of winning."

Alaves, another team that was recently in a third division, jumped to second place in Spain and closed the gap on the leaders Valencia to two points yesterday with a 4-0 win over Oviedo. Jordi Cruyff got the fourth.

Newly promoted Anji Makhachkala made light of having to play their home game against Chernomorets Novorossiisk in the neighbouring city of Vladikavkaz to win 2-1 yesterday and hold on to third place in the Russian League with one game left to play. Magomed Adiyev, a Russian Under-21 international in prolific form as the season comes to its close, scored both goals.

Anji, who were given a three-game stadium ban after assaults on a referee and a league official in last month's game against Dynamo Moscow, play fourth-placed Torpedo Moscow in the capital next week, when a draw may not be enough to secure their lofty position.

Spartak Moscow made sure of their fifth successive Russian title on Thursday, when they beat Rostselmash Rostov 1-0. Lokomotiv Moscow, who were thereby consigned to the runners-up spot, crushed last-placed Uralan Elista 9-0 on Friday to set the Russian league record for the biggest win.

Hertha Berlin, on top of the Bundesliga for the first time in 30 years, beat Werder Bremen 4-1 on Saturday with two goals from Michael Preetz and one from the former Villa midfielder Stefan Beinlich. Bayern Munich maintained the pressure by crushing Borussia Dortmund 6-2 (Hasan Salihamidzic 2, Mehmet Scholl 2, Giovane Elber and Paulo Sergio the scorers).

The national team coach Rudi Voller continues to prosper in his part-time job at Bayer Leverkusen -- the Rheinlanders beat Eintracht Frankfurt 1-0 on Friday -- but his stint may be coming to an end. Klaus Toppmoller, a slightly less distinguished former striker who has been coaching 1FC Saarbrucken in the Bundesliga 2, says he has been offered the job provisionally. "There have been contacts," he told Welt am Sonntag, "but all depends on what Rudi Voller decides."

In the Netherlands, Paul Bosvelt scored three goals inside 10 minutes to help Feyenoord to a 4-2 victory over Roda JC Kerkrade and keep them top of the league. Bob Peeters hit two goals to give second-placed Vitesse Arnhem a 2-1 win at Doetinchem on Sunday. Ajax Amsterdam gained their first away win in the league since November 28 when they beat Willem II Tilburg 1-0 with a goas from Wamberto. And at the foot of the table, RBC Roosendaal beat winless Fortuna Sittard 3-1 with the help of two goals from Regi Blinker.

Maritimo pulled off the result of the weekend in Portugal in the last match of the weekend. Frederico Lagorio scored all the goals in the Madeira islanders' 3-0 win over Benfica.

And in Sweden, the season finished terribly for AIK Solna. Held 1-1 by Elfsborg Boras on Saturday, they fell to third place, allowing Helsingborg to take the league's only Uefa Cup spot, dropping themselves into the Intertoto Cup and precipitating the resignation of their manager, Stuart Baxter. "I don't have confidence about the future," the Scot told Swedish television.

Halmstad had already clinched the championship and two Gothenburg clubs, Vastra Frolunda and GAIS, the relegation spots. Malmo, the 14-time Swedish champions, and Djurgaarden, the eight-time champions, have won promotion. Mjallby play off against Hacken to decide if there will be a third promoted team.

Hertha Berlin, on top of the Bundesliga for the first time in 30 years, beat Werder Bremen 4-1 on Saturday with two goals from Michael Preetz and one from the former Villa midfielder Stefan Beinlich. Bayern Munich maintained the pressure by crushing Borussia Dortmund 6-2 (Hasan Salihamidzic 2, Mehmet Scholl 2, Giovane Elber and Paulo Sergio the scorers). The national team coach Rudi Voller continues to prosper in his part-time job at Bayer Leverkusen -- the Rheinlanders beat Eintracht Frankfurt 1-0 on Friday -- but his stint may be coming to an end. Klaus Toppmoller, a slightly less distinguished former striker who has been coaching 1FC Saarbrucken in the Bundesliga 2, says he has been offered the job provisionally. "There have been contacts," he told Welt am Sonntag, "but all depends on what Rudi Voller decides." In the Netherlands, Paul Bosvelt scored three goals inside 10 minutes to help Feyenoord to a 4-2 victory over Roda JC Kerkrade and keep them top of the league. Bob Peeters hit two goals to give second-placed Vitesse Arnhem a 2-1 win at Doetinchem on Sunday. Ajax Amsterdam gained their first away win in the league since November 28 when they beat Willem II Tilburg 1-0 with a goas from Wamberto. And at the foot of the table, RBC Roosendaal beat winless Fortuna Sittard 3-1 with the help of two goals from Regi Blinker. Maritimo pulled off the result of the weekend in Portugal in the last match of the weekend. Frederico Lagorio scored all the goals in the Madeira islanders' 3-0 win over Benfica. And in Sweden, the season finished terribly for AIK Solna. Held 1-1 by Elfsborg Boras on Saturday, they fell to third place, allowing Helsingborg to take the league's only Uefa Cup spot, dropping themselves into the Intertoto Cup and precipitating the resignation of their manager, Stuart Baxter. "I don't have confidence about the future," the Scot told Swedish television. Halmstad had already clinched the championship and two Gothenburg clubs, Vastra Frolunda and GAIS, the relegation spots. Malmo, the 14-time Swedish champions, and Djurgaarden, the eight-time champions, have won promotion. Mjallby play off against Hacken to decide if there will be a third promoted team.

fields.headline: Moans, groans and rodents
fields.trailText: There's no place like moan
fields.body:
There's no place like moan

Another weekend has brought on another bout of depression for football fans across the country. And guess what? That includes Spurs supporters!

After George Graham's side beat Sunderland on Saturday, Jonathan Rose writes: "One win does not make Spurs a good team. I am embarrassed when I watch Arsenal and see the football their team plays. The standard at the worst patch in any Arsenal game is on par with that which earns applause at Spurs.

"Tottenham need to bring in at least three WORLD CLASS players to have a chance of breaking into the self-perpetuating elite group of clubs who can attract the world's best players without having to pay Middlesbrough wages. Leeds are threatening to do this. I hope George Graham can put Spurs on a similar path."

96stsma is similarly unconvinced. "I feel that Graham and Sugar should get out," he writes (in capitals as well). "Although we won yesterday, over half of faithful Spurs supports know that it is time for them to go. I feel that Glenn Hoddle should come in as he is a true Tottenham boy."

But if you think Spurs fans complain too much for a team in the upper reaches of the Premiership, just check out this from Brian Reid. "The two goals Manchester United scored against Coventry highlight the problems United face in Europe," he writes.

"Neither goal would have been scored against half-decent European opposition. Andy Cole wouldn't have got so much space at the near post to score his, and David Beckham's shot would have been easily stopped by a better goalkeeper.

"United score a lot of their goals in the Premiership not by being inspiring or creative, but by simply exploiting the defensive lapses of other teams that usually occur by the bucketload. When they come up against a good, well-organised European side, they find this approach just doesn't work. They then find themselves bereft of ideas, and just come charging at the opposition in desperation at the end of a match. Over and over again, they struggle in this way in Europe. Isn't it time that Alex Ferguson admitted there was something wrong?"

But while the collapse of Old Trafford is imminent, Liverpool are in even worse shape. According to Rod Shaw, anyway. "It was not the brilliance of Viduka that beat Liverpool," he says, "but their abysmal defence once again. Can you imagine Arsenal or Manchester United surrendering a two-goal lead or gifting goals like the first one for Leeds?

"Hyypia is too slow for Premier League football," he goes on, "as was evidenced by his absence when all four goals were scored. Ziege was supposed to guard the Liverpool left flank where all the Leeds goals came from. His gift for the first goal would have disgraced a schoolboy playing his first game of football. I hope he is not paid by performance as he would owe the club money.

"Babbel was not much better. No team expecting to win the Premiership can afford to score three goals and still lose a game, and the fanatically loyal fans deserve better than this mob is serving up."

Do Carlisle fans have anything to add at this point?

A celebrity writes

Rodent secret agent Danger Mouse gets in touch to register his opinion in the big Svennis debate. "Yes, the English FA got it half right by getting a foreign coach," he says, "but for full marks they'll now have to talk Fifa into allowing foreigners to play for England. Then England will probably win a match or two."

And with that, goodnight.

fields.headline: Indonesian landslide kills 53
fields.standfirst: The Jakarta Post
fields.trailText: At least 53 people are reported to have been killed by a series of landslides in Indonesia. The death toll is expected to rise steeply as aid workers struggle through the mud and wreckage to search for victims.
fields.body:
At least 53 people are reported to have been killed by a series of landslides in Indonesia. The death toll is expected to rise steeply as aid workers struggle through the mud and wreckage to search for victims.

The landslides followed two days of heavy monsoon rain in the densely populated hill district of Purworejo in central Java, the main island in the massive Indonesian archipelago.

In the village of Pacekelen, 14 people were buried alive. As many as 13 other villages were wholly or partly engulfed by sliding mud and debris. Many more have been flooded.

Landslides are a major hazard in central Java, where much of the population lives on steeply sloping and deforested hillsides. Last week, 36 people were killed by landslides in the region.

The monsoon rains are also affecting the Indonesian capital, Jakarta. Teams of emergency workers are shoring up the city's flood defences with sandbags, and digging out waste and silt from miles of canals and streams.

webTitle: Asda reveals plans for expansion of online shopping facilities

fields.headline: Asda to expand online shopping facilities
fields.trailText: 2.30pm:Wal-Mart Stores-owned Asda has revealed plans to expand its online shopping facilities over the next two years. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Wal-Mart Stores-owned Asda has revealed plans to expand its online shopping facilities over the next two years.

The supermarket chain has said that it is now ready, after months of delays, to launch its fully transactional internet shopping service, called asda@home, which will launch tomorrow at Asda.com.

The internet shopping service had until now only been available to households within the M25. An interactive TV service is to be launched on Open in January, and further interactive TV shops are planned with other DTV operators.

Asda plans to cover 60% of the UK market by 2003 in an aggressive head-to-head battle with Tesco, which was the first UK grocery retailer to launch an internet shopping venture.

Tesco Direct now claims to be the world's largest online grocery retailer, with more than 250,000 UK users, a service that covers 90% of the country and deals with 60,000 orders each week.

By the end of next year Asda expects Asda@home to be available from around a quarter of its 240 stores and from almost half its store count by the end of 2002.

Asda's internet plans have, however, never gone quite as planned. It first talked of e-commerce some 18 months ago, but has been slow to develop anything on a comparable scale to competitor Tesco.

Asda's attempt to appeal to the rip-off Britain campaign - a superhero called Captain Value Mad (valuemad.com) - lasted less than a year before Asda realised it was damaging its brand. Value Mad has since been ditched and rolled in ShopSmart, in which Asda recently took a strategic stake.

webTitle: BBC's online plug delivers a shock

fields.headline: BBC's online plug delivers a shock
fields.trailText: BBC Online takes advertising on EastEnders site. Shock, horror! According to some politicians, it signals the end of the licence fee, for others it's another betrayal of the civilised society by Roland Rat's dad.
fields.body:
BBC Online takes advertising on EastEnders site. Shock, horror! According to some politicians, it signals the end of the licence fee, for others it's another betrayal of the civilised society by Roland Rat's dad.

At one level it's all nonsense, of course. The sums involved are tiny, and the BBC, far from being the domineering force that it is in TV and radio, has a strong, but not overwhelming audience on the web. Its weekly reach of UK surfers stands at around 20%, dwarfed by portals such as Yahoo and commercial sites such as Amazon.

On the other hand, there are important forces at work here. For a director-general of the BBC to open the curtains slightly and let us peek into the debates bubbling in the open-plan offices of the third floor of Broadcasting House is a bit like watching the first chip fall from the Berlin Wall. One has to hope it presages an era of openness from the corporation about the way forward for the BBC when analogue is finally switched off.

Although the launch of BBC Online was a bit of a kick, bollock and scramble affair (I should know, the team running it reported to me, and my already grey hair was shot white by the end), it quickly established itself as a presence in the market. It came in top among the European content sites, and the news site was widely admired around the world. Mind you, we were spending more than anyone else in Europe on content, and we had the massive cross-promotion power of our networks. It would have been a disastrous result if we had not taken a strong position.

The strategic backdrop to the launch throws some light on the importance of Greg Dyke's rethink on online advertising. In 96/97, the BBC was deeply worried about the implications of the internet, particularly as it emerged as a platform that could support interactive TV and audio downloads. We had endless arguments, for example, about the transition between watching Gardeners' World on TV, clicking through to the GW interactive public service site and then on to a GW commercial site. Any sane commercial broadcaster would have the ads and the commercial fulfilment one flick of a button away, but many of us argued for a protective cordon sanitaire, that would insulate licence-funded services from commercial ones. It wasn't that we were afraid of grubby little ads: most of the people involved in the debate understood that the licence fee was not enough to fund our aspirations, and we were afraid of jeopardising the £2bn a year we received from the public.

Also, as ever, corporate politics played their part. The public-sector wing launched a jihad on Worldwide's sites, forcing it away from content and into commerce. Not that there was anything wrong with any of this. Peering into the future, beyond the period when scheduled networks would roam the earth, we simply did not see how the BBC could survive as a licence-funded broadcaster if we had given away the birthright on the web. If you could watch streamed or downloaded GW on a website supported by ads, why couldn't you on TV? What's the difference?

As it happens, I think I was wrong to be such an adamant supporter of a total licence-fee solution to online. It wasn't just the wall of irrational VC money pouring in to support MBA wet dreams that made me change my mind in '98: I couldn't in the end believe that online was like broadcasting. The market failure arguments did not hold, there is nothing that the BBC is doing online that someone else can't or won't do; the barriers to entry are not as excruciating as they are in TV and radio. Also, given that 80% of the population did not use the service and possibly never would, there was a basic issue of social justice. Should pensioners be forced to pay for well-heeled webbies? This was a classic example of taking from the poor and giving to the rich and, as such, was deeply problematic.

The solution, it seemed to me then, as it does now, is to move the vast bulk of BBC Online into an accountable commercial business, and to keep a beady eye on the volume and type of cross-promotion to prevent unfair advantage. And therein lies the problem. If you are a specialist car website, how happy are you going to be that at the end of Top Gear the url flashes up and the presenter tells the viewer to speed to a commercially funded TG site? Aren't you going to be thinking, "I want a bit of that?" Or, "Hello Mr OFT, this bully is kicking sand in my face."

The government wrestled with a similar issue once before, with the Sadler committee of inquiry into advertising BBC magazines, and concluded that the BBC should not be allowed moving image advertising to support its mags, and all references should be editorially justified. It's not beyond the wit of either civil servant or BBC mandarin to draw up a similar guidelines. The real issue is not whether the GW site or EastEnders should be allowed to dip their beaks into the tiny but growing online advertising market, but how the BBC should be funded when analogue is switched off.

David Docherty is head of broadband content at Telewest

fields.headline: Butcher tribute revs up Beeb ratings
fields.trailText: 2.15p, TV overnights: Frank Butcher Revealed, an afternoon tribute to departing EastEnders actor Mike Reid, won the BBC's its highest audience share yesterday, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Frank Butcher Revealed, an afternoon tribute to departing EastEnders actor Mike Reid, won the BBC's its highest audience share yesterday.

Clever scheduling of this 30-minute salute to Walford's favourite secondhand car salesman in the middle of EastEnders' Sunday omnibus, won it a 39% share of the available audience, or 4.4m viewers.

The only prime time show that could get anywhere nears this extraordinary share was Antiques Roadshow, which drew 8.6 million viewers but an audience share of 37%.

Channel 4's new Tony Marchant drama, Never Never, may not make easy viewing, but it took a respectable audience on its debut last night.

The two-part drama, one of the heavily trailed highlights of the Channel 4 autumn season, is a tale of the disenfranchised urban poor that focuses on John Simm's London council estate money lender. Never Never averaged 2.1m and a 9% share from 9pm.

Two nights earlier that rare beast, an original Channel 5 drama, also made an impression on late-night audiences.

Headless, which stars former Casualty star Patrick Robinson as a detective on the trail of a killer who decapitates victims, opened with 1.1m and a 9% share on Friday night from 10.50pm.

So Graham Norton made a triumphant return to Channel 4 at 10.30pm the same evening. The first part of Mr Norton's eight week Friday night residency featured 1980s teen flick chick Molly Ringwold and averaged 3m and a 19% share.

On BBC1 yesterday evening Lenny Henry school drama Hope and Glory, shifted from a midweek slot after poor ratings, bowed out in a similarly disappointing fashion with 4.8m and a 19% share from 8.20pm.

ITV's Inspector Morse aperitif, a behind-the-scenes documentary about the making of the last televisual outing for the grumpy, real al- guzzling detective, fared better later on Sunday night. The Last Morse averaged 6m and a 33% share over 60-minutes from 10pm.

The BBC2 Art Zone documentary overlapped with a similarly esoteric offering on Channel 4. Building of the Year: the Stirling Prize, hosted by former Channel 4 arts tsar Waldemar Januszczak, averaged a slightly higher audience - 0.9m - but got the same share, 0.3%, as Changing Stages from 8pm.

webTitle: Oftel unveils pricing proposals for web surfing

fields.headline: Oftel unveils lower pricing proposals for web surfing
fields.trailText: 2.15: Telecoms watchdog Oftel has unveiled pricing proposals intended to take the steep cost out of web surfing, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Telecoms watchdog Oftel has unveiled pricing proposals intended to take the steep cost out of web surfing.

Oftel recommended that the rental BT charges operators for a "loop" - the internet line from the local phone exchange to the customer - will be capped at £118, with a connection fee of £95.

Oftel also moved to pre-empt further bickering between BT and rival telecom operators.

It says BT will be obliged to help its rivals by installing telephone lines for ordinary customers if there are none available.

The regulator hopes to increase the availability of broadband internet services across the UK.

Broadband services, expected to launch next year, will offer consumers the opportunity to dial up high-quality video at a high speed.

Watchdogs hope the new services will bring increased competition between rivals and drive down prices.

David Edmonds, Oftel general director, said: "I am confident these charges are at a level that will encourage competition in the provision of broadband services."

A BT spokeperson said the prices were broadly in line with the company's expectations, though it is still consulting the proposals.

BT and its competitors can consult Oftel about the charges until December 4, when the regulators will fix the prices.

BT has faced heavy criticism for its handling of local loop unbundling and internet access prices, with rival companies, including AOL Europe and Cable & Wireless, complaining about the pace of change.

Colt Telecom, which last month protested to Oftel about the progress, said it is reviewing the pricing document, though analysts said it contained no surprises.

A Colt spokesperson confirmed the company is still working closely with other operators, believed to include Energis and Kingston Communications, in monitoring the speed of the unbundling process.

The Teaching Awards

"In many staff rooms the response will be a loud, resounding raspberry," writes a correspondent who prefers to remain anonymous.
"Can't teachers welcome any positive move? The problem is that unless conditions radically improve for the all teachers, award ceremonies can actually reinforce feelings of helplessness - 'we are not worthy'.... The fear is that if conditions do not improve we will be left with an ageing and demoralised workforce. Increasingly we will be left with the sad, the mad and the ever diminishing downright brilliant.
At best the Oscars are well meaning and well intentioned, at worst they are a patronising, cynical PR stunt by New Labour's luvvies."

Chris Woodhead's resignation

24ron's contribution was terse and jubilant: "ding, dong, the witchfinder is dead." According to Chris McDonnell, head of Fulfen Primary School in Staffordshire, "there will be much rejoicing in staff rooms and readership of the Guardian should soar." (And Education Unlimited, we hope). But not everyone agreed. "As a parent Chris Woodhead did a good job at Ofsted, it's a shame that he went or was he pushed by this government?" writes Malcolm Neslund. But the overall mood was one of relief. "[He should have gone] about five years ago. I might have stayed in teaching if he had," wrote another correspondent. Peter Ryland wanted to go further. "Blunkett should now resign as he has proved himself incapable of listening to the grassroots."

webTitle: BBC business channel on new editor's agenda

fields.headline: Dyke and Randall in talks over new BBC business channel
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: New BBC business editor Jeff Randall has had talks with Greg Dyke about launching a BBC business channel, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
New BBC business editor Jeff Randall has revealed that he has had talks with director general Greg Dyke and other senior BBC news executives about launching a BBC business channel.

Mr Randall, who is quitting the editorship of Sunday Business to become the BBC's first business editor, told MediaGuardian.co.uk: "In the loosest possible terms we have been talking about a BBC business channel.

"I sat down with Greg Dyke, Mark Damazer and Tony Hall and I talked about a wish-list for new BBC services. A business channel was on my list and it was definitely on Greg's too."

The claim flies in the face of the BBC's denials that it plans to launch a business channel. Greg Dyke said at the Edinburgh Television Festival in August that the BBC would not launch any more new channels beyond BBC3, BBC4 and its two new children's channels.

Mr Randall, 46, said he had apprehensions about joining a public service organisation after a career working in the commercial sector.

"It is the biggest challenge I will face after proprietors including the Barclay brothers, Rupert Murdoch and Conrad Black. I'm a very commercially-minded person and I share their views and philosophies."

He said he believed that US-style all-business channels like CNBC could be popular in the UK.

Questioned on his plans for the BBC's business coverage, Mr Randall added: "We'll have to suck it and see." But he said that beefing up the corporation's business coverage in heavyweight news programmes such as Today and the Ten O'Clock News would be a priority.

Meanwhile, the BBC and Mr Randall have denied claims that he was offered £250,000 to leave Sunday Business, following industry claims.

webTitle: LFF Review: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon

fields.headline: LFF Review: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.standfirst:
Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
London film festival
****
fields.trailText:
Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
****
fields.body:
After Ride with the Devil, his dull sentimentalisation of the American civil war, Ang Lee here makes an exhilarating return to form. This martial-arts fable set in 19th-century China combines breathtaking fight sequences with a genuinely sweet love story. Not for nothing does Ang Lee describe his film as Bruce Lee meets Jane Austen.

It is a story of a legendary warrior, Li Mu Bai (Chow Yun-fat), who, for all his courage, is scared to admit that he is hopelessly in love with Yu Shu Lien (Michelle Yeoh). Meanwhile, the beautiful magistrate's daughter Jen (Zhang Ziyi) is herself a secret martial-arts practitioner, rebelling against her engagement. She is in love with Lo (Chang Chen), a bandit. This movie soars above the crudeness of lesser martial arts flicks, and reconnects the genre with its traditional sense of decorum, pathos and romance.

When the film was first screened in Cannes, the audience stood up and whooped. Though it may not have this effect every time, the stylised combat sequences, devised by Yuen Wo Ping (who did similar work on The Matrix) are things of wonder. I was on the edge of my seat - particularly for the gripping one-on-one that kicks the film off, showing a running, flying battle at night across rooftops.

Crouching Tiger has the inventiveness of a fairy tale, and in the sheer old-fashioned entertainment that it so unassumingly delivers, has the feel of nothing so much as a Saturday morning kids' show. But more than this, the director dazzles you with the flair and energy with which he moves from location to location, from intricate interior to vast desert landscape. Ang Lee puts a girdle around his cinematic world in seconds. What he finally achieves is the epic sprawl and sweep of the western. Might Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon father a vibrant revival of this genre in a new western/Asian form? It's got romance, thrills, drama - all human life is here!

At the Odeon West End, London WC2 (020-7928 3232), November 6 and 7..

webTitle: The joys of broadband internet access

fields.headline: The day I became a faster woman
fields.standfirst: Roused from her dreams by a man from BT and the promise of an ADSL connection,  Imogen O'Rorke experiences the joys of broadband internet access - and 24-hour South Park
fields.trailText: Roused from her dreams by a man from BT and the promise of an ADSL connection, Imogen O'Rorke experiences the joys of broadband internet access - and 24-hour South Park.
fields.body:
I had been hassling BT Openworld's press office for an ADSL connection since August (allegedly they are so popular with journalists that there's a waiting list stretching up to Christmas). So when, two weeks ago, a phone call came out of the blue from a BT engineer, saying he was round the corner and was ready to fit me up, I didn't even mind that it was 8am and I was still dreaming. After all, I was about to be initiated in the joys of always-on, flat-rate, super-fast broadband access - the internet as God (or Microsoft) had always intended it.

In the UK, ADSL (Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line) is supplied by BT, HomeChoice and a few ISPs, although from next year 14 other companies, including Cable and Wireless, Easynet, Telewest, NTL and MCI Worldcom, will begin installing their equipment in BT's local exchanges and rolling out retail services. The central benefits of BT's IPStream include speeds up to 10 times faster than a good modem, with 500 kbps downstream and 250 kbps upstream, and the ability to use the phone simultaneously, as well as enabling the use of rich media such as webcasts and video clips.

The jury is still out on whether ADSL is the most suitable connection for small businesses, let alone domestic use. It has major drawbacks, say its detractors: it's clunky for two-way communications such as video-conferencing; it makes systems highly vulnerable to malicious hacking and as yet BT doesn't offer a Firewall protection plan; it suffers frequently from "Crosstalk" (when telecom signals interfere with each other) and "brownouts" (when there are bandwidth "log jams"), although BT claims these problems will disappear this month when it switches all internet connections to a new network. There are even doubts that BT wants ADSL to become mass market since, as the various "surftime" packages have proven, it will put an enormous strain on the network. In some central areas, connection speeds have already dropped by 25% because of broadband, which is "bandwidth competitive".

Since my surfing habits have been doubling my quarterly phone bill, I worked out that even with the £150 installation fee and the £39.99 a month USB-type subscription, ADSL would be worth it. Conven tional surftime packages just don't work for freelancers who use the net heavily in the day.

One week, six hour-long phone calls to Openworld's support line and several technology-induced tantrums later, having still failed to find anyone who could tell me how I could pick up my email from my existing Demon account through my new BTClick ISP (one even suggested there was a software clash), and having enjoyed only 20 minutes of spontaneous, free-flowing access before the connection disappeared altogether, I was starting to feel like a long-suffering rail commuter in the comfort of my own home.

Apparently the local area server was down and it took engineers three days to rectify the problem. It was restored on Monday, only to be replaced by another BT recorded message saying it was "experiencing network connection problems" and if I was calling about anything else, I should hang on (what for - a chat?) - at which point, I reverted to using my old 56k modem, which at least I knew I could trust.

Admittedly, it is early days for BT, which promises to have overcome all teething problems by the time it hard launches early next year. And you can't really blame the poor techies stuck in a low-rent call centre in Aberdeen. One of them confessed that he had never seen an ADSL connection in his life (they are too remote) and wasn't allowed to surf at work any more since the Orange- gate staff porn scandal - he had nothing but a manual to work from! I am still hugely grateful to Jamie who taught me handy PC-rage tips such as wrapping it in bubble wrap before punching the life out of it and putting a rope around the base of the terminal before throttling it.

Technical grouches aside, how did broadband actually enhance my experience of the internet? Ironically, one of the first rich media delights I got to sample (once the servers were up again, and I had downloaded RealPlayer Plus) was a Reuters video news broadcast about how Openworld would "dramatically influence the way people work", with secure environments for online transactions, video conferencing, and so on. BT is marketing the business package hard at £99.99 a month.

The first noticeable improvement is speed. I am connected at 576,000 bps (10 times faster than usual, although it can drop to 56,000 at certain times of day), and have been for seven hours and 30 minutes. I am listening to an ABC news broadcast about the US election as I type, and simultaneously searching the archives of newspapers. Which is pretty cool. My email problem now resolved, messages flow in and out as easily as water from a tap. There's another one now - probably more spam from sites such as Shockwave, AtomFilms and MP3, to which I now feel obliged to subscribe.

The problem with most UK media sites is that they are still stuck in the 20th century - functional, html-based and pretty shallow. I can now listen to any BBC radio channel as I work, which is great, except that ADSL can be disabled by interference from AM signals. I tried in vain to find the promised broadband offerings from the likes of Channel 4, Carlton Interactive and Granada Broadband, but they appear to be months behind schedule. Virtual newscaster Ananova, however, is a total switch-off - like listening to the synthetic female voice of the speaking clock reading a bedtime story, and her green hair and relentless bulletins about the Beckhams make one feel quite queasy. Reuters video news and www.ITN.com were exciting for live-action breaking news, with storm reports from around the country, but it has more impact when you watch it on TV.

Yet again, you have to look to American sites for a more satisfying streaming media experience. The US has had broadband for a couple of years and there is already a good range of channels such as CNN and ABC news, the Discovery Channel (with live coverage of the Ebola crisis in Africa) and Space.com (the latest transmissions from Mars) and, best of all, Comedy Central, where you can get South Park on tap and Jon Stewart's Daily Show, satirical coverage of the presidential election which has become cult viewing. Download times are 15 times faster - quick enough for you to hang on rather than give up, making the whole experience dangerously addictive.

Street.TV, a style and culture channel, is one of the UK's first tentative broadband offerings. But with low-grade live interviews with the likes of singer Sophie Ellis- Bextor and Sadie Frost (yet again) on how great it is being married to Jude, and some non-event fashion show coverage, it's hardly the kind of must-see viewing that would drag you away from Jerry Springer even. Lack of quality control will continue to be a problem with internet media.

What the net now does really well is comedy, underground film and satire, as evidenced by the rash of online film and media clubs. There are hours of fun to be had checking out the spoof trailers in www.trailervision.com, such as American Booty (Man Falls Madly in Love with Fat Ass), the Hollywood spoofs on www.Ifilm.com (the Oz Witch Project, in which DVD-toting Dorothy gets Toto, Tinman, Lion and Scarecrow into a spot of bother in the woods, is a brilliant foil to Blair Witch 2), and www.Shockwave.com and www.MediaTrip.com are great for pop video spoofs and new animation. There is no doubt that the new South Park is out there somewhere.

Good British sites such as www.thejunkies.com and www.madcowTV.com are beginning to sprout, but it will be another six months before broadband content is good enough to justify an ADSL connection in the home (and before the prices become competitive). In the short term, the most obvious consumer benefit would be multi- terminal connections for libraries and schools, but at the current price it is unlikely to happen.

webTitle: Leagas Delaney sold to Envoy for £59m

fields.headline: Leagas Delaney sold to Canadians for £59m
fields.trailText: 1.15pm update: Leagas Delaney, one of the last remaining independent UK ad agencies, has been sold to Envoy Communications for £59m, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
One of the last remaining independent advertising agencies, Leagas Delaney, has been sold.

The company, responsible for high profile campaigns including Adidas and Barclays, has been acquired by Canadian group Envoy Communications for £59m.

The deal, announced today, comes as an enormous surprise to the ad industry because the agency seemed to cherish its independence.

Bruce Haines, the agency's chairman, said: "The merging of Leagas Delaney with Envoy is the perfect marriage. Envoy is leading the revolution in the convergence of marketing, design and technology and we are excited to be a part of the campaign."

At a time when advertising agencies are consolidating, Leagas stood out as one of the few companies which believed the smaller, the better.

To prove its point, just two years ago the management staged a buyout from Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO for just £4m.

Leagas Delaney's client list includes the BBC, cosmetics giant Clarins, America's CNET.com, Goodyear, Harrods and Telecom Italia. The sale will see its billings soar to £517m.

Tim Delaney, Leagas Delaney's founder, CEO and creative director, said: "We have always aimed to be ahead of the market in advertising creative terms.

"This merger gives us the opportunity to move even further ahead by working with like-minded professionals in areas like digital technology and retail design that are of increasing importance to our clients."

The purchase will push the Canadian group's billings to close to £337m. Envoy has offices in London, Hamburg, Paris, Rome and San Francisco and the deal forms part of its strategy to build a network of the best in marketing, design and technology.

Its clients include Adidas-Salomon, BASF, CIBC, Castrol, CDNOW, FedEx, Hewlett Packard, Honda, Panasonic, Pizza Hut, Prudential (USA), Safeway, SalomonSmithBarney, Sprint Canada, Steelcase, TD Waterhouse and Wal-Mart.

Leagas Delaney was established in London in 1980. The agency rapidly gained a reputation for outstanding creativity, winning major awards for its work. Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO acquired it in 1986.

Leagas Delaney's management bought out the company in April 1998. Since then the company has seen huge growth in its home market, the establishment of successful offices in San Francisco, Paris, Rome and Hamburg plus a standalone new media company, The Digital Partners, in London.

fields.headline: UK hit by more flooding
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Weather events

 Two dead in crash
 Uckfield flooded again
 28 severe flood warnings
fields.trailText:
Special report: Weather events

 Two dead in crash
 Uckfield flooded again
 28 severe flood warnings
fields.body:
The after-effects of torrential rain were today continuing to cause havoc across Britain as police revealed the bad weather death toll has now risen to eight.

A tree fell on a car in "atrocious" conditions in Herefordshire, killing two passengers and critically injuring the driver.

The environment agency increased the number of severe flood warnings from 22 to 28 as people in flood-hit areas began a waiting game to see how last night's rain will make rivers break their banks.

Areas still recovering from last week's deluge were swamped once again, and the river Uck at Uckfield in Sussex burst its banks, flooding the town for the second time in three weeks.

A West Mercia Police spokesman said the latest deaths happened at about 7.35pm last night on the B4361 at Richards Castle, near Tenbury Wells, when a large tree came down on a Daihatsu Fourtrak.

"Two people were declared dead at the scene. The driver was taken to hospital with head and spinal injuries and is in a critical condition," he added.

"The driver took no avoiding action and the tree fell fair and square right on the car.

"The weather conditions were atrocious and very windy. The tree narrowly missed a passenger coach travelling in the opposite direction."

Post-mortem examinations and formal identification of the two victims were due to be carried out later today. All three people involved are from the Ludlow area.

The environment minister, Michael Meacher, told a London news conference that local authorities had taken advice from the environment agency over building in flood plains. He added: "In the overwhelming majority of cases that advice has been taken."

Mr Meacher said: "Whether there should be a veto, to be exercised by the agency is quite another matter.

"After all, local authority planning departments and planning committees are meant to represent the local community.

"They are accountable and I do think it is right that the ultimate responsibility should lie with them."

A band of heavy rain is now concentrated over the north east and North Yorkshire, said PA WeatherCentre forecaster Paul Knightley.

"We've had the worst of the heavy rain but the system will hang around for a few days, gradually getting more patchy," he added.

"But any more rain in areas like North Yorkshire is potentially very bad news."

Severe flooding is likely to occur in Kent and Sussex as more than 50mm (2 inches) of rain fell in the region during the night and parts of the counties have already flooded.

The environment agency reported the heaviest rainfall in Plumpton, East Sussex, where 60mm (about 2.3 ins) fell in 12 hours.

In Hampshire, the worst affected area was along the river Meon which burst its banks this morning, flooding the villages of Exton and West Meon. Police said eight houses were under about 3ft of water.

About 100 homes have also been evacuated in Dorchester, Dorset, after the environment agency said the river Frome was at its highest ever level.

In West Sussex, 100 properties had to be pumped out at Maidenbower by firefighters overnight after the Gatwick Stream overflowed into properties.

Rivers across Wales, Yorkshire, Devon and Cornwall were also put on flood watch.

Meanwhile, 100 people have been evacuated from the East Yorkshire villages of Snaith and Gowdall, which are both near the River Aire.

webTitle: ITC warns children can learn harmful behaviour from TV

fields.headline: ITC admits kids can learn harmful behaviour from TV
fields.trailText: 1pm: Children can learn harmful behaviour from the television, the ITC has admitted, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Children can learn harmful behaviour from the television, the ITC has admitted.

Just days after reports that bullies are copying Anne Robinson in the playground, a new report by the Independent Television Commission shows there are links between television adverts and behaviour.

"Children learn by copying what they see and most of the time that's healthy and positive. Very occasionally they copy something harmful in a commercial - after all, they see them again and again," said Stephen Locke, director of advertising at the ITC.

Respondents to the ITC survey found it difficult to measure the actual effects of TV on kids, but agreed that programmes and advertising could influence behaviour in both positive and negative ways.

WWF wrestling, South Park, Power Rangers and, to a lesser extent, The Simpsons were mentioned as having actual or possible undesirable influences on children.

The ITC study, Copycat Kids?, concluded that TV was a secondary, but powerful influence on children.

The report found that the media and especially TV, along with sport, pop music, computer games and hanging out with friends, formed the main components of youth culture.

Copycat Kids? also identified some aspects of TV advertising that increase the chances of children imitating what they see: behaviour which is easy to copy; a familiar or accessible situation; an easily understood storyline or scenario; potential for emotional empathy; intrigue and challenge; wicked or forbidden things; participants who "get away with it"; humour and jokes; well-known characters, role models or celebrities; products relevant to or appealing to a child; advertisements shown at an accessible time for the relevant age group; high production values - eg colour, music, action.

webTitle: Conjoined twins: what the operation entails

fields.headline: What the operation entails
fields.standfirst: More about the conjoined twins' case
fields.trailText: The operation to separate conjoined twins Jodie and Mary, which began this morning, will mean that only Jodie will live to be three months old, a landmark she reaches on Wednesday.
fields.body:
The operation to separate conjoined twins Jodie and Mary, which began this morning, will mean that only Jodie will live to be three months old, a landmark she reaches on Wednesday.

Surgery began early this morning after a protracted legal battle over the ethics of the case. The girls' parents had said God should decide their fate, but doctors prevailed in the courts by arguing that both twins would die if they did not act.

A huge team of doctors, nurses, anaesthetists and other health workers are involved in the complex surgery, which will result in an uncertain future even for the stronger sister.

Mary is certain to die as soon as the aorta she shares with Jodie is severed during the surgery. Jodie's heart and lungs are keeping both girls alive through blood vessels which connect them.

Experts predict Jodie has a 5% risk of dying on the operating table, but after that her problems will be functional rather than life threatening.

Medical opinion varies but doctors say there is a chance she could be doubly incontinent and will need to have reconstruction of her rectum, sexual organs and lower abdomen.

She will need extensive skin grafts - possibly using tissue from her dead sister - and is expected to spend the first five years of her life in hospital. Extensive X-rays and scans of the twins were taken in a bid to gain as much knowledge as possible of what they would find when surgery began, but there was still uncertainty about the exact extent of their condition.

What is known is that the girls are joined at the lower abdomen, with their spines fused, and that they share Jodie's heart and lungs.

Mary has a heart but it is useless and her lungs never inflated after her system failed at birth. While Jodie is considered to be functioning normally, Mary has a primitive brain and her life was not considered by doctors to be "viable".

Cases of conjoined twins are so rare - around one per 100,000 live births - and the ways in which they can be joined so different, that there is little precedent for this latest case.

In the UK, only Great Ormond Street hospital in London and St Mary's hospital in Manchester, where the twins' operation is taking place, have any experience of separating conjoined twins.

At St Mary's, all three attempts have resulted in the deaths of the twins.

Closed circuit television is being used during the operation so that teams of specialists can watch its progress while preventing overcrowding of the operating theatre.

There will inevitably be a moment of silence as Mary's life ebbs away, and the battle to save Jodie begins in earnest.

fields.headline: Dyke attacks TV business coverage
fields.standfirst: Sunday Business editor joins BBC
fields.trailText:
10.15am: BBC director general Greg Dyke has launched a scathing attack on the BBC's business coverage over the past 20 years, writes Jason Deans.
Sunday Business editor joins BBC
fields.body:
BBC director general Greg Dyke has launched a scathing attack on TV and radio business coverage over the past 20 years.

Mainstream news and current affairs programmes on TV and radio have "ignored" or failed to understand the business agenda, Mr Dyke said today.

Mr Dyke said there had not been enough programmes that explained the complexities of business or introduced personalities to ordinary viewers.

His comments will be seen as an implicit attack on Peter Jay, the corporation's economics and business editor until this summer.

Mr Jay, who was hired by John Birt, was rarely seen on screen and was criticised by many observers for his "lecturing" style of delivery.

Speaking at the Confederation of British Industry's national conference in Birmingham, the BBC boss said he believed coverage of business on radio and television over the past 20 years had not been good enough.

He said: "Whilst the coverage of politics and international affairs has been first class, the coverage of business hasn't always been of the same quality."

Mr Dyke, who said he wanted to see better business journalism when he took up the post early this year, added that he came from a generation which was suspicious or even hostile to business.

Few people thought about a career in business but the number of A-level students taking business studies had doubled in the past seven years and that there was much more interest in the subject.

Mr Dyke is himself an entrepreneur who made a fortune from business. He was unemployed at 30, but went on to become a millionaire after he and the current chairman of the BBC, Sir Christopher Bland, drew up a lucrative share option scheme at LWT.

This summer Mr Dyke created the BBC's first business division, headed by Robert Thirkell, the man behind Troubleshooter and Blood on the Carpet.

He also announced changes at The Money Programme, which now concentrates on only one subject each week.

Mr Dyke made a number of changes to the BBC's coverage of business issues including a doubling in length of the Working Lunch programme on BBC2 and an expansion of business stories on BBC Online.

He added that he was aiming to develop a daily early morning business programme on television.

webTitle: Queen Mother fractures collarbone in fall

fields.headline: Queen Mother fractures collarbone in fall
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Queen Mother
fields.trailText: The Queen Mother has fractured the left-hand-side of her collarbone in a fall at her London home, Clarence House said today.
fields.body:
The Queen Mother has fractured the left-hand-side of her collarbone in a fall at her London home, Clarence House said today.

The 100-year-old Queen Mother tripped and fell while unattended late on Friday afternoon at Clarence House, her residence in the capital, and was discovered by a member of her staff.

She has not been admitted to hospital and was treated by doctors at Clarence House. Members of the royal family have been informed of the accident.

This morning she was out of bed and sitting up with her arm in a sling. It was decided not to put the Queen Mother's fractured clavicle in plaster.

"Her Majesty is reasonably comfortable and has cancelled her engagements for the time being," said a Clarence House spokeswoman. The Queen Mother tripped and stumbled last Tuesday evening while getting into her Daimler limousine.

On that occasion, she tripped on her long evening gown after attending a Garden Society annual dinner at the Four Seasons Hotel in central London.

Witnesses said the Queen Mother appeared to hit her head on the car but Clarence House said she was unhurt.

The Queen Mother, who turned 100 on August 4, walks with the aid of two sticks after two hip replacement operations.

The Prince of Wales, who was returning to London today from Highgrove, his Gloucestershire home, was expected to visit his grandmother. But members of the royal family appear to have responded to the incident with calm.

fields.headline: To sell out takes a lot of bottle
fields.standfirst: Keen for publicity to promote his new book, Bill Fitzhugh came up with a simple idea - words for whisky. Here, he defends his novel attempt at product placement.
fields.trailText: Keen for publicity to promote his new book, Bill Fitzhugh came up with a simple idea - words for whisky. Here, he defends his novel attempt at product placement.
fields.body:
If, in the final accounting, I am remembered for nothing else, at least I will be remembered as the man who ruined literature once and for all. Of course there are those who will argue that Jackie Collins beat me to this long ago - and she may in fact have won in the distaff category - but according to more than a few folks here in America, I am the winner. So if you're looking for some way into the record books, look elsewhere. The blame for the ruination of the literary form known as the novel has been laid at my feet, so bugger off - this one's mine.

How did I do it? Simple. I became the first novelist to use product placement in a work of fiction. Product placement, for you literary purists, is a form of advertising previously restricted to the famously whorish mediums of television and film. One of the earliest and most famous examples of product placement was in Steven Spielberg's 1982 film ET: The Extra-Terrestrial.

The way I understand it, the script originally called for the kids in the story to use M&M candies to lure the wrinkled little space guest into their home. However when the producers contacted the candy-maker and suggested it pay for the privilege of having its product featured in the film, the candy-maker balked. So the producers contacted the maker of Reese's Peanut Butter Cups and asked if it would be interested. It was, and sales of Reese's soared when the film was released. Ever since, film- makers and advertisers have expanded their unholy alliance. Now, when MI6 gives James Bond a BMW you can rest assured that somebody gave one to the film's producer as well.

Flash forward 16 years. I'm in the throes of writing Cross Dressing, a satire on religion and advertising. My research has me neck-deep in obscure Catholic theology and modern advertising theory when a thought occurs to me. Sadly, it isn't an idea about character development or an ingenious plot twist. Rather it is about how to get some publicity for the book's release.

Why would such crass considerations ever cross my mind? The answer is, again, simple. I'm in the business of writing books. Unfortunately it's not enough just to write them; they must be marketed as well. And, in the US at least, publishers are not famous for how well they market the books of their mid-list authors. Without marketing, fewer people know about your book. When fewer people know about your book, fewer buy it. When fewer people buy your book, you'll soon be looking for a new publishing contract. Thus the crass consideration.

Before my first novel (Pest Control) was published I asked what sort of publicity campaign the publisher would do for it. My agent said it would send copies to reviewers and hope for the best. Fortunately, debut novels are considered newsworthy - especially when they sell to a major Hollywood studio as Pest Control did - and thus the book received a fair amount of attention in the press.

Before my second book, The Organ Grinders, was published I was told to lower my expectations about press coverage. As my US publicist explained, "Author publishes second novel" isn't considered a newsworthy item. Without a good angle, I was told, it was nigh impossible to get PR for a second novel not written by a best-selling author.

I was left to my own devices to find an "angle" for Cross Dressing. As I said, it came to me while writing. Since my protagonist is a hotshot in the advertising business and since much of the book satirises American hyper-consumerism, I thought it might be considered "newsworthy" (and ironic) if I made Cross Dressing the first novel to feature product placement.

My US editor loved the idea, but said I would have to make the deal on my own as the company wouldn't have a clue where to start. After a few quick calls I had a list of companies interested in helping to make literary history. On the list was a fast-food chain, a cosmetics company and a liquor distributor. For reasons of artistic integrity and pure laziness I wanted a product that was already in the book. I felt this strategy would shield me from accusations of writing to accommodate a "sponsor", while simultaneously saving me the trouble of writing any new pages.

The novel doesn't feature anyone enjoying fast food or applying cosmetics, but there were a few scenes involving cocktails. Then another idea hit me. I had sold the book's film rights to Universal Studios. Universal (at the time) was owned by Seagrams. Two calls resulted in a deal wherein I would replace references to generic drinks with various Seagrams products.

Now, before all this happened, I was under the impression that money changed hands in a product placement deal. Since I was doing this for publicity, not cash, I thought I might do the deal for a single dollar, or I would donate the money to a charity. However, when I discovered the deals were typically done in exchange for the "placed" product (in this instance, hooch) I had to re- evaluate my position. It would be more than a little insensitive to send a couple of cases of single malt scotch to the Diseased Liver Association, am I right? So I accepted (and disposed of) them in my own selfless way.

Just before the book came out, my publisher sent copies of Cross Dressing to magazines and newspapers, with letters explaining the product placement deal in the hopes of generating some publicity. It worked. Brill's Content and Publisher's Weekly did articles on the deal. Time magazine and Entertainment Weekly both made mention of it as well.

The only problem was, no one seemed to get the joke. It was clear from the articles that certain people in the book world were taking exception to the deal. The gist of what they were saying was that I had cheapened either literature in general, or the novel form in particular.

For example, in Sean Gullette's article for Brill's Content (June 2000), Jonathan Galassi, editor-in-chief at Farrar, Straus and Giroux, is quoted as saying about the deal, "Well, I think it's pretty lame."

Well, imagine my shame. Such a stinging indictment was hard to swallow, but what really bothered me was that poor Johnny boy just didn't get it. And he wasn't alone. Since so many are having a problem getting this, allow me to explain.

Cross Dressing lampoons the advertising industry. To do something as brazen as product placement in something as sacred as a novel is to make a joke on the subject. Now, had I done a product placement deal in a book that had nothing to do with advertising, that would have been selling out. As I said earlier, if I'd had to add drinking scenes to the book to accommodate the product, that, too, would have been selling out. But what I did was to name the drinks that were already in the book - in fact the names are so overstated in ad-speak as to be a joke. Get it? In a book ridiculing advertising? Ta-da! Irony.

While I had anticipated a mild backlash to the deal, it never occurred to me anyone would attack it so viciously. I mean the notion that my product placement deal could harm literature in some way that my novels hadn't already done was just plain silly. As if by this time next year, Annie Proulx will be revising her latest manuscript to oblige a corporate sponsor, substituting a nicely placed scene involving the "new condom for cowboys" at the expense of mood or real character development.

"But Bill," someone cried, "doesn't this deal fundamentally cheapen the novel as a form of literature?" No, of course not. You want to know what does? The pitiful advances so many novelists get. That's what cheapens the novel. But me? I lack the influence, thank you very much.

Still, some tut-tutting critics say I crossed a line no one else had dared to cross before. As if there are thousands of authors out there who had considered doing a product placement deal for their novel, but decided the whole transaction would sully literature and, thus, in defence of the Muses they decided not to do it.

Pur-leeze. All I can say is, that's pretty lame.
fields.bodyText: If, in the final accounting, I am remembered for nothing else, at least I will be remembered as the man who ruined literature once and for all. Of course there are those who will argue that Jackie Collins beat me to this long ago - and she may in fact have won in the distaff category - but according to more than a few folks here in America, I am the winner. So if you're looking for some way into the record books, look elsewhere. The blame for the ruination of the literary form known as the novel has been laid at my feet, so bugger off - this one's mine. How did I do it? Simple. I became the first novelist to use product placement in a work of fiction. Product placement, for you literary purists, is a form of advertising previously restricted to the famously whorish mediums of television and film. One of the earliest and most famous examples of product placement was in Steven Spielberg's 1982 film ET: The Extra-Terrestrial. The way I understand it, the script originally called for the kids in the story to use M&M candies to lure the wrinkled little space guest into their home. However when the producers contacted the candy-maker and suggested it pay for the privilege of having its product featured in the film, the candy-maker balked. So the producers contacted the maker of Reese's Peanut Butter Cups and asked if it would be interested. It was, and sales of Reese's soared when the film was released. Ever since, film- makers and advertisers have expanded their unholy alliance. Now, when MI6 gives James Bond a BMW you can rest assured that somebody gave one to the film's producer as well. Flash forward 16 years. I'm in the throes of writing Cross Dressing, a satire on religion and advertising. My research has me neck-deep in obscure Catholic theology and modern advertising theory when a thought occurs to me. Sadly, it isn't an idea about character development or an ingenious plot twist. Rather it is about how to get some publicity for the book's release. Why would such crass considerations ever cross my mind? The answer is, again, simple. I'm in the business of writing books. Unfortunately it's not enough just to write them; they must be marketed as well. And, in the US at least, publishers are not famous for how well they market the books of their mid-list authors. Without marketing, fewer people know about your book. When fewer people know about your book, fewer buy it. When fewer people buy your book, you'll soon be looking for a new publishing contract. Thus the crass consideration. Before my first novel (Pest Control) was published I asked what sort of publicity campaign the publisher would do for it. My agent said it would send copies to reviewers and hope for the best. Fortunately, debut novels are considered newsworthy - especially when they sell to a major Hollywood studio as Pest Control did - and thus the book received a fair amount of attention in the press. Before my second book, The Organ Grinders, was published I was told to lower my expectations about press coverage. As my US publicist explained, "Author publishes second novel" isn't considered a newsworthy item. Without a good angle, I was told, it was nigh impossible to get PR for a second novel not written by a best-selling author. I was left to my own devices to find an "angle" for Cross Dressing. As I said, it came to me while writing. Since my protagonist is a hotshot in the advertising business and since much of the book satirises American hyper-consumerism, I thought it might be considered "newsworthy" (and ironic) if I made Cross Dressing the first novel to feature product placement. My US editor loved the idea, but said I would have to make the deal on my own as the company wouldn't have a clue where to start. After a few quick calls I had a list of companies interested in helping to make literary history. On the list was a fast-food chain, a cosmetics company and a liquor distributor. For reasons of artistic integrity and pure laziness I wanted a product that was already in the book. I felt this strategy would shield me from accusations of writing to accommodate a "sponsor", while simultaneously saving me the trouble of writing any new pages. The novel doesn't feature anyone enjoying fast food or applying cosmetics, but there were a few scenes involving cocktails. Then another idea hit me. I had sold the book's film rights to Universal Studios. Universal (at the time) was owned by Seagrams. Two calls resulted in a deal wherein I would replace references to generic drinks with various Seagrams products. Now, before all this happened, I was under the impression that money changed hands in a product placement deal. Since I was doing this for publicity, not cash, I thought I might do the deal for a single dollar, or I would donate the money to a charity. However, when I discovered the deals were typically done in exchange for the "placed" product (in this instance, hooch) I had to re- evaluate my position. It would be more than a little insensitive to send a couple of cases of single malt scotch to the Diseased Liver Association, am I right? So I accepted (and disposed of) them in my own selfless way. Just before the book came out, my publisher sent copies of Cross Dressing to magazines and newspapers, with letters explaining the product placement deal in the hopes of generating some publicity. It worked. Brill's Content and Publisher's Weekly did articles on the deal. Time magazine and Entertainment Weekly both made mention of it as well. The only problem was, no one seemed to get the joke. It was clear from the articles that certain people in the book world were taking exception to the deal. The gist of what they were saying was that I had cheapened either literature in general, or the novel form in particular. For example, in Sean Gullette's article for Brill's Content (June 2000), Jonathan Galassi, editor-in-chief at Farrar, Straus and Giroux, is quoted as saying about the deal, "Well, I think it's pretty lame." Well, imagine my shame. Such a stinging indictment was hard to swallow, but what really bothered me was that poor Johnny boy just didn't get it. And he wasn't alone. Since so many are having a problem getting this, allow me to explain. Cross Dressing lampoons the advertising industry. To do something as brazen as product placement in something as sacred as a novel is to make a joke on the subject. Now, had I done a product placement deal in a book that had nothing to do with advertising, that would have been selling out. As I said earlier, if I'd had to add drinking scenes to the book to accommodate the product, that, too, would have been selling out. But what I did was to name the drinks that were already in the book - in fact the names are so overstated in ad-speak as to be a joke. Get it? In a book ridiculing advertising? Ta-da! Irony. While I had anticipated a mild backlash to the deal, it never occurred to me anyone would attack it so viciously. I mean the notion that my product placement deal could harm literature in some way that my novels hadn't already done was just plain silly. As if by this time next year, Annie Proulx will be revising her latest manuscript to oblige a corporate sponsor, substituting a nicely placed scene involving the "new condom for cowboys" at the expense of mood or real character development. "But Bill," someone cried, "doesn't this deal fundamentally cheapen the novel as a form of literature?" No, of course not. You want to know what does? The pitiful advances so many novelists get. That's what cheapens the novel. But me? I lack the influence, thank you very much. Still, some tut-tutting critics say I crossed a line no one else had dared to cross before. As if there are thousands of authors out there who had considered doing a product placement deal for their novel, but decided the whole transaction would sully literature and, thus, in defence of the Muses they decided not to do it. Pur-leeze. All I can say is, that's pretty lame.

webTitle: Casting news: Polanski's pianist found abroad

fields.headline: Polanski's pianist found abroad
fields.trailText: Plus: Lopez bags Baghdad remake; Hamilton terminates Terminator rumours; Aniston to tackle Hell's Angels; Bon Jovi to don fangs; Hurley and Leary cast together; Scoody-Doo cast rumours solidify; and Steve Martin flogs his play
fields.body:
 Despite placing an ad in the Guardian answered by 2,000 hopefuls, Roman Polanski failed to find an actor for the lead role of his new film The Pianist. An American actor will play the part of Wladyslaw Szpilman, whose war memoirs were published two years ago. Casting director Celestia Fox denied that the advert was a publicity stunt: "Roman had thought he might find the right person, an unknown."

 Jennifer Lopez will star in a musical remake of The Thief of Baghdad. The classic 1924 silent movie, which starred Douglas Fairbanks, has been remade twice: in 1940 by Michael Powell and in 1978, in a version that starred Terence Stamp and Peter Ustinov.

 Linda Hamilton has pulled out of Terminator 3. Though her co-stars from T2 Arnold Schwarzenegger and Edward Furlong have signed up for the second sequel, Hamilton said she's had enough of the role of a mom trying to save the planet from murderous robots. "I was asked," she said, but: "I turned it down. I felt it was more courageous not to do it. I spent nine years trying to get the image of my Terminator character out of people's minds. I'm tired of being ever-earnest and stricken."

 Jennifer Aniston will take the leading role in thriller Chain of Evidence. The Friends actress will play a police cadet who goes undercover to expose drug dealing among the Hell's Angels. A Hollywood insider said: "It's a gritty role, a million miles away from Friends. They're looking for a big-name male star to appear with her."

 Jon Bon Jovi has been cast as the lead in John Carpenter's Vampires: Los Muertos. Production will begin early next year on locations in Mexico.

 Liz Hurley isn't letting her impending Screen Actors Guild trial get in the way of her work. The actress is due to start filming Servicing Sarah in the new year, but meanwhile has signed up to Dawg, opposite Denis Leary. Leary plays a ladies' man who must apologise to the women he has betrayed, while Hurley plays the attorney who accompanies him on his mission. Victoria Hochberg, the woman behind Ally McBeal and Sex in the City, is to direct.

 Real-life couple Freddie Prinze Jr and Sarah Michelle Gellar could be together on the big screen, in Scooby-Doo: The Movie. The Hollywood Reporter claims that Prinze Jr will play straight guy Fred, while Gellar is in line for the role of Daphne. Prinze Jr, a self-proclaimed comic addict, recently lost the Spiderman role to Tobey Maguire. Christina Ricci is said to be a strong contender for the role of Velma. Raja Gosnell (Never Been Kissed, Home Alone 3) will direct the coming film, recently was given the green light. The film will start production in February and shoot in Australia.

 The film rights to Steve Martin's play Picasso at the Lapin Agile, about a fictitious night in 1904 when Picasso and Einstein meet by chance in a bar, have been bought by Abandon Pictures. Fred Schepisi, the man who directed 1987's Steve Martin-starring Roxanne, will helm the project.

webTitle: In brief: Merchant bemoans inelegant England

fields.headline: Merchant bemoans inelegant England
fields.trailText: Plus: Mel contemplates gorier Braveheart cut; Daily Mail alert! - Baise-Moi to rampage through British cinemas; Mexican success in Tokyo; Brosnan defects to USA; and Steven Spielberg gets Bafta back-slap
fields.body:
 Ismail Merchant, one half of the Merchant-Ivory team, whose lush adaptations of classic English novels have made them world famous, has lamented that Britain is no longer the home of classical elegance. The producer claimed in an interview with the Sunday Telegraph that the country is being inherited by a lower class obsessed with computers, making money and football, and has ceased to be a place where "an Englishman's word is his bond". Such surprised indignation surely means Ismail has spent more time watching his own films than actually visiting England in recent decades.

 Mel Gibson is considering putting together a director's cut of his 1995 Oscar-winning Braveheart. The actor said that he watched his epic tale on DVD recently, and thinks it could be better. "You know there was stuff that would have been more effective and would have brought down the time," said Mel, whose movie ran at almost three hours. His director's cut would feature less words and more action, including footage that was removed because it was too gory.

 Baise-Moi, which caused outrage when it was released in its native France because of its content of relentless sex and violence, has been picked up by UK distributor The Feature Film Company, and could be on release in UK cinemas by next March. The film will be shown at London's Institute of Contemporary Art (ICA) next Friday as part of a season of controversial films highlighting censorship. Baise-Moi follows two women on a rampage of sex and violence after one is raped. It has been submitted to the British Board of Film Classification, who will decide if it can be screened in its present form.

 The 2000 Tokyo International Film Festival last night gave its top prize to Mexican director Alejandro Gonzales Inarritu for his feature Love's a Bitch. Edward Norton's Keeping the Faith received the best screenplay award, Moussa Maaskri best actor for his performance in Swiss director Nicolas Wadimoff's "Mondialito" and Jennifer Jason Leigh best actress for her role as a free-spirited Lolita in Dane Kristian Levring's The King is Alive. Full details of the winners are at Screen Daily.

 Pierce Brosnan is to become an American citizen. The Irish-born actor has spoken of his love for the country and plans to base himself there permanently, following in the footsteps of Sir Anthony Hopkins. He said, "I would like to be an American. I've enjoyed my time here, it's a very, very fine country."

 The Duke of York last night presented Steven Spielberg with a Bafta film award honouring "extraordinary contribution to film".

webTitle: Dixons Group targets handheld market with online service

fields.headline: Dixons and Braindock.com create new online service
fields.trailText: 11.30am Dixons has launched a new online service to extend its reach into the handheld computer market, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The Dixons Group has launched a new online service to extend its reach into the growing market for handheld computers.

It has teamed up with mobile internet content specialist Braindock.com to provide software downloads for Psion, Palm, Handspring and Pocket PC handhelds from its newly revamped website, dixons.co.uk.

The early move into this area will position Dixons at a strategic advantage to its competitors vying for a share of the burgeoning handheld market.

Dixons, which is the largest retailer of handheld computers in the UK, claims it is the first national high street retailer to offer handheld consumers software downloads direct from a website.

In addition to software, consumers will also be able to download travel guides, dictionaries, investment managers, maps, restaurant guides and film listings.

As part of the tie-up, Dixons is promoting the new service through point-of-sale displays, after-sales service and across its website. Braindock will receive an undisclosed transaction fee for each download.

Ralph Percival, director of direct sales and marketing at the Dixons Store Group, said: "By becoming the UK's first high street retailer to create a mobile internet world for our customers we are giving our customers even greater choice and flexibility."
