fields.headline: Portillo's party
fields.standfirst:
There is life after turning back

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: There is life after turning back.
fields.body:
Attention necessarily focuses this week on the government's capacity to wield its clubs and mops. But it is also a time of trial for the opposition. To reproach Tory MPs for failing to provide coherent alternatives to present policy is to ask for a degree of maturity that is rarely witnessed in Westminster's schoolroom confrontations. Still, it would be a tonic for democracy to get at least an occasional sense that the right thinks itself fit once again to hold power. The Tories cavil at accepting Thatcherism's mistakes - rail privatisation, for example. They lack the self-knowledge, born of honesty about your history, that is a precondition of effective government.

Take William Hague's response to Chris Woodhead's "resignation". The chief inspector is a pedagogue whose head has been filled with vainglory. If he really wanted to continue improving schools - and he would be less modest than he clearly is if he did not claim there had been betterment during his time at Ofsted - he would see that bipartisanship ensures that change sticks. It would indeed suit opponents of change in the schools if Mr Woodhead became a Tory peer: they could say he was blue all along. If the Tory leadership cannot see that, it is because it cares little about the long-run process of raising attainment, much about making a rude noise behind the Blairites' backs.

Last week Michael Portillo turned back, perhaps realising after all these years that a good few of his colleagues on the right care more for the scrap and battle of personalities than the compromising business of government. Thus the Tory politician with the most acute sense of his party's history and future repositioned himself for the long game. Reports said Lady Thatcher now regards him as "confused", a telling adjective. He is well out of that long list of unfortunates - remember John Moore! - once regarded as the lady's heirs. The shadow chancellor believes the Tories must prove themselves to be responsible; that as a precondition of becoming electable they must face up to the changed nature of British society. The public in its present skittish mood may not care whether the opposition is sound and sensible. To his credit, Mr Portillo thinks he has to, because he genuinely wants power and knows how hard it would be to run a cabinet made up of his shadow cabinet colleagues as they now are.

webTitle: Depp to step into Marlowe's breeches

fields.headline: Depp to step into Marlowe's breeches
fields.trailText: Johnny Depp is to play the controversial 16th-century poet and playwright Christopher Marlowe in a new British film, Marlowe, produced by Natural Nylon, the production company owned and run by McGregor, Jonny Lee Miller, Sean Pertwee, Sadie Frost and Jude Law
fields.body:
Johnny Depp is to play the controversial 16th-century poet and playwright Christopher Marlowe in a new British film, Marlowe. Natural Nylon, the production company owned and run by Ewan McGregor, Jonny Lee Miller, Sean Pertwee, Sadie Frost and Jude Law will produce the movie, and German firm Advanced Medien, will co-finance the $20m project. Jude Law is also set to star, writes the Hollywood Reporter.

British director John Maybury, who last worked on the acclaimed Francis Bacon biopic Love Is the Devil, is to helm and production will begin in March in Italy and London.

Marlowe, one of England's greatest playwrights, was most recently portrayed by Rupert Everett in the multi-Oscar winning Shakespeare in Love. The poet was killed in a Deptford pub brawl when he was 29 in 1593, and controversy still surrounds his brief but colourful life. Some claim that he was a spy, or that he was killed by government agents - his professed atheism and homosexuality making him a dangerous destabilising influence.

The film will focus on Marlowe's relationship with William Shakespeare, and is based on the long-argued theory - dismissed as bogus by most academics - that Marlowe had a hand in some of Shakespeare's early plays.

 More about Christopher Marlowe.

fields.headline: Picnic pixie
fields.standfirst: Giles Smith suppresses the urge to whistle the Postman Pat theme as he gets into the cutely diminutive Suzuki Ignis.
fields.trailText: Giles Smith suppresses the urge to whistle the Postman Pat theme as he gets into the cutely diminutive Suzuki Ignis.
fields.body:
Let's cut straight to the picnic table in the boot. You don't often see one of those. Not one with legs and everything. Certainly not in a small car. But Suzuki - responding to what must have been an extraordinarily specific piece of market research, or perhaps one using focus groups who were hungry at the time - has put a picnic table in the boot of the new Ignis.

It's under the floor and, yes, it looks more like a plastic box at first sight. But it lifts out and you can ask your dealer to supply legs. And then you can go about the place, confident that, as a driver, you will never again need to eat sandwiches off the ground in the lifetime of your Ignis.

The pull-out picnic table is very Suzuki - kind of useful, but also a bit barking at the edges. This, remember, is the company that brought us hordes of road-burning motorcycles and the quad bike. According to a Suzuki publication - The Corporation and the People, a glossy but extremely thorough document which takes the trouble to incorporate colour photographs of, among other things, the company's incinerator and its sludge recycling facility - the Suzuki philosophy, in a Japanese nutshell, is "value-packed products". Well, say what you like, but here is a car which costs less than £7,000 for a bottom-of-the-range three-door model and which comes with removable garden furniture as standard. Value-packed or what?

The Ignis looks like a Fiat Punto after two years of military service. Where cars are concerned, military service is all the rage. A surprisingly large portion of the new car market goes for inspiration to the Jeep or, in the case of some of the bigger Mitsubishis and Hyundais, to the amphibious personnel carrier - anything, really, which might have seen action in Korea. It's an arresting fact about transport in our time that, however ostensibly peaceful their ambitions as drivers, many people now expect their vehicles to look combat-ready.

Suzuki's bold but plausible plan with the Ignis seems to be to try to shrink-wrap this cultural tendency around the chassis of a small car. It looks like a Grand Vitara (Suzuki's chunkiest and most bellicose people carrier) which has accidentally been put in with the hot wash and has come out a third of the size.

As with any miniaturising - except, possibly, the shrinking of human heads by cannibals - a degree of cuteness inevitably sets in. Suppressing the urge to whistle the theme from Postman Pat every time I climbed into the Ignis was a perpetual struggle. The luggage bars on the roof could almost be handles. The Ignis appears, disconcertingly, to be the die-cast model of the car, rather than the real car itself - a Dinky collectible.

Would you give it shelf-room? Well, it's likably snub-nosed at the front, pleasantly anonymous at the back, and sensibly frippery-free. There is, for instance, no remote locking device, so owners will have to refamiliarise themselves with an ancient and valuable ritual, little practised these days, known as "putting the key in the door and unlocking the car yourself". It feels oddly unnecessary at first, but one soon gets the hang of it.

The interior is, inevitably within this price range, a small homage to functional grey plastic and serviceable cloth. Holders for drinks are moulded into the shelf under the dashboard, which may not be the most sensible use of limited space, given the amount of times one has to find space for drinks in a car compared with the amount of times one has to find space for things which aren't drinks. And in any case, you would have thought that those who would gorge and water themselves while driving were already amply provided for with the picnic table.

It's a peculiarly slippery car to drive. Strictly speaking, a 1.3-litre engine could pull two cars of this weight without complaining too much. As the Ignis's engine is merely obliged to deal with one, and hooked up to power steering, it shoots off towards the horizon almost of its own volition. You're somewhere up around 45mph even before you have got out of second. And anyone who makes it to fifth in an Ignis in an urban area is surely within minutes of being pulled over and breathalysed.

Suzuki is about to launch a competition rally model of the three-door Ignis. Doubtless the rally drivers will work out what to do about the suspension. The company speaks lyrically about the 6.5-inch clearance between the road and the bottom of the Ignis (offering greater clearance, apparently, than any other car in the class) but even so, I'm not sure exactly how durable the standard road model would prove in extreme circumstances. At one point, seeking a potential picnic-table opportunity on one of the wilder roads around Barnes Common in London, I hit an open drain. The jolt was so severe that I have yet to recover fully the sense of feeling in my upper body.

Better with the Ignis, I think, to stay close to smooth roads and well-lit places. And forget about going to war. It's only a little car, after all.

The lowdown

Suzuki Ignis 1.3 GL

Price: from £6,995

Top speed: 99.4mph

Maximum torque: 110Nm @ 5,500 rpm

Consumption: 44.14mpg

At the wheel: Ken or Barbie

On the stereo: Livin' Doll

En route for: Legoland

webTitle: Yo-yo dieting is bad for you

fields.headline: Up and down and up and down and up and . . .
fields.standfirst: It's official: yo-yo dieting is bad for you.
fields.trailText: Dieting is stupid. We know this. It doesn't work, it makes you grumpy, it gobbles up swathes of time and attention that could be more usefully devoted to other things - and now it's bad for your health as well.
fields.body:
Dieting is stupid. We know this. It doesn't work, it makes you grumpy, it gobbles up swathes of time and attention that could be more usefully devoted to other things - and now it's bad for your health as well.

A study published in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology found that women who repeatedly diet - "yo-yo" dieters - have lower levels of the "good" cholesterol, high density lipoprotein, which protects against heart disease.

Right, so we'll all stop being silly, shall we? Not likely. Yo-yo dieting is simply the expression of an ongoing dissatisfaction with appearance that pervades many women's lives. It is an exaggerated form of the skewed attitude to food and calories that affects many women. Clearly, the gravity of the health risk depends on how fanatical you are about dieting. The study found that women who tried to lose 10lbs three times in their lives were 12% more likely than other women to develop heart disease.

But "trying" to lose 10lbs could mean almost anything. If your method is to live on Evian and chewing gum for a fortnight, you are almost certainly doing yourself damage; if, on the other hand, your idea of weight-watching is choosing a smaller slice of pie and skipping elevenses, you're probably all right.

Serious yo-yo dieters, forlornly ekeing out carrot sticks, then giving in to the temptation to stuff themselves with cookies and guilt, are easy to spot. But even among "normal" women, a seesaw approach to food and calories is endemic. Foolish and unspeakably naff it undoubtedly is, but look inside the mind of an apparently well-adjusted woman and as likely as not you'll discover a running tally, of Points Scored (a no-fun No Mayo Chicken sandwich for lunch when what you really wanted was the All Day Breakfast with sausage, egg and bacon) against Bad Things (cleaning out the bread basket, late-night pizza).

I don't think men do this. This is probably the one area in which women really are the dumb ones, particularly because, however obsessed with our weight most of us might be, we don't actually lose that much weight. That's why the tally never goes away - if we were good all the time, we wouldn't have anything to make up for. Half a stone is enough to affect how your clothes fit, but not enough for anyone to do a double take, so the calorie scoreboard that is so much a part of the psychological landscape for women is seldom obvious to the outside world. What's more, dieting, compulsive as it may be, is the stuff of solitary obsession rather than sparkling dinner table banter. Fussing about how you "really shouldn't", as if succumbing to the charms of the dessert menu was the naughtiest thing you've ever done, does make you seem a very dull person.

When you've been "good" and are riding high on the seesaw, unburdened by the memory of second helpings, the outlook seems sunny; when you're weighed down with the guilt of Bad Things, it taints your day. To make matters more complicated, the tally does not relate simply to food: exercise counts as Points Scored as well. Indeed, unintentional exercise of the larking about variety garners the best kind of points - free points. Not even the accompanying Bad Things (nobody remembers to ask for slimline tonic after midnight) can mar the joy of waking up to the tequila shot of happiness you get from realising that not only did you dance for hours (the calories burned! the thighs toned!), you never got round to going for dinner.

A skipped meal is a Get Out Of Jail Free card, credit to be cashed in at a later date. The best thing about the seesaw regime is that, like a pay-as-you-go mobile phone, you can use your top-up cards at any point. Lying in bed on a dark Monday morning, you can justify not going to the gym because you only had cornflakes for supper on Friday, so you have in effect already gone to the gym and burned a half supper-worth of calories, only in advance. Conversely, the memory of having ruined a day of restraint by shovelling in a half pound of pistachios during that dangerous 6.30pm hunger period can niggle for a week.

Confusingly, while some good things are healthy (going to the gym, not eating chips), some unhealthy things still count as Points Scored. I once accompanied a friend, stricken with food poisoning, home to her (French) flatmate, who exclaimed: "You are so lucky! Throwing up is so good for the figure!"

The most ridiculous aspect of the whole ridiculous business is that it is simply too unscientific to work. Sometimes your concentration wanders: there is a whole chapter in the American diet bible The Skinny, entitled What To Do If You Accidentally Drink A Coke Instead Of A Diet Coke. Sometimes, you simply miscalculate: I remember a friend's indignation when I told her I'd read that brown bread, preferred as the "healthy" (read: thin) alternative, has more calories than white bread. "That's not fair!" she complained. Mad? Yes. Unusual? You wish.

webTitle: In Style poaches top names for launch

fields.headline: Celebrity lifestyle mag poaches top names for launch
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Time Inc has poached the editor of the Evening Standard's ES Magazine and a former editor of Cosmopolitan for its celebrity lifestyle magazine, In Style. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Time Inc has poached the editor of the Evening Standard's ES Magazine and a former editor of Cosmopolitan as it gears up for the UK launch of its celebrity lifestyle magazine, In Style.

In Style editor Dee Nolan today announced the editorial line-up for the magazine, which launches next spring.

Louise Chunn, editor of ES Magazine, will be deputy editor, and Linda Kelsey, the launch editor of Wedding Day and a former editor of Cosmopolitan, has been appointed as executive editor.

Ms Nolan said: "We are building a team with superlative talent. Between them, the staff have a wealth of experience drawn from all the top newspapers and magazines.

"We've really got the best of both worlds: all the strength of In Style in the US, and a team here which can translate the essence of the magazine in a UK context."

Other new hirings include Paula Reed, fashion director at Conde Nast Traveller, who takes the same title at In Style; Vanessa Friedman, fashion director of the Financial Times, who becomes fashion news and features director; and Polly Williams, features editor of the Mail on Sunday's You magazine, who becomes senior editor, fashion.

In Style was launched in the US in 1994 and has gone on to become one of the most successful US fashion magazines.

Its US circulation stood at 1.57m in the first half of this year, a 16% increase on the first half of 1999.

Time Inc has already launched international editions of In Style in Australia and Germany.

webTitle: Omnicom's BBDO picks up Daimler Chrysler account

fields.headline: Omnicom pips True North to post for Daimler Chrysler
fields.trailText: 10/45am: Daimler Chrysler has shifted its entire £1.25bn business to Omnicom's BBDO creating the world's biggest single car account, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Daimler Chrysler has shifted its entire £1.25bn business to Omnicom's BBDO creating the world's biggest single car account.

The decision, made late on Friday, ends a fierce two-month battle for the business between the Chicago-based True North and the New York-based BBDO network.

David Bell, chairman and chief executive at True North, said: "We're disappointed that the superior quality of our global work and our experience in integrating business from other agencies for Chrysler Group did not seem to be the critical drivers that we'd anticipated."

The result marks a serious setback for True North as it sees £97m, or 9% of revenue, and up to 15% of earnings wiped off its business overnight.

It also poses a huge threat to True North's independence. Losing the business makes it vulnerable to a takeover by other groups, including Interpublic Group of Companies or the Publicis Group.

The knock-on effects in the UK, where Mercedes-Benz and Jeep are its biggest brands, are widespread. Banks Hoggins O'Shea/FCB in the UK will lose its £10m Jeep and Chrysler accounts. FCB Worldwide handles Jeep and Chrysler, worth £294m a year, while BBDO Worldwide is responsible for the £309m Dodge brand, which does not exist in the UK.

Omnicom is the second biggest agency worldwide after the WPP Group, and number three in billings behind WPP and Interpublic.

True North is ninth in revenue and eighth in billings.

Mike Vogel, chief executive of FCB Detroit, said: "Our focus is now on replacing this business and finding the next set of challenges for our agency."

The Mercedes-Benz business, which is handled in the UK by Partners BDDH, is not affected by the switch.

fields.headline: The Tube goes online
fields.trailText: 11am: London Underground chiefs reckon they have come up with a way to ease the daily stress of travel with the launch of its first website, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
It will probably be the lost cause of the internet.

As weary Tube commuters battle to make their way to work, London Underground chiefs reckon they have come up with a way to ease the daily stress of travel.

London Underground today launched its first ever website, providing up-to-the-minute information about service disruptions and a journey planner for those unfamiliar with the network.

The website, thetube.com, is the first step towards making the tube information more accessible for customers, a process which will lead to the development of Wap, PDA and interactive TV-based services next year.

Designed by London-based agency Precedent Communications, the site adds to London Transport's three-year-old website, Londontransport.co.uk.

London Transport is currently rebranding itself as Transport for London.

Tony Maguire, director of communications for London Underground, said: "The new dedicated London Underground website will be a great communication tool for a fast growing base of internet users.

"The site underlines our continuing commitment to explore and develop avenues of communication in response to today's burgeoning information superhighway."

webTitle: Angels kick ass at US box office

fields.headline: Angels kick ass at US box office
fields.trailText: Drew Barrymore's Charlie's Angels remake met with a heavenly reception at American cinemas on its opening weekend. The film went straight to the top of the US box office over the Thanksgiving weekend, taking $40.5m
fields.body:
Drew Barrymore's Charlie's Angels remake met with a heavenly reception at American cinemas on its opening weekend. The film went straight to the top of the US box office over the Thanksgiving weekend, taking $40.5m.

The movie drew criticism from reviewers for its thin plot, but praise for its campy humour and glossy action. "It's eye candy for the blind. It's a movie without a brain in its three pretty little heads," wrote Roger Ebert, the Chicago Sun-Times reviewer.

Variety were more forgiving: "Packed with action, attitude, skin-tight costumes and enough dazzling white smiles and slo-mo hair flips for a season's worth of toothpaste and shampoo commercials, this entertaining confection possesses the substance of the TV show, the pacing of a Hong Kong actioner and the production values of a James Bond thriller."

Meet the Parents, which held the top box-office slot for an astonishing four weeks, has now fallen to second place. It has become the biggest October opening ever, earning $100m to date.

Robert Redford's The Legend of Bagger Vance which stars Matt Damon and Will Smith, also opened this weekend, in respectable third. Many critics dismissed the golf parable as shallow.

Overall, US box office takings were up for the fourth weekend running, following a long slump that started in midsummer. Hollywood's revenues are currently running slightly ahead of last year's, when the industry took in a record $7.5bn.

fields.headline: With friends like these . . .
fields.standfirst: On Friday, C4 unveiled E4, must-see TV for the under-34s pitched at Sky One's audience. But Michael Jackson denies they are rivals.
fields.trailText: On Friday Channel 4 finally screwed up its courage, and announced that its long-awaited entertainment channel, E4, will launch on January 18. Oddly, this is a Thursday - not the most obvious night on which to introduce a new channel aimed at the under-34s.
fields.body:
On Friday Channel 4 finally screwed up its courage, and announced that its long-awaited entertainment channel, E4, will launch on January 18. Oddly, this is a Thursday - not the most obvious night on which to introduce a new channel aimed at the under-34s.

But the key to this seemingly strange decision is the appearance in the opening night schedule of the first episode of the new (seventh) series of Friends, followed by a new episode of ER.

A straight lift, in other words, from Sky One's "must-see TV" Thursday night schedule (which, in fairness, was itself a straight lift from NBC). It was Sky, of course, which rather bitterly pulled out of the bidding for the satellite rights to Friends and ER when the multi-million pound price tag became too rich. In its first year E4 is spending £40m on programming.

Besides Friends and ER, E4 will be screening The Sopranos, Sex in the City, and Dawson's Creek, plus such home-grown entertainment shows as So Graham Norton, Da Ali G Show, Smack the Pony and Trigger Happy TV. Many will screen on E4 first, with the US shows on Channel 4 six months later.

The under-34s targeted by E4 are an audience who can react with enthusiasm, commitment and, crucially, disposable income to a channel which treats them properly. Sky One, with its annual budget of £66m, has spent 10 years slowly increasing its market share, aiming at establishing itself as the multi-channel world's (necessarily younger) equivalent of ITV. E4, according to Adam Smith of Zenith Media,"represents the most serious challenge yet to Sky One in that aim".

Acknowledging the new channel's debt to Sky, Channel 4's entertainment supremo Kevin Lygo (who doubles up as E4's controller of programming) is unashamed. "Give people what they want," he shrugs. Mark Sharman, Sky's director of broadcasting, responds: "Wherever you look we face increasing competition, including UK Gold. But we are widening our demographic up to 50." They are also specifically targeting women with new UK drama and spending on original production has risen by 60% under him.

Sky One's other main threat, the youth-oriented BBC3 which will grow from the ashes of BBC Choice, is at least nine months away from getting its act together. Which gives E4, buoyed by the exclusive rights to not only Friends and ER but this year's Emmy victor, The West Wing, a chance to streak ahead.

With a launch marketing budget of £10m, far in excess of anything the BBC could muster, Dan Brooks, E4's marketing head, can proclaim that the newcomer is "the last big channel launch in this country". All the other genres - sport, film, children's and factual - are full, he claims. Though if Channel 4's plans to launch a racing channel hadn't been put on hold by a rights battle, that statement might have been different.

E4's launch will be based on a viral internet campaign (isn't everything aimed at the under-35s, these days?), but Brooks has a far more valuable and absolutely free marketing tool at his disposal - access to Channel 4's airtime. The obvious point to plug E4 will be at 7pm as Channel 4's after-school teen programming gives way to the news. T4 - the successful youth zone created by Andi Peters which occupies Sunday mornings on Channel 4 and houses Dawson's Creek and the Hollyoaks omnibus - will go to five nights a week. Anchored by the achingly hip Dermot O'Leary, it may be partly simulcast on Channel 4 and E4. Presumably with plenty of cross-promotion.

Though C4 chief executive Michael Jackson confirmed the go-ahead at last week's press launch, there was more than a touch of a wing and a prayer in his presentation. Success depends on distribution, getting E4 into as many of the 9m multi-channel homes in the UK and Ireland in January.

Yet the only agreement signed so far is with NTL, the UK's largest cable operator, (1.2m TV homes). Deals with Telewest and ONdigital are said to be imminent. Spending £40m on programming for a channel which little more than a million homes can receive seems excessive, but every new channel launch is dogged by "nearly" signed carriage deals up to the day of its launch and most are signed fairly soon after.

Just like Sky One, E4 is a hybrid pay service. It is expected to justify the £100m investment being ploughed into the TV channel and linked website by securing a combination of advertising revenue and subscription income - the latter calculated in pence per month paid back to Channel 4 by the distributor for each subscriber home the channel reaches. The amount of pence per subscriber varies from service to service, and fixing this tariff and getting the channel on to basic subscription packages together provide scope for endless haggling. Negotiations with Sky - by far the largest distributor - have inevitably been coloured by the fact that Sky One is E4's main rival.

Gerry Bastable, head of Channel 4's pay TV team, says he "expects" the channel to be on all platforms. "Our experience with Film Four [which launched two years ago] was that we ended up signing distribution deals with Sky and ONdigital a few days before launch, and with NTL afterwards." BSkyB's focus, he says, is on the bottom line. "They have to be absolutely sure what they are getting. Until we firmed up our plans, it was difficult for us to give them chapter and verse. There's a long tradition of terrestrial broadcasters not really cracking it. We've tried to learn from their mistakes."

Though there have been rumours of joint venture discussions with partners ranging from Paramount Comedy Channel to Warner Brothers and of course Sky, Channel 4 is currently going ahead with E4 as a wholly-owned venture (Emap is a partner in the E4 website). Significantly, though, Bastable says a partner has not been ruled out. Sky likes to take equity stakes of 50% in the channels it distributes, though Film Four, as a premium £5.99 per month service, was given the kid glove treatment and remains wholly owned by Channel 4.

A deal would allow Channel 4 to recoup its investment more quickly and harness Sky's formidable marketing and subscription team (the people who ring you up at home and ask if you'd like to subscribe to Film Four. No? Well how about a free three-month trial?), who have helped take Film Four subscriptions to a pro jected 400,000 by Christmas. The conflict centres on the key issue of how valuable E4 is in relation to Sky One: if Sky One is priced, say, around 80p per home per month, is E4 worth 40p, or more or less? How much is access to Friends worth? This year an episode of Friends recorded 2.9m viewers, Sky One's biggest audience ever, ahead of ITV and BBC1 in satellite and cable homes.

The truth is that the first year will be experimental. "We want to get it up and running," says Bastable. "It has a very close relationship with Channel 4 and we want to figure out how it works. The whole thinking is about taking Channel 4's reputation and expanding on it."

"It's a balance. We don't want to take away from Channel 4," says Andrew Newman, head of E4 programmes. "The big American shows are there to bring in the ratings. And the new shows are there to do something for the landscape. Our new commissions have to be distinctive and get talked about for having bottle."

Lygo says all the shows made for E4 will be screened on Channel 4. He adds that "someone may make a new show for Channel 4, and it may be we'll decide to premiere it on E4". He cites Dylan Moran's new sitcom, Black Books, which has struggled on Friday night against BBC2's Buzzcocks. "We could get a wind behind something, get people talking". Already Channel 4 has adopted one of E4's ideas to make video diaries from contestants on the castaway gameshow, Shipwrecked.

Channel 4's entertainment budget under Lygo, now £70-75m, will clearly play a big part in bolstering E4, as will access to its distinctive archive. "In Year one it will change all the time," Lygo says. The stars associated with Channel 4 have been squared, he says: "They want to be part of E4".

However, the benchmark for an E4 show performing well (100,000 viewers, compared with 2m for Channel 4) may put some off. Newman thinks audiences can be much bigger. The E4 schedule (see panel) has been designed to work with, rather than offer full-blooded competition to, the parent channel. Channel 4 concentrates its entertainment on Wednesday and Fridays, so E4 will target Mondays, Thursdays and Sundays. It's all so beautifully complementary, put like that. But what if you love Friends and ER but just happen to be aged 40, like Bastable?

"While our core audience is 16-34, that's shorthand, really, for people who have the Channel 4 values and attitudes, the young in spirit," he says. Profits aren't projected until after five years of operation. Bastable adds: "Financially, we are trying to be commercially grounded, but we do have other objectives, such as retaining C4's relevance in a multi-channel age."

Of E4's £40m programme budget, just over half is for acquired shows. But some 350 hours a year of new programming will be made. The aim is to spend around £40,000 per half-hour - not significantly different from the terrestrial programme budgets of Channel 5 - and learn the lesson of BBC Choice: it's better to make fewer programmes with decent budgets than lots of cheap rubbish.

Channel 4 must prove with this launch that it can roll out a popular digital channel. Film Four's income may be high but there is no shortage of doubters questioning its churn rate. E4 must secure and retain a substantial audience to pay its way - and there will always be those who doubt whether a public service channel with a remit to serve disenfranchised minorities should be launching commercial entertainment channels and outbidding Sky for the rights to US shows.

At the launch, Jackson pointed to the expansion of digital channels in Britain and said: "Channel 4 can't afford to stand still in this changing landscape, and we don't intend to." E4 would be "salient and relevant" to its audience. It was not a rival to Sky One, but a station aimed at the Channel 4 core audience. "It will be intelligent and youthful in attitude."

It's true that there will be more in E4 for its target audience than there is on Sky One - and there will be none of the Fox-produced car crash clip shows that drag down the latter's schedule. But Jackson's claim that there is no rivalry looks like a clear case of wishful thinking.

Wooing the under-34s: indicative E4 schedule

4-8 pm: T4 teen zone, including Popworld (live music show), Dawson's Creek, US high school docu-soap and next-day repeats of C4 shows: Hollyoaks, Shipwrecked, As If (new urban teen soap), The Secret Life of Us (Australian 'Dawson's Creek meets This Life meets Cold Feet' drama)

8-9 pm: Blind Date (US version), Channel 4 repeats (eg Smack the Pony, Party of Five).

9-10 pm: First-run US drama and comedy: Friends, ER (Tuesday and Thursday), Ally McBeal, Sex in the City, The West Wing, The Drew Carey Show (sitcom) 10-11 pm: New British entertain ment (12 series commissioned, including first run of new series of Trigger Happy TV).

11-11.30pm: Generation E - original youth documentaries. Expect lots of sex-related material.

11.30pm-4 am: Channel 4 archive - The Word, Eurotrash, Graham Norton, Oz, Queer as Folk, Father Ted.

In development now: Camper Van - Five gays hit the road to journey from LA to New York. Touches of Ibiza Uncovered.

In production now: 5 Go Dating - five young women and five men come to London, live in adjacent houses, must date each one, report back on 25 dates, and what they said about each other.

fields.headline: Six get successful at Radio 1
fields.standfirst: The BBC Talent drive has given some young hopefuls a break. Merope Mills gets on their wavelength.
fields.trailText: The BBC Talent drive has given some young hopefuls a break. Merope Mills gets on their wavelength.
fields.body:
Sitting in the reception at Yalding House is like being in the middle of the HQ for the young and young-at-heart. Girls in skin-tight T-shirts and combats jog past. Twentysomething guys show off their latest Adidases with denim turn-ups. The Sugarbabes belt out on the radio and a man shuffles past dressed as Uncle Bulgaria of the Wombles. Anywhere else it would be surreal. But this is Radio 1, Britain's premier youth station.

Here reside the latest additions to the Radio 1 team: the beneficiaries of the radio arm of the BBC Talent drive launched earlier this year. They are Becci Abbott, Kasey Clarke, Lee Edmenson, Natasha Lynch, Andy Taylor and Antonia Wright. Aged 18 to 24, they capture the older end of the Radio 1 target audience (15-24) but - like so many of their co-workers - they reflect the station's stance on having a workforce that mirrors the interests and ages of listeners.

The trainees, who have won year-long contracts, will spend the first six months shifting between departments, and the final six specialising in the area in which they have shown potential. They have been at the London base for less than three weeks.

Mary, the PR who is chaperoning them during our interview, takes me to "the chill-out room" where they're waiting. "They're a lively bunch," she says as she ferries me down the stairs, past framed pictures of Zoe, Jamie, and the saluting Sara; past machines dispensing Skittles and M&Ms, and into the dimly lit den, decked out with bean-bags, furry footrests and play-stations, where the group is waiting.

Teeth are sure to grind at the sight of the successful six. The BBC had more than 16,500 applications, which were whittled down to 400 for the second stage and 56 for the interviews from which the final group were chosen.

Asked if they always wanted to work in media, five of them say yes. Two were also drawn to the TV application, including 18-year-old Becci, who auditioned but claims it put her off TV work. "I did the children's TV one and they said to me 'be cheesy' and it was so fake." She bursts into an over-animated impression of herself: "'Hi! I'm Becci!' - God, it was horrible."

Lee is the oldest. While the others had only recently left education with their sights set on the media, he had a career carved out as a welder on Formula 1 cars. He says he finds the media question weird. "To me, it's not about media, it's about being passionate about music," he says, before following one textbook answer with another. "Every time I got through to the next round, I was just really pleased. I was happy to get through all those people. That was a buzz in itself."

Not yet familiar with the intrica cies of Auntie's expected protocol, the trainees' enthusiasm doesn't always throw up such fawning answers. I see the PR's face twitch when they compare notes on the application process: how the online application form was confusing; how they were told they'd hear by the end of July but heard nothing until mid-August; how they received interview invitations addressed to somebody completely different. For the BBC it was a bureaucratic nightmare, not helped by the criticisms that, with so many eager - and experienced - youngsters out there, the BBC Talent drive was a waste of time and money.

When I ask how they would respond to the accusation that they have taken a bit of a short-cut, they are outraged and bombard me with justifications: "We worked very hard", "We had to prove ourselves", "We had to answer a psychometric questionnaire", "and design a radio show." "And besides," says Andy, leaning forward, "a lot of people get in through short cuts and people they know." Mary butts in, "It is perceived," she says, " perceived ."

Suddenly, Andy Parfitt, controller of Radio 1, arrives at the door. Seeing us there, he's about to turn and go, when he changes his mind. "Actually," he says, beckoning in his companions, "This is Mark and Lard." There's an "ooh" and a bit of a giggle from the trainees.

"These are the Radio 1 trainees," says Andy to the presenters.

"Thank you for introducing me to Belle and Sebastian," pipes up Natasha.

"Oh, right. Nice one. Good. Yeah. Glad to be of service," says Mark in his Mancunian burr. They all laugh.

"I'm star struck," says Becci, when they're gone.

"Bless 'em," says Kasey.

Do they all want to be presenters, I ask? Kasey does. Becci isn't sure. "They asked the same question in our interview," says Antonia, "and my answer was 'Well, every guy wants to play for their favourite football team, but most end up playing Sunday football and are happy with it.'" They all compliment her on her interview skills and agree. "Everything that holds this building together is exciting. There are so many people who've got important jobs that you just don't see. Anything would be great. Producing, marketing . . . anything."

Trying to decipher whether the station went for a particular type, I ask them to write down three words to describe themselves. Outgoing comes up twice, as does open-minded. Easy-going is in there, alongside creative and ambitious. One of them writes sexy which, if nothing else, shows confidence, which was bound to be a requirement. Do they think they're similar?

"Nooooo," they say, with a lot of head-shaking. "I'd say we get on..." "But we're a real mix of personalities." "It's like being in Big Brother except without the annoying one."

Just like Big Brother contestants, they say, they have to do video diaries throughout the year to chart their progress. "And Chris Moyles has this thing that he wants to evict one of us every month."

"As a joke", adds Antonia.

Before I leave, I ask who they think will win the Spice Girls v Westlife battle this week. They think for a moment. "The pop industry," mumbles Natasha. Which goes to show that the reason the BBC picked them is because, as far as it is concerned, they already know their stuff.

Suddenly, Andy Parfitt, controller of Radio 1, arrives at the door. Seeing us there, he's about to turn and go, when he changes his mind. "Actually," he says, beckoning in his companions, "This is Mark and Lard." There's an "ooh" and a bit of a giggle from the trainees. "These are the Radio 1 trainees," says Andy to the presenters. "Thank you for introducing me to Belle and Sebastian," pipes up Natasha. "Oh, right. Nice one. Good. Yeah. Glad to be of service," says Mark in his Mancunian burr. They all laugh. "I'm star struck," says Becci, when they're gone. "Bless 'em," says Kasey. Do they all want to be presenters, I ask? Kasey does. Becci isn't sure. "They asked the same question in our interview," says Antonia, "and my answer was 'Well, every guy wants to play for their favourite football team, but most end up playing Sunday football and are happy with it.'" They all compliment her on her interview skills and agree. "Everything that holds this building together is exciting. There are so many people who've got important jobs that you just don't see. Anything would be great. Producing, marketing . . . anything." Trying to decipher whether the station went for a particular type, I ask them to write down three words to describe themselves. Outgoing comes up twice, as does open-minded. Easy-going is in there, alongside creative and ambitious. One of them writes sexy which, if nothing else, shows confidence, which was bound to be a requirement. Do they think they're similar? "Nooooo," they say, with a lot of head-shaking. "I'd say we get on..." "But we're a real mix of personalities." "It's like being in Big Brother except without the annoying one." Just like Big Brother contestants, they say, they have to do video diaries throughout the year to chart their progress. "And Chris Moyles has this thing that he wants to evict one of us every month." "As a joke", adds Antonia. Before I leave, I ask who they think will win the Spice Girls v Westlife battle this week. They think for a moment. "The pop industry," mumbles Natasha. Which goes to show that the reason the BBC picked them is because, as far as it is concerned, they already know their stuff.

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: • Early favourite for internet celebrity of the month is Curry at Rubberburner.com, probably the most handsome man on the web. Well, that's what he reckons anyway. Bold, confident, and good-looking are the words he uses to describe himself, but he doesn't stop there, oh no, 80s throwback Curry boasts that he is gorgeous, sexy, tender and brave. The rules of internet celebritydom are strict indeed: contenders have to be completely self-obsessed, have no concept of their real shortcomings and have an obsession with sex. Past winners - cyber stud Mahir Cagri who wants to kiss everyone and Seska of Seska.com fame - have finally been upstaged. Gives "fancy a curry" a new meaning.

Past winners - cyber stud Mahir Cagri who wants to kiss everyone and Seska of Seska.com fame - have finally been upstaged. Gives "fancy a curry" a new meaning.

 Hasbro could be making the biggest mistake of its life by jumping on the internet bandwagon with a dot.com Monopoly board. Given the current climate, in which no dot.com is safe, the Old Kent Road contenders - Priceline, Oxygen, About.com and Weather.com - could end up causing Hasbro more headaches than it was banking on. Who's to say that any of these internet properties will still be around next year when the boardgame eventually makes it to the UK?

 Andy Mitchell, the man who made AltaVista into a household name for all the wrong reasons, is back. Dan Wagner of Bright Station - the man who makes a habit of picking up scraps - is behind the comeback. Three months after the AltaVista unmetered fiasco, dynamo Mitchell is now running new search engine Webtop and says it's nice to be in the driving seat. Is he be implying that he never had full control of AltaVista's UK strategy? Stand up and say what you think, hero fallguy.

 Famous names do not maketh success. Celebrity chefs had their fingers burned last week when their big dot.com venture, Foodoo.com, went bellypork up. Sunday Business, the paper that gave Foodoo.com a regular column, is left with egg on its face. Clearly Foodoo.com just couldn't find the right ingredients, namely advertising revenues. Or was it just a case of too many celebrity chefs spoiling the broth?

 Those of you that haven't got hold of a copy of The Net Effect by Richard Lord, editor of Revolution, and would desperately like a copy, get in touch as Random House kindly sent more copies than I know what to do with. I'm sure Richard would be devastated to think his works of literary genius are now being used by a fellow new media hack as a desk steadier. Be warned though, regular readers of Richard's column expecting to hear his mum's erudite words will be gutted to find not a single mention of what she feels about the latest new media development. Apparently, they've had creative differences.

Amy.vickers@theguardian.com
 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: Kate Buggeln
fields.trailText: Kate Buggeln, president of the recently relaunched boo.com
fields.body:
Favourite sites?
Obviously boo.com is my favourite. At the moment, I tend to spend a lot of time in our community area, chatting to other users. I always loved the original boo.com when I could get full access to it. Beyond visiting boo, I spend a lot of time on news sites. In terms of where I spend my money, there's Expedia for my travel and Amazon for my books. And I've been surfing sex sites because we're looking to bring sex content onto boo.

Last online purchase?
A jacket from Ted Baker. I shop online for clothing quite a lot.

Most recent technological faux pas?
I came to London with a new cell phone but I couldn't get international service so I was unreachable for a few days. Prior to that, I spilt water on my keyboard.

Main news sources on the web?
BBC Online because it covers the world fairly well, and provides deep coverage of the UK. Wall Street Journal online has different editions, European as well as American. And the New York Times, which is my homepage.

Most persistent spam emailer?
I've done a good job of keeping that out of my work mail. But skiareas.com targets my personal aol mailbox quite a lot, although I don't mind. It reminds me of the days when I had time to go skiing.

Time spent on web?
I'm online all day. It's just a function of my job. Even in meetings, I tend to end up in front of some site or another.

Next boo.com/clickmango?
I strongly believe that this Christmas season is going to be the last great wave of cleansing on the internet. There are people hanging on, but post-holiday you're going to see an enormous amount of people that don't survive. But I think it's good. It's very Darwinian, if you will.

Least useful site/s on web?
People's personal websites.

Most useful site/s?
Any site that is providing you information on what you're about to buy in addition to giving you the opportunity to purchase. Amazon is great for that.

What screensaver do you use?
It's a quote from the original Miss Boo: "I can work 24 hours a day without getting bored. I can be everywhere at once and not confuse myself with God."

Most irritating thing about the web?
The vastness of it.

Do you bother with old media?
Oh yeah. I read newspapers and books, and I go to see films. I'm very much a tactile person. I adore having people around me. I don't think the web replaces that.

Kate Buggeln is president of the recently relaunched boo.com

webTitle: Lis Howell's website for the over-35s

fields.headline: Bowling along
fields.standfirst: Fancy talking to the stars? You can if you sign up to Lis Howell's website.  She tells Amy Vickers about a £500,000 gamble on the over-35s market.
fields.trailText: Fancy talking to the stars? You can if you sign up to Lis Howell's website. She tells Amy Vickers about a £500,000 gamble on the over-35s market.
fields.body:
Ask Lis Howell, a woman who has devoted her life to television, why she made the leap into the uncharted waters of the internet at the age of almost 50, and you'll get a decisive answer that could warm the cockles of many a disenchanted old TV exec's heart. "It's good for the soul," she says.

She's not sure her family would agree, however. She has worked flat out, spending weekends in the office, to get the website, bowlofcherries.com, up and running on time. The website, a community-focused magazine site for over-35s with something of a celebrity edge, made its debut, as planned, last Tuesday.

The five partners in the company - Ola Steinsrud, David Hurst, Jane McCormick, Alyson Pearce and Howell herself - each stumped up cash to get the venture off the ground, and a private investor, a friend Howell declines to name, managed to ramp up the total launch fund to £500,000.

Howell is chief executive; Hurst, previously publishing director of Financial Times Business, is managing director. McCormick, who has worked as a journalist for the Sun, the Sunday Mirror, the Sunday Express, GMTV and Reuters, is editor-in-chief. Pearce, who has experience in showbusiness, the media and the hospitality industry, is events director. Steinsrud, the founder of TVNorge, Norway's first commercial TV station, will be new media consultant.

Given the option of being backed by Howell's former company Flextech, where she was senior vice-president of Flextech Channels, the five partners didn't think what was on the table was worthwhile, even though it would have had PR value and involved support marketing. They also decided to avoid the complex venture capital route. Instead, with gritty determination, they opted to go it alone.

Will it work? Not even Howell seems 100% certain. She says that the project is safe until Christmas, by which time it needs to have established a good revenue model.

Howell may have a strong record in TV but, as everyone has learned from the past year, the internet is a whole different ball game, and top teams don't necessarily equal automatic success. However, if energy and enthusiasm could guarantee success in the cut-throat world of the internet, bowlofcherries would be an instant success story.

But who's to say it won't be a success? With a strong, experienced management team behind it, a good well-researched niche market to target and no malevolent venture capitalist on its back, it perhaps stands a better chance than many. It has already got off to a springing start, with, according to Howell, almost 100 pre-launch subscriptions taken out. At £100 a pop for a year's members' benefits, that's a nice £10,000 in the bank after its first week.

"The site has hit a nerve already and we're starting off with no debt because we've covered all the start-up costs with our own money. We've done our research and we know there is a market out there for us," says Howell, reeling off some research bowlofcherries commissioned from BMRB in the summer. More than 10.5m people over 35 now use the internet for pleasure; 7% said they would pay a subscription if they thought it gave them something; they constitute the fastest growing sector of the internet; and they know what they want - mainly relevant information and good conversation. To this end, bowlofcherries aims to provide users with information about everything from decorating and gardening to cooking and travel, top-and-tailed with a bit of celebrity opinion. The company is entering a market that has yet to be tapped. While the number of websites for people over 45 or under 25 has spiralled, no one has yet developed a website targeted at both sexes over 35.

Other revenues from advertising and e-commerce will kick in later, but the subscription-based model should give bowlofcherries a good foundation on which to build. Additionally, the site has signed e-commerce and content deals with Tesco, the RAC and Crabtree & Evelyn, the upmarket gift shop.

For their £100, bowlofcherries club members will get a free gift from Crabtree & Evelyn and an organised social calendar, including wine tastings, tennis tournaments and weekly cocktail parties where club members can meet the 50 personalities who write for the site. Members also have access to experts (such as a personal celebrity shopper) and get discounts on some goods.

Club members will even be encouraged to strike up personal email conversations with the stars - a list that includes Toyah Wilcox, Michael Cole, Fern Britton, Edwina Currie and Jilly Johnson - who will be writing for the website.

The rest of the website and all the content are free, but Howell says that the celebrity involvement and the weekly parties are its unique selling point. "It's not about glamour, it's about conversations," she says.

Howell says she's having the time of her life and now sees the TV industry as stale and unwilling to change with the times. She's glad she made the move and likes the new-found sense of control over the whole project - a far cry from the enveloping bureaucracy at her former employers, Flextech, GMTV and BSkyB.

More than anything, and not just because she and her partners have money riding on the success of bowlofcherries.com, she is determined that this new venture is one of the few dot.com start-ups that survive. Could she be trying to prove a point to her former colleagues?

webTitle: Capital's Aviva to launch this year

fields.headline: Capital's Aviva to launch this year
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Capital Interactive, the new media arm of Capital Radio, has said its first internet radio station will launch by the end of the year, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Capital Interactive, the new media arm of Capital Radio, has named its first internet radio station Aviva and said it will launch before the end of the year.

Targeted at women from 25-34, the round-the-clock station will feature the likes of George Michael, Texas, Madonna, Barry White and Tina Turner.

The move is part of Capital Interactive's £5.5m investment in internet radio, of which the cornerstone is its new kikido brand - the engine that will power the niche radio sites.

Two more 'narrowcast' web stations will follow the launch of Aviva.

These will include a station aimed at male computer and console game players and a soul music station.

Capital is also working on a further project, codenamed Pub Carpet, which is a jukebox-focused internet radio station that plans to run trivia quiz nights targeted at pub audiences.

Another plan is to hive off Capital's normal music output into genres such as pop, guitar and dance and have these accessible from its existing sites, Capitalfm.com, xfm.co.uk and CapitalGold.com.

Mark Frost, managing director at Capital Interactive, said: "It's going to be a big change from what radio has been so far. We're aiming these products directly at desk potatoes."

Capital has developed branded desktop radio players, based on Microsoft's Media Player, that will carry banner advertising.

It plans to announce a number of distribution partners in the coming months, a raft of sponsors and a broadband partner at launch of Aviva.

Capital Radio is entering a market that is becoming increasingly crowded by US companies that have been able to gain fast-stream internet radio licences through the licensing body the RIAA, while UK internet radio companies have been dogged by the absence of any common licence.

Instead, companies have to spend months talking to record companies on an individual basis to gain internet music rights.

Capital is still awaiting approval on rights from Sony and Warner but has secured two-thirds of all UK albums, which was Mr Frost's minimum launch point.

fields.headline: Sunday Business editor joins BBC
fields.standfirst: Dyke slams BBC business coverage
fields.trailText:
9.45am update: Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall has quit to join the BBC as its first business editor. By Jason Deans.
Dyke slams BBC business coverage
fields.body:
Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall has quit the paper after just two years to join the BBC as its first business editor.

He has been personally lured to the corporation, where salaries rarely match those in the commercial sector, by director general Greg Dyke.

Mr Randall, who successfully relaunched Sunday Business in early 1998, will be joining the BBC in March when his current contract ends. He is the former City and business editor of the Sunday Times.

Mr Dyke said: "I am confident that Jeff will make a significant difference to our output. One of the things that I want Jeff and his team to capture is the extent to which a great deal of ideology that surrounded the very word 'business' is no longer relevant in the first decade of the 21st century."

The BBC director general highlighted business coverage as an area where he wants to see urgent improvements.

Up until now Peter Jay has held the position of economics and business editor.

However he was rarely on screen and has been criticised for his heavy presentation style.

Mr Dyke is particulary keen to transform the BBC's business coverage to reflect the interests of ordinary viewers, more and more of whom have shareholdings.

Other initiatives planned in this area include the doubling in length of BBC2's Working Lunch to an hour for a trial period; the development of a weekly show in which a panel of business experts analyse current issues, based on US programme Wall Street Week in Review; and the creation of two new programme brands, BBC Money and BBC Business.

The BBC is also expanding its online business team from seven to 13 journalists to add more Nasdaq coverage and analysis.

Mr Dyke will announce these changes during a speech at the CBI conference in Birmingham today.

webTitle: Carphone Warehouse rings up bumper profits

fields.headline: Carphone Warehouse rings up bumper profits
fields.trailText: 10am:Carphone Warehouse, Europe's largest mobile phone retailer, has posted a 62% rise in profits. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Amateur investors are heaving a sigh of relief following bumper profits at Carphone Warehouse, Europe's largest mobile phone retailer.

The group said first half turnover was up 62% to 447.9m, with pre-tax profits at £21m, against £6.7m last year.

The figures are good news for the thousands of people who bought Carphone shares at 200p when the company floated in July, but were subjected to a three-month sale lock-in.

Jittery shareholders could only watch as the shares fell to a low of 144p, and must be hoping that today's figures push it into profit. Shares were up 1.3% at 190.5p in early trading.

The group defended the time restrictions, which did not apply to big financial institutions, saying it would calm the market volatility that had hit recent IPOs.

fields.headline: Boycott against takeover by the dominant Mail
fields.standfirst: With at least five companies taking a serious interest in buying Express Newspapers,  Roy Greenslade clears up a few misunderstandings.
fields.trailText: With at least five companies taking a serious interest in buying Express Newspapers, Roy Greenslade clears up a few misunderstandings.
fields.body:
The Daily Express's future may be opaque, but with its owners now considering their options there is no better moment to take stock. Questions have been raised in the wake of the various bids which demand answers.

Let me clear up some misunderstandings following the bid by the Daily Mail & General Trust (DMGT). The Express editor, Rosie Boycott, initially appeared to have favoured such a takeover. This is evidently not the case. Her positive comments reflected the logic of the initiative for the Mail, but she is personally hostile to the concept, believing her paper could not exist within DMGT's culture.

Despite the Mail's guarantees about editorial independence and its willingness to let her continue in office at least until the next general election, my understanding is that she would reject the offer.

Similarly, in spite of the Mail's pledges, I find it very hard to believe that the government would be able to justify to the public, or itself, the contraction of national newspaper competition. The decision of the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, on whether to allow a takeover would be based on commercial, rather than political, criteria. A strict interpretation of the rules would inevitably block DMGT, and its hiring of the lobbyist Mike Craven, even if he is considered a Labour insider, is unlikely to affect the outcome.

Competitive considerations would also affect any possible bid by the Telegraph group's owners, Hollinger, which has asked for financial details on the Express titles from Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, advisers to the papers' owner, United News & Media.

It will be interesting to see if United treats Hollinger any differently from the Barclay brothers, who withdrew their bid after waiting in vain for the same information. Dan Colson, Hollinger's vice-chairman, believes that United has "to take an expression of interest from us seriously" because of his company's strong business links with Express Newspapers. They are co-owners of the lucrative Westferry printing plant, and have a joint distribution and newsprint-buying operation.

In spite of the speculation and the public announcement of bids, United's chief executive Clive Hollick has remained tight-lipped, though I imagine, in private, he is smiling.

Apart from Hollinger's interest and firm bids of more than £100m from DMGT and the Hinduja brothers, it would appear that David Montgomery has not given up hope of stitching a bid together. The Barclays may have stepped back for the moment, but they are watching events carefully. So Hollick, without even putting the papers up for sale, already has at least five companies hooked on the idea. Can he and his board play the ostrich much longer?

It's all very well for United to pretend that it is business as usual at Ludgate House, thumbing its nose at would-be buyers, but the three titles - Daily and Sunday Express and Daily Star - are in urgent need of attention. Despite bland assurances, the apprehensive staff feel as if they are in some sort of limbo.

All newspaper takeovers are subject to referral, whether the bidder is a competitor or not, which means a lengthy delay should United ever hold an auction or enter into proper negotiations. Meanwhile, the value of the property is likely to decline because papers need constant attention by committed owners, one of the major reasons that all the Express titles have lost circulation consistently in the past 30 years.

My soundings among the Express staff show a clear split between the younger intake and those who have been with the paper for a long time. The majority, especially among the old brigade, tend to favour a Mail takeover while the minority, including most of those who have joined under Boycott and prefer the paper's liberal political agenda, fear Mail ownership. Some of this vocal group doubt the Mail's sincerity in promising to create a politically neutral paper in the style of its free Metro. Plenty of other journalists don't think it feasible anyway, arguing that British popular papers are driven by their partisan passions.

Rightly, a long-time journalist friend also pointed out the fallacy of my claim last week when I wrote: "I don't believe any news is impartial." News, he said, is impartial. It's the presentation, selection and omission which reveals partiality.

True enough. The floods are news. The threats by fuel protesters are news. The continuing railway hold-ups are news. But there has been a huge difference between the presentation of that news in the Mirror and the Daily Mail.

Last Thursday, for example, the Mirror's front page attacked the protest leader David Handley: "Stop This Silly Fuel", while the Mail splashed on supposed panic-buying of petrol under the headline: "Here We Go Again".

The Mirror played down the rush to the pumps, carrying a small picture inside, while the Mail's central message amounted to an incitement to panic, despite a leader telling readers to avoid being talked into a crisis by the government! News may be impartial, but what about the spin?

webTitle: Operation to separate conjoined twins under way

fields.headline: Operation to separate conjoined twins under way
fields.standfirst: Talk about it
fields.trailText:
Doctors are expected to operate today to separate conjoined twins Jodie and Mary.
Talk about it
fields.body:
A complex 15-hour operation to separate conjoined twins Jodie and Mary is under way, health officials said today.

The surgery at St Mary's hospital, Manchester, will almost certainly mean the death of the weaker twin Mary but should give her sister Jodie the chance of a relatively normal life.

In a statement the hospital said: "We can confirm the operation is taking place today.This complex operation is expected to last approximately 15 hours and involves a team of up to 20 staff."

The twins were born in August and the original timetable for the operation was that it should be carried out in the first three months of the twins' lives.

On Friday, the Prolife Alliance failed in two dramatic court attempts to halt the operation.

First the high court, and then the court of appeal, rejected an application to have the official solicitor, Laurence Oates, removed as Mary's legal guardian and replaced by the Alliance's director, Bruno Quintaville.

The separation is the climax to a legal battle which started nearly three months ago.

Doctors went to the high court in August and won the right to separate the twins despite their parents objections. They are devout Roman Catholics from the Maltese island of Gozo and are opposed to the operation on religious grounds.

In September they launched a privately funded appeal against the high court decision which they subsequently lost.

The twins are joined at the abdomen with arms and legs at right angles to their conjoined upper bodies. Their spines are fused.

Mary is described as having "primitive brain" functions while Jodie is thought to have normal mental functions. Mary is draining the life from her sister as she relies on her for oxygen and blood circulation.

It has been reported that their parents have agreed a TV deal with Granada to appear on Tonight with Trevor McDonald. Money they are paid for their interview will be put into a trust to pay for Jodie's medical care once she has been separated from her twin.

Pro-life campaigners described the operation as "eugenic". A spokesman for ProLife Alliance, claimed Mary's life was being extinguished because she was mentally impaired.

A spokesman said: "It is difficult not to see certain eugenic parallels in the series of judgments against baby Mary in the past weeks. These are very sad times for English law and English medicine."

webTitle: Tiscali launches bid for World Online

fields.headline: Tiscali launches bid for World Online
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Italian telecoms and internet company Tiscali is to launch its official bid for Dutch-based internet service provider World Online today, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Italian telecoms and internet company Tiscali is to launch its official bid for Dutch-based internet service provider World Online today.

Tiscali said it had received commitments for 62.1% of World Online shares, including the 8% owned by US chip manufacturer Intel.

The merger of Tiscali and World Online will create the second largest ISP in Europe in terms of subscriber numbers, after Deutsche Telekom subsidiary T-Online.

Channel 5 directors have drawn up plans for a 50% increase in the channel's broadcasting budget next week to £180m. P21

John Kampfner, former political correspondent on Radio 4's Today programme, describes Westminster's attempts to influence the show. P2&3
Roy Greenslade says Daily Express editor Rosie Boycott is against a Daily Mail bid for the paper. P3

Novelist Bill Fitzhugh discusses the use of product placement in his latest work. P9
Merope Mills meets some of the young hopefuls who are benefiting from the BBC Talent drive. P10

Directors at Camelot will earn a bonus of up to £2m if their lottery franchise is renewed. P2
The Surrey police force has closed down a "bent copper" website run by a member of its workforce. P6
A cemetry in northern Italy is doing booming business - it is for bookworms mourning the death of characters from classic novels. P14
Lord Hollick, the boss of United News & Media and the Express newspapers, is said to have demanded a non-refundable deposit of £60m from the Daily Mail, so the would-be-buyer can view the financial accounts of the titles. P26

Follow-up on Sunday Times exclusive about confidential document drawn up by BBC2 controller Jane Root. It says the channel should be more like the Daily Telegraph, with more programmes on food and the aristocracy. P1
An open letter to Ms Root, demanding she drops her fixation with the 18-24 age bracket. P15
BBC producers are worried by sadistic nature of The Weakest Link. P4
Trials of internet voting are set to take place in the UK over the next 12 months. P7
US talk show icon Larry King says Tony Blair makes a great interview subject. P13
BT to announce the partial flotation of its mobile phone operations on Thursday. P25
Search engine Yahoo! resumes a French court case today, in which French anti-racist groups are seeking to block online sales of Nazi memorabilia. P29
Bidders for the Express newspapers furious over Lord Hollick's alleged deposit demands, are accusing him of favouritism to the Hinduja brothers. P4
The negative, personalised TV adverts in the US presidential elections have been nasty. P13
BT is to broadcast Thursday's interim results presentation live on the net, prompting fears that hackers might get in on the act. P17
Theatre director David KS Tse is using computer animation to simulate computer games in his Plymouth-based, multi-media production. P10

FINANCIAL TIMES

The Hinduja Brothers are said to have approached regional newspaper group Trinity Mirror over a circulation and distribution deal if they win control of the Express Newspapers. P38
Music giant BMG is to lose two top executives only days after parent Bertelsmann signed a deal with online music site Napster. P42

DAILY MAIL

Oprah Winfrey has signed a two-year TV contract worth £70m a year. P5
Andreas Whittam Smith, president of the film censoring British Board of Classification, wants more sex shops in order to curb the unlicensed trade in pornography. P33

DAILY EXPRESS

Trevor McDonald's Tonight Show has been condemned for offering £150,000 to the parents of Jodie and Mary, the tragic siamese twins. P15
A Channel 4 documentary will claim that the drug-fuelled lifestyle of Michael Hutchence caused the death of his lover Paula Yates. P21
The paper runs a feature on pop stars and TV characters who unwittingly spark a craze in certain products, such as Wallace and Gromit. P34&35

THE SUN

EastEnders star Clare Wilkie, who plays Sandra di Marco, is being axed from the BBC soap. P11
Pig puppets Pinky and Perky are to make a comeback on the BBC's Children In Need appeal. P21

THE MIRROR

Britain is drinking less beer despite advertisers spending twice as much promoting it, from £62m in 1979 to £135m in 1999. P17
Paula Yates best friend speaks to Channel 4 about day she found the TV star dead. P8

DAILY STAR

Who will win the chart battle between Westlife and The Spice Girls. The ones with the biggest marketing budget? P11

AND FINALLY

TV comic Frank Skinner is to impersonate singing fish Billy Bass on his show tonight, while dressed as new England soccer boss Sven Goran Eriksson. The joke's in there somewhere... P3
