fields.headline: My life in spin city
fields.standfirst: After 16 months as political correspondent on the Today programme, John Kampfner has left the BBC. He lifts the lid on Westminster's constant attempts to influence the opinion-former's favourite.
fields.trailText: After 16 months as political correspondent on the Today programme, John Kampfner has left the BBC. He lifts the lid on Westminster's constant attempts to influence the opinion-former's favourite
fields.body:
It took me less than a minute to make the 20-yard walk from Studio S1 of Television Centre to my desk at the Today programme. It was 6.35am one Thursday in the middle of September and, as ever, my mobile phone was ringing. "Your report was wrong. We demand a correction." It was the duty Downing Street press officer. I inquired what the problem was and then suggested that there was nothing to apologise for.

A short while later the phone rang again. It was Joe Irvine, John Prescott's special adviser. "You're talking off the top of your head," he shouted. Again, I talked it through with him. Every 15 minutes or so over the next hour, I heard more of the same from different members of the government media machine. They even faxed me a statement, setting out the words I should use for my "correction".

At about 7.30am, I phoned Alastair Campbell. I had called him late the previous evening - I tried to call either him or his deputy, Godric Smith, most evenings. The same went for any of the Tories - Amanda Platell, Nick Wood or Andrew Scadding. The night before, Campbell had been cooperative and polite. That morning was different.

"I'm fed up with the garbage you've been putting out. Where's your social responsibility? You're just regurgitating the Daily Mail." I told him I had been particularly busy that morning fielding calls from his people, and hadn't yet got round to reading the Mail.

"I'm not going to talk to you until you get into that studio and apologise," he continued. At 8.10am, Alan Milburn was the government minister on the block. He began by making clear, from what sounded suspiciously like a written text, that he would like to correct the erroneous impression I had given earlier in the programme. (You can rarely tell nowadays whether politicians are using crib sheets, as they tend to use remote studios rather than travel to W12 for interviews.)

The crime I had committed happened to be on the day the fuel blockades were coming to a head. Nerves were understandably fraught. At 6.30am I had reminded listeners of John Prescott's assertion, early in the life of this government, that he would have failed in his job had he not reduced the number of journeys made by car. I asked, rhetorically, what had happened to the government's green agenda of prising people out of their vehicles and on to public transport. What the officials insisted I had said was "pricing people" out of their cars. They had misheard me. Either way, I didn't see what the difference was. Any government serious about dealing with our third-world transport system would have been braver about stating its intentions. But, no, ministers were now going out of their way to make it clear that they had never wanted to harm the floating-voter car-driver.

That morning was an extreme example of something that happened almost every day of my 16 months as the Today programme's political correspondent. Sometimes the complaints contained fruity expletives. I became so used to the monster phone call - from all sides - that mornings weren't quite the same if my mobile or pager remained silent.

There were two reasons for the hypersensitivity - the programme itself, and what I was trying to do on it. I saw my role as part reporter, setting out the day's agenda, and part commentator/analyst. In doing so I frequently sailed close to the wind. The staple of the job is the so-called "6.30". For those who haven't heard it - and I must confess that until I joined the BBC I had never listened before 7am - the slot is supposed to be a briefing by three or four correspondents of the top stories of the day. And politics, for better or worse, is invariably one of them. On average I would then have one or two more slots in the course of the rest of the programme, sometimes a package, sometimes another live. I interpreted my job as explaining what is really going on - sometimes through an original story, sometimes an original take on the mainstream story. And, of course, when you take risks, you make mistakes. When I got facts wrong I tried to correct them later in the programme. When that was impossible, I would phone or write to whoever made the complaint. Where I would not budge was on a piece I knew to be right but difficult for one side to take.

Another example: last February, Today did a special programme from Brussels. This was a conspicuous attempt to take a sceptical (in the original sense of the word) look at the EU, its institutions and British policy. The programme led to a five-page letter of complaint from Campbell. He was most annoyed with my 8.10am package, leading into an interview with Robin Cook, in which I set out all the various contradictions in government policy, quoting various ministers from other countries as expressing frustration at the UK's inability to move on the euro or other issues.

Such complaints lead to much soul-searching at the corporation. A reply was drafted, seeking to rebut each point line by line. Instead the decision was taken to send an extremely short reply, making clear that all the facts had been looked into, but the BBC rejected the criticism and said it had no intention of going down the route of a deconstruction of every package that is transmitted. Such responses are absolutely vital. More often than not BBC journalists complain of managers caving in under pressure.

It is not that every complaint by a politician is wrong; far from it. Sometimes ministers are not given enough time to make their points before being pummelled by a presenter; sometimes the programme might try too hard to get an item picked up by the Press Association and followed up later by the papers. Sometimes ministers are tackled on something outside their remit, and not on the issue they thought they were coming on to discuss. But these are matters of judgment, not conspiracy or bias. Ministers have dropped the line they tried at the start of this government that the Today programme is no longer important; Tony Blair once, famously, said that he preferred to watch GMTV.

The problem is that far too often the spin doctors, the advisers and the politicians themselves are just trying it on. They will do virtually anything. I remember Gordon Brown's effervescent spinner, Ian Austin, saying to me down the telephone line, without a hint of irony: "What you should really be saying in your piece is that the Chancellor is prudent for a purpose." Sometimes they will go to a junior producer on the desk to get something changed; sometimes they will complain only after the event to a particular executive they know. I always preferred the in-your-face approach. I would have a good laugh with John Reid, the Scottish Secretary and unofficial minister for the Today programme, each time he went on to the programme to slag off a piece I had just done.

Sometimes they refuse to appear - Robin Cook has tried this route several times; more recently, so has William Hague. Sometimes it is because a particular politician refuses to debate with another politician; sometimes it is in protest at their treatment the previous time they were on.

One former minister, who usually took part from remote studios, boasted to me that once, when he didn't like the way an interview was going, he pressed the "hang up" button. I could not tell whether or not he was having me on. Sometimes there are fraught negotiations about who appears for the government. "No, we don't want Margaret Beckett for the third day running," the night editor might tell the Downing Street press officer. "Then we won't put anyone up," comes the reply. It becomes a game of brinkmanship.

And sometimes it comes down to internal BBC rivalry - the Today programme has a tendency to stand politicians down at the last minute after finding out that they have had the temerity to do an interview on Newsnight the night before. The uncomfortable truth is that politicians need "Toady", as it is known at the BBC, as much as the programme needs them.

Politicians who don't try it on - such as Jack Straw, David Blunkett and Michael Portillo - tend to come off best. The special advisers and press officers, who are perhaps more subtle - who realise that some days they win, some days they lose - are the ones who are listened to most.

Yet, the larger the general election looms, the more they - the spinners of all parties, all interest groups - will try to bludgeon programmes into submission. After all, the tactic has so often worked in the past. On many news outlets there has been a culture of caution, the bland, the "on the one hand, on the other" school of journalism too often seen as the best means of achieving balance. There has been little incentive for correspondents to stick their necks out. The Today programme, The World at One and Newsnight have tried to go against the grain.

The corporation has whole armies of executives whose job it is to fret about the output. One old hand said to me, after a piece I did about Mo Mowlam and her problems with Downing Street: "Very interesting. Very controversial. Are you sure you got your facts right?" They worry about politicians. But they particularly worry about the press. Each morning, huge piles of cuttings arrive for each executive, containing every mention of the BBC over the previous 24 hours. Papers are regarded with unhealthy reverence. They are seen as founts of all wisdom when they break political stories and, far too often, criticism of the corporation leads to anguished meetings.

Ultimately it comes down to what people want the output to be. Many politicians want it just to regurgitate what they say. They maintain it is not the job of the BBC journalist to interpret. But what may have been right in the past may not be right now. Recent appointments suggest that the BBC may be becoming more confident in dealing with controversy, more robust in taking on those who complain. It could, at a time when it most needs it, rediscover a new model for public service broadcasting - to reconnect viewers and listeners with politics by, perish the thought, being more brave, more interesting. To coin another Prescott phrase: traditional values in a modern setting.

 John Kampfner is an author, commentator and broadcaster.

fields.headline: 'The best job in the world'
fields.standfirst: Students may only be interested in reading about mice in the halls of residence and cheap beer in the uni bar, but editing a university newspaper is a great way into journalism. Matt Wells on this year's media wannabes.
fields.trailText: Students may only be interested in reading about mice in the halls of residence and cheap beer in the uni bar, but editing a university newspaper is a great way into journalism. Matt Wells on this year's media wannabes.
fields.body:
I was a terrible student newspaper editor. My vision for our paper was to turn it into the Daily Telegraph of university publications, which was a really bad idea, because the Daily Telegraph is by most measures a very good newspaper and we were by most similar measures really terrible journalists. Anyway, students generally want to read stories about the mice in their halls of residence rather than travel features about Czechoslovakia. (We did both, and I know which one now makes me cringe when I look at it.)

Unsurprisingly, Birmingham University's student magazine was never shortlisted under my stewardship in the Guardian's annual student media awards. Despite these shortcomings, it launched the career of a BBC children's TV presenter, nurtured the talents of a prominent newsreader's son, and (fortunately or not, depending on your point of view) confirmed my desire to be a reporter.

Whether the newspaper, magazine or website is produced from an attic in the students' union or a purpose-built campus office, almost every higher educational establishment has some sort of student media scene. With advances in technology, producing a student publication has become easier and cheaper than ever. And as the media in general expands more university and college students are turning to their publications for that essential work experience before hitting the real world.

Guy Adams, 22, who won the overall prize at this year's awards and was student journalist of the year for the second year running, says his experience at Sheffield University's Steel Press was invaluable. "You have to get involved in student journalism, because it's the one time in your life when you're given free rein, and don't get bollocked if it all goes wrong."

Adams, who has now graduated, is freelancing for the Daily Telegraph's Peterborough diary and has won six weeks at the Guardian as part of his prize. He says his experience as an editor gave him, early on, the perspective of someone who commissions and edits stories as well as originates them. He adds: "As a reporter on a student paper you have to find stories yourself, so you sometimes have to be quite inventive."

At a recent Top of the Pops event in Sheffield, a pushy young man with a mini-disc recorder was at the front of the pack to interview Craig David and Melanie C backstage, looking for all the world as if he were from Radio 1 or the local commercial network. In fact, he turned out to be from Swansea University's radio station. It was a stark indication that standards are rising fast.

This year, there were more entries than ever for the Guardian's student media awards, with hundreds of applications from all over the country. The judges, who included the Guardian's editor Alan Rusbridger and broadcasters Jon Snow and Mark Thomas, said they were particularly struck by the quality of entries. Adams agrees: "It's improving every year."

Working in student media is almost always immense fun - although it rarely contributes to exam success - but can often seem a lonely business. There is no training, no guidance and no peer review - you just sit in front of a computer and get on with it. That's why the Guardian runs a conference on the day of the awards ceremony, where student journalists can meet established professionals, and each other.

This year, students heard the Newsnight presenter Jeremy Vine deliver a strong advertisement for the profession; questioned the Guardian's website staff over the advances and opportunities in new media, and were told how columnists and editors view their changing profession.

One thing emerged clearly - there is no longer a straightforward entry route into journalism. Will Woodward, the Guardian's education editor, outlined his traditional journey from student newspaper to the Guardian via journalism college, local and regional newspapers and the Mirror. Mediatheguardian.com's Amy Vickers took a circuitous route through the trade press and does not have a formal journalistic qualification to her name ("doing a course just lands you in £4,000 debt when you can learn all you need on the job"), while columnist Gary Younge started on the paper as a translator.

Vickers advises aspiring journalists to be clear about what they want to do. There is no reason to make tea for nothing in a local newsroom for six months and hope someone throws you a press release, when there are scores of trade magazines and websites which are clamouring for dedicated, specialised - and not necessarily experienced - staff to write copy for cash, she says. Others, however, counsel a more traditional route.

But whatever way you go, the words of Will Woodward at last week's conference are worth bearing in mind when you're at your lowest ebb: "It's the best job in the world."

fields.headline: Marketeers come to their senses
fields.trailText: 8.30am Wake up and smell the coffee... A marketing agency has launched a new agency dedicated to so called "sensory marketing", writes Claire Cozens
fields.body:
Shoppers are already familiar with the aroma of freshly baked bread greeting their entrance to supermarket.

And although they may not know it, Thomas Pink devotees are gently cajoled towards a purchase with the smell of freshly laundered shirts.

Now, a marketing agency has seized the initiative by launching a new agency dedicated to so called "sensory marketing" - the invisible incentives deployed by sharp retailers

Carlson Marketing Group, a marketing consultancy that counts Nestle, Scottish Courage and UDV among its clients, decided to set up the agency to provide its clients with an alternative to traditional marketing.

The new agency will be called Emote and will be the UK's first dedicated sensory marketing agency. It will be headed by Brona Connolly and its first client will be the video-on-demand service, Videonet. Emote has also signed up a work-related dot.com.

"Everyone knows that shops use coffee and bread smells and that's how it all started," says Ms Connolly.

"But sensory marketing can be used in lots of other ways, such as on packaging and in design. Most traditional marketing is very visual - companies are missing out by not using the other five senses."

Starbucks already uses coffee grinds in the packaging for its fresh coffee products. And a Leicester University study found that music can also influence customer choice.

One supermarket found that 76% of the bottles of wine it sold were French when it played French music in the store. When German Bierkeller music was played, German drinks became more popular.

But until now, sensory marketing has been mainly about smell.

In 1995 Woolworth's decided to pump 20 of its stores with the smell of mulled wine in the four-week run-up to Christmas.

The move was more of a PR stunt than a genuine marketing technique, but the commercial value of sensory marketing should not be underestimated. In one American study, shoppers bought more expensive bottles of wine when they heard classical music than when country music was played.

Geoff Crook, director of MA studies at St Martin's College of Art & Design, will act as a consultant to Emote.

"Sensory marketing is the oldest technique in the world," he said. "Just think of going to an Italian food shop, where you are encouraged to touch and smell the produce and the shopkeeper offers you things to taste. It's much easier to wrap things up in plastic and put a picture on the packaging but that makes your products far less inviting."

fields.headline: Sindy joins Barbie on the web
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Sindy is to get her own website as manufacturer Pedigree Toys gears up for a pre-Christmas marketing push. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Sindy is to get her own website as manufacturer Pedigree Toys gears up for a pre-Christmas marketing push.

Visitors to www.sindy.com will be able to dress a Sindy doll in a range of outfits, play a Sindy colouring game and read Sindy's Secret Diary to find an update on her latest adventures.

Users will also be able to download Sindy-branded party invitations to send to their friends.

The site was created by digital marketing agency Monitor Media and brand specialist Pipeline. The two companies have previously collaborated on projects for Ericsson, IBM, Courage and Hasbro.

The launch of Sindy's website comes just weeks after the Barbie FM internet radio station was launched with the backing of toy giant Mattel

fields.headline: BlueWater unveils Christmas ad campaign
fields.trailText: 8am: BlueWater, Europe's largest shopping development, is gearing up for Christmas with its biggest ad campaign yet, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
BlueWater, Europe's largest shopping development, is gearing up for Christmas with its biggest ad campaign yet.

A multimillion pound national TV, press and radio campaign, breaking this week, positions the shopping centre as a far better option than London's over-crowded and crime-ridden West End.

The £1.2bn complex in Kent, which opened in March last year, stretches over 50 acres, has 320 shops including three anchor stores - John Lewis, Marks & Spencer and House of Fraser - and is pulling in an estimated 25m visitors per year. It employs 6,700 staff.

The campaign, created by Banks Hoggins O'Shea/FCB, will feature the trademark blue background and will highlight the centre's Christmas opening hours and some of its unique facilities.

webTitle: C5 content budget to rise by 50%

fields.headline: C5 content budget to rise by 50%
fields.trailText: 8am: Channel 5 directors have drawn up plans for a 50% increase in the broadcaster's programming budget next year to £180m, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
Channel 5 directors have drawn up plans for a 50% increase in the broadcaster's programming budget next year to £180m.

The figure, up from £120m this year, is designed to underpin the repositioning of the channel away from its reliance on cheap imports and soft porn.

Directors from RTL, the pan-European media group which now controls Channel 5, are understood to be backing the increase. The prospect of a significantly higher investment could prove the catalyst for Lord Hollick's United News & Media to make a decision on whether it wants to remain as a shareholder.

United owns 35% of Channel 5 but is expected to quit the television market entirely after selling its three ITV franchises earlier this year.

Neither Lord Hollick nor RTL chief executive Didier Bellens have yet rubber-stamped the increase in the programming budget, which is planned to take effect from January 2001.

Channel 5 will hope the extra cash will give the station new impetus. Since gaining control earlier this year, RTL has made it clear it wants to reshape the channel away from some of its more lurid content and into a more mainstream market.

The decision to reposition the channel was clearly illustrated 10 days ago when Channel 5 chief executive David Elstein was asked to leave the company. He was replaced by director of programming Dawn Airey.

A Channel 5 spokesman declined to comment on exact figures, but said: "Channel 5 managers have been pressing for an increased investment and we are awaiting feedback."

Channel 5 launched 3 years ago with a programming budget of only £100m. At the time it faced considerable criticism relating to the quality of reception and programming but has nevertheless managed to build an impressive consituency among viewers.

The channel has an audience share of 6% and RTL recently said the channel was aiming for a share of 10% within two to three years. Channel 5 has continued to attract criticism and was dubbed "channel filfth" by the more tub-thumping press. Many thought the broadcaster plumbed new depths when it aired a gameshow called Naked Jungle fronted by a nude Keith Chegwin.

Richard Eyre, director of strategy and content for RTL and former head of the ITV network, is fully behind the higher investment, sources said. fields.bodyText: Channel 5 directors have drawn up plans for a 50% increase in the broadcaster's programming budget next year to £180m. The figure, up from £120m this year, is designed to underpin the repositioning of the channel away from its reliance on cheap imports and soft porn. Directors from RTL, the pan-European media group which now controls Channel 5, are understood to be backing the increase. The prospect of a significantly higher investment could prove the catalyst for Lord Hollick's United News & Media to make a decision on whether it wants to remain as a shareholder. United owns 35% of Channel 5 but is expected to quit the television market entirely after selling its three ITV franchises earlier this year. Neither Lord Hollick nor RTL chief executive Didier Bellens have yet rubber-stamped the increase in the programming budget, which is planned to take effect from January 2001. Channel 5 will hope the extra cash will give the station new impetus. Since gaining control earlier this year, RTL has made it clear it wants to reshape the channel away from some of its more lurid content and into a more mainstream market. The decision to reposition the channel was clearly illustrated 10 days ago when Channel 5 chief executive David Elstein was asked to leave the company. He was replaced by director of programming Dawn Airey. A Channel 5 spokesman declined to comment on exact figures, but said: "Channel 5 managers have been pressing for an increased investment and we are awaiting feedback." Channel 5 launched 3 years ago with a programming budget of only £100m. At the time it faced considerable criticism relating to the quality of reception and programming but has nevertheless managed to build an impressive consituency among viewers. The channel has an audience share of 6% and RTL recently said the channel was aiming for a share of 10% within two to three years. webTitle: Joe Public fumes as chaos hits Blair's watch

fields.headline: Joe Public fumes as chaos hits Blair's watch
fields.standfirst: The weather, transport and fuel chaos might not all be Labour's fault, but, the public won't see it like that, explains chief political correspondent, Patrick Wintour
fields.trailText: The weather, transport and fuel chaos might not all be Labour's fault, but, the public won't see it like that, explains chief political correspondent, Patrick Wintour.
fields.body:
Sitting in his perch in Downing Street and reading civil service briefings on the chaos engulfing the nation, the prime minister is probably reflecting on how little real power his massive Commons majority provides him.

But sitting in his flooded home, unable to find a working train timetable and listening to the news of petrol queues forming outside his local filling stations, Mr Joe Public is seriously fed up and looking for someone to blame.

In Britain's merciless political culture, he is malevolently eyeing the men and women ensconced in Downing Street.

The nation's infrastructure is falling apart. Even the CBI bosses admit Britain resembles a banana republic. Ergo this government is not competent.

Labour officials can reasonably claim that, in this cocktail of crises, they have responsibility without power.

The railways are suffering from decades of under-investment and a form of privatisation only considered practicable by lawyers, accountants and Tory think tanks.

Equally, if motorists see a petrol queue and feel magnetised to join it, they have only themselves to blame for wasting their own time.

And if the rain is the most persistent since the 19th century, can this really make Blair's the worst government since Gladstone's?

On occasion, at times of crisis, the British rally round, conjure up the Dunkirk spirit and have a laugh.

Unfortunately, the modern electorate seems to be a less forgiving beast. Labour promised to make the trains run on time, yet they can hardly make them run on the rails.

Blair jacked up petrol duty for two years, at a time when world oil prices were just starting their slow ascent to the roof and beyond.

The quantity of rain that is falling on Britain may not be a matter for cabinet collective responsibility, but what happens to the water after it falls is another issue - especially if local councils seem too bureaucratic to help.

It all just adds to the fed-up factor.

So Tony Blair knows it would be fatal for a prime minister to shirk responsibility, even for acts of God. After all, even acts of God - and the Dome - happen on Blair's watch.

Fortunately for governments, the main way they assert power is through getting and spending - the budgetary process.

By chance, later this week, in his pre-budget report, chancellor Gordon Brown will have the ideal stage on which to show the country that ministers are still shaping events rather than being shaped by them.

However, if he blows the opportunity, largely by getting the balance wrong between tax cuts and public services, the government really will only have itself to blame.

webTitle: Park rangers' horse cull enrages public

fields.headline: Park rangers' horse cull enrages public
fields.standfirst: National songs may portray a romanticised ideal of man and nature, but, as Patrick Barkham discovered, conservationists are upsetting a lot of people
fields.trailText: National songs may portray a romanticised ideal of man and nature, but, as Patrick Barkham discovered, conservationists are upsetting a lot of people.
fields.body:
"He hails from Snowy River, up by Kosciusko's side,
Where the hills are twice as steep and twice as rough,
Where a horse's hoofs strike firelight from the flint stones every stride,
The man that holds his own is good enough."

The iconic Australian ballad, The Man from Snowy River, celebrated the courage of a 19th century horseman who was sent out into the country's rugged Great Dividing Range to round up a group of wild horses.

The modern-day man from Snowy River might be a park ranger. But their stock is far from iconic today, after rangers in helicopters shot 617 wild horses in Guy Fawkes national park, 300 miles north of Sydney.

The National Parks and Wildlife Service wants to cull another 2,000 wild horses in the Snowy Mountains Kosciusko national park, further south.

But New South Wales' environment minister Bob Debus last week ordered the suspension of all culling of feral horses in national parks while an independent review of the practice is conducted.

Local people were enraged after discovering badly mutilated carcasses scattered across the park. "The manner in which these horses were killed was absolutely barbaric. It was damned murder - that's what it was," said landowner Greg Everingham.

Mr Everingham contacted the RSPCA, which claimed it discovered several bullet-riddled horses had survived the cull to stagger on for another day.

Arriving on ships with the first white settlers in 1788, more than 300,000 feral horses now roam Australia.

Affectionately called brumbies, after James Brumb - a famous horse breeder who released horses into the wild in 1804 - they are part of the country's landscape and literature, even appearing alongside other Australian icons at the Olympic opening ceremony.

Across the arid wastes of the Northern Territory, 130,000 horses are shot each year.

Conservationists insist that the feral horses are pests, reaching plague proportions in many areas, where they damage biodiversity, displacing all kinds of native flora and fauna, from gum trees to kangaroos.

They also fear that some local farmers are slipping their horses into the national parks, where they can feast on prime, untouched grazing land.

"We're getting falsely sentimental over feral horses while the native wildlife that the parks are established to protect are forgotten about. It's a ridiculous situation," said Noel Plumb of the Colong Foundation for Wilderness.

"Horses are very hard hooved whereas Australian native animals have soft pads.

"Many of our soils are poor and easily erodable, so when large mobs of horses move about these landscapes they quickly do a lot of damage," Mr Plumb explained.

The horses congregate around water, trampling banks, fouling water and damaging aquatic life and the water habitats of unique mammals such as platypuses.

The National Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS) said its first aerial cull was long overdue and had only been made possible after bush fires had cleared out undergrowth, enabling helicopters to track and kill the horses.

Conservationists also pointed out that it is during periods where trees and plants sprout back after fires that native plants are most vulnerable to being eaten by the horses.

However, the Australian Veterinary Association (AVA) said that aerial culling should only be considered in Australia's dry open plains, where helicopters could easily track and put down injured animals without causing undue suffering.

"The very rugged forest terrain in the Guy Fawkes national park is not suitable for this because of the obvious difficulty in conducting the operation in the most humane manner possible," said vice president Dr Garth McGilvray.

Animal welfare groups suggest that birth control methods could be a more humane alternative to sharpshooters in helicopters.

But this requires horses to be rounded up, which is deemed impractical after 17 attempts to round up wild horses in New South Wales national parks in the last decade only resulted in the culling of around 150 horses.

It is also claimed that the slow and expensive mustering of horses is more stressful than aerial culling.

AVA president Dr Tony English is leading the inquiry into the culling. It have already condemned the "lack of concern by the National Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS) for the welfare of the many horses which suffered terribly in this incident".

Conservationists fear that the suspension of culling will give the mobs of horses more time to damage the rugged and yet fragile cliffs and gullies of the Great Dividing Range.

While the inquiry talks, the horses roam free. There is no man from Snowy River to round them up.

"Then they lost him for a moment, where two mountain gullies met
In the ranges, but a final glimpse reveals
On a dim and distant hillside the wild horses racing yet,
With the man from Snowy River at their heels"

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report headed, Two square miles of housing hell, page 12, October 24, we said Harold Best, MP for Leeds North West, and his wife had their eight student neighbours evicted. In fact, an action was taken by Leeds city council against the landlord owner of the house next door to the Bests for a breach in planning law. The Bests were witnesses in the public inquiry which found in favour of Leeds city council. The students who were in occupation at the time of the inquiry were at the end of their agreed lease.
fields.body:
In a report headed, Two square miles of housing hell, page 12, October 24, we said Harold Best, MP for Leeds North West, and his wife had their eight student neighbours evicted. In fact, an action was taken by Leeds city council against the landlord owner of the house next door to the Bests for a breach in planning law. The Bests were witnesses in the public inquiry which found in favour of Leeds city council. The students who were in occupation at the time of the inquiry were at the end of their agreed lease.

In our piece about the new Dyson washing machine, page 25, Finance, November 3, we puzzled some readers by our reference to a time of five hours 54 minutes for "an average weekly load". The time referred to the total accumulated washing time of 30lb of washing (14 kilos); not to the average time for a single load.

Our reference to the national "herd" of sheep, a leader, page 23, November 2, should have been to the national flock.

webTitle: Letters: Films and all that jazz

fields.headline: Films and all that jazz
fields.trailText:
Tony Benn said during the debate on what was to be done with North Sea oil revenues that the windfall should be ring-fenced and invested in the country's infrastructure (Thousands evacuated as floods worsen, November 4). Pity it got used to destroy the unions and manufacturing industry.
Stanley Graham
Barnoldswick, Lancs
fields.body:
Tony Benn said during the debate on what was to be done with North Sea oil revenues that the windfall should be ring-fenced and invested in the country's infrastructure (Thousands evacuated as floods worsen, November 4). Pity it got used to destroy the unions and manufacturing industry.
Stanley Graham
Barnoldswick, Lancs

 Surely the way to solve the problems of motorists who keep topping up their cars is to insist on a minimum purchase of, say, £15?
Roger Fryatt
Dereham, Norfolk

 Blackboard Jungle was not the "first proper rock 'n' roll movie" (The highs and lows of film, Dumb?, November 4). Bill Haley's seminal Rock Around The Clock only appeared under the credits. Whenever violence and thuggery appeared in the film, it was jazz that was used to heighten the tension - the stock Hollywood device until the 60s. As for allocating "down" triangles to this film and Singin' in the Rain, one of the best, and certainly the funniest, musicals ever, one can only wonder at the point of this whole "dumb" exercise.
Brian Blain
London

 As far as amusing song titles go, Kinky Friedman is in a class of his own (A life in writing, Review, November 4). But I have never been clear whether songs such as Drop Kick Me Jesus Through the Goalposts of Life and They Don't Make Jews Like Jesus Anymore actually exist.
Frank Desmond
London

 Further to Joan Tozer's letter (November 1), my Mum used to sing I'll Be Your Sweetheart to me when I was a child. I now sing it to my daughter, who is five. I hope she still remembers it when she is the same age as Joan Tozer.
Alan Shaefer
Belper, Derbs

fields.headline: BSE agent
fields.trailText: Harash Narang was, with Alan Dickenson and David Adams, among the best qualified scientists dealing with BSE, none of whom was listened to. Narang pointed out that sheep suffered from two quite different diseases that the vets confused (Sheep slaughter fear over BSE, November 1). The trembling disease was less common in Britain than the scratching disease, but was well known in France, where it was called maladie folle or tremblante.
fields.body:
Harash Narang was, with Alan Dickenson and David Adams, among the best qualified scientists dealing with BSE, none of whom was listened to. Narang pointed out that sheep suffered from two quite different diseases that the vets confused (Sheep slaughter fear over BSE, November 1). The trembling disease was less common in Britain than the scratching disease, but was well known in France, where it was called maladie folle or tremblante.

Narang suggested the infective agent of the trembling disease may have been the source of BSE, whereas that of scrapie was not. How odd experts are now suggesting sheep may have two different diseases by having caught BSE from cows!
Colin Leakey
Cambridge

webTitle: Letters: Apartheid in the prison system

fields.headline: Apartheid in the prison system
fields.trailText: The murder of Zahid Mubarek at Feltham young offenders' institution (Sick institution in need of urgent cure, November 3) is yet another indictment of the prison service's failure to implement its excellent race policies and its inability to protect and treat all people with equity and fairness, irrespective of their colour.
fields.body:
The murder of Zahid Mubarek at Feltham young offenders' institution (Sick institution in need of urgent cure, November 3) is yet another indictment of the prison service's failure to implement its excellent race policies and its inability to protect and treat all people with equity and fairness, irrespective of their colour.

I have more than 18 years of association with the criminal justice system, including as a member of the prison service's race relations policy group. Ethnic minority prisoners and staff - and indeed members of boards of visitors like myself - continue to be treated like a herd of cattle in these bigoted institutions. Over the years I have become tired of hearing the same hypocritical apologies by successive director-generals of the prison service whenever there is a race incident.

The so-called independent board of visitors, many of whom are also magistrates, ought to be in a position to monitor the way that mentally disturbed and rabidly racist people are allowed to remain in such institutions. Yet their training has never covered race awareness. There is little hope that under the present apartheid culture, multiracial imprisonment will achieve much success.
Anver Jeevanjee
Member, board of visitors, Winchester prison

 Zahid Mubarek was convicted of the theft of £6 worth of razor blades and tampering with a car and sentenced to 90 days in Feltham - where he paid with his life. Two murder suspects in the Stephen Lawrence case were fined £100 each for stealing 14 kegs of alcohol from a pub (Lawrence pair stole drink, November 3). Why was Zahid in that prison in the first place? Racist justice, or what?
Ulrike Preuss
London

 A racist with a known history of violence is put in a youth custody cell with a young British Asian who, arguably, should never have been imprisoned in the first place. It results in a vicious racist killing. So much for the state's duty of care, and so much for taking racism seriously. Thirteen years ago we wrote: "Of increasing concern is the number of cases of assault, neglect or ill-treatment of black people in custody ... Racism is institutionalised and rooted in the agencies of law enforcement and imprisonment." We were dismissed as ultra-leftists whose politics warped our academic analysis.

Since then, along with the Institute of Race Relations, Inquest and the Runnymede Trust, we have continued to monitor and research controversial deaths using whatever paltry funding we can access. Despite sustaining and publishing this work, not one of the institutions responsible for the safe custody of men, women and children in prison has consulted with us or commissioned further research.
Dr Kathryn Chadwick
Prof Phil Scraton
Edge Hill University College

 In 1993 I helped establish Britain's first prison radio station at Feltham young offenders' institution and I am now involved in programmes to combat the appalling problems there. Yes, it needs greater investment and the government should reappraise the "benefits" of locking up children and keeping young men on remand for far too long. But there is more immediate help closer at hand.

Charitable trusts and foundations continue to invest in our ailing prison. With more than 15 voluntary agencies working inside Feltham, a committed and professional group of people, supported by governors and staff, is offering a wide range of programmes including essential first night support, counselling, numeracy and adult literacy support, mentoring, pre-release training, accommodation help, an advocacy programme and parenting skills. A much-needed multi-disciplinary skills workshop is being established for those over 18 and will be opened after Christmas.
Roma Hooper
Friends of Feltham

 There is no doubt that many of Feltham inmates have mental health problems with which the institution has struggled to cope. However, in the last year Feltham has acknowledged the extent of the problem and, in an innovative partnership with a local NHS trust, has made progress towards delivering mental health care at an equivalent level to that one would find in the NHS.

As the clinical director of forensic mental health services for the local trust and one of the consultant forensic psychiatrists responsible for the care of inmates at Feltham, I think credit needs to be given to those who have worked hard to change the culture of mental health care at Feltham.
Dr Kevin Cleary
Ealing, Hammersmith and Fulham Mental Health Trust

 Do we need any further justification for Lord Woolf's recent decision to set a minimum tariff for the killers of James Bulger? Lord Woolf recently described the "corrosive atmosphere" in young offenders' institutions, reiterating the view of Sir David Ramsbotham, chief inspector of prisons, that conditions in them are "unacceptable in a civilised society", as Sir Stephen Tumim before him also held. I have more than 18 years of association with the criminal justice system, including as a member of the prison service's race relations policy group. Ethnic minority prisoners and staff - and indeed members of boards of visitors like myself - continue to be treated like a herd of cattle in these bigoted institutions. webTitle: Scottish rethink on care of elderly puts McLeish 'puppet' tag in doubt

fields.headline: Scottish rethink on care of elderly puts McLeish 'puppet' tag in doubt
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Scotland's new first minister, Henry McLeish, is considering footing the bill for long-term care of the elderly north of the border, raising the prospect of a fresh divide between Holyrood and Westminster.
fields.body:
Scotland's new first minister, Henry McLeish, is considering footing the bill for long-term care of the elderly north of the border, raising the prospect of a fresh divide between Holyrood and Westminster.

In a move which will compound the differences created by the abolition of student tuition fees in Scotland, Mr McLeish has indicated that he will reconsider the findings of the Sutherland commission which recommended that the government pay for all nursing and personal care in residential homes.

The findings were rejected by Whitehall and by Mr McLeish's predecessor, Donald Dewar, who said they would meet the costs of nursing care but not personal care. It has been estimated that personal care for Scotland's elderly would cost £110m each year.

In an interview in a Sunday newspaper, Mr McLeish said he had been prompted to re-think the Scottish executive policy by the weight of public and political opinion.

"If you are rooted in public concern then you will know that if every organisation you talk to, every medical group, every local authority, the Sutherland people themselves, the parliamentary Labour party, the Liberal group, the opposition - then sometimes you just have to say to yourselves there is a firm body of opinion. Is what we have as a policy the right thing to do?"

Mr McLeish continued: "It doesn't necessarily mean you can change it overnight, because of resource implications. But... they have to take this kind of feeling on board. Never be so out of step that you can be accused of not listening."

A spokesman for Mr McLeish said that no decision had been taken and even if one was, it would be years before anything was in place. Budgets for the next three years have already been allocated for devolved departments.

"The first minister would not flag this up if he was not concerned about it," the spokesman said. "If he could find a way of doing more he would like to. Devolution means that within your budget you can do things differently if you want to. Look at tuition fees."

The move will also silence critics of Mr McLeish who have portrayed him as a Whitehall puppet. Mr McLeish made it clear following his election that he would not shirk reviewing executive policy.

A spokeswoman for Age Concern, meanwhile, has said organisations representing elderly people in England and Wales should be asking tough questions of the prime minister over his stance on the issue.

Under new health service plans unveiled this year, only the cost of nursing care in residential homes will be paid for from October next year. Thousands of elderly people have been forced to use their savings or sell their homes to pay for care once they can no longer look after themselves.

Sir Stewart Sutherland, who wrote the commission report, has been strongly critical of government failure to accept his recommendations. The commission had argued against any distinction between medical and personal care of the elderly.

"Our view was that to provide care for those in need at this stage in life was to follow the same principles of the national health service, that care should be free at point of delivery as the need is assessed objectively by clinicians and nurses and social workers," Sir Stewart said at the time.

webTitle: Starting up on the net: Rools co-founders

fields.headline: Then the questions came. We had to start working for our wine and nibbles
fields.standfirst:
Starting up
Net news
fields.trailText: When you are running your own business, your evenings are often not your own. The other week we attended an evening function hosted by one of our venture capitalists.
fields.body:
When you are running your own business, your evenings are often not your own. The other week we attended an evening function hosted by one of our venture capitalists.

Primarily intended as a report to their own investors, it was a rare and fascinating opportunity for us to meet the people whose money it is that we are working with - the investors' own investors. It was also a bit of a treat for us to see our investors justifying their activities rather than us justifying ours, for once.

The main body of the evening was spent with a presentation from the venture capitalists reviewing their investment year. This included a brief overview of each of the companies in the investment portfolio. It felt peculiar watching someone else, in this case the VC's representative on our board, give a presentation on our business.

You could also tell from the tone of these presentations - whether the company was being talked up or whether expectations were being set somewhat lower - how positively the VC viewed the respective businesses. This was a key measure of perceived progress, particularly as a number of these business, including our own, were still in the euphemistically termed "pre-revenue" stage.

There were also questions from the private investors. Among these, the general downturn in the value of internet stocks was the hottest topic. But a number of questions were addressed directly to representatives of the companies in attendance. We seemed to attract a disproportionate share.

The most persistent questioning concerned the public relations risks of launching a product for teenagers - particularly one that dealt with online purchasing. The fear was that we could be accused of encouraging irresponsible spending.

We needed to persuade the private investors - many of whom had teenage children - that we could deal with it. We had to start working for our wine and nibbles.

The nature of the discussion that followed reinforced for us the level of sensitivity that exists around delivering products for teenagers. This was brought into even starker relief last week when internet chatrooms, another online service that is incredibly popular with teenagers, made headlines after a teenage girl who had befriended and then been assaulted by a paedophile she met in an online chat room.

Chat rooms are inherently difficult to supervise. After all, anonymity and the ability to be someone else is a key part of the attraction for youngsters - you don't get conversations between DodgySheep and GlitterBabes in real life.

We do not have a chat room at Rools, but our partners at Teenfront.com have just launched one.

As a service for teenagers by teenagers they are simply responding to demand - for a long time now chat has been the service most requested by users in feedback that they have submitted via the Teenfront.com site.

Teenfront.com tries to protect users of the chat room by displaying clear guidelines for use, employing watchers to monitor the rooms and by banning transgressors. It is relatively easy to do while they are small but is going to require tight management as they grow.

Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools, an online payments service for teenagers.

fields.headline: Daniel in the lion's den
fields.standfirst: Daniel Barenboim's Berlin orchestra is one of the most celebrated in the world, renowned for its unique, silky tone. So why are the authorities trying to merge it with another? And who is making anti-semitic slurs? John Hooper meets an irate maestro.
fields.trailText: Daniel Barenboim's Berlin orchestra is one of the most celebrated in the world, renowned for its unique, silky tone. So why are the authorities trying to merge it with another? And who is making anti-semitic slurs? John Hooper meets an irate maestro.
fields.body:
For the past nine years, said Daniel Barenboim, he had been doing a "huge" job in Berlin. As artistic director of the Staatsoper and its orchestra, the Staatskapelle, he has been responsible not just for the creative revival of the two institutions, but also for their day-to-day administration. Now, everything he has achieved is in danger of being erased. And Barenboim is incandescent with anger.

It is not that he has lost his sense of humour. He often smiles and even tosses in the odd joke. But, as he makes his points, he leans towards you, sometimes holding you by the forearm, his eyes sparkling. "Do you understand?" he asks. And if you don't, then he's only too happy to go back and repeat his arguments till they are clear.

The upshot of nine years' work hangs on persuading the rest of the world that he is right, and that the men and women who run the Berlin city council are wrong. Their scheme to merge the Staatsoper, in the east of the city, with the Deutsche Oper in the west, has become a cultural cause celebre.

Like the fracture lines of a smashed mirror, its ramifications have darted in every direction, raising sensitive questions about the way the arts are funded in Germany, about how much culture a reunified Berlin can afford, about the authenticity of German reunification and even about whether Barenboim, an Argentinian-born Jew, is the victim of an anti-semitic plot.

At heart, though, it is a simple issue of conservation. You realise that the moment you hear Barenboim's musicians play. "The Staatskapelle has a very particular sound which, for want of a better term, is described as the German sound. It is a kind of sound that great German orchestras probably had before the war," he says. German music lovers call it sahnig ("creamy"). It arises mainly from the strings, but is enriched by the remarkable resonance and colour of the brass and winds.

"It is a sound that is based on a set of values that have gone slightly out of fashion today: the values of harmony, the values of legato, over the values of brilliance. In other words, it is a more spiritual and less athletic way of playing," says Barenboim.

The Staatskapelle's unique sound is one of many things, good and bad, to have survived intact in the aspic of the former East Germany. Barenboim's decision to take over what was then a relatively obscure orchestra surprised many. He had long since been recognised as one of the world's pre-eminent musicians. He gave his first public performance at the age of seven, and went on to a glittering career, first as a pianist, then as a conductor, and finally as a creative supremo, starting in London on the South Bank in 1968. He was married to cellist Jacqueline Du Pre.

Since arriving in Berlin in 1991, Barenboim has lifted the Staatskapelle into the top flight. Earlier this year, 50 critics polled by Opernwelt magazine voted it Orchestra of the Year. But he has taken care not to interfere with the singularity of that sound, which - he says - has a unique role to play in the unending debate over authenticity versus excellence.

"It is a very difficult question. What is it that makes Beethoven in some ways belong to the late 18th and early 19th centuries, and why is his message contemporary today? Each great work of art has two faces in my opinion: one [facing] towards its time and one towards the future, towards eternity. Now, when you talk about its face towards eternity, how far do you go in modernising the instruments and using the means of expression that didn't exist then? This is a question which can only be answered individually. Some musicians have answered it by saying, 'We want to play the original instruments'; others have said 'No'."

Gesturing towards the musicians of the Staatskapelle as they packed away their instruments, he said: "These people have maintained a line that was developed, as it were, with the composers - don't forget this is the orchestra that played for years under the leadership of Richard Strauss - you can't say it's not valid any more today."

Strauss was the musical director of the Staatsoper for a very long time: from 1898 to 1920. Creatively, the stakes in this row are high, which is why opponents of the council's plan tend to react - not with point-by-point refutation - but with bewildered outrage. It is rather as if environmentalists had learnt that China was intending to balance its budget by culling the remaining pandas.

"I think the idea that the Staatsoper could be made to disappear is so . . . so . . . so . . . disastrous ", splutters Barenboim, "that the question should be asked the other way round: how much extra money do we need to keep this treasure?"

We are talking in an unlikely setting: the peeling, stained auditorium of the Tacheles art centre on Oranienburgerstrasse. It began life as a squat by artists from east and west Berlin after the fall of the Wall, and has evolved into one of the city's most vibrant cultural institutions. As a melting pot for eastern and western values, Tacheles has a history that is strikingly reminiscent of that of the Staatsoper since 1991. And, like the Staatsoper, it is threatened with death by financial cuts under the council's plan. So high culture Staatsoper and deeply alternative Tacheles had joined forces. The Staatskapelle musicians - the men in white tie; the women in black dresses - have just been giving a concert in Tacheles's ineffably trashed auditorium.

The Berlin council, or Senat, which is heavily in the red, argues that the time has come to address the financial consequences of the cultural cold war. In their efforts to show that East or West was best, the authorities on either side of the Wall subsidised like crazy their respective orchestras, theatres, galleries and so on. The Senat has continued that tradition of generosity. Till now.

But Barenboim says he can make no sense of the arguments put forward by the councillor responsible for culture. "When he asked me whether I had a counter-proposal, my first question was: how much do you want, or do you need, to save? If you tell me you need to save 10 million marks, this is one thing. If you tell me you need to save 50 million marks, it is another thing. But he was unable to tell me how much money."

Barenboim agrees that the legacy of cold war is central to the debate - but in a quite different way. "The whole Berlin senate is the former West Berlin senate. The same people who were there in 1989 taking decisions for former West Berlin are now taking decisions for the whole of Berlin - and they cannot stomach what is happening in the east," he says.

"They are not going to destroy the building; they are going to destroy the people inside, close it for three or four years with the excuse that it has to be redone . . . then they will reopen it with great pomp in 2006 or 2007 as a western institution."

In today's Germany, this is social Semtex. Since reunification 10 years ago, east Germans have seen their economy gutted and their politics sidelined. Westerners have taken over their universities, companies and bureaucracies. Now, one of the world's pre-eminent musical geniuses is telling them that one of their most valuable cultural assets is about to be raped by the westerners out of sheer spite.

"It's a takeover," insists Barenboim. "We talk about German reunification. But in Berlin, it is not reunification: it's a takeover. It is the western economy that is rebuilding Potsdamer Platz. It is western money that has built the centre of Berlin. Reunification, in my understanding of the word, means to unite two things that belong together and were separated. But there is no reunification in Berlin."

Those sort of remarks alone would ensure a venomous struggle over the future of opera in the city. But, amid a bout of national soul-searching over the neo-Nazi right, allegations have been made that the proposed merger also has undertones of anti-semitism. The man who used to be the councillor responsible for the arts in Berlin suggested as much in an article in the newspaper, Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung.

On the question of anti-semitism, Barenboim, who has had a life-long love affair with German music and made an immense personal commitment to its future, is impossible to pin down. He denies and asserts within the same breath. Yet he addresses the issue in hugely emphatic language. "I don't for one minute believe it is a general sentiment," he says.

Then he adds: "But they don't understand that there is a difference, even today, between being an anti-semite in Great Britain or the United States and to be one in Germany. I don't for one second believe that the German nation should be [asked to assume] collective guilt - certainly not so many generations afterwards. Absolutely not.

"But I do, by the same token, firmly believe that it is the responsibility of each German of any generation to make sure that the events of the 1940s do not repeat themselves. And therefore I think it is absolutely apt and necessary to expect greater sensitivity."

Does he mean greater sensitivity than Germans had shown towards him during his stay among them? "I haven't felt that personally," he replies.

But then he adds: "I know a lot of Germans - obviously, working in Germany for so long - and I feel many of them have not really worked out for themselves the problems of the Nazis and what the Nazis have left here . . . I believe that the Nazi time has to be seen as a dreadful time, but one part of German history and not the only part of German history. But they have not been able to work it out and therefore, as a reaction, said 'Let's not talk about it. Let's leave it aside', especially immediately after the war. So there are a lot of people in Germany still today who are ignorant about it."

The remark which lay at the origin of the claims of anti-semitism was made by no less a figure than Klaus Landowsky, the leader of the Christian Democrat group on the city council. As he acknowledged, he said that the future of opera in the city lay between the conductor of the Deutsche Oper, whom he described in glowing terms, "and the Jew Barenboim".

I put it to Barenboim that this is pretty raw stuff.

The man concerned had apologised, he says.

"This chapter is closed."

"When he asked me whether I had a counter-proposal, my first question was: how much do you want, or do you need, to save? If you tell me you need to save 10 million marks, this is one thing. If you tell me you need to save 50 million marks, it is another thing. But he was unable to tell me how much money." Barenboim agrees that the legacy of cold war is central to the debate - but in a quite different way. "The whole Berlin senate is the former West Berlin senate. The same people who were there in 1989 taking decisions for former West Berlin are now taking decisions for the whole of Berlin - and they cannot stomach what is happening in the east," he says. "They are not going to destroy the building; they are going to destroy the people inside, close it for three or four years with the excuse that it has to be redone . . . then they will reopen it with great pomp in 2006 or 2007 as a western institution." In today's Germany, this is social Semtex. Since reunification 10 years ago, east Germans have seen their economy gutted and their politics sidelined. Westerners have taken over their universities, companies and bureaucracies. Now, one of the world's pre-eminent musical geniuses is telling them that one of their most valuable cultural assets is about to be raped by the westerners out of sheer spite. "It's a takeover," insists Barenboim. "We talk about German reunification. But in Berlin, it is not reunification: it's a takeover. It is the western economy that is rebuilding Potsdamer Platz. It is western money that has built the centre of Berlin. Reunification, in my understanding of the word, means to unite two things that belong together and were separated. But there is no reunification in Berlin." Those sort of remarks alone would ensure a venomous struggle over the future of opera in the city. But, amid a bout of national soul-searching over the neo-Nazi right, allegations have been made that the proposed merger also has undertones of anti-semitism. The man who used to be the councillor responsible for the arts in Berlin suggested as much in an article in the newspaper, Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung. On the question of anti-semitism, Barenboim, who has had a life-long love affair with German music and made an immense personal commitment to its future, is impossible to pin down. He denies and asserts within the same breath. Yet he addresses the issue in hugely emphatic language. "I don't for one minute believe it is a general sentiment," he says. Then he adds: "But they don't understand that there is a difference, even today, between being an anti-semite in Great Britain or the United States and to be one in Germany. I don't for one second believe that the German nation should be [asked to assume] collective guilt - certainly not so many generations afterwards. Absolutely not. "But I do, by the same token, firmly believe that it is the responsibility of each German of any generation to make sure that the events of the 1940s do not repeat themselves. And therefore I think it is absolutely apt and necessary to expect greater sensitivity." Does he mean greater sensitivity than Germans had shown towards him during his stay among them? "I haven't felt that personally," he replies. But then he adds: "I know a lot of Germans - obviously, working in Germany for so long - and I feel many of them have not really worked out for themselves the problems of the Nazis and what the Nazis have left here . . . I believe that the Nazi time has to be seen as a dreadful time, but one part of German history and not the only part of German history. But they have not been able to work it out and therefore, as a reaction, said 'Let's not talk about it. Let's leave it aside', especially immediately after the war. So there are a lot of people in Germany still today who are ignorant about it." The remark which lay at the origin of the claims of anti-semitism was made by no less a figure than Klaus Landowsky, the leader of the Christian Democrat group on the city council. As he acknowledged, he said that the future of opera in the city lay between the conductor of the Deutsche Oper, whom he described in glowing terms, "and the Jew Barenboim". I put it to Barenboim that this is pretty raw stuff. The man concerned had apologised, he says. "This chapter is closed."

fields.headline: French fear home-grown beef
fields.standfirst:
Officials call in vain for calm: people suspect a cover-up
Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Schools all over France are expected to stop serving beef to children in their canteens, following the lead of many districts in Paris in responding to rising panic about the safety of French beef.
fields.body:
Schools all over France are expected to stop serving beef to children in their canteens, following the lead of many districts in Paris in responding to rising panic about the safety of French beef.

Europe's biggest beef exporter now finds itself the object of international distrust in its billion-pound meat industry after leading the campaign to bar British beef from Europe because of the risk from animals with BSE, mad cow disease.

A total ban on French beef has been imposed by Hungary. Other countries, including Russia, are preparing to follow suit. Some French restaurants and butchers are refusing to sell beef on the bone.

Many people now fear that eating beef could put them at risk of variant Creutzfeld Jakob Disease (vCJD), which is thought to come from the meat of cows that had BSE.

So far this year no more than 80 cases of BSE have been diagnosed in France, including two new cases reported on Friday. Last year 31 cases were reported.

Instead of reassuring consumers, the tightening of safety checks in June seems only to have increased public wariness after a series of recent food scandals ranging from infected duck liver paté to contaminated beef and lamb sausages.

The reinforced monitoring is concentrated in Normandy. Whole herds are destroyed if one case of BSE is found.

Public suspicion that the authorities might be concealing a wider outbreak was heightened last week when the Green movement, backed by President Jacques Chirac, demanded an immediate halt to sales of meat and bone meal from carcasses of cows for use as feed for poultry and pigs.

It is still legal in France for these products to be used this way.

Neither the publicly declared figures for BSE (expected to be no more than 100 animals this year), nor the two confirmed cases of vCJD are on the scale of the outbreak in Britain, where vCJD has killed 81 people since being identified by government scientists in late 1995.

But there are fears that the numbers could rise sharply, in part because of better detection but also, because of reports of cheating by some cattle dealers and breeders trying to cover up the disease.

The biggest shock was revealed a fortnight ago when some of France's most popular supermarket chains, led by Carrefour, admitted that a tonne of BSE-infected meat had been sold to customers after it got through the safety checks at an abattoir.

This coincided with a government request to Afsa, the independent food safety agency, to study the possible dangers of beef on the bone, including T-bone steaks and a French favourite, cte de boeuf.

Although under no obligation to react, the national steak restaurant chain Buffalo Grill withdrew the cuts from its menus this weekend and most butchers voluntarily followed suit.

The mayors of 11 of Paris's 20 districts have banned beef entirely from school menus, a measure likely to be widely followed in the provinces.

These actions prompted an urgent ministerial meeting as the weekend began, to try to calm public fears.

The consumers' minister, François Patriat, said there was no justification for an immediate withdrawal of bone meal while Afsa, which defied a EU ruling this year and outlawed the resumed import of British beef to France, said that a decision on bone meal would need at least four months' scientific study.

Mr Chirac's spokesman said that even tighter monitoring was needed to stop BSE-infected cattle reaching abattoirs, but the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, said France has already taken the most stringent precautions of any country to control BSE. And a BSE specialist, Jeanne Brugère-Picoux, said she was astonished at the latest panic, "at a time when it is obvious that the maximum exposure to risk is well behind us because of increased inspection".

Estimates of losses to farmers vary widely, but supermarkets say that beef sales are down 25-40% .

The farmers' union FNSEA is about to launch a publicity counter-offensive. Its slogan will be a traditional expression of self-satisfaction: "Je suis bien dans mon assiette," literally, I'm OK in my plate.

fields.headline: Newspaper unearths archaeologist's fake find
fields.trailText: A leading Japanese archaeologist has admitted that he planted stone artefacts which he subsequently "discovered" at an important stone-age site.
fields.body:
A leading Japanese archaeologist has admitted that he planted stone artefacts which he subsequently "discovered" at an important stone-age site.

Shinichi Fujimura, vice-chairman of the Tohoku Palaeolithic Institute, remained bowed - a Japanese sign of humility - throughout the press conference at which he admitted planting the items. "I did something I shouldn't have done," he said.

A newspaper had printed three pictures of him digging holes and burying artifacts on October 22. "He's right there in the photos, digging holes and putting stones in them. There's nothing more you can say," the institute's chairman, Toshiaki Kamata, said.

"All our work over the years is as good as ruined."

Mr Fujimura's team claimed to have found evidence of pillars that supported primitive dwellings at the site, 180 miles north-east of Tokyo.

But 61 of the 65 stone items dug up were from Mr Fujimura's own collection, Mr Kamata said, adding that Mr Fujimura had legitimately found a host of ancient items.

fields.headline: Home at last: Haile Selassie laid to rest
fields.trailText: Twenty five years after he died in mysterious circumstances and eight years after his remains were exhumed from beneath his successor's office, the former emperor of Ethiopia, Haile Selassie, was finally laid to rest yesterday.
fields.body:
Twenty five years after he died in mysterious circumstances and eight years after his remains were exhumed from beneath his successor's office, the former emperor of Ethiopia, Haile Selassie, was finally laid to rest yesterday.

His coffin was greeted by large crowds as it was carried through the streets of the capital, Addis Ababa. Awash with early morning light and against a background of wailing women, the procession was honoured by the regal, if ageing, imperial bodyguard, resplendent in lion's mane head-dresses. Soldiers who had fought under him stood to attention, wiping away tears as the cortege passed by.

The patriarch of the Ethiopian Orthodox church gave a eulogy before the coffin was placed on a decorated flatbed lorry, which carried it to the vast Maskal Square. There it was greeted by 26 members of Haile Selassie's family, and Rita Marley, the widow of singer Bob Marley. Ms Marley is one of many Rastafarians who revere Haile Selassie as Ras (prince) Tafari, his title before ascending to the throne in 1930.

Prince Beedemariam Mekonnen, Haile Selassie's grandson, said his grandfather was a symbol of proud independence for the rest of Africa."He was a father to all of us. Our king of kings."

That contrasted with the official silence surrounding the reburial. Last week Meles Zenawi's government called Haile Selassie "a tyrant and oppressor of the masses".

No officials attended the ceremony.

The procession ended at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, where his grandsons, acting as pall bearers, carried the emperor's remains to their burial place.

fields.headline: October's weather
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Daytime temperatures
fields.body:
Daytime temperatures

Although the first few days of the month started mild, October as a whole was a rather cool month, more so over England, Wales and Northern Ireland than over Scotland. Lerwick in the far north, for example, was 0.8C above the monthly norm, whereas Belfast was 0.8C colder than usual. Birmingham and Aberdeen had very similar temperatures during October. The coldest days occurred at the end of the month with the 30th being the coldest. The year as a whole remains well above the average UK temperature, however, as does the world as a whole.

Rainfall

As everyone will know, October was an extremely wet month, all of the 20 locations monitored here recording rainfall totals well above average. This was probably the wettest October in the UK since 1903. The greatest rainfall excess was in the south of England and the midlands. Folkestone and Birmingham, for example, both recorded nearly three times their average October rainfall. Again, Lerwick was the least anomalous, recording only 20 per cent more rainfall than usual. During the last week of October, the country received nearly its entire average October rainfall.

Sunshine

Despite the rather unpromising temperatures and high rainfall, October also managed to give us rather more sunshine than usual. The country as a whole recorded 9 per cent above average and much of Scotland received more than 20 per cent more than usual. Lerwick managed more sunshine than Lowestoft during the month, a rare achievement for October. But even with all the rain over England, some parts also enjoyed high sunshine totals. Bristol and Morecambe, for example, recorded 10 per cent more sunshine than the norm, despite receiving well over twice normal rainfall levels. The sunniest day of the month was the 19th, with nearly seven hours sunshine across the country. In contrast the 28th recorded less than one hour of sun.

Dr Mike Hulme is a research climatologist at the University of East Anglia (more details at the website)

Summary

October 2000 Very wet and rather cool

Daytime temperature 0.3C below average

Rainfall 86 per cent above average

Sunshine 9 per cent above average

[all average figures are based on the 1951-80 average]


Mean monthly extremes

Warmest Guernsey 15.8C

Sunniest Scarborough 133 hours sun

Wettest Morecambe 246mm

Coldest Lerwick 11.1C

Cloudiest Birmingham 69 hours sun

Driest Skegness 75mm
