webTitle: Palestinian mother too angry for peace

fields.headline: A mother too angry for peace
fields.standfirst:
Two more Palestinians shot to death in Gaza as Arafat prepares for crucial meeting with Clinton
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Two more Palestinians shot to death in Gaza as Arafat prepares for crucial meeting with Clinton.
fields.body:
On the electronic monitor three dotted yellow lines plot the ebbing of a young girl's life. From Ghazala Jaradet, 13, whose body has sprouted plastic tubes, there comes only a small ghostly flutter of the left hand.

Yesterday, with Ghazala's unseeing brown eyes staring out from her bandaged head, her mother gave her up for dead.

A day after her eldest daughter was shot in the head by an Israeli soldier's rubber bullet, Maha Jaradet committed her to the past tense: another shahid (martyr) from more than five weeks of bloodshed.

"I am sure my daughter was assassinated," she said. "She always talked about martyrs because she kept seeing them on TV."

And so it went on, the weekend when the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, agreed to visit Washington for talks to try to end the fighting that has stolen more than 170 lives and left hundreds as critically injured as Ghazala.

Mr Arafat is due to meet President Bill Clinton on Thursday, two days after the American voters elect a new leader.

In the chill of her sitting room in the village of Beit Anoun, Mrs Jaradet does not want Mr Arafat to go. She is not sceptical of Mr Clinton's waning powers: after watching the doctors shake their heads over her daughter, who wanted to grow up to be a doctor, she is simply too angry for negotiations.

"It is much better to keep on fighting and to be a martyr then live in situation where you are humiliated," she said.

Israeli officials say the prime minister, Ehud Barak, could also find his way to Washington within days of Mr Arafat, provided the fragile truce agreed at the end of last week takes hold.

Ghazala may not live that long. Doctors at al-Ahlia hospital in Hebron say that the rubber bullet that ricocheted off the back of her head pushed a sharp fragment of bone deep into her brain, causing severe damage.

If she survives she will be paralysed on the right side of her body. Such tragedies have become wearily familiar.

Israeli soldiers killed two more Palestinians in Gaza yesterday, one a 16-year-old boy shot in the head.

On Saturday it was Ghazala's turn. She was in a gaggle of girls in school uniform - green dresses and white headscarves - who walk home together every day.

There were some boys stoning an Israeli patrol near the entrance to the village, but the girls went around it.

"Suddenly Ghazala said 'oh', and fell down," said Dima al-Motor, 14. A villager bundled the girl into his car and drove towards Hebron.

It took two hours for Mrs Jaradet to follow her daughter to the intensive care unit - a distance of a few miles - because of Israeli concrete barricades blocking the main roads into Hebron.

Palestinian and international human rights organisations have reported a disturbingly high incidence of head injuries from Israeli fire: about 70% of the 5,500 Palestinians injured were hurt in the upper body, including 26% shot in the head and neck.

They accuse the Israelis of a shoot-to-kill policy against Palestinians.

The army says it shoots only when soldiers' lives are endangered.

A spokesman said last night that Ghazala was injured in a car crash and her family and doctors fabricated the story.

Even if President Clinton can cajole Mr Barak and Mr Arafat into a bring about a lasting ceasefire and resuming negotiations for peace, the casualties of these weeks will continue to haunt hundreds of Palestinian families.

"She was my best friend, and when the Israelis shot her, I feel they took a part of my body," Dima al-Motor said.

fields.headline: Rome bars Veneto devolution poll
fields.trailText: The Italian government has tried to shore up its constitutional authority by blocking a referendum in Veneto, the region that includes Venice, on greater independence from Rome.
fields.body:
The Italian government has tried to shore up its constitutional authority by blocking a referendum in Veneto, the region that includes Venice, on greater independence from Rome.

The wealthy region proposed a constitution last week which amounted to near secession raising the stakes in the northern battle for power and increasing the fear that Italy may break up. Rome will push its own diluted proposals for devolution through the senate this week.

But the president of Veneto, Giancarlo Galan, vowed to press ahead with the referendum. Mr Galan, who belongs to the centre-right coalition which is expected to win next year's general election, wants to keep two-thirds of the tax revenues raised in Veneto and to control health, education, immigration, law and order, and elements of foreign policy.

Francesco Rutelli, the centre-left's candidate for prime minister, denounced the plan as a recipe for a Yugoslavian-type disintegration, adding that the diversion of funds would force hospitals in the impoverished south to close.

A cabinet meeting decided that a referendum could be called only by the central government. It would interfere with the devolution bill.

Veneto's proposal raised the stakes in the north's game of cat and mouse with Rome. The regions of Lombardy and Piedmont, also controlled by the right, want to distance themselves from the south, which they regard as parasitic, corrupt and crime-infested.

Agazio Loiero, the regional affairs minister, said blocking the referendum was safer than letting it go ahead and hoping it failed. Some colleagues said the block could give rise to a separatist backlash.

It is uncertain that the devolution bill will be passed before the elections, due by April. Opinion polls suggest that the centre-right will thrash the government, which has promised but so far failed to deliver devolution.

The regions of Lombardy and Piedmont, also controlled by the right, want to distance themselves from the south, which they regard as parasitic, corrupt and crime-infested. Agazio Loiero, the regional affairs minister, said blocking the referendum was safer than letting it go ahead and hoping it failed. Some colleagues said the block could give rise to a separatist backlash. It is uncertain that the devolution bill will be passed before the elections, due by April. Opinion polls suggest that the centre-right will thrash the government, which has promised but so far failed to deliver devolution.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Protest closes Czech border
fields.body:
Protest closes Czech border

Austrian anti-nuclear activists sealed off the border with the Czech Republic yesterday to force the Czech government to shut down a recently activated nuclear power plant.

Citing concern for the safety of the nuclear plant near Temelin, 30 miles from the Austrian border, the activists set up blockades at the first of 15 crossing points between the two countries last week after talks between the Czech prime minister, Milos Zeman, and the Austrian chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, produced little progress in the controversy.
AP, Prague

Boxer fought despite HIV

A former Zimbabwean boxing champion has claimed that he contested a Commonwealth title fight 14 years ago, despite testing HIV positive, it emerged yesterday.

The former national middleweight champion Gilbert Josamu told the Sunday Mail that he fought the Briton Chris Pyatt in October 1986 after forging the results of a medical test because it was his only means of earning a living.

The southern African country has one of the highest rates of HIV infections in the world: health officials say about 3m people are either HIV positive or have full-blown Aids. The disease kills about 1,700 Zimbabweans every week.
Reuters, Harare

Big cat attacks girl, 5, at circus

A circus animal wounded a five-year-old girl while trying to pull her inside its cage, police said yesterday.

The liger, a lion and tiger cross, was passing through an enclosed tunnel at the circus in Amberg, Bavaria, on Saturday when it put its paw through the bars and grabbed the girl, tearing skin and muscle tissue around her left foot. Her father and another man helped pull her back.
AP, Munich

webTitle: Running mate Lieberman performs marathon sprint

fields.headline: Running mate Lieberman performs marathon sprint
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The first Jewish vice-presidential candidate in US history ignored the Republican poll lead and observed the Jewish Sabbath with his family. But as soon as the sun went down, Joe Lieberman began one of the most gruelling campaigning days in modern electoral history.
fields.body:
The first Jewish vice-presidential candidate in US history ignored the Republican poll lead and observed the Jewish Sabbath with his family. But as soon as the sun went down, Joe Lieberman began one of the most gruelling campaigning days in modern electoral history.

Having spent the Saturday in Miami in prayer and relaxation, he went into the political equivalent of hyper-drive: a 6,000-mile tour of seven key states in just over 24 hours, with only the odd hour off for sleep.

First stop was a visit to El Pub, a bar in the heart of Miami's Little Havana district. Then, at 8pm, he left for Miami airport and the 230-mile flight to Orlando, where he gave his final speech in the battle for Florida's vital 25 electoral college votes.

"This great wave starts in southern Florida and works its way up to central Florida and takes Al Gore and me to the White House," he told supporters.

But the route to the White House is a roundabout one. From Orlando Mr Lieberman flew 1,000 miles to Springdale, north-west Arkansas, Bill Clinton's state, for an 11.15pm rally. An hour later he was back in the air, heading south-west to Albuquerque, New Mexico, another 1,000-mile leg, and his hotel bed.

By 7am he was shaking hands in local diners and cafes. Three hours later he was off to Las Vegas, Nevada, 1,470 miles away, another state that the Gore-Lieberman ticket thinks could flip their way.

After lunch he was leaving Las Vegas for another 1,000-mile flight, this time to Portland, Oregon, where the Democrats are battling to stop Ralph Nader's voters handing the state to George W Bush.

By 5.30pm he still had two more states to visit. The 175-mile flight to Seattle, Washington, took less than an hour, from where he was driven to a local rally.

At 9.30pm he was rolling down the runway for the final, and longest leg: Minneapolis, Minnesota, 1,670 miles and two time zones east.

By the time the campaign plane touched down in the midwest, it was 2.55am.

If that was not enough, he will be notching up a further 2,200 air miles today, from Minnesota to Wisconsin, then to Maine and New Hampshire, before a final stop in Pennsylvania en route to - he hopes - a victory party in Nashville, Tennessee, on polling day tomorrow.

webTitle: Gay getaway called off after complaints

fields.headline: Gay getaway called off after complaints
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Health bosses were yesterday forced to cancel a country weekend break aimed at helping gay men come to terms with their sexuality after protests that it was a waste of NHS money.
fields.body:
Health bosses were yesterday forced to cancel a country weekend break aimed at helping gay men come to terms with their sexuality after protests that it was a waste of NHS money.

Up to 18 young men were to stay at a farmhouse in the Brecon Beacons as guests of a group which is given NHS funding to promote safe sex.

But the weekend - Come Together - was cancelled after criticism from the Conservatives and local people who said money for the trip would be better spent elsewhere.

Even though it pointed out that the cash had to be used for projects connected to a national campaign to halt the spread of HIV, Birmingham Specialist Community Heath Trust said the trip had been cancelled to protect the men involved. It also said it would reconsider the course's "aims and objectives" to consider whether it was appropriate.

The weekend, costing £1,000 and due to take place from December 1, was organised by Birmingham-based Healthy Gay Life Project. The group booked a self-catering farmhouse in the village of Libanus.

Food, transport and accommodation, as well as condoms, were to be provided. The men were to pay a £10 deposit each for the break, which would have been returned.

Bonding sessions, discussion groups and role-playing were to be part of the programme with counsellors on hand to offer advice and comfort.

Darrell Gale, project manager for Healthy Gay Life, said the weekend was to be free to "men who are either gay or are confused about their sexuality and want to come out".

He said: "We are committed to safe sex and aim to prevent the spread of HIV in the Birmingham gay community. We have found that men, concerned about coming out, practise unsafe sex." It had been hoped the weekend would be a first step for those men who wanted to come out.

But yesterday, after the trip was highlighted in a Birmingham newspaper, politicians objected strongly. Shadow health secretary Liam Fox said: "At a time when the NHS is under enormous pressure, it is completely unacceptable that money earmarked for healthcare is being given over to lifestyle issues such as this."

Villagers in Libanus also expressed dismay. Steve Coop, a pub landlord, said: "It is inappropriate for NHS money to be spent on a weekend away for a group of homosexuals."

Geoff Phillips, a farmer, said: "In Brecon, our local maternity department is being closed. Why could the money not be used to save that instead of being spent on sending a load of men, unsure about their sexuality, on a nice weekend?"

Cynthia Bower, chief executive of Birmingham Specialist Community Health Trust - which is funded by Birmingham Health Authority - said: "The weekend was to be funded from money specifically set aside as part of the national campaign to prevent the spread of HIV and Aids."

However, she added that, following the complaint about the weekend, the trust would review the course.

fields.headline: Professor butchers 'Giotto's bones'
fields.trailText: The world has been fooled in hailing a skeleton unearthed in Florence Cathedral as that of Giotto, the father of European painting, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
The world has been fooled in hailing a skeleton unearthed in Florence Cathedral as that of Giotto, the father of European painting, it was claimed yesterday.

Franklin Toker, who led excavations in the cathedral in the early 70s and is writing an archaeological history of Florence, derided the claim in an open letter to Cardinal Silvano Piovanelli, who plans a service in January to bless the remains.

Dr Toker, professor of art and architecture at the University of Pittsburgh, said there was no reason to suggest that the skeleton of a short, squat man with an oversized head was that of the painter.

"For heaven's sake, your eminence, do not treat it as Giotto. You risk blessing and honouring the bones of a fat butcher."

Two months ago a team led by Francesco Mallegni, a lecturer in human paleontology and anthropology at Pisa and Palermo universities, caused a minor sensation by rebuilding a face on the skull and identifying it as Giotto, who died in 1337.

They claimed that the skull, unearthed 30 years ago but ignored art the time, showed a strong resemblance to Giotto's presumed self-portrait in the cycle of frescoes in the Scrovegni chapel in Padua.

But Prof Toker, who worked in the cathedral between 1969 and 1974, said that coins found beside the body dated from long after Giotto's death.

The team has also been misled by a description of the tomb by the Renaissance art historian Giorgio Vasari, because the cathedral had subsequently been altered.

The skeleton's indications of an enthusiastic meat-eater suggested a butcher, not a well-off artist.

The Italian team argued that the crooked nose, bull neck and deformed forehead matched the poet Petrarch's description of Giotto, and that high levels of aluminum, arsenic, zinc, lead - elements used in medieval painting - were found.

It said that a contraction of the neck suggested much time looking upwards, presumably at frescoes; that the teeth had done a lot of chewing, presumably of paintbrushes; and that the left leg was injured, presumably from a fall from a ladder.

Giotto di Bondone, who was born to a poor Tuscan family, paved the way for the Renaissance by abandoning the stylised rigidity of the middle ages in favour of perspective and naturalism.

Cardinal Piovanelli, who proposed to perform the blessing on the anniversary of Giotto's death, remained silent yesterday.

fields.headline: Economics made easy
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: So how big is the chancellor's war chest?
fields.body:
So how big is the chancellor's war chest?

Some city analysts have suggested recently that Gordon Brown could have as much as £25bn left over in the kitty at the end of this financial year. But when the chancellor stands up on Wednesday to give his half-yearly update on the health of the public finances, he is likely to declare that the difference between the government's income and expenditure will be less than half that sum.

Who is more likely to be correct?

Mr Brown does have a history of underestimating the size of his surpluses. At the end of the 1999 financial year he had £16bn in the bank, instead of the £3.5bn he had expected. But as the Treasury is at pains to stress, the public finances are based on deliberately cautious assumptions, in order to avoid repeating the mistakes of the late 1980s.

What mistakes?

When the budget moved into surplus in the late 1980s, policymakers assumed that it was a permanent improvement rather than - as it turned out to be - just a temporary result of the economy running at full speed. The then chancellor, Nigel Lawson, cut taxes and succeeded in adding more fuel to the boom. Three years later, the government was running its largest ever peacetime deficit.

So is Mr Brown being too pessimistic this time?

The Treasury says that the City is being too optimistic. There are still six months to go before the end of the financial year, and there are signs that company tax receipts will not be anything like as buoyant as some forecasters expect.

They also argue that it makes sense to base public finances on cautious assumptions because it is much easier to deal with a surplus than fill a deficit. After all, increasing taxes or cutting spending is never popular.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: The Lake District
fields.trailText: Snowbound hills glistening in the sunshine - the first snow of the winter - greeted me when I opened my bedroom curtains the other morning. Always an exciting sight, the first snows with their promise (even to doddery old-timers like me) of winter adventure.
fields.body:
Snowbound hills glistening in the sunshine - the first snow of the winter - greeted me when I opened my bedroom curtains the other morning. Always an exciting sight, the first snows with their promise (even to doddery old-timers like me) of winter adventure.

Five miles north-east of my home, but in the clear morning air looking almost within throwing distance, rose the little pointed summit of Whiteside Pike, sharply outlined against the sparkling white of the twin summits of White Howe. This Whiteside Pike - not to be confused with Whiteside near Helvellyn, or the Buttermere Whiteside - is a splendid spiky little hill just to your left as you drive over Shap Fells, beyond Longsleddale. A delectable summit devoid of beer-can rings, litter or scratches on the rocks - nothing but heather, bracken, handholds of Coniston Grit, a few pools, maybe buzzards overhead, and views of unspoiled fell country. And from this first summit you can do the exhilarating 10-mile round of the fells enclosing the remote valley of Bannisdale, perhaps to Grey Crag and back, and never see a soul.

Of course this early snow doesn't necessarily suggest a long hard winter; it was quite a plastering but it might have all disappeared by now. True, with global warming we don't get the winters of 30 years ago, with up to four months of skiing in the fells, but there's been more snow on the tops in recent years than even the locals realise. Last winter there was skiing on Raise near Helvellyn for several weekends before the year end, and intermittently for a month or two afterwards. In retrospect a "good" winter - for some.

 The Coniston Tigers, published by Sigma Press

fields.headline: Where there's a Will
fields.trailText: Changing Stages (BBC2, Sunday) is Richard Eyre's new series about the history of British theatre in the 20th century. This first instalment was all about Shakespeare, and how actors and directors have approached him, and its presenter prepared the ground with some ringing rhetorical phrases.
fields.body:
Changing Stages (BBC2, Sunday) is Richard Eyre's new series about the history of British theatre in the 20th century. This first instalment was all about Shakespeare, and how actors and directors have approached him, and its presenter prepared the ground with some ringing rhetorical phrases.

"Theatre insists on being live, in the present tense, when we're increasingly surrounded by electronic images and frozen information," Eyre orated. Apparently, it's "the most human of all art forms", which is the kind of thing theatre-lovers always say even though it has no detectable basis in fact. As for the Bard of Avon, he is "our theatrical DNA".

Stirring stuff, but you sensed that Eyre's elegantly wrought bravado masked a sense of desperation that not enough people share his passion for the medium.

The more you have to plead for theatre's special wonderfulness, the more you remind viewers of the way that audiences have drifted off to movies, football, the internet or, of course, to watch TV. Despite all that, Eyre's programme made gripping viewing, not least because he'd raided the film and TV archives to illustrate his narrative. Rather than being forced to watch clunky old stage productions of various Bardic warhorses, we got vivid chunks of Larry Olivier's Henry V and Richard III, lumps of Baz Lurhmann's recent celluloid treatment of Romeo And Juliet, Herbert Beerbohm-Tree playing a hilariously overwrought King John in the first-ever specimen of Shakespeare on film, a fragment of Shakespeare In Love, and extracts from the RSC's televised Shakespeare cycle, The Wars Of The Roses. In making the fullest use of the TV medium, Eyre was offering even more reasons not to go to see live theatre.

His strongest ammunition in his crusade to bring audiences teeming back into the stalls came in the form of encounters with top thesps from the last century. John Gielgud, in what must have been one of his last interviews, was warm, witty and full of anecdotes. Judi Dench brilliantly evoked the excitement which had surrounded Trevor Nunn's 1976 production of Macbeth, in which she starred alongside Ian McKellen. Above all, it was the clips from a TV interview with Olivier, conducted by Kenneth Tynan (complete with preposterous Masonic-style grip on his cigarette), which best illustrated the value of having a superstar at the centre of the nation's theatrical life. Olivier oozed charisma, as he recalled the the sensational impact of his stage performance as Richard III.

Larry had found himself overwhelmed by the sweet smell of success. "It just smells like Brighton and oyster bars and things like that," he said, with throwaway hauteur . But not only are there no more Oliviers, it's impossible to imagine what anybody would do with one now, were he to appear.

On November 15, ITV will broadcast The Remorseful Day, Inspector Morse's fateful final case. As a curtain-raiser, The Last Morse (ITV, Sunday) was a reflective stroll down Morse's blood-drenched memory lane, with contributions from all the key figures in what has been a notable sliver of TV history. John Thaw reflected on Morse's moroseness, solitariness, grumpiness and inability to love anybody properly. Kevin Whately, the luckless Sgt Lewis, recalled how much he had enjoyed being allowed to deflate the Chief Inspector's insufferable intellectual pomposity. There was a droll clip of the pair of them driving along in Morse's Jaguar, listening to opera. Morse: "That, Lewis, was Maria Callas."

Lewis: "Was it from Cats?"

Morse's creator, Colin Dexter, has no illusions about his tetchy, pedantic sleuth. "It would be a dreadful thing to meet Chief Inspector Morse in a pub, wouldn't it?" he suggested.

Will New Yorkers vote for Hillary Clinton? Hillary Clinton's New York Adventure (BBC2, Saturday) was an intelligently assembled biography by John Bridcut, and while it strenuously avoided editorialising, a clear picture emerged of a woman who is probably too clever and accomplished for American politics. She gets impatient with people who can't understand her point of view, she has no instinct for political schmoozing and wheel-oiling, and she'd rather die than dumb herself down. It was difficult to avoid the conclusion that Hillary simply believes she's superior to the great mass of the American public.

As a curtain-raiser, The Last Morse (ITV, Sunday) was a reflective stroll down Morse's blood-drenched memory lane, with contributions from all the key figures in what has been a notable sliver of TV history. John Thaw reflected on Morse's moroseness, solitariness, grumpiness and inability to love anybody properly. Kevin Whately, the luckless Sgt Lewis, recalled how much he had enjoyed being allowed to deflate the Chief Inspector's insufferable intellectual pomposity. There was a droll clip of the pair of them driving along in Morse's Jaguar, listening to opera. Morse: "That, Lewis, was Maria Callas." Lewis: "Was it from Cats?" Morse's creator, Colin Dexter, has no illusions about his tetchy, pedantic sleuth. "It would be a dreadful thing to meet Chief Inspector Morse in a pub, wouldn't it?" he suggested. Will New Yorkers vote for Hillary Clinton? Hillary Clinton's New York Adventure (BBC2, Saturday) was an intelligently assembled biography by John Bridcut, and while it strenuously avoided editorialising, a clear picture emerged of a woman who is probably too clever and accomplished for American politics. She gets impatient with people who can't understand her point of view, she has no instinct for political schmoozing and wheel-oiling, and she'd rather die than dumb herself down. It was difficult to avoid the conclusion that Hillary simply believes she's superior to the great mass of the American public.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: George Bernard Shaw's unexpected friendship with Gene Tunney, the 1920s American heavyweight boxing champion, is recalled by Tunney's son Jay in The Master And The Boy (11.0am, Radio 4).
fields.body:
George Bernard Shaw's unexpected friendship with Gene Tunney, the 1920s American heavyweight boxing champion, is recalled by Tunney's son Jay in The Master And The Boy (11.0am, Radio 4).

Tunney, when not flooring opponents, liked nothing better than to curl up with a good book - he even lectured Yale students about Shakespeare. Shaw was a great admirer of Tunney's "scientific" approach to boxing, and their correspondence led to a joint family holiday in Italy.

Isobel Hilton presents a survey of one of the world's least-known cultures in the first of a new series about contemporary China. She first arrived there as a language student 27 years ago. Now, as she and other observers report during their five-hour Chinese Evening (7.30pm, Radio 3), life in the major cities has prospered beyond recognition. But how has such a dramatic material change affected the inner life of the 1.2 billion people living in the last major Communist country?

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Charlize Theron in Two Days In The Valley
fields.body:
Charlize Theron in Two Days In The Valley (John Herzfeld, 1996)

Who? South African-born former model. After making her debut in the Tarantino-esque Two Days In The Valley, Theron starred alongside Al Pacino and Keanu Reeves in The Devil's Advocate (1997), and almost managed to save it from total absurdity. But not quite. She fared a bit better as a nameless supermodel who is "polymorphously perverse" in Woody Allen's Celebrity (1998) but blew it with a film that managed to make The Devil's Advocate look sophisticated - The Astronaut's Wife (1999). She played the wife of, you've got it, astronaut Johnny Depp, whose Southern accent is almost as bad as her acting. Since then, however, she's been in the Oscar-nominated Cider House Rules (1999) and has starred alongside James Caan, Mark Wahlberg and Joaquin Phoenix in The Yards (2000), which is released this Friday.

The role: Helga Svelgen, ex-ice skater and current lover of psychotic criminal Lee Woods (James Spader). Her finest moment is a stand-up brawl with Becky Foxx (Teri Hatcher) in a sleazy motel room.

Best line: When Lee jealously enquires about Helga's dalliance with a man they went on to kill, she tells him "sometimes I really think you should have been born during the Spanish Inquisition".

Cringe factor: A bit of nudity and a skintight white catsuit are nothing to be ashamed of.

Other wannabes: Michael Jai White plays Buck, and went on to star as superhero Spawn in the eponymous 1997 movie.

Critical judgement: Barbara Shulgasser in the San Franciso Examiner called the film "Short Cuts without the darkness".

Also not starring in: Children Of The Corn IV: The Gathering, in an uncredited role in 1996, and as Tina in Tom Hanks' That Thing You Do!, the same year.

Two Days In The Valley, 10pm, Tues 7 Nov, Carlton Cinema

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Butch Cassidy And The Sundance Kid / Le Colonel Chabert / American History X / Turkish Delight
fields.body:
Butch Cassidy And The Sundance Kid

(George Roy Hill, 1969)

11.50am, 6pm, Sky Cinema

This charming, lighthearted Western features one of the great "buddies" pairings: Newman and Redford's affable, slightly dim outlaws remain forever freeze-framed on the memory. Despite the sepia-toned nods towards authenticity and some Peckinpahesque slo-mo violence, it's really a mock Western that comi cally deflates the traditional set-pieces of the genre: the train robbery, the fistfights and gunfights. Marvellously watchable.

Le Colonel Chabert

(Yves Angelo, 1994)

6pm, FilmFour

Sombre but involving historical drama based on a Balzac story. It stars a restrained Gérard Depardieu (pictured) as the heroic Chabert, returning from the Napoleonic wars after wandering amnesiac for years. But his wife has married again; and Chabert's estate now belongs to the ambitious Count Fer raud. An intelligent film, with Depardieu the picture of weary anguish.

American History X

(Tony Kaye, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

An awesome performance from Edward Norton centres this compelling study of American neo-Nazism. His charismatic Derek, a hate-filled skinhead, kills two black car thieves and after rehabilitation emerges from prison a changed man, now struggling to free his brother Danny (Edward Furlong) from the grip of fascist gang leader Cameron (Stacy Keach). Norton reportedly re-edited and Kaye disowned the final cut, but it's a highly charged and thought- provoking movie.

Turkish Delight

(Paul Verhoeven, 1973)

3.40am, FilmFour

Rutger Hauer stars in this early Verhoeven feature, playing a sculptor reliving, mainly in flashback, his relationship with the beautiful, spoilt young Monique van de Ven. They marry, but don't live happily ever after - in a very Hollywood-style plot development she succumbs to a brain tumour. In fact, this is Love Story, done in the liberated, soft-porn 70s Dutch manner.

fields.headline: Royal approval
fields.trailText: Intended as the kind of BBC show-off project which impresses governors, government and prize juries, Simon Schama's (pictured) A History Of Britain (Wednesday, 9pm, BBC2) has brought the unexpected bonus of a big viewership. Eventually running to 16 episodes, the series this week reaches the end of the eight programmes scheduled for 2000 AD.
fields.body:
Intended as the kind of BBC show-off project which impresses governors, government and prize juries, Simon Schama's (pictured) A History Of Britain (Wednesday, 9pm, BBC2) has brought the unexpected bonus of a big viewership. Eventually running to 16 episodes, the series this week reaches the end of the eight programmes scheduled for 2000 AD.

This edition is the biggest test of Schama because it deals with what is probably the period of history most visually familiar to viewers: the relationship between Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots. A more cynical production would have plumped out the show with clips of Glenda Jackson and Cate Blanchett in the white face make-up, but the style of the series is maintained: a huge and elegant essay spoken by Schama over boldly photographed landscapes and documents of the period.

The courage required for a show bearing a 21st-century copyright line to take this approach has not properly been acknowledged. Except for the beauty of the illustration, this is precisely how factual television began: an expert lecturing a camera. They did it then because they had to; here it's an intellectual choice. It works because Schama has an ear for the jump-off-the-sofa anecdote.

In this edition, the surprises are gynaecological. Schama notes that in Elizabethan England prolonged virginity was a medical emergency which was believed to lead to something called Green Disease. And, in a twist on the honeymoon practice in some cultures, sheets stained with Elizabeth's menstrual blood were sent to the politicians to prove the surviving possibility of an heir.

Viewers may also be startled by an off-air footnote. Most of the producers and directors on Schama's series learned their trade on BBC2's The Late Show - easily dismissed as a pretentious aberration, but series such as A History Of Britain confirm its significance as a nursery for programme-makers.

fields.headline: Cold comfort
fields.standfirst: Sparky, surreal and wildly original, Cold Feet returns in style for a third series. Mark Lawson applauds the drama which more than lives up to its billing as Britain's answer to Friends.
fields.trailText: Sparky, surreal and wildly original, Cold Feet returns in style for a third series. Mark Lawson applauds the drama which more than lives up to its billing as Britain's answer to Friends.
fields.body:
The moment of diagnosis with cancer has featured in many TV dramas and documentaries. But only one series would have dramatised a patient's panic by showing him being pursued through a shopping street by a giant bouncing testicle, his dreaming mind's terrified projection of the affected part. Such non-naturalistic action is one of the selling points of Cold Feet (Sunday, 9pm, ITV), which returns for a third series next weekend.

When piloted by ITV in 1997, Cold Feet was touted as a British version of Friends, and this wannabe prophecy has proved surprisingly true.

Helen Baxendale - who plays the cool and sometimes cruel love-object Rachel in Cold Feet - even appeared as the token Brit in the American series with the other Rachel in it. The cast of Cold Feet was recently given a Friends-style salary-handcuff by ITV and also find their off-screen sex lives a target for the tabloids.

Like Friends and thirtysomething, Cold Feet is television with a reflective texture, mirroring the lives of the target audience. Many households will watch the two-hour return episode with a mental marker pen, ticking off incidents. Marital love-making is interrupted by a sleepless child's appearance at the end of the bed. The childcare arrangements of a separated couple function smoothly until one of them seeks to alter the roster for a trip with a new lover.

But - as was demonstrated by the Dambuster-gonad scene after Adam's testicular cancer scare - the strength of Cold Feet is that it's willing to make the mirror a distorting one. Highly naturalistic acting - Fay Ripley's jumpy-funny Jenny and Robert Bathurst's status-crazed David and the rest all remind you of sometime you've known - is combined with the non-verité scenes of which the genital in the shopping centre is merely the best-remembered.

In the new series, when estranged husband Pete looks round an emergency bachelor flat, there's a flashback to him and his then-fiance checking out what would become the family home. Speaking at the local residents' association to a largely empty hall, David has a sudden Blairite fantasy of balloons and tickertape and hero-acclaiming applause. Drama's weakness in comparison with the novel is the difficulty of dramatising inner thoughts. The usual solution is voiceover. Cold Feet's dream sequences are a far more satisfying way of entering the head of the characters.

And, while a worsening problem in soap opera is the ease with which people live as if terrible recent events never happened, this drama plays fair with the back story of its cast. Some series would use cancer and abortion just as plot-bombs, but here these details from the past inform a storyline about the struggle to have children of two people who fear that, through choice and fate respectively, they have wasted their chance.

While the characters in Cold Feet head for 40, the seventh episode in the rival young urban professional drama Attachments (Tuesday, 9pm, BBC2) hangs on a 30th birthday bash. And, where Cold Feet has one internet entrepreneur, in this series every character travels through cyberspace, setting up a website.

Its first series now 70 per cent downloaded, this adroit dot.comedy of manners has been the main ratings victim of the 9pm drama slot in the new BBC1 schedule. You hope, though, that the BBC doesn't get cold feet about its performance because this is truly unusual television.

Some early notices scolded the show for being This Life Lite. The accusation was inevitable because it was Tony Garnett's follow-up to his celebrated shagging-lawyers series but, as Attachments has developed, it has been clear that this series is entirely different in conception. Where This Life was essentially a house-share drama with office interludes, Attachments reverses the equation. It is a rare attempt by TV drama to deal seriously with work.

Television is usually interested in professional technique only when it involves dead or dying bodies which come to the attention of the numerous doctors, detectives, pathologists and lawyers in the schedules.

Attachments courageously takes on the potentially more boring aspects of business: the deal, employment practices, office routine. One sub-plot involves the contractual rights of freelance web journalists when their copy is altered.

Apart from working harder than usual to depict business, the series is also distinctive in the link between subject and look. The story of this internet company is frequently told through webcam images and emails. The attempted seduction through electronic messages has already been depicted in Patrick Marber's play Closer and the movie You've Got Mail, but the cyberspace flirtation at the end of tomorrow's Attachments is both daringly more extended and, in the way the camera isolates key words, more stylish.

Most internet start-ups have failed but this one deserves further investment and a re-run away from the brilliant same-timed The Sins (Tuesday, 9.05pm, BBC1) which this week reaches the reliable ratings-inflater of Lust. With Tony Marchant's black-economy drama Never, Never (tonight, 9pm, Channel 4) also on offer, this is a rare fruit-machine moment for reviewers: with distinctively written and imaginatively shot drama serials across all four serious terrestrial channels.

webTitle: Retailers face hard times as shopping goes out of fashion

fields.headline: Retailers face hard times as shopping goes out of fashion
fields.trailText: The concept of Britain as a nation of shopkeepers is fast coming to an end, with a combination of soaring rents and weak high street demand likely to send many retailers to the wall over the next few years, according to Verdict, the leading retail research group.
fields.body:
The concept of Britain as a nation of shopkeepers is fast coming to an end, with a combination of soaring rents and weak high street demand likely to send many retailers to the wall over the next few years, according to Verdict, the leading retail research group.

The outlook for small operators is particularly bleak as bigger rivals merge or are taken over, creating just two or three dominant names in any one sector, and as international players dominate by virtue of their scale and cost efficiencies.

In its annual research report forecasting likely changes among retailers through to the middle of the decade, Verdict notes that rents, which have jumped almost 30% over the past five years, are the main culprit.

More pain is expected after the recent rate review, leaving some store operators facing increases of up to 50%.

"Combined, they will score a direct and severe hit on the margins and profitability of retail companies," Verdict says. "It is inconceivable that retailers will be able to pass on these cost rises to consumers. The current competitive environment in Britain is keeping prices low and has actually reduced the price of many goods."

The research group sees a boom in merger and acquisitions and believes areas such as furniture and health and beauty will quickly follow the lead being set by grocery chains and do-it-yourself specialists. But it warns that scale alone "is not the panacea for retailers".

Verdict says: "They need to make it work for them by squeezing suppliers, IT costs, supply chain costs and personnel. If retailers can make these elements of their cost base more productive, they will be able to increase volume and protect margins."

The growth in spending by shoppers is expected to slow from the 24% increase seen between 1995 and 2000 to a more modest 20% over the next five years, with the two largest retail sectors - food and clothing - suffering the worst rates of growth.

With consumers deserting retail in favour of spending on holidays, eating out, mobile phones and other leisure spending, Verdict believes retailers will have to make themselves more attractive, "creating greater experiences, excitement ... retail as theatre or leisure and entertainment."

webTitle: CBI demands ban on more workers' rights

fields.headline: CBI demands ban on more workers' rights
fields.standfirst: Thus far and no further - industry leaders berate Labour for the 'unnecessary pain that goes with laudable gain' for employees
fields.trailText: Leading employers' body the CBI last night came under sustained fire from senior ministers and union leaders for demanding an immediate and lasting ban on further employment rights legislation.
fields.body:
Leading employers' body the CBI last night came under sustained fire from senior ministers and union leaders for demanding an immediate and lasting ban on further employment rights legislation.

On the eve of its national conference in Birmingham, the CBI urged the government to drop plans for paid parental leave and measures to enable women to return to work part-time, claiming that 15 separate employment regulations had cost business £12.3bn since Labour came to power three years ago and stifled industry with red tape.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, and John Monks, TUC general secretary, accused the CBI of using code for an "attack on decent standards in the workplace" in its strictures on regulation, with Mr Byers saying he would make no apology for measures such as the minimum wage.

Digby Jones, the CBI director-general, and his deputy, John Cridland, went out of their way to insist they were not criticising new employment rights. "The government has delivered on its manifesto commitments," Mr Jones said. "We are against all the unnecessary red tape that's been brought in around those rights."

Mr Cridland added: "There is mounting frustration within the business community about the uncessary pain that goes with laudable gain, particularly for small firms which lack the personnel resources to deal with it."

They admitted that the bulk of the £12.3bn costs of implementing new workplace rights was to pay for higher wages and shorter working weeks, which had been absorbed by businesses, rather than the extra bureaucracy involved in administering them which has cost only tens of millions.

"We are not even attacking the necessary administration involved - but simply unnecessary red tape," Mr Cridland said, claiming it diverted managers from more important functions. But he and Mr Jones insisted that the government should drop plans for any more rights and resist calls for automatic increases in the minimum wage.

Ministers plan to launch a green paper before Christmas on paid parental leave, including measures to enable women to return to work part-time, and insist they have already consulted widely with employers. "This will be a new phase of consultation and we are already aware of the implications for business, especially small firms," insiders said.

Mr Byers said: "If the CBI can identify areas of excessive bureaucracy I would be the first to take action to tackle it. But what I am not prepared to do is deny people decent conditions at work."

He even held out the prospect of a regulatory reform bill in next month's Queen's speech to ensure that regulation is only introduced when absolutely necessary.

DTI figures suggest 3m have gained an entitlement to four weeks' paid holiday for the first time while 1.5m stand to benefit from the minimum wage. The TUC said it cost only 9p a week each to introduce equal rights for part-time employees and 2p a week for parents' time off.

Mr Monks said employers gained £23bn a year from unpaid overtime and instead of "moaning" about red tape, they should work with government and unions to increase productivity and skills.

The CBI's attack on red tape came as part of a wider campaign, including a business election manifesto, for lower taxes and regulation. webTitle: Comment: The shady side of GW Bush

fields.headline: A slavish press connives to hide GW's shady side
fields.standfirst:
It's not only his drink-driving arrest Bush has lied about

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: It's not only his drink-driving arrest Bush has lied about.
fields.body:
To the Guinness Book of Records: reserve a whole page under hypocrisy. It's for George W Bush and the managers of his bid for the White House. They have run a campaign of character assassination. Knowing that Al Gore has an intimidating grasp of the issues, they have used every trick, every dollar of special interest money, every toady in the press, to smear the vice-president as a liar. The cleverness of that diversionary tactic was that if it worked it would relieve GW of giving proper answers to the questions of substance he finds so bewildering.

It worked.

Now Bush is revealed as a liar on a serious issue of character. And what happens? The smear artists are shouting "dirty politics".

Given the anti-Gore bias of the mainstream press, last Thursday night's revelation that Bush was arrested for drunken driving in 1976, when he was 30, may have come too late to affect his lead. The Republican spin machine has also been adept in damage control. Within 24 hours it had almost managed to turn the story into "who leaked?" instead of "why didn't he come clean?' It is true the disclosure came from a Maine Democrat, though not from the Gore campaign. But the point is that it is true, and the real question is the character of the candidate who tried to conceal his past.

He did confess to "mistakes" of his youth, but he would never be specific - hoping the "mistakes" would be thought of as youthful pranks, not serious crime. It is an offence to apply for any federal office without divulging an arrest record. Bush not only went to great lengths to cover up his conviction. He lied about it, too. In a 1998 interview, a Dallas Morning News reporter asked Bush point-blank if he had ever been arrested other than for a 1968 fraternity prank and Bush said flatly: "No." The exchange was not reported at the time; it didn't seem newsworthy. And when Bush was called to jury service in a drunk-driving trial in Texas, he filled out the jury questionnaire, but left blank the yes-no entry asking if he had ever been accused in a civil or criminal case. Then he hastily got himself excused on the basis that he was the governor of the state.

Imagine if this had been Al Gore! The Wall Street Journal, the most sedulous of the defamers, would have dispatched ferrets to find out what happened on the other form-filling occasions when "the liar" had to yield his record. Now the Journal, you bet, will be part of the great "Smeargate" diversion.

Bush's handlers are saying, with some success, that his ready admission of the offence, when found out, is another sign of his probity. This sums up their entire campaign, one of breath-taking arrogance wrapped up in feel-good bromides. And they have got away with it.

The basic misperception here is to confuse amiability with integrity, marketable charm with ability. The truth, bluntly, is that Bush is an irresponsible know-nothing. His instincts are those of the 1930s isolationist, little America, rather than the America that led the world in the creation of a new liberal world order. If he is president, say goodbye to the nuclear test ban, to action on global warming, to peacemaking interventions.

Those of you in sodden Britain who might conclude that global warming, for instance, is a matter of concern should know that Bush, like the Wall Street Journal, regards it as a leftist scare. Asked what he would do, he responds that we need more study before ratifying the Kyoto agreement, putting me in mind of a fire chief who arrives at the blaze to say he will have to study the origins of the fire before trying to put it out.

On social security, he has never throughout the entire campaign explained how he can take a trillion dollars and put it into personal accounts for mainly young workers without saying where the money will come from to secure the retirement payments for the rest of the ageing workforce. This weekend, attacking federalism, he did not even seem to realise that social security is a federal programme. Why hasn't the press blown the whistle? The economist Paul Krugman in the New York Times, a rare pundit who bothers to do the sums, writes: "Really big misstatements, it turns out, cannot be effectively challenged because voters can't believe that a man who seems so likeable would do that sort of thing."

But he would. The drunken driving arrest is not the only character evidence from Bush's past that has been suppressed or glossed over. On October 2, the Center for Public Integrity in Washington and Bill Muntaglio and Nancy Beiles in Talk magazine revealed that Bush not once but repeatedly missed the legal deadlines for reporting his insider stock trades when he was a director and member of the audit committee of a ropey Texas oil company, Harken Energy. In 1991, three years before he ran for governor, the Wall Street Journal headlined one instance when Bush sold near the top of the market before the stock plunged, pocketing nearly $850,000. He was eight months late in reporting this coup. He claimed he had but that the SEC had "lost the paperwork". But neither the Journal, or anyone else, has asked Bush if the SEC "lost the paperwork" when he was derelict on three other newly-documented insider trades he did not report in the way required by the anti-corruption laws.

The 1991 SEC investigation, criticised for being run by friends of then President Bush, ended inconclusively. Bush, it was said, could not have known of the magnitude of Harken's impending loss when he sold out. But the SEC never interviewed Bush and documents obtained last month under the Freedom of Information Act clearly show that Bush had more knowledge than he admitted. At least twice during the month he cashed out, he received memos showing the company was in financial peril.

The man who claims the presidency on the grounds of probity has asserted: "I believe in individual accountability and individual responsibility." But the credulous press and the cerebrally challenged television talk shows have been too busy pillorying Gore to ask Bush to reconcile rhetoric and action. "I will do everything I can," he has said, "to defend the power of private property and private property rights." But he has failed to reconcile that public testament with his enrichment from the seizure of private land for his Texas Rangers baseball stadium. Though then a private citizen, he contrived to use the power of the state to claim eminent domain over 270 acres - most of which was not needed for the stadium. Families who lost their land so that Bush and his partners could profit from the development potential are still mad at him for the land-grab and the ordeal of court hearings they had to initiate before getting a fair price. Maree Fanning, who lost the family horse farm, told a reporter: "If I saw him today, I'd say 'Bite my ass'."

Tomorrow too many American voters, deprived of the real story, may kiss it.

Harold Evans is the author of The American Century

webTitle: Art forgers show their true colours

fields.headline: Art forgers show their true colours
fields.trailText: It may be the sincerest form of flattery, but curators at the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art are not impressed by a collection of imitations mimicking their latest display of masterpieces.
fields.body:
It may be the sincerest form of flattery, but curators at the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art are not impressed by a collection of imitations mimicking their latest display of masterpieces.

The aptly named Outrageous Art Gallery in Edinburgh claims to have used a worldwide network of forgers to produce exact copies of works displayed in the Scottish Colourists exhibition.

The official exhibition at the national gallery features the work of the Edinburgh-born artists Samuel Peploe, John Duncan Fergusson, Francis Campbell Cadell and George Leslie Hunter, whose bold, colourful canvasses are much sought after by collectors.

When the Outrageous Art Gallery heard that the Colourists' work was to move from the Royal Academy in London to Edinburgh, it set about acquiring identical fakes of the paintings.

And while the originals can cost upwards of £500,000, the forged copies are being offered for between £200 and £800. "We're offering people a choice they have never had," said Hunter Walker, the owner of the Outrageous gallery. "Before this you could either buy the original for £40,000 or a poster for maybe £40. Now you can buy an exact copy of a masterpiece for £400 or just come and view them for free. Nobody else is catering for that market."

The national gallery staff have dismissed the parallel show as a cheap publicity stunt. "Here we have 70 original paintings by some of Scotland's most important artists," said Philip Long, the head curator. "When people come here they may have to pay a small admission charge but they will be able to enjoy some of Scotland's history and culture rather than an imitation of the real thing."

Staff at the Outrageous Art Gallery, meanwhile, say they can also do a nice little Van Gogh or Monet to order. Just leave enough time for the paint to dry.

webTitle: The future of the Stirling prize

fields.headline: Prize fools
fields.standfirst: The Stirling prize needs to be more than the equivalent of the Brit awards for architecture, argues Jonathan Glancey.
fields.trailText: The Stirling prize needs to be more than the equivalent of the Brit awards for architecture, argues Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
And the winner of this year's Stirling prize is_ Peckham Library, south London, by Alsop and Sturmer. Good luck to the undoubtedly talented beneficiaries of this £20,000 architectural prize organised by the Royal Institute of British Architects, and bonne chance to next year's contenders. I don't want to sound curmudgeonly, but I don't get the Stirling prize and I'm not sure what good it does architecture. True, everyone likes a prize. Remember Alice in Wonderland, when the Dodo organised a caucus race for the animals? After they had run around in circles for a bit, the Dodo decided that "everybody has won and all must have prizes". Alice presented the animals with comfits from her pocket while she was awarded her own thimble.

A good decision by that sensible Victorian girl and one that might apply to the arts and, notably, to architecture today. To get any half-decent building commissioned and completed in Britain is a small triumph, deserving of comfits, thimbles, acclaim, and even a cheque for £20,000. But, as to how we judge one new building better than another when the contenders are so very different in form, spirit and function, I have no idea. Certainly those in this year's Stirling prize - named after the late Sir James Stirling (1926-92, architect of a fascinating awkwardness of radical buildings in Britain, the US and Germany) - are like the contents of a jamboree bag.

Here's the calm, collected Walsall New Art Gallery by Caruso St John; Foster and Partners' cavernous Canary Wharf Station; and the London Eye by Marks Barfield. There's the diaphanous office block at 88 Wood Street, City of London, by the Richard Rogers Partnership; a deftly remodelled headquarters building in Berlin by Sauerbruch Hutton; and the jaunty Peckham Library. Finally, there's the "people's choice": Sainsbury's supermarket in Greenwich.

Line these up along a very large imaginary catwalk. How would you rate them? Hard, isn't it?

Dumb though the Miss World and Eurovision Song contests may be, it is easy enough for a panel of judges or a clapometer linked to the viewers at home to make a judgment based on the merits of fairly equal contenders. Now try judging the Stirling contenders the same way. It doesn't work. Each is built for a different purpose and to very different budgets. Each building offers a wholly different experience; they have been designed for longer or shorter lives. None should be judged by appearances alone. And here lies the rub. A PR-driven architecture prize can hardly be expected to concern itself with long-term concerns or values. The prize forces instant judgments, and generates instant fame and column inches (and I don't mean Ionic or Corinthian) for the winner. Care about a new Tube station, big wheel or municipal art gallery this year, forget about it the next. The same goes for the architects.

A building takes time to mature. It needs to be used and experienced, to bed in to its surroundings, before it can be said to be anything like the best new building in Britain. It may face teething problems that make it a sitting target for the press in its early days. It might be berated for being late and expensive, as was Barry and Pugin's Palace of Westminster - but who cares now? It might be unpopular in its early years simply because it's unlike anything else that has gone before. Think of the Pompidou Centre (Piano and Rogers) or Lloyd's of London (Richard Rogers Partnership), two misfits when first built, the butt of many jokes, but now integral parts of Paris and London. Both cities would be poorer for their loss.

There are many other considerations a judge of buildings might like to make. Given that you need to experience a new building in different weather and at different times of the year, does it work on a simple environmental level? Does the low winter sun come dazzling through its artistically arranged windows and make it difficult to work in? Does it get hot and bothersome inside, as so many modern buildings do? Is it likely to wear well? A building can go in and out of fashion as, say, the Gormenghast-like Midland Grand Hotel fronting St Pancras station has. A building isn't just for a season, it's for the life of, possibly, very many generations.

What the Stirling prize does is put architecture into the "new rock'n'roll" camp, to nip and tuck it into the fashion world, to wash it on a tide of never-ending champagne, finger food and gossip into the groomed and polished clutches of the PR and marketing industry. Hardly a week seems to pass without yet another new prize being announced that promises to do for whatever field of creative endeavour "what the Turner prize does for art".

Like a number of writers who love architecture, I have tried to promote it as best I can through the media, hoping to engage readers, listeners and viewers without resorting to the smoke-and-mirrors tricks of the PR industry. I want people to go and look at and experience buildings, old and new, and to learn how to make a judgment based on knowledge and experience, not on media sensation, peer group and PR pressure.

I admit to feeling a pang of guilt: is this hungry-for-prizes world a monster of my own and my colleagues' making? We have long dreamed of making architecture a popular subject for discussion, but not an all-singing, all-dancing branch of showbiz. Showbiz is rightly contained by architecture (in theatres, concert halls, cinemas); architecture doesn't need to be caught in the sequinned embrace of showbiz.

Prizes have a tendency to be sensational, transitory, feel-good-for-the-moment things that, like a dry martini, a cigarette or a line of cocaine, offer an instant boost to jaded systems. At least they might be linked to some charity or other and do something for a good cause; they rarely do. Some architectural awards do make sense, including the RIBA's own annual Royal Gold Medal for a lifetime's achievement or some unique and effective contribution to the world of architecture. Then there are awards for well restored or environmentally sound buildings and their architects; these are good because they recognise and encourage high standards in specific and measurable areas. Soon enough we won't be able to see the buildings for the awards and the surrounding facade of disingenuous hype.

If the Stirling prize is to continue, and if its organisers want it to be more than the Brit awards for architecture, they need to ensure its role is serious without being worthy, that like is compared with like, and that any judgment is made on the true worth of a building and not just its instant appeal.

Then there are awards for well restored or environmentally sound buildings and their architects; these are good because they recognise and encourage high standards in specific and measurable areas. Soon enough we won't be able to see the buildings for the awards and the surrounding facade of disingenuous hype. If the Stirling prize is to continue, and if its organisers want it to be more than the Brit awards for architecture, they need to ensure its role is serious without being worthy, that like is compared with like, and that any judgment is made on the true worth of a building and not just its instant appeal.

webTitle: MPs expected to criticise 'brutal' jail raid

fields.headline: MPs expected to criticise 'brutal' jail raid
fields.trailText: A "brutal" raid on a model liberal prison which shattered the trust between officials and inmates is set to be fiercely criticised by MPs this week.
fields.body:
A "brutal" raid on a model liberal prison which shattered the trust between officials and inmates is set to be fiercely criticised by MPs this week.

A report by the Commons home affairs committee into the search of Blantyre House, a resettlement prison boasting a reoffending rate of only 8%, is expected to be scathing.

Martin Narey, the director-general of the prison service, who admitted that the raid in May failed to find the amount of contraband which had been suspected, finds his reputation in danger of being tarnished.

It is claimed the controversy exposes a rift between those in the prison service who believe no risks should be taken with security and others who think a trust needs to be shown if inmates are to be reformed.

The committee's inquiry heard how a team of 86 prison officers, 20 sniffer dogs and two control and restraint squads swooped on the prison near Tunbridge Wells in Kent.

During Operation Swinford, doors were prised open and their frames smashed. More than £5,000 of damage was done and when the squad left, the words, "We woz 'ere" were found chalked on a blackboard. All 120 inmates were drug-tested, although none proved positive.

Alan Roger, a former inmate, said: "The raid was brutal. It was a fishing expedition. An act of revenge. They want to destroy Blantyre House by stealth."

A fortnight later Mr Narey told MPs that "a quite frightening" amount of contraband was found, including 25 bank cards, passports, driving licences in forged names, and equipment which could have been used in an escape. He also said "large quantities of money" were discovered.

By the time Mr Narey testified again last month he accepted that the amounts of contraband had been small.

An internal prison service document confirmed that the haul amounted to £370 in cash - of which £130 belonged to the chaplain - three unauthorised mobile phones, bank cards, cameras, building tools, seven pieces of pornography, a small amount of cannabis and three ecstasy tablets.

The bank cards were mainly debit cards, which had been authorised by the governor and used by prisoners who went out to work.

A lump hammer and spirit level also found were authorised work tools.

There were combative exchanges between MPs and Mr Narey and his south-east area manager, Tom Murtagh.

The all-party group of MPs was visibly outraged at the impact on this prison, one of only three "resettlement" jails in England and Wales. "It was thoroughly unjustified and a ghastly mistake," complained the Tory MP, Humfrey Malins.

All agree, including the prisons minister, Paul Boateng, who was told in advance about the raid, that trust between inmates and prison staff had been "shattered".

Operation Swinford was ordered soon after Blantyre's long-serving governor, Eoin McLennan-Murray, and his deputy, David Podmore, were told they were being moved, with only two hours' notice, to other jobs in the service.

Mr McLennan-Murray and Mr Murtagh fell out when the governor refused to institute searches of prisoners returning from outside work - around half are allowed out. The governor pointed at the exemplary record of Blantyre. There had been no escapes in two-and-a-half years.

The chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, described Blantyre's record as "remarkable" and thought the raid extraordinary. When Sir David was asked if he thought the search was to look for evidence to use against Mr McLennan-Murray, he replied: "One presumes that the governor being removed was the main purpose of the exercise."

Mr Narey said the prison service had been nervous about the possibility of places at the prison being "bought" by powerful inmates ever since 1995 when the underworld boss Kenny Noye was involved in an attempt to place a prisoner there as part of a fraud plot.

But his credibility with the MPs rested on an "intelligence" briefing he gave in private. The indications are that the claims centred on a drug ring in the jail. It was found that the phones had been used to keep in contact with prominent criminals. But the allegations are not thought to have been sufficient to convince MPs to tone down the report.

fields.headline: Look at me, I'm a gargoyle
fields.standfirst: Patrick Killoran's art is obsessed with putting bodies in odd situations - even as far as pushing people out of windows. Chris Arnot investigates.
fields.trailText: Patrick Killoran's art is obsessed with putting bodies in odd situations - even as far as pushing people out of windows.
fields.body:
It's not every day that you slide out of a window on the top floor of a Gothic tower. A small, circular room, 50ft above the ground, has been opened at Birmingham's Ikon Gallery to accommodate New York artist Patrick Killoran and his Observation Deck.

Furniture-maker Nick Finn is still blowing away the sawdust as I prepare to be the first person to put the device to the test. "Safe as houses," he assures me as I clamber aboard and lie flat on my back. A push and the central platform moves on a roller. "Don't worry - there's a brake," Finn adds as I edge backwards until my head disappears through an adjacent window. "The key is to get your eyes past the facade of the building so that it becomes a landscape line," Killoran tells me. "You're going to see this room in a totally different way. You're going out into the world to have an interior experience."

The only thing between me and the ground is air and a piece of wood. Shoulders and upper arms follow my head, but the lower part of my torso remains anchored inside the room. Thank God the brake works. Thankfully, too, the rain has held off, as have the clouds of incontinent starlings. So I lie there and look up into a clear blue sky. Then I swivel my head to the right and study the exterior decorations on this handsome Victorian building. Above is a window through which I can see a meeting in progress. Can the participants see me? If so, they aren't letting on.

By swivelling my head to the left and beyond 90 degrees I can see down into the square. People are walking past, jabbering into mobiles or lighting cigarettes. As far as I can tell, nobody looks up. They just assume that I'm the window cleaner - don't they?

"I think your head would look to them like an ornament on the building, a gargoyle," Killoran says when I'm back inside. "People could be looking at your body in an entirely different way, as an object."

Killoran is an engaging man of 28 who was born in Pennsylvania and now lives in Brooklyn. Slightly built, he is, by his own admission, obsessed with his own body. And other people's. In Hertford, Connecticut, he persuaded a taxi company to have its fleet painted the colour of flesh, on to which he transferred vinyl-adhesive body parts - nipples, belly buttons. "The idea was to make the car look like the body of the driver with his shirt off," he explains. "The drivers liked it because they thought they were going to get off with more women. And I liked it because there was this idea of getting into a body and leaving a body."

In Sydney, he had 3,000 T-shirts made with an eyelet fashioned in the front which acted as a camera obscura. The instructions read: "Pull the neck out and point the hole towards a source of light. The image should project on to your body. With practice, you should find windows, light bulbs and candles all over yourself_"

Endless hours of navel-gazing fun for Killoran. "I'm continually perplexed by the fact that my body is a container for me," he says. "Our physical circumstances define who we are and how we're perceived by ourselves. I'm interested in modifying the world so that we reconsider our circumstances."

A bit like any other artist, then. Except that he doesn't put on exhibits. He just likes to put viewers in positions where we see things differently, with a heightened sense of reality. Speaking as a human gargoyle, I can tell you that reality can become very heightened indeed when you're 50ft up the outside of a Gothic tower.

 Patrick Killoran's Observation Deck is at the Ikon Gallery, Birmingham (0121-248 0708), until November 26.

fields.headline: When will I be famous?
fields.standfirst: Daniel Johnston used to give his drawings and songs away. Now, he tells Iain Aitch , he wants them to help make him a star.
fields.trailText: Daniel Johnston used to give his drawings and songs away. Now, he tells Iain Aitch , he wants them to help make him a star.
fields.body:
During 1979 songwriter, performer and artist Daniel Johnston discovered the two great loves that would shape his life. The first was the music of the Beatles, whose influence is apparent in his lyrics and music, the second was a young woman named Laurie. Sadly for the then 18-year-old Johnston, Laurie already had a fiance, a fact that provided him with enough material for over 50 songs.

"My story was really quite dismal," says Johnston, speaking of his teenage years. "I'm a manic depressive and in junior high I had a nervous breakdown and I was really out of it. I discovered the Beatles and man, I was saved. I loved the music and everything about it. I started writing myself." The songs he began writing and recording were touching slices of emotion that detailed his rejection by Laurie and chronicled the downward trend in his mental health. His manic depression would lead to numerous hospital stays, which have seen him compared to "outsiders" such as Syd Barrett and even Van Gogh.

Johnston first came to prominence in the early 1990s with a rash of releases on independent labels, of music he had taped on a cheap cassette recorder during the 1980s. Those who cut through the sound quality found a naive, honest beauty amid the shaky recordings which feature Johnston playing organ or singing in his high-pitched voice over jazz 78s. The songs dealt with his fragile mental state with frankness and a wry, self-deprecating humour.

"Daniel's appeal is obvious: he writes very catchy songs," says Irwin Chusid, author of Songs in the Key of Z, an exploration of outsider music which features a chapter on Johnston. "He's done a lot of studio recording in the past 10 years, and in multi-tracked splendour, the strength of his songs is evident."

During 1983 Johnston enjoyed his most productive period to date, recording over 100 songs in the garages of family members. But this creative explosion was a symptom of his illness spiralling out of control. His state of mind is neatly summed up in the lyric of Desperate Man Blues: "I don't feel much like living. Can't see what for." The track comes from the tape he was recording as he finally suffered a breakdown.

Rather than seek treatment Johnston hit the road, settling a few months later in the Texan capital, Austin. By 1985 he had become a minor celebrity there by handing out his tapes to strangers in the street, or at McDonald's where he was working. He even appeared on an MTV programme about Austin and won a local award for best songwriter. But by the time of his second MTV appearance in December 1986 he was in hospital under heavy medication.

Johnston's breakdowns are part of his legend. There have been a litany of incidents, including the time he caused his father to crash-land a small aircraft he was piloting. Johnston became convinced that his father was Satan and tried to take the controls. Once again he was committed to a mental institution.

The late 1980s and early 1990s were a particularly difficult time for him, even though he was starting to receive critical acclaim. A trip to New York to record in 1988 resulted in the album 1990, a bleak affair with none of Johnston's trademark humour. The main theme is Satan and Johnston's belief that "the devil has Texas". It was a breakdown set to music; some reviewers accused Johnston's label of exploiting his illness to sell records.

The 1991 follow up, Artistic Vice, could not have been more different. Another stay in hospital was followed by an outpouring of upbeat material. He was backed for the first time by a full band, a bunch of misfits Johnston had met at a local church in West Virginia, where he was recuperating. Around this time he also recorded a tribute to his hero, John Lennon.

Johnston's love for Lennon is nothing, however, compared to the flame he holds for Laurie. His hope that he will eventually be united with Laurie, in this world or the next, has never wavered and at the age of 38 Johnston is still writing about her. Half of the songs on his most recent album, Rejected Unknown, seem to be about her, his hopes of romance having been boosted by her recent divorce. His plan now is to make the big time, because this may enable him to win her heart.

"I started talking to her a little bit on the phone," he says. "As she was no longer married I was very interested in talking to her. But it would be best if I waited until I was rich and famous, if I ever get to be rich and famous."

Although it seems barely possible that one as awkward as Johnston would hit the big time, he has come close. In 1994 he released Fun on Atlantic records in the US. Their relationship ended after disagreements on working methods and a realisation that an ill Johnston was not easy to market. Johnston was also courted by Elektra but refused to work with them because of his belief that one of the label's other acts, Metallica, were in league with Satan.

As the popularity of Johnston's music has blossomed so has appreciation of his childlike art work. He would previously hand out his felt-tip cartoons to friends and fans but has now come to see the value of his visual work and is regularly exhibiting it in the US. Simpsons creator Matt Groening purchased an armful of Johnston's drawings when the pair met. Ever the overgrown teenager, Johnston took the cheque, and Groening, straight to a comic shop.

Johnston's drawings reflect the same themes as his music, namely love and rejection, dreams and nightmares, good and evil. They are inhabited by the same cast of cartoon characters who often appear in his songs. Fellow felt-tip artist Graham Dolphin, who is curating Johnston's first London exhibition, became a fan the first time he saw Johnston's art on his record sleeves. "I liked the way that they were absolutely honest," he says. "He makes totally sincere art."

Whether Johnston is too sincere to make it big remains to be seen. His health is holding, aided by anti-depressants. His enthusiasm means that he will have plenty of people cheering him on and he doesn't mind too much whether they are laughing with him or at him, as long as they help him towards his goal of stardom, stadiums and getting the girl. "I'm not really Jerry Lewis but I understand that I'm kind of humorous," he says. Fingers crossed.
