fields.headline: My quiet word with Her Majesty
fields.standfirst: Clive Stafford Smith is a British lawyer who has spent 22 years fighting the death penalty in the US. He is also a staunch republican. So what did he say to the Queen when he met her to collect his OBE?
fields.trailText: Clive Stafford Smith is a British lawyer who has spent 22 years fighting the death penalty in the US. He is also a staunch republican. So what did he say to the Queen when he met her to collect his OBE?
fields.body:
What? Me, accept the Order of the British Empire? Someone who does not believe in the monarchy that bestows it, let alone the erstwhile empire? As someone who routinely rails at America's democratic hypocrisy for insisting on a place on the dictatorial UN Security Council, can I really accept something from the hands of someone whose sole source of authority is a particular configuration of DNA?

They gave it to me for "humanitarian" works, a polite euphemism for a couple of decades' work trying to thwart the US's efforts to execute thousands of its own citizens, and five of ours. Bashing the Americans does not seem much of a qualification for Her Majesty's gratitude (the Gentleman Usher to the Queen told us that was the proper way to address her). And there are many reasons to refuse it. But in the end, I accepted, although not without conceding several rounds in a long argument with my lefty friends.

My friends were polite, and did not ask whether I deserve any such recognition. But first, they demanded, how could any right-thinking person possibly accept an OBE when this denotes an Officer of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire, a title that combines pretension with colonial illusion.

Certainly, I must agree that it should be changed to the Order of England (now that Scotland and Wales are thankfully free to go it alone). So, the name alone is a reason to reject it.

Second, how could I even accept a "gong"? To this, at least I had some response. After years of firsthand observation, I recoil at the American predilection for expressing appreciation only with money. I have often wondered whether - casting aside the bizarre British tendency to bestow gongs disproportionately on those who are already privileged - it would not be better to have non-monetary tokens. Let us be done with the pretensions of chivalry, and make it more like a moral olympics, encouraging gold, silver and bronze medals for those who seek to foster decency in our society.

Third, my friends said, how could I accept a token so inextricably entwined with British nationalism? Again, a valid point, but I must confess that the Americans have instilled in me an increasing appreciation for the country of my birth. I have spent 22 years in the belly of the beast, watching the excesses of the US as my clients have died in the electric chair. I now marvel at Britons who ogle across the Atlantic. Are they so blind that they do not see the future they covet? I have been held up at gunpoint five times in five years, a record unmatched by most London neighbourhoods. I'm not sure which I found more depressing: the prevalence of crime or the heart lessness it instils in the population at large.

When I complained that my British client, Nicky Ingram, was not allowed to die with dignity in Georgia's electric chair, the Atlanta paper published a letter with just one word: Good. Truly, I have seen our future in America, and it does not work. Some of our well-known authors have recently flown off to New York to a bellow of criticism. Good luck to them. My years in the US have taught me to appreciate the better traits of the British.

My friends did not raise the most troubling question of all: the Queen officially directs her subalterns to hang people in the Caribbean. In the name of Queen Elizabeth II, a warrant is issued "to authorise and command you to carry the said sentence into execution by causing the said [human being] to suffer death . . . at some convenient place" within the Caribbean prison system.

Could I really accept an award, supposedly for my battle against executions, when others received a "convenient" hanging from the same hand? Since I was not born to be a prosecutor, I was unwilling to believe that the Queen, a human being severed from the reality of the world, personally savours a good hanging. I doubted that she even knew of her role. So, without wishing to be churlish, I resolved to test the point at the OBE-awarding ceremony.

When she gave me the medal, this kindly old lady was probably nodding off after making brief small talk with a hundred momentary acquaintances. Amid so many others whose worthy acts took place far closer to home, she seemed confused when her equerry whispered some hint as to why I was there, having fought in faraway lands against the death penalty. When I thanked her, and suggested that I hoped one day to ensure that no executions should be carried out in her name or anyone else's, she simply nodded.

The ephemeral audience in the gilded ballroom was over, and I can hardly pretend that we enjoyed a lengthy debate on the issue. Yet I very much doubt she knows that her officers give "sufficient warrant" to kill around her Commonwealth.

But if the discussion had ended there, my friends would still have won the debate, and I could not have accepted this medal. What possible good could come of such self-aggrandisement?

Ultimately, my reasons were two-fold. I have been discreetly informed that it was the Foreign Office that put my name forward for this award. In being kind enough to recognise a legal war of attrition against the Americans, my government has made a small, public condemnation of these executions. To be sure, I resent it when those in power fail to save the lives of my friends on death row, but it was John Major, not Tony Blair, who refused to ask the Americans to stop Nicky Ingram's death. In contrast, Robin Cook has expressed strong opposition to the death penalty worldwide.

And then there is the question of the future. The government has taken a quiet moral stance. In the next few months, it will have plenty of occasions to put just a little of its moral authority where its mouth is. Kris Maharaj, formerly of Peckenham and now on Florida's death row, will shortly learn whether he gets a new trial. Jackie Elliott, born near me in Suffolk, waits lonely for death in George W Bush's Texan execution chamber. Scotsman Kenny Ritchie sits innocent beside Ohio's gurney. And then there is Tracy Housel, perhaps in the most dire danger, hovering only one appeal away from Georgia's electric chair.

The OBE says nothing about me, but it does say that the government believes it to be in the interest of Britain that our citizens should not be executed. I did not ask for the honour, though it was a generous act to give it. But I will be asking the government for help with my British clients. And I expect it to act in the interests of Britons - and to help me prevent their execution.

They gave it to me for "humanitarian" works, a polite euphemism for a couple of decades' work trying to thwart the US's efforts to execute thousands of its own citizens, and five of ours. Bashing the Americans does not seem much of a qualification for Her Majesty's gratitude (the Gentleman Usher to the Queen told us that was the proper way to address her). fields.headline: What Lucy did next
fields.standfirst: She cast herself away on a desert island, then retreated to a remote spot in the Scottish Highlands. Now Lucy Irvine is back from her latest adventure.
fields.trailText: She cast herself away on a desert island, then retreated to a remote spot in the Scottish Highlands. Now Lucy Irvine is back from her latest adventure.
fields.body:
Handshakes must pose a problem for Lucy Irvine. They represent convention, which she dislikes, and require superficial social contact, which she has spent a lifetime avoiding. So the hand that is offered - one that has speared fish, grazed over coral and wielded a machete - is inanimate and reluctant, despite the wide, welcoming smile.

Irvine calls herself a "solitaire", a woman who craves the ability to do things for herself; her way and on her own. It's a trait that took her away from home at the age of 12, through jobs as charlady, monkey-keeper and tax clerk, then, famously, to the tropical island of Tuin with ageing adventurer Gerald Kingsland, where she became the castaway girl, or the focus of a freak show, as she now sees it.

Returning from the Torres Strait and retreating from the media maul, she settled, as far as her nature would allow, in Inchreoch, an isolated house in the Scottish Highlands, with no visible neighbours and water from a burn. It is here she has raised her three sons from two brief relationships.

"I think I probably am hooked on remoteness," she says. "I like independence. The fact that I have lived in situations in which there simply isn't a Tesco down the road means it does not enter my head to aspire to the sort of lifestyle many people feel is real life. I hate paraphernalia and I am a very private person."

It is 16 years since Irvine returned from Tuin and wrote her bestselling book on the experience, and while she harboured dreams of taking off, with her boys, for another adventure, she did nothing to make it happen. Until last year, when a chance meeting brought her into contact with Diana Hepworth, an octogenarian Englishwoman who had spirited her family away to the remote Outer Solomon Islands 40 years earlier and wanted Irvine to spend a year with them and tell the story of their "wonderful life". Only it wasn't so wonderful, as Irvine was to discover and has written about in Faraway, her compelling new book - part Swiss Family Robinson, part Heart of Darkness.

Irvine hesitated only slightly at the idea of taking her sons to Pigeon Island, a five-acre dot in the Pacific ocean. "I had desperately wanted to give them a taste of the positive side of remote island living," Irvine says of Magnus, then 13, Benji, 11, and Joe, nine. "Nothing as raw and life-threatening as I'd experienced. Pigeon seemed the ideal compromise because there were other people there and buildings. I didn't worry."

The last leg of the journey to Pigeon, an eight-hour canoe trip, almost cost them their lives when a vicious squall blew up. Eventually battling through, they were greeted by the bikini-clad, be-ribboned figure of Diana Hepworth, a former model, who served dinner on the veranda, complete with hibiscus flowers, cut-glass dishes and a "housegirl" on hand.

Diana and Tom Hepworth had arrived on Pigeon in 1957, 10 years after quitting the grey of postwar Britain for a life at sea. After sailing around the tropics, they decided to settle; they wanted to raise a family in paradise and Pigeon seemed as close as it might get. They bought the islet from the local Reef Islanders for £15 and a couple of sticks of tobacco.

But their life in paradise was to be blighted by tragedy, pride and the taint of Empire. When their daughter Tasha was a toddler, her fits and tantrums were eventually diagnosed as severe mental impairment. Then, when she was five, Tasha was sexually assaulted by a man from a neighbouring island and Diana had to deal with it in the only accepted way: publicly naming and shaming the perpetrator. Twin sons followed, but puberty brought further problems and a gradual estrangement between boys and parents.

Irvine charts the Hepworths' life through Tom's diaries, carefully detailed and laboriously kept. He had wanted to write the book himself but died in 1994 before he had a chance to complete it. His diary made disturbing reading for Irvine. The family never integrated with their Reef Island neighbours - something Irvine made a point of doing and her boys did without thinking. Instead, the Hepworths maintained a haughty, dismissive distance from the people among whom they had settled.

"It is very hard to get your head around the prejudice," Irvine says. "You have to remember that these people were behaving quite normally for their time. They were from another era; they had the Empire mindset." She says she managed to look past the politically incorrect exterior and see in Diana the indomitable spirit of a fellow adventurer. "Having read Tom's diaries, I could see where she was coming from."

Irvine herself learnt many things on Pigeon. The first was that paradise is not a place: "It is very much in your head." The second, that children should not be raised somewhere so remote that they are unable to integrate naturally with others. Most importantly, she learnt that perhaps she was ready to break her self-imposed isolation.

Several years ago, after a failed attempt to live with the father of her two youngest sons, Irvine had pronounced herself celibate. "My body came back to me on Pigeon," she says. "I began to feel less distant from my own feelings. Solitude had become a habit and it is something that I am now, in my mid-40s, starting to regret. I don't think the big bad outside world is all bad and mad by any means."

There is already talk of turning Faraway into a film, as Castaway was, and Irvine is in negotiations to work as a freelance writer based in Scotland in the summer and overseas when winter sets in. Her beloved boys are in a boarding school close to Inchreoch and, spurred by their sociability and her new-found fascination with other people's lives, she says she can now meet the fresh challenge she has set herself. "Just to be able to mix and have fun is something that might be my next big adventure. If it doesn't work, it doesn't work and I will end up a grey-haired-old-lady-writing-with-cat. It would not surprise me to find that happens but now I feel I should give the rest of society another go. I'm ready for it."

fields.headline: And now for the forecast
fields.standfirst: People have been staring into crystal balls for hundreds of years, sometimes with alarming accuracy. But usually they have been hugely, and entertainingly, wrong. Jonathan Margolis looks back at the history of futurology - and risks a few predictions of his own.
fields.trailText: People have been staring into crystal balls for hundreds of years, sometimes with alarming accuracy. But usually they have been hugely, and entertainingly, wrong. Jonathan Margolis looks back at the history of futurology - and risks a few predictions of his own.
fields.body:
Buried deep in the stack at the Bodleian library in Oxford, from which it is exhumed on average once every 50 years, lies a forgotten early 18th-century book which is both fascinating and disappointing by turns. A rare volume - and deservedly so - Memoirs of the 20th Century: Being Original Letters of State under George VI was the first ever complete work of futurology.

Written around 1730 by a clergyman, Samuel Madden, it opens intriguingly enough, with a letter datelined Constantinople, Nov 3 1997, but sadly goes downhill from that point. Madden's 1997 is dominated by a George VI who is a mighty world emperor, but most of the book's 527 turgid pages are mired in contemporary, 18th-century concerns.

A couple of ideas suggest, none the less, that Madden really was thinking systematically about the future. He envisages the establishment of public granaries in all villages - pretty radical stuff, really - and even some prototype women's rights legislation. Thirty years later, another, more ambitious forward-looking book appeared, The Reign of George VI, 1900 to 1925, became a bestseller, and futurology was on its way.

This George was also a conquering hero, who tames the nations the anonymous author believed would be the miscreants of the early 20th century: France and Russia. The latter, 25,000 of whose troops sack Durham in a war of 1900, is seen as the world's second most powerful nation by this time, with America close behind. Not bad at all as predictions go.

The book wasn't all politics, either. It foresaw the legacy of the canal-building boom, which had just begun, and extrapolated that by 1900, a network of waterways would form a superhighway system, with the effect that "Villages grew into towns and towns became cities". Substitute trains for barges and you are looking at a decent stab at what today's multinationals call trend forecasting.

The Reign of George VI also envisages a king who hates modern architecture so much that he builds a new English capital city, called Stanley, in Rutland, which he fills with neo-classical buildings and surrounds by artificial mountains. Fanciful, perhaps, but strangely reminiscent of our own heir to the throne's ideal village, twee little Poundberry, in Dorset.

Futurologists tend not to get a great press. No wonder Samuel Goldwyn was moved to observe, "Never predict anything - especially the future", and Arthur C Clarke, whose 2001 has in so many ways failed to materialise, to comment wryly that, "The future isn't what it used to be."

Yet it is arguable that we are far too harsh in smug retrospect on those who attempt to peer round chronological corners. Naturally, when we try to envision the future, we always get trivialities such as the fashions and shape of cars wrong. Those sorts of visual cues are decided on a whim rather than a response to need. But most futurological predictions I have come across are almost spookily prescient in more significant respects. Take this extraordinary forecast, made in 1661-70 years before Samuel Madden - in a scientific treatise by the philosopher Joseph Glanvill, a clergyman and chaplain to Charles II, and a founder member of the Royal Society. "To them that come after us," Glanvill wrote, "It may be as ordinary to buy a pair of wings to fly to the remotest regions, as now a pair of boots to ride a journey; and to confer at the distance of the Indies by sympathetic conveyances, may be as usual in the future as by literary correspondence . . . I doubt not posterity will find many things that are now rumours verified into practical realities. It may be that, some ages hence, a voyage to the Southern tracts, yea possibly to the Moon, will not be more strange than one to America . . . the restoration of grey hairs to juvenility and the renewing of the exhausted marrow may at length be elicited without a miracle; and the turning of the now comparatively desert world into a paradise may not improbably be effected from late agriculture."

By the late-Victorian era, futurology was becoming really quite slick. Jules Verne described, for example, how musical recitals would by 2000 be sent down a wire from the artist to pianos around the world. Well, MP3 music on the internet hasn't worked out quite like that, but it's hardly dissimilar.

An American journalist, David Goodman Croly, writing in 1888 as Sir Oracle, predicted for the coming new century: "Women throughout the world will enjoy increased opportunities and privileges. Along with this new freedom will come social tolerance of sexual conduct formerly condoned only in men. In addition, because of the greater availability of jobs, more women will choose not to have children."

Twelve years later, another journalist, John Elfreth Watkins, having interviewed "the wisest and most careful men in our greatest institutions of science and learning" on behalf of The Ladies' Home Journal made a brilliant series of consumer predictions. The future, Watkins reported, would witness air-conditioning, international telephones, colour photography, frozen meals, medicine taken through skin patches, snowmobiles, the tapping of energy from wind, tides and sunlight - and out-of-season fruit.

Most amazing of all, perhaps, was Watkins's prophecy that, "Persons and things of all kinds will be brought within focus of cameras connected electrically with screens at opposite end of circuits, thousands of miles at a span."

John Maynard Keynes, also writing at the end of the 19th century, even prophesied e-commerce: "The inhabitant of London could order by telephone, sipping his morning tea in bed, the various products of the whole earth and reasonably expect their early delivery upon his doorstep; he could at the same moment and by the same means adventure his wealth in the natural resources and new enterprises of any quarter of the world, and share, without exertion or even trouble, in their prospective fruits and advantages." (Modern web shoppers will applaud Keynes's foresight, but regret that the "delivery upon the doorstep" part has yet to be sorted out.)

Oddly enough, the would-be seers who consistently get the future wrong are specialists in their field, the media's beloved "experts", whose futurological track record isn't nearly as good as that of those whose approach is that of the generalist (aka, inspired guessing).

The first expert futurologist was probably the Dorking vicar and demographer, Thomas Malthus, who in 1798 anonymously wrote a sensational pamphlet sounding the alarm on overpopulation. People had been complaining of overpopulation since Horace in 20BC, but Malthus was so convinced humanity would run out of space within a few years that he favoured effectively culling the working class, for which he was later derided by Karl Marx as "a miserable parson".

Two hundred years on, Malthus still has his fans, and the fashion for apocalyptic forecasting grows apace. In 1964, a British physicist, John Fremlin, speculated in New Scientist on population trends for the coming 1,000 years, and argued that by the middle of the 29th century, 60,000 trillion people, a million times today's population, would spend their lives lying prone and eating recycled human bodies in cubicles in 2,000 storey buildings spread across both land and what had been sea.

The apocalyptic certainty of choice today, of course, is global warming, which if its advocates are right, would be the profoundest ever future prediction. It is worth noting, however, that just a couple of decades ago, many of the same experts were confidently predicting global cooling , and a new ice age. "A new ice age must now stand alongside a nuclear war as a likely source of wholesale misery and death," said International Wildlife magazine in 1975. The next year, Science magazine reported that we were "heading for extensive northern hemisphere glaciation."

Even experts proferring non-apocalyptic futurology have been hugely and entertainingly wrong over the years. The Nobel prize winning physicist, Ernest Rutherford, the founder of nuclear physics, once declared that talk of nuclear power was "moonshine". Britain's astronomer royal, Sir Harold Spencer Jones, dismissed the idea of space flight as "bunk" in 1957 - a fortnight before the Soviet Union launched Sputnik 1.

And then there was Thomas J Watson, the former CEO of IBM, who never quite lived down a statement he made in the late 1940s: "I think there is a world market for maybe five computers." (Perhaps he really meant five computers per household.) No wonder that, in another of his dictums, Arthur C Clarke said that "when a distinguished but elderly scientist states that something is possible, he is almost certainly right, but when he states that something is impossible, he is very probably wrong."

So what predictions for the next century would I make, having interviewed dozens of both expert and generalist futurologists, and explored the pitfalls and triumphs of past futurology? Well, I can't see the old favourite, household robots, ever taking off - another massive instruction book to read, another machine to drive us mad with software seizures.

It is hard, similarly, to see artificial, computer intelligence being much of a starter, although it's promised for as early as 2015. Even if it could be achieved (which human brain experts are very sceptical of, pointing out that our most powerful computer currently has the intellect of an earthworm) there would, surely, be no market for computers which, when given a boring job, told you to do it your damned self.

We like computers, surely, for their artificial stupidity . And if they get too clever, won't they soon start complaining of cruelty? (You laugh, but cruelty to computers is said to be close to becoming a social issue, and is already being discussed by acade mics specialising in human rights.)

Genetic engineering will, I strongly suspect, also fail to deliver a fraction of what its advocates promise. There will be endless cases reported in the press around 2025 of people who supposedly had the "criminal gene" edited out of their DNA, and subsequently been convicted of car theft. Likewise, parents who paid to have the "gay gene" excised (probably illegally) from their children's make-up and ended up disappointed by the result will be locked in litigation with the clinics who did the genetic work.

Time travel, I can't see happening either. It took the great Stephen Hawking to point out the obvious objection - that if it were possible, surely we would have seen tourists from the future by now? Quantum teleportation a la Star Trek is said to be a possibility, however. But whether a teleported human will arrive at his destination complete with his mind and memory intact will be an interesting one to watch.

Medical advances, meanwhile, may well soon make death a lifestyle option rather than an inevitability, and this could have extraordinary repercussions. If you take the view, for example, that religion has only existed for the past few thousand years because of our fear of death, could the prospect of eternal life finally destroy religion once and for all? And could that, in turn, lead to an overwhelmingly amoral society?

Space travel - and the eventual colonisation of other planets is probably inevitable if we all live for hundreds of years - may throw up some interesting conundrums too. For what will be tax position of the colonists? The first generation living on another planet may feel allegiance to the country that paid for their trip and the building of their base. But thereafter, it seems probable that Mars-born humans who only know Earth as a dot in the night sky, might resist attempts to tax them. Maybe there will be a space repeat of the 1773 Boston tea party?

One thing is certain for the future. Just as we fervently believe we are living in a special time, and are a special generation witnessing a huge turning point in human affairs - so will our grandchildren and their grandchildren. Every generation thinks the same, and they're always just a little bit wrong.

 A Brief History of Tomorrow: The Future, Past and Present, by Jonathan Margolis, is published by Bloomsbury, priced £14.99

A rare volume - and deservedly so - Memoirs of the 20th Century: Being Original Letters of State under George VI was the first ever complete work of futurology. Written around 1730 by a clergyman, Samuel Madden, it opens intriguingly enough, with a letter datelined Constantinople, Nov 3 1997, but sadly goes downhill from that point. Madden's 1997 is dominated by a George VI who is a mighty world emperor, but most of the book's 527 turgid pages are mired in contemporary, 18th-century concerns. A couple of ideas suggest, none the less, that Madden really was thinking systematically about the future. He envisages the establishment of public granaries in all villages - pretty radical stuff, really - and even some prototype women's rights legislation. Thirty years later, another, more ambitious forward-looking book appeared, The Reign of George VI, 1900 to 1925, became a bestseller, and futurology was on its way. This George was also a conquering hero, who tames the nations the anonymous author believed would be the miscreants of the early 20th century: France and Russia. The latter, 25,000 of whose troops sack Durham in a war of 1900, is seen as the world's second most powerful nation by this time, with America close behind. Not bad at all as predictions go. The book wasn't all politics, either. It foresaw the legacy of the canal-building boom, which had just begun, and extrapolated that by 1900, a network of waterways would form a superhighway system, with the effect that "Villages grew into towns and towns became cities". Substitute trains for barges and you are looking at a decent stab at what today's multinationals call trend forecasting. The Reign of George VI also envisages a king who hates modern architecture so much that he builds a new English capital city, called Stanley, in Rutland, which he fills with neo-classical buildings and surrounds by artificial mountains. Fanciful, perhaps, but strangely reminiscent of our own heir to the throne's ideal village, twee little Poundberry, in Dorset. Futurologists tend not to get a great press. No wonder Samuel Goldwyn was moved to observe, "Never predict anything - especially the future", and Arthur C Clarke, whose 2001 has in so many ways failed to materialise, to comment wryly that, "The future isn't what it used to be." Yet it is arguable that we are far too harsh in smug retrospect on those who attempt to peer round chronological corners. Naturally, when we try to envision the future, we always get trivialities such as the fashions and shape of cars wrong. Those sorts of visual cues are decided on a whim rather than a response to need. But most futurological predictions I have come across are almost spookily prescient in more significant respects. Take this extraordinary forecast, made in 1661-70 years before Samuel Madden - in a scientific treatise by the philosopher Joseph Glanvill, a clergyman and chaplain to Charles II, and a founder member of the Royal Society. "To them that come after us," Glanvill wrote, "It may be as ordinary to buy a pair of wings to fly to the remotest regions, as now a pair of boots to ride a journey; and to confer at the distance of the Indies by sympathetic conveyances, may be as usual in the future as by literary correspondence . . . I doubt not posterity will find many things that are now rumours verified into practical realities. It may be that, some ages hence, a voyage to the Southern tracts, yea possibly to the Moon, will not be more strange than one to America . . . the restoration of grey hairs to juvenility and the renewing of the exhausted marrow may at length be elicited without a miracle; and the turning of the now comparatively desert world into a paradise may not improbably be effected from late agriculture." By the late-Victorian era, futurology was becoming really quite slick. Jules Verne described, for example, how musical recitals would by 2000 be sent down a wire from the artist to pianos around the world. Well, MP3 music on the internet hasn't worked out quite like that, but it's hardly dissimilar. An American journalist, David Goodman Croly, writing in 1888 as Sir Oracle, predicted for the coming new century: "Women throughout the world will enjoy increased opportunities and privileges. Along with this new freedom will come social tolerance of sexual conduct formerly condoned only in men. In addition, because of the greater availability of jobs, more women will choose not to have children." Twelve years later, another journalist, John Elfreth Watkins, having interviewed "the wisest and most careful men in our greatest institutions of science and learning" on behalf of The Ladies' Home Journal made a brilliant series of consumer predictions. The future, Watkins reported, would witness air-conditioning, international telephones, colour photography, frozen meals, medicine taken through skin patches, snowmobiles, the tapping of energy from wind, tides and sunlight - and out-of-season fruit. Most amazing of all, perhaps, was Watkins's prophecy that, "Persons and things of all kinds will be brought within focus of cameras connected electrically with screens at opposite end of circuits, thousands of miles at a span." John Maynard Keynes, also writing at the end of the 19th century, even prophesied e-commerce: "The inhabitant of London could order by telephone, sipping his morning tea in bed, the various products of the whole earth and reasonably expect their early delivery upon his doorstep; he could at the same moment and by the same means adventure his wealth in the natural resources and new enterprises of any quarter of the world, and share, without exertion or even trouble, in their prospective fruits and advantages." (Modern web shoppers will applaud Keynes's foresight, but regret that the "delivery upon the doorstep" part has yet to be sorted out.) Oddly enough, the would-be seers who consistently get the future wrong are specialists in their field, the media's beloved "experts", whose futurological track record isn't nearly as good as that of those whose approach is that of the generalist (aka, inspired guessing). The first expert futurologist was probably the Dorking vicar and demographer, Thomas Malthus, who in 1798 anonymously wrote a sensational pamphlet sounding the alarm on overpopulation. People had been complaining of overpopulation since Horace in 20BC, but Malthus was so convinced humanity would run out of space within a few years that he favoured effectively culling the working class, for which he was later derided by Karl Marx as "a miserable parson". Two hundred years on, Malthus still has his fans, and the fashion for apocalyptic forecasting grows apace. In 1964, a British physicist, John Fremlin, speculated in New Scientist on population trends for the coming 1,000 years, and argued that by the middle of the 29th century, 60,000 trillion people, a million times today's population, would spend their lives lying prone and eating recycled human bodies in cubicles in 2,000 storey buildings spread across both land and what had been sea. The apocalyptic certainty of choice today, of course, is global warming, which if its advocates are right, would be the profoundest ever future prediction. It is worth noting, however, that just a couple of decades ago, many of the same experts were confidently predicting global cooling , and a new ice age. "A new ice age must now stand alongside a nuclear war as a likely source of wholesale misery and death," said International Wildlife magazine in 1975. The next year, Science magazine reported that we were "heading for extensive northern hemisphere glaciation." Even experts proferring non-apocalyptic futurology have been hugely and entertainingly wrong over the years. The Nobel prize winning physicist, Ernest Rutherford, the founder of nuclear physics, once declared that talk of nuclear power was "moonshine". Britain's astronomer royal, Sir Harold Spencer Jones, dismissed the idea of space flight as "bunk" in 1957 - a fortnight before the Soviet Union launched Sputnik 1. And then there was Thomas J Watson, the former CEO of IBM, who never quite lived down a statement he made in the late 1940s: "I think there is a world market for maybe five computers." (Perhaps he really meant five computers per household.) No wonder that, in another of his dictums, Arthur C Clarke said that "when a distinguished but elderly scientist states that something is possible, he is almost certainly right, but when he states that something is impossible, he is very probably wrong." So what predictions for the next century would I make, having interviewed dozens of both expert and generalist futurologists, and explored the pitfalls and triumphs of past futurology? Well, I can't see the old favourite, household robots, ever taking off - another massive instruction book to read, another machine to drive us mad with software seizures. It is hard, similarly, to see artificial, computer intelligence being much of a starter, although it's promised for as early as 2015. Even if it could be achieved (which human brain experts are very sceptical of, pointing out that our most powerful computer currently has the intellect of an earthworm) there would, surely, be no market for computers which, when given a boring job, told you to do it your damned self. We like computers, surely, for their artificial stupidity . And if they get too clever, won't they soon start complaining of cruelty? (You laugh, but cruelty to computers is said to be close to becoming a social issue, and is already being discussed by acade mics specialising in human rights.) Genetic engineering will, I strongly suspect, also fail to deliver a fraction of what its advocates promise. There will be endless cases reported in the press around 2025 of people who supposedly had the "criminal gene" edited out of their DNA, and subsequently been convicted of car theft. Likewise, parents who paid to have the "gay gene" excised (probably illegally) from their children's make-up and ended up disappointed by the result will be locked in litigation with the clinics who did the genetic work. Time travel, I can't see happening either. It took the great Stephen Hawking to point out the obvious objection - that if it were possible, surely we would have seen tourists from the future by now? Quantum teleportation a la Star Trek is said to be a possibility, however. But whether a teleported human will arrive at his destination complete with his mind and memory intact will be an interesting one to watch. Medical advances, meanwhile, may well soon make death a lifestyle option rather than an inevitability, and this could have extraordinary repercussions. If you take the view, for example, that religion has only existed for the past few thousand years because of our fear of death, could the prospect of eternal life finally destroy religion once and for all? And could that, in turn, lead to an overwhelmingly amoral society? Space travel - and the eventual colonisation of other planets is probably inevitable if we all live for hundreds of years - may throw up some interesting conundrums too. For what will be tax position of the colonists? The first generation living on another planet may feel allegiance to the country that paid for their trip and the building of their base. But thereafter, it seems probable that Mars-born humans who only know Earth as a dot in the night sky, might resist attempts to tax them. Maybe there will be a space repeat of the 1773 Boston tea party? One thing is certain for the future. Just as we fervently believe we are living in a special time, and are a special generation witnessing a huge turning point in human affairs - so will our grandchildren and their grandchildren. Every generation thinks the same, and they're always just a little bit wrong.  A Brief History of Tomorrow: The Future, Past and Present, by Jonathan Margolis, is published by Bloomsbury, priced £14.99

fields.headline: Art attack
fields.trailText: Last weekend, Olga and Olivia had a day of culture. As they both work in the Art World, they needed to be up to date, so they started with Thrift Shop Art, then tried Thrift Shop Ceramics, some of which they would have adored if their infant children had made it, then they went to some real art about Altered States.
fields.body:
Last weekend, Olga and Olivia had a day of culture. As they both work in the Art World, they needed to be up to date, so they started with Thrift Shop Art, then tried Thrift Shop Ceramics, some of which they would have adored if their infant children had made it, then they went to some real art about Altered States.

It was round about this time that they stopped having fun. One can only take so much mental torment, blood, innards and rubbish. Oh, for a cheery flower painting or uplifting landscape, but no such luck.

Altered States meant flickery videos, projections, bad soundtracks, darkened rooms and voices of the dead. Olga and Olivia trudged into a pitch black room, sat on uncomfortable chairs and suddenly a screen lit up showing a scrappy bit of text about someone's attempts to communicate with severed heads. Then more pitch black, then the same scrap of text again. And again.

But just as they were about to give up in despair, someone told them about a perfect Art Work showing at Sadler's Wells. Marvellous. They rushed home to book. No need, said Sadler's Wells. There are plenty of seats. So they floated off in plenty of time to have a relaxing coffee before the show.

The refurbished theatre looked ravishing, very modern and hi-tech, but what a horrid surprise! Huge queues stretched from every ticket office out into the street. Olga and Olivia stood in a queue. For 20 minutes. Then, just their luck, the person in front had lost his tickets and an in-depth inquiry was under way. At last they reached the ticket office, with their credit cards. Just a quick swipe of the cards and they would be in.

Wrong. "Could you please do it on one card," asked the ticket lady, "because I've got to write your names and addresses down, and it'll take a long time." Then she poked the letters into her keyboard with one finger while smoke poured from Olga's ears, the queues grew longer and the ballet started.

But as they rushed into the auditorium, Olga suddenly had a fearful sense of deja vu. Yes! She had seen these performers before, hated it and swore never to go again! Her memory is obviously on the way out. Perhaps, in the Art World, that is a bonus.

fields.headline: Pass notes
fields.standfirst: No: 1756 Uri Geller
fields.trailText: No: 1756 Uri Geller
fields.body:
Ah, yes. The world famous magician. Shush! The celebrated metal-bender is a "psychic". People who claim otherwise tend to hear from his lawyers.

Right. Bit litigious, is he? And then some. Last week, he announced he's suing the makers of Pokémon. He says, reasonably, that an evil Pokémon character wielding a bent spoon, "Yun Geller", is based on him. He also claims, perhaps less reasonably, that the Japanese maker owes him "hundreds of millions of dollars" in damages.

Short of a few quid, is he? Couldn't he just predict Wednesday's lottery results or something? Surprisingly, for a man who claims to have supernatural powers, he says he can't do that. His main concern, apparently, is the effect evil Pokémon will have on kids. And anyway, he's reputed to have made millions locating oil and minerals for big business.

Not as if the Pokémon people can't afford it, though. True, and Geller's headline-grabbing lawsuits have a habit of petering out before they actually reach court.

Perhaps he should be doing something more productive with his time. Reversing global warming. Ending all war. Erasing the Millennium Dome . . . He's done better. He says his powers helped Reading Football Club to the premiership play-offs.

I guess Sven-Goran'll be getting in touch, then. Uri claims to be able to do the impossible, but some things . . .

So what's Uri got that the rest of us don't? Can I have some? No problem. Try contacting the residents of planet Hoova.

Um, OK. Have you got the number? Sadly, they have to call you. Geller claims to have been left messages by the aforementioned extraterrestrials on his answering machine. It's all about who you know, these days.

Do say: So, Uri, the 3.40 at Newmarket . . . any tips?

Don't say: Not a bad trick, mate. I saw Paul Daniels do it in Blackpool last year.

webTitle: View from elsewhere: Luke Harding in Afghanistan

fields.headline: Luke Harding @ Herat
fields.trailText: Arriving at Kabul airport for a 6am flight to Herat, in the north-west of Afghanistan, it soon became clear that this was going to be no ordinary journey.
fields.body:
Arriving at Kabul airport for a 6am flight to Herat, in the north-west of Afghanistan, it soon became clear that this was going to be no ordinary journey. For a start, only one other passenger was waiting in the gloom. Everyone else was at the mosque. They were right to pray. If British Airways is the world's favourite airline, then Ariana Airways - Afghanistan's national carrier - is the world's most dangerous. Since America imposed sanctions on Afghanistan a year ago, none of its planes has been serviced.

Two years ago an Ariana 727 ploughed into a mountainside, reducing the fleet to three. Then in February, an internal flight to Mazar-i-Sharif was hijacked. The plane ended up at Stansted airport, where most of the passengers promptly claimed asylum. Seeking to calm my nerves, I had asked a pilot the night before departure how safe the remaining two Russian-built Antonov 24 planes were. "Completely unsafe," he replied. "The pilots are themselves too scared to fly. If I were you I'd throw your ticket in the bin."

Gradually more passengers emerged into the chilly Kabul morning from yellow and black taxis. Four wraith-like women dressed in faded blue burkas moved among them, begging. Though it has been four years since the Taliban swept into Kabul, Ariana is still issuing the same pre-revolutionary tickets. They carry a picture of Afghanistan's most famous tourist attraction - a giant Buddha statue - on the back. Or at least they did - someone in a back office spends all day scrubbing out the Buddha's face with a black pen.

There is no x-ray machine at Kabul airport, which perhaps explains last February's hijack. Instead, a security guard rummages briefly through your luggage. After half an hour we trooped on to the mortar-damaged runway, and climbed aboard. The six burka-clad women on the flight all sat together at the back. And then the engines started - not with the spluttering I had expected but with a confident purr. The plane even took off, rising into the mountains above a shattered city of bombed out houses.

I started chatting to Abdul Hakim as we passed over the immense Hindu Kush mountains. Mr Hakim, it transpired, had been Afghanistan's minister for the interior until the Russians invaded in 1979, when he lost his job. He was also friends with Mohammad Daoud, the prime minister, who was murdered in a communist coup. "The 70s was a marvellous period for Afghanistan. Lots of tourists came here." I asked him what he thought of the Taliban. His face fell. "They have brought peace," he said. Mrs Hakim sat silently. With her face still concealed, she discreetly lifted her burka to peer out of the window.

About halfway through our two-hour flight, a man carrying a Kalashnikov sauntered down the aisle. He was clearly not the Ariana steward, busy doling out Iranian cherry juice and cake. Sensing my alarm, Mr Hakim explained that since the hijack the Taliban had decreed that two armed guards should travel with every Ariana plane to prevent further mischief. Below us, the undulating Hindu Kush was giving way to a flat, dry landscape. We were nearly at Herat. The wheels popped down. Things were looking up. One of the two tyres on my side of the plane even had tread on it.

Herat was the capital of medieval Islam. The city has long been famed for its learning and liberal traditions. All this changed when the Taliban arrived in 1995, closing down the girls' schools and the public baths. But Herat is still a long way from Kabul. Five years on there are signs that its inhabitants are making their own accommodation with the Taliban's edicts. You can secretly buy TV sets here. During the World Cup, rumour has it that five Taliban knocked on the door of someone who had one - not to smash it up, but because they wanted to watch the football.

webTitle: Brown's £1bn tax breaks to boost inner cities

fields.headline: Brown's £1bn tax breaks to boost inner cities
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: A £1bn string of tax breaks designed to end the dereliction of Britain's inner cities and the middle class flight to the countryside is to be announced this week by the chancellor, Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
A £1bn string of tax breaks designed to end the dereliction of Britain's inner cities and the middle class flight to the countryside is to be announced this week by the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

The main measure will be the abolition of stamp duty for domestic and commercial properties in run down areas - a move which will cost the Treasury £100m a year and save some house purchasers thousands of pounds.

In further measures to end urban sprawl and the relentless pressure on greenfield sites, the chancellor is also to announce new fiscal incentives for developers to clean contaminated land. He will announce that developers can immediately claim back the cost of restoring derelict land, instead of waiting until the site is sold.

The move will reduce risk, cited as the main reason developers will not touch contaminated land: 58% of property developers blame contamination for blocking investment.

The chancellor will also offer 100% capital allowances for property owners converting space above shops or commercial property into flats. A similar measure has already been introduced in Ireland with success. As many as 73,000 additional homes could be created in London alone by the measure.

In a fourth move, he will reduce VAT for conversion of houses into flats for rent.

The stamp duty relief will benefit property buyers of old and new property. Stamp duty is levied at a rate of 1% on homes sold at between £60,000 and £250,000. For houses above that rate, stamp duty is levied at 3%.

Ministers are likely to define deprivation more tightly than simply by borough so as to avoid anomalies of wealthy home owners gaining tax breaks by purchasing property in a rich area of a run down borough.

The measures amount to the government's fiscal response to the urban task force set up by the government and chaired by the architect Lord Rogers of Riverside. Lord Rogers argued the pressure on rural greenfield sites could only be relieved by an urban renaissance designed to restore population density in Britain's big inner cities.

He is likely to welcome the Treasury's overall approach even if the chancellor has rejected his main proposal for the equalisation of VAT on new buildings and conversions.

Lord Rogers had proposed tax relief on home contents and car insurance in run down areas, as well as more incentives through the council tax system to end the social polarisation of poorer urban areas.

Mr Brown's package of measures will be announced on Wednesday. They will contribute to the government target of securing 60% of new housing on brownfield sites by 2008.

The statement will also contain measures to set up a community enterprise fund proposed by the Treasury's social investment task force.

The aim is to create £1bn of extra investment by the private sector over five years through providing tax credits.

Mr Brown will also seek to assuage the CBI by lifting red tape for tens of thousands of small businesses. Firms with a turnover of below £600,000 a year will only be required to file annual VAT returns, rather than quarterly ones.

Tax-free individual savings accounts will be made available to 16- and 17-year-olds for the first time. The £7,000 limit on annual investment will be retained for five years.

webTitle: Archbishop steps aside in paedophile scandal

fields.headline: Archbishop steps aside in paedophile scandal
fields.trailText: The Roman Catholic archbishop of Cardiff yesterday issued an apology and agreed to be replaced following the latest scandal concerning paedophile priests in his diocese.
fields.body:
The Roman Catholic archbishop of Cardiff yesterday issued an apology and agreed to be replaced following the latest scandal concerning paedophile priests in his diocese.

In a letter read at masses across the principality, the Most Rev John Ward apologised for the "distress, anguish, hurt and betrayal" to victims of a priest, Father Joe Jordan, jailed for eight years two weeks ago for sexually abusing young boys.

The archbishop, now 71, ordained Jordan in 1998 despite warnings, including one from a bishop, that the priest posed a danger to children. The revelation led to calls for the archbishop's resignation.

Two years ago, the archbishop's press officer, John Lloyd, was also imprisoned for eight years following his conviction for indecent assaults against children.

The archbishop said yesterday that he wants another bishop to be brought in to assist him in his duties and then succeed him.

It was clear that the move was prompted by his meeting with the Apostolic Nuncio, Archbishop Pablo Puente, the pope's ambassador in England and Wales, on Friday. Earlier the archbishop had insisted that he would not be resigning and only the pope could force his retirement.

The archbishop was interviewed about the scandal on the BBC's Panorama programme, broadcast last night. He said: "I deeply regret what has happened, the pain caused to others, the pain caused to the archdiocese. I regret that and I take responsibility for it."

The archbishop's behaviour has exasperated fellow bishops and senior Catholics as it became clear that he had ignored warnings about Jordan and even allowed him to stay at his residence while in training. His actions breached the church's guidelines on sex abuse agreed in 1994.

In a confidential letter, written in 1995 when Jordan sought to change dioceses, Christopher Budd, Bishop of Plymouth, warned the archbishop that Jordan, a trainee priest, had been cleared of indecent assault when he was a teacher in Sheffield in 1989. Despite the acquittal, Jordan's name was placed on the Department for Education's list 99, meaning that he was considered unsuitable for work with children.

A priest, Father Christopher Higgins, told the programme that when he raised concerns about Jordan's inappropriate behaviour, the archbishop dismissed them, saying that he knew what was best for the diocese. Jordan decided that he wished to be ordained in Cardiff rather than Plymouth after Bishop Christopher told him that he wanted to review his past behaviour.

The archbishop then subsequently failed to pass on the warning to the Cardiff diocese's vocations board. Offences, against two boys aged nine and 10 in his parish in Barry, south Wales, occurred within months. When police arrested Jordan, more than 500 pornographic photographs of children were found in his computer.

fields.headline: The great floods of 1947
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: The floods have been described by the environment agency as the most widespread in Britain since 1947 and, in some places, more severe.
fields.body:
The floods have been described by the environment agency as the most widespread in Britain since 1947 and, in some places, more severe.

During the great floods of that year, several months of harsh winter were followed by the worst flooding for a century. After nearly a month of rain and melting snow, 30 of the 40 English counties and a large part of Wales were flooded.

Nottingham experienced the highest flood waters since 1875 and new development on its flood plains meant it was one of the worst hit areas. Twenty eight miles of streets, 3,000 properties and 86 factories were flooded. The cost of the damage was estimated at £12m.

The heavy snowstorms and sub-zero temperatures caused economic chaos. More than 4m workers were made idle by power cuts. With hundreds of coal trains unable to travel through 20ft high snowdrifts, thousands of homes were without heat or light for long periods.

In Norfolk, Lincolnshire and Yorkshire, the RAF dropped food for stranded villagers and their animals. Sheffield was left without milk. A hamlet near Widecombe in the Moor, Devon, sent a telegram on February 12 saying: "No bread since Jan 27. Starving."

Channel shipping was halted by non-stop blizzards, threatening food supplies. Fishing fleets were confined to ports and air travel ceased. The Great North road, Britain's north-south artery, was blocked for 22 miles and hundreds of rail passengers were left stranded by huge drifts.

Troops were called in throughout the country and 500 prisoners were enlisted for snow clearance in Yorkshire.

fields.headline: Recidivist rivers
fields.standfirst:
Ouse by name, not by nature

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Ouse by name, not by nature.
fields.body:
According to weekend reports, tens of thousands of motorists set out to see the latest tourist attractions - the high water at Bewdley and York. That implied they had enough petrol to make the pilgrimage, which in turn meant that they had queued at the pumps or, more likely, that tales of forecourt famine had been exaggerated. For drivers to fail to make any connection between their leisure use of motor vehicles and the possible causes of the floods in global warning due to carbon emissions is, sadly, all too typical. For environmentalists the motto has to be "only connect".

And yet the vast expansion of rivers out of their usual course does make a tremendous sight. If the property damage, human injury and public inconvenience can be put out of mind, the great spread of the waters on the land is indeed biblical to behold. The several Ouses and the Severn, the Derwent and the several Avons, placid and stolid one season, now run swollen and fast; they periodically undergo a personality change that demands human witness.

We gave up personifying natural phenomena as part of our passage to civilisation and yet it is hard not to read character into the inland waterways. Some streams are pacifist by nature. Others never make the headlines, not because they never flood but because - chance or good policy - they are lined not with brick and puny embankment but acres of water meadow. Take the Welland or, for much of their course, the Trent and the Tweed. The Severn below Gloucester spreads as nature intended, as do the Forth east of Stirling and the Kent, with that huge sandy bowl of Morecambe Bay to fill. The Nene and Witham safely pour their excess into the great sump of Fenland. Some, heroic in a past life, carved gorges and deep channels, too narrow to allow much riparian building. A minority just will not stop offending. Pity those who live beside those recidivist rivers of Avon, Ouse and Uck.

fields.headline: Media Monkey
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: * The FT made history on Wednesday by being the first British newspaper to use the F-word unexpurgated on its front page - and above the fold at that. The story ("Bush bunkers down to protect slender lead") by Washington correspondent Richard Wolffe included this racy news in its fifth paragraph: "The Bush team's strategy reflects the closeness of a campaign that the latest polls show as a statistical dead-heat. They call it their DFIU strategy - Don't Fuck It Up." By Friday the paper carried a letter from a reader complaining of "a decline in journalistic standards", but this sign that the FT is becoming more lively is a contrast to its previously staid policy. When Ray Snoddy was its media correspondent, he had a quote by Kelvin MacKenzie that included the F-word yanked from the middle of a profile after the first edition, when it was spotted by senior editors. According to the legend, Ray's response also included a number of Fs.

* The FT made history on Wednesday by being the first British newspaper to use the F-word unexpurgated on its front page - and above the fold at that. The story ("Bush bunkers down to protect slender lead") by Washington correspondent Richard Wolffe included this racy news in its fifth paragraph: "The Bush team's strategy reflects the closeness of a campaign that the latest polls show as a statistical dead-heat. They call it their DFIU strategy - Don't Fuck It Up." By Friday the paper carried a letter from a reader complaining of "a decline in journalistic standards", but this sign that the FT is becoming more lively is a contrast to its previously staid policy. When Ray Snoddy was its media correspondent, he had a quote by Kelvin MacKenzie that included the F-word yanked from the middle of a profile after the first edition, when it was spotted by senior editors. According to the legend, Ray's response also included a number of Fs.

Anyway, this no-holds-barred approach could bring the FT a wider readership. Monkey can't wait for Sir Samuel Brittan describing the Treasury's forecast for the public sector net cash requirement as "a big pile of shite".

*Nicholas Witchell has been strutting his stuff much more than usual lately. Sources at TV Centre tell Monkey that the BBC's royal reporter is in training for a Children in Need appearance later this month with the doyenne of court correspondents, his colleague Jennie Bond. The pair will appear in costume as John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John, singing You're The One That I Want. Monkey's source, however, is unsure of who will be who.

*Also doing his stuff for charity is Newsnight presenter Jeremy Vine, who has secretly been taking dancing lessons with his opposite number on the Six O'Clock News, Fiona Bruce. A few minutes before appearing on the flagship BBC2 current affairs show, Vine will don top hat and tails to waltz his way through the Children in Need studio. Time for a costume change is said to be tight, so don't be surprised if Vine looks extra-smart on the Newsnight set later.

*Conscious of its public image, the BBC has been smartening up its security guards at TV Centre in west London. On a recent visit, Monkey noticed that following the lead of Channel 5 - whose dishy desk boy has been highlighted on these pages before - full body searches are now being carried out only by the highest-quality personnel. "All the fat and ugly ones have been banished to the basement," says our source. "It's only top totty on the front desk now."

*It's good to know that principles are cheap in the dot.com world. Lis Howell, the former multichannel exec who this week launched bowlofcherries.com (see page 56), spoke movingly at the Guardian Edinburgh International TV Festival of her cynicism about some aspects of online life. One of her worst experiences, she noted, was shopping at Tesco.com where the functionality was poor, the design dreadful and the results random. Imagine our surprise then to discover bowlofcherries.com has launched with a (paid for?) click through link on its front page: "buy all your groceries online. Click here . . . Tesco".

*Nothing screams "Public Service Broadcasting" like a new David Attenborough series, State of the Planet, which starts next week. Such landmark programming on BBC1 - providing a defence against charges of dumbing-down - is promised oodles of on-air trails and publicity under the Dyke regime. Plus, you'd assume, a prime slot. So where has State of the Planet's opener been scheduled? Opposite the last-ever Inspector Morse. And people still wonder why Sir Dave's hair is white.

*Monkey reprints verbatim a memo sent from Mirror editor Piers Morgan to his devoted colleagues on Friday: "Dear staff, if I catch anyone actively joining a huge queue for petrol today, then I will deem them mentally unfit for work and they will be offered free counselling and a week in the Priory Clinic." Monkey can only assume the prospect of a week off was too tempting, as at least two of the poor buggers immediately rushed out to panic buy.

*The switch of Have I Got News For You to BBC1 is rumoured to be very good news for the cheery trio of Angus Deayton, Paul Merton and Ian Hislop, even if the show looks out of place on BBC1 at 10pm. A couple of days before the switch, Monkey hears from his showbiz pals that Merton asked for his fee to be doubled. Hat Trick's doughty Denise O'Donoghue said no, but took it to Mark Thompson, BBC director of television - since it's the BBC that pays out. Up went payments by 50%, to a rumoured £30,000 an outing for Deayton and £20,000 for Merton and Hislop. So that's how Hislop finances all those controversial improvements to his listed Kent retreat.

*The Royal Television Society's seminar last week on the communications white paper was a disappointing damp squib according to several participants - despite the timely opportunity to grill culture secretary Chris Smith on the thing itself. So obsessed was everyone with the BBC, no one even thought to raise the issue of the 15% rule on "share of voice" that scuppers the further consolidation of ITV. Patricia Hodgson (ITC), David Edmonds (Oftel) and Stephen Whittle (BSC) appeared together on the platform and tried to give the impression they were working in harmony, despite the fact that Oftel's approach to open access to broadcasting networks is seen by the ITC as far too lax to cope with the likes of Rupert Murdoch. But then no one seemed to be trying too hard. "This isn't exactly Jeremy Paxman," remarked the urbane Smith of Will Wyatt's gentle Radio 2-style questioning.

fields.headline: 10 dumb things...
fields.standfirst: . . . about TV titles and credits
fields.trailText: . . . about TV titles and credits
fields.body:
1. Sorry, it's a secret

For US drama series, identifying the characters actors play is taboo: titles typically unroll with the star's name (Sarah Michelle Gellar, say, or Dennis Franz) accompanied by a montage of images of the character in action, but with the crucial information frustratingly withheld. Result: you spend most of the first episode trying to puzzle out who all these people are.

2. Yup, still a secret

Also de rigueur in American imports is a second wave of actors' names, arriving (after the big-impact opening) at any time from 10-20 minutes in. Just as unhelpfully, they typically list all non-regular performers, with no distinction between starring roles and barman with a single line.

3. It's the last episode, stupid

No American trend can be ignored, so British drama now routinely opens with a recap of the previous episode, thereby implicitly insulting the intelligence of viewers capable of remembering what they watched seven days ago. And cutting into the time writers get for new stuff.

4. It's the next episode, stupid

Equally obligatory is a 'precap' enticing viewers to watch the same show next week (but how will you remember, if you need reminding what happened?) by zipping through the key action. As with movie trailers, though, you might easily feel you've already seen all the best bits.

5. Just hysterical luvvies and grumpy blokes in Barbours

Credits are an annoying obligation for broadcasters, using time that could be devoted to ads or trailers. So why not make that clear by sulkily racing through them as fast as possible?

6. Can you spot the credits, children?

The even more insulting solution: cramping the unrolling credits into tiny letters in a corner of the screen, while an announcer flogs the video/ spin-off book/magazine that occupies the rest.

7. Producing assistant to the acting assistant co-producer (Portugal)

What do all these 'producers' do? The simplest indy doc or drama now typically involves two from the production company, two more from the broadcaster, and a fifth from the foreign co-producer; a Frasier or an ER can require between 8-15, with baroque variations of nomenclature.

8. Hey, I signed the cheques

Heads of originating departments invariably insist on a credit as 'executive producer', whether their actual role consisted of overseeing the project from the outset, visiting the set once to schmooze with the stars, or merely inheriting someone else's work. There's an upside: you know who to blame for bummers.

9. Anything she wants, OK?

It started on movies, but now it's on telly, it's the "personal assistant to Ms Pfeiffer" credit. Does it really matter who did their hair? These look suspiciously like vanity credits, awarded to pamper big egos.

10. Music? What music?

Although most TV drama now uses pop songs - a trend started by Cold Feet - BBC policy still stubbornly resists identifying any music. So, crazily, the lowliest member of the film crew gets a name check, but not the snatch of Monteverdi or Moby which sets the mood of the entire piece. Hence all those surprisingly un-angry 'could you settle an argument?' letters to Radio Times. John Dugdale

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst:
Jimmy Nesbitt

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Jimmy Nesbitt, star of Cold Feet, which returned to ITV last night
fields.body:
Newspapers: I only buy the Guardian and Observer. When I was doing Welcome to Sarajevo, my bible for that film was Ed Vulliamy's book. He and Maggie O'Kane were brilliant.

Magazines: I've never really done the men's magazines, ever. I get Private Eye and When Saturday Comes, and when I'm at my father-in-law's I have a look at his Spectator because of the, er, unusual stuff that's in it. I quite like Boris Johnson.

Books: I'm reading Amsterdam by Ian McEwan. I love him and I've read all his stuff. I always read fiction - I don't do biography or anything like that.

Film: Last week on video I saw Three Kings - very good; Mark Wahlberg was fantastic. My favourite film is The Sting. The most recent outing to the pictures was to take Peggy (who's three and a bit) to see Chicken Run. After five minutes she was bored and wanted to go, whereas we loved Toy Story 2.

Television: Match of the Day is a number one priority. It's a tragedy that it has gone to ITV. It's such a shame to lose the Lineker, Lawrenson and Hansen format just as they've really cracked it, and however mad it is, there is a thing about the tradition. I'll watch anything - even tractor racing. I'm not allowed to have digital TV because of the sport. My wife knows I'd watch tractor racing all day.

Radio: I grew up listening to a station that was almost Radio 4, but my mother couldn't quite find it, so it was 10% Radio Gdansk. I don't like the way the Today programme has changed. I can't bear John Humphrys' interrogation technique: all the interviews are about battles. But I love Melvyn Bragg's radio work: his Start the Week was great.

Ads: The Guinness one with the old guy swimming was good. All the Guinness ads are good.

Multimedia: I'm illiterate. I'm 35 and I've never been on the internet. I just can't be arsed. It's like additional maths - I'm never going to need it and I don't feel I'm missing out.

 Jimmy Nesbitt stars in Cold Feet, which returned to ITV last night www.coldfeetonline.com

fields.headline: It's politainment, with George 'n' Al
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: America's two presidential wannabes may not have much time for anything except campaigning in the frenetic final days of their White House race, but both George W Bush and Al Gore have found time for television comedy shows.
fields.body:
America's two presidential wannabes may not have much time for anything except campaigning in the frenetic final days of their White House race, but both George W Bush and Al Gore have found time for television comedy shows.

It's a sign of the changed nature of campaigning that presidential candidates have to make a self-mocking appearance on a show that pokes fun at their foibles.

Saturday Night Live specialises in satirising America's political leaders, but last night was the first time both men appeared in person. And both Mr Bush and Mr Gore gamely acted up to their respective stereotypes as a word mangler and a credit hogger.

"When they asked me to help introduce tonight's special, I felt frankly ambilavent," said Mr Bush. "Although I'm a big fan, I have seen things on the show I thought were, in a word, offensible."

Mr Gore cut in: "Well, you know, I was one of the very first to be offended by material on Saturday Night Live."

Back in 1968, Richard Nixon's brief cameo on Rowan and Martin's Laugh-In was seen as a major - and questionable - breach of political taste when the candidate said the show's buzzphrase "Sock it to me."

Nowadays, the divide between politics and entertainment barely exists. Both Mr Bush and Mr Gore seem eager to squeeze credit out of appearances with hosts such as Jay Leno and David Letterman who routinely describe Mr Bush as a crackhead and Mr Gore as a humourless nerd.

After the first Gore-Bush debate in October, both campaign teams studied how Saturday Night Live parodied the event to help them prepare for the next two debates. Mr Gore personally viewed tapes.

Perhaps the most striking aspect is the way both candidates have absorbed and exploited the comedians' digs.

Mr Bush told Letterman that one of his first moves in the White House would be to ensure that the library has plenty of "books with big print and big pictures". When Mr Gore went on the show he turned to the camera and warned: "America, I gave you the internet, and I can take it away."

Saturday Night Live's producer, Lorne Michaels, says both men are baby-boomers and that "part of what defines this generation is a certain sense of humour. It's playful."

webTitle: Hillary's rival hurt by his own attacks

fields.headline: Hillary's rival hurt by his own attacks
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton and her opponent in tomorrow's election for a seat in the US senate delivered their penultimate barbs of the contest as though they were running for office in the Middle East.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton and her opponent in tomorrow's election for a seat in the US senate delivered their penultimate barbs of the contest as though they were running for office in the Middle East.

The Republican candidate, Rick Lazio, tried to boost his depiction of Mrs Clinton as soft on Palestinian terrorists. Her campaign denounced him as a sleaze-monger.

Mr Lazio, trailing in two new polls, relied on the disclosure of a friendly letter from Mrs Clinton to an Islamic conference at which the keynote speaker described the US and Israel as "the true terrorists".

The Clinton campaign had already returned some £34,500 in funds raised for her by the alliance and put out a weekend advertisement in which ex-New York City mayor Ed Koch says: "Have you seen this? It's garbage. Rick, stop with the sleaze already."

Both campaigns are eager to court Jewish voters, who account for about 12% of the electorate in the state and back Mrs Clinton by a two-to-one margin. Mrs Clinton, considered vulnerable on the issue of Israel since expressing support two years ago for a Palestinian state, appeared to have restored her lead by yesterday.

One poll, conducted by Blum & Weprin Associates, put her ahead by 47 to 40.

The Lazio campaign had spent part of the week trying to link Mrs Clinton to last month's bombing of the destroyer USS Cole. "That [phone blitz] was boneheaded and clearly backfired," said pollster John Zogby. "He made a major effort to try to lose with those incredibly stupid and malicious phone calls."

webTitle: Winner could be he who doesn't take all

fields.headline: Winner could be he who doesn't take all
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush remains ahead in the polls as the two main presidential hopefuls enter their last day of campaigning. But Al Gore's advisers believe their man will capture the White House by doing well in enough key states to dominate the electoral college - the body that decides the race.
fields.body:
George W Bush remains ahead in the polls as the two main presidential hopefuls enter their last day of campaigning. But Al Gore's advisers believe their man will capture the White House by doing well in enough key states to dominate the electoral college - the body that decides the race.

US presidential elections are decided not by the numbers of votes cast for each candidate nationally but by a state-by-state contest in which the candidate who finishes top in each state collects all of that state's votes in the "electoral college".

The college has 538 seats. A state's population determines how many of these seats it gets. A candidate needs 270 electoral college votes to win.

Mr Gores Democratic camp hopes to upset the odds by winning the electoral college votes of the handful of key states that are too close to predict. If that happens, Mr Gore may become president even though more people nationwide voted for the Republican Mr Bush.

If this happens - a Gore win in the electoral college despite a Bush victory in the popular vote - it will be the third time in US electoral history. In 1876 Rutherford Hayes defeated Samuel Tilden this way, and Benjamin Harrison pipped Grover Cleveland in 1888. But it would be the first time since blacks and women got the vote.

"It won't be a pretty victory, but it will be a victory nevertheless. A bit like winning the World Cup on penalty kicks," a Gore adviser said yesterday.

As the largest state, California has 54 votes in the electoral college. New York is second with 33. Both seem likely to support Mr Gore. Seven sparsely populated states, plus the District of Columbia, have three votes each, the minimum allowed.

With this year's contest so tight, both sides have put most of their effort into capturing the unusually large number of up-for-grabs states that will decide the outcome tomorrow.

Mr Gore's hopes now rest absolutely on a victory in Florida, a state with 25 electoral college votes. At one time it seemed likely to go to Mr Bush, but as things have turned out Mr Gore has been in the lead there in most opinion polls this autumn.

Mr Bush spent all day yesterday campaigning in Florida, a mark of how important the state will be tomorrow.

The other fiercely fought state Mr Gore has to win is Pennsylvania (23 votes) where the polls now put him ahead.

He also needs to win in Michigan (18 votes), where the race has been neck-and-neck and the survey results contradictory, and in Wisconsin (11 votes). And he must squeeze Ralph Nader's Green support to take Minnesota (10), Oregon (7) and Washington state (11).

The most recent electoral college survey by Reuters showed Mr Gore lagging, with 196 votes solid or leaning his way, against Mr Bush's 209. This leaves 133 in states that are too close to call. A less cautious survey by the National Journal magazine showed Mr Gore predicted to win 269 electoral college votes, against 248 for Mr Bush - with just 21 still up for grabs.

Opinion surveys tell a different story. Mr Bush continued to lead in all the national weekend opinion polls, the first to be completed after last week's news that the Republican candidate had concealed a drink-driving conviction in Maine in 1976.

But there were contradictory indications whether the revelation had had any effect on the exceptionally tight contest between the two men.

Mr Bush increased his lead by one point in yesterday's Gallup tracking poll, in which he now leads 48% to Mr Gore's 43%.

But in the rival Zogby tracking poll, Mr Bush's lead narrowed to two points, at 46% against Mr Gore's 44%. A Washington Post tracking poll also gave Mr Bush a two-point lead, 48%-46%.
