webTitle: Gore's last plea to the great undecided

fields.headline: Gore's last plea to the great undecided
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: If this is Sunday, it must be Philadelphia. Or Michigan. Or Iowa. His eyes almost closed from exhaustion, his voice sometimes cracking and his trademark plea of "I need your help" sounding more and more heart-felt, Al Gore is squeezing every last moment from the day and the night as he swings one last time through the states that could go either way.
fields.body:
If this is Sunday, it must be Philadelphia. Or Michigan. Or Iowa. His eyes almost closed from exhaustion, his voice sometimes cracking and his trademark plea of "I need your help" sounding more and more heart-felt, Al Gore is squeezing every last moment from the day and the night as he swings one last time through the states that could go either way.

It falls to the Rev Albert Campbell, pastor of the Mount Carmel Baptist church in the black area of West Philadelphia, to make the early morning introduction of the vice-president after invoking an even higher authority.

"Work your will, Lord, this election time," Mr Campbell implores as he stands before one of the city's finest gospel choirs, "because what we do, dear God, has impact on all the world".

Al Gore, looking just like a man who has had to exist on between two and five hours' sleep a night and big doses of coffee and political adrenaline, takes up the religious theme in the packed church by telling the congregation that "the day and is drawing nigh, the one day every four years when the people have the power". He reminds them of the words of St Paul to the Galatians: "Be not weary in well doing."

Weary in every other respect, the Democratic party's presidential candidate has subjected himself to this desperately punishing schedule buoyed by a late feeling in his team that victory is still within his grasp if he can but claim the "toss-up states".

Nowhere is closer than Pennsylvania, where the latest local opinion survey shows Mr Gore at 43% compared to 42% for his Republican opponent, George W Bush, and 8% for the Green party standard-bearer, Ralph Nader.

With its 23 votes in the electoral college - the body reflecting the popular vote in each state which then elects the president - Pennsylvania could even swing the result. That is why its biggest city is playing host this Sunday to three Gorerallies.

This last weekend started in Aimes, Iowa, on Friday. By the time Air Force II touched down in the early evening drought-breaking rain at Memphis airport that night, Mr Gore had already delivered his standard speech in three states. The visit to his home state of Tennessee should not have been necessary, but the polls have put Mr Bush just ahead there.

The vice-president has become more expansive with the travelling press since the summer, but his message now is very much over the heads of the media and towards the great undecided.

The crowd of around 2,000 in Court Square in downtown Memphis has been serenaded by no less then the Rev Al Green, Preston Shannon and Ruby Wilson, the cream of soul and rhythm and blues here.

Wilson refers to Al Gore as our "homeboy" although homeboy may not be the first - or even the 101st - description that springs to mind when the vice-president bounds on stage with his wife Tipper and his daughter Kristin, a comedy script writer in Los Angeles.

Memphis is a predominantly black town and that is reflected in the crowd. The rally has been arranged at speed - campaign headquarters in every swing state have been put on alert for a visit.

The Team Tennessee youngsters working for Mr Gore and his running mate Joseph Lieberman have to make sure that the placards - tonight they say "Tipper Rocks", whatever that means - are handed out to willing hands to wave when the camera lights hit them.

Mr Gore's voice has started to go - it cracks a couple of times during a speech delivered jacketless despite the damp. He finishes with the standard: "I may not be the most exciting politician in the world - like Willie Herenton [the dashing local mayor] - but I will work for you each day and I will fight for you with all my heart."

The Gore team is deliberately making no comment on the drink-driving story that has emerged from Mr Bush's distant past, but privately there is much glee, not least because of the Bush TV commercial beaming out in Tennessee tonight, which has him saying: "I believe we need to encourage personal responsibility so people are accountable for their own actions."

There's not much sleep in these final hours. Mr Gore will get between the sheets too late even to see Madonna endorsing him on Dave Letterman's Late Show: "I'm a chick so who [else] would I vote for?"

Grey dawn Saturday, and a prayer meeting at the Peabody Hotel, Memphis. Then the motorcade takes Mr Gore out of his home state, his campaign here possibly concluded. He may not returns until he casts his vote in Carthage tomorrow.

The motorcade blue-lights its way to the airport for a flight to Huntington, West Virginia. Here a small rally has supporters arranged strategically behind the vice-president nodding and smiling like loyal bankbenchers during televised question time in the House of Commons.

Then there is the private trip to watch Al Junior playing football for his high school team in Washington, and finally on to chilly Pittsburgh. "It ain't really cold, it just acts that way," the bearded airport employee tells the shivering arrivals. "You've all been down in the South too long."

The Wesley Centre African Methodist Episcopalian Zion church is the first stop here and has honoured Mr Gore with another stellar gospel choir singing Blessed Lord and O Happy Day as he arrives almost dead on time.

If this race was decided on who has the best musical accompaniment Mr Gore would win by a landslide. Mr Bush's best shot so far seems to have been Hank Williams Jr: those heirs to famous names must stick together.

The clear strategy in these last few days is no longer just to deliver the message, for everyone in these churches is converted, but to get people to persuade everyone they know to vote. Mr Gore presses the buttons again: affirmative action, Martin Luther King, Gandhi, the tragedy of Africa's Tutsis and the Hutus, the need for hate-crime legislation, his boyhood horror at seeing rings for tying up slaves in a mansion on the hill in Carthage, the threat to civil rights if Mr Bush is elected and appoints conservative judges to the supreme court.

The last rally of Saturday is with another solid Democratic sector, the unions. They have organised a bash in Pittsburgh's Hot Metal Street. Here the audience is much whiter, big men from this old steel city in baseball caps and jackets, promising to get out the vote on the day.

This is not so much a marathon as a steeplechase, vaulting the time and weather zones and plunging through the cold water of public scepticism. The finishing post is in sight. But first it's off to Fairmount park in the heart of the city of Brotherly Love on this glorious autumn day.

On the whole, WC Fields said in his famous epitaph, I'd rather be in Philadelphia. On the whole, Al Gore would rather be anywhere than buried by George W Bush.So, one more time, the voice cracking: "I will fight for you! I need your help!" as Air Force II prepares to take off for the last destination of the day, a place in Iowa called Waterloo.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: West End star dies aged 50
fields.body:
West End star dies aged 50

The theatre world was last night mourning the death of West End and Broadway star Stephanie Lawrence. Ms Lawrence, 50, who took leading roles in Cats, Evita and Starlight Express, was pronounced dead at her home in Fulham, south-west London, on Saturday.

Transplant drugs 'too dear'

The first recipient of an arm transplant cannot afford the anti-rejection drugs needed to ensure the operation remains successful, his surgeon said yesterday. Nadey Hakim, of St Mary's hospital, London, said Clint Hallam, who received his new hand in September 1998, cannot meet the £10,000 yearly drugs bill.

Man dies in cylinder blast

The health and safety executive last night launched an inquiry after one man was killed and another seriously injured in a blast on an industrial estate in Thorne, South Yorkshire. The explosion happened while they were cleaning a cylinder.

Murder inquiry begins

A murder inquiry has been launched following the discovery on Friday of a woman's body near Danby, North Yorkshire, police said yesterday. Vicky Glass, 21, went missing from Middlesbrough in September.

32 share £20m lottery jackpot

Thirty-two people shared Saturday's £20m lottery jackpot. Each will receive £625,000. The winning numbers were 2, 8, 17, 29, 33, and 44. The bonus number was 11. In the Thunderball draw, the winning numbers were 5, 15, 17, 25 and 31 and the Thunderball was 11.

fields.headline: Be bold for the old
fields.standfirst:
Mr Brown is under close inspection
Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: No Labour chancellor before him has approached a general election with the economy as stable and with so much money to spend.
fields.body:
No Labour chancellor before him has approached a general election with the economy as stable and with so much money to spend. Gordon Brown is expected to be sitting on a budget surplus of nearly £20bn by the end of the financial year, without including the £22.5bn raised from auctioning off the radio spectrum. But this does not mean that the chancellor will splatter money in all directions in his pre-budget statement on Wednesday. That is because no chancellor before him has approached an election with an independent Bank of England watching his every move, ready to raise interest rates at the slightest hint of excess. An independent bank was, of course, Mr Brown's own creation. It was meant to prevent politicians from spending their way back into office - so Mr Brown will be judged on Wednesday by criteria of his own devising.

Even so, he still has upwards of £2bn to "give away" without loosening his fiscal stance enough to worry the bank - more if he raises money from other sources - such as a windfall tax on oil companies or making non-UK hauliers pay for their use of roads. Unsurprisingly, with such a big war chest to hand, Mr Brown faces an unprecedented array of claims from special interests.

There are two priorities for the next budget: help for pensioners and improvements in infrastructure. The way old people are looked after is the ultimate test of a civilised society. This government has done a lot. The trouble is that it has, rightly, been carefully targeted on those that need it most and never made the headlines. To restore the link between pensions and average earnings would entail an increase of 5p in the pound in income tax, according to the independent National Institute for Economic and Social Research. But the NIESR also says the strength of the public finances makes a more generous state pension "eminently affordable". It would be wrong to spread such help equally among all retired people because the same money can be up to five times more effective if targeted on poorer people - especially those without company pensions.

There has never been a better time to boost spending on infrastructure. It would be exaggerating to say that the subject has become sexy - but there has never been a time when the public has become so angered by the cumulative effects of disintegrating railways, floods, under-maintained roads and antiquated hospitals and schools. Labour made a Tory legacy of underinvestment worse by applying an unnecessary tourniquet on spending in its first two years that not even the Tories would have kept to. That generated adverse publicity for Labour because it has prevented any of the belated extra spending earmarked for hospitals and schools producing actual buildings during Labour's first administration. If Mr Brown is to take any risks in his statement, they should be for a sustained increase in spending on infrastructure. This will carry fewer risks to inflation than any cuts in income tax he may feel obliged to concede because of Michael Portillo's opportunistic pledges.

The last thing needed now is a policy to make road transport more attractive. There is a case for reducing vehicle excise duties on smaller and environmentally friendlier cars, but the case existed before hauliers took to the streets. Rail and bus fares have been rising at nearly three times the rate of motoring costs. Mr Brown should not give into the hauliers just because, unlike the pensioners, they can threaten to bring the country to a halt.

webTitle: Pregnancy cravings put gym shoes on the menu

fields.headline: Pregnancy cravings put gym shoes on the menu
fields.trailText: Children's gym shoes, burned matchsticks and ice lollies dipped in mustard are just some of the cravings that pregnant women have confessed to eating, a survey published today finds.
fields.body:
Children's gym shoes, burned matchsticks and ice lollies dipped in mustard are just some of the cravings that pregnant women have confessed to eating, a survey published today finds.

Imminent motherhood appears to turn the nation's women into gruesome gourmets, with custard-covered beetroot, garlic bread with strawberry yoghurt, and even chocolate mixed with salad cream also on the menu.

The poll of 200 pregnant women in the UK for vitamin makers Sanatogen found that other strange food cravings admitted to included stuffed olives with lemon curd, chocolate ice cream with prawns and pineapple, and coffee granules on crumpets.

Despite their strange tastes, one in 10 women are still unsure about exactly what they are allowed and not allowed to eat while pregnant. An obviously pregnant woman is still a source of fascination for many people, with three quarters of survey respondents saying people had asked to touch their stomachs.

But four in five expectant mothers had been forced to stand on public transport because "modern men" failed to give up their seats for them.

A spokeswoman for the Maternity Alliance said: "If a craving seems very bizarre, it's worth checking with your doctor or midwife."

fields.headline: Rising Severn threatens chemical plant
fields.standfirst:
Prescott criticises insurance firms

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Prescott criticises insurance firms.
fields.body:
The floods posed a fresh hazard last night when it emerged that the rising waters of the Severn were threatening a chemical plant.

Firefighters in protective suits were checking safety at the Cleansing Services Group plant at Sandhurst, near Gloucester, where last week six people were taken to hospital after an explosion and fire.

About 50 villagers were evacuated afterwards and dozens have since complained of stinging faces, sore throats and stomach pains. Health officials later took blood samples from villagers and results are expected this week.

As storms swept the country with 34mm of rain falling on Cornwall yesterday, Yorkshire remained the area worst affected seeing people evacuated from the village of Selby on Saturday night.

Police guarded empty properties from looters while soldiers sandbagged river defences in the town centre.

Inspector Malcolm Green of North Yorkshire police said: "At the moment we are monitoring the height of the river very carefully."

Deputy prime minister John Prescott spent another day touring flood-ravaged areas of Yorkshire and promised long-term assistance to help people get back on their feet.

"I would like to see a recovery team which is there as the people go through a process of change, finding accommodation, finding heaters, getting the insurance companies to help to quicken the process to relieve the damage they face and the misery. When the cameras are gone I want the pressure still there to help."

He criticised insurance companies following reports that some were demanding inflated premiums or rejecting applications altogether.

The government will urge insurers to scrap rules requiring claimants to restore flooded homes to their previous condition, even if the old design, such as wooden floors, did not represent the best protection from further floods.

"I have received a lot of complaints about how slow they are dealing with claims and sometimes the work is not of a good quality," Mr Prescott said.

Insurers warned yesterday that repeatedly flooded homes could become uninsurable.

House prices could fall by as much as 25% in areas where the risk of flooding is highest. Once-desirable riverside properties have taken a knock in value, while homes in flood-devastated areas have been taken off the market.

The Law Society will announce early next year that solicitors must include any "environmental risk" to a property - particularly flooding - when checking a house.

The society has been liaising with the environment agency, which from next month will make flood risk information available to the public on its website, on a postcode basis.

A spokeswoman said: "We have been working to produce an improved property search making a number of environmental questions standard.

"At the moment flood risk isn't routinely checked for in property searches by solicitors."

The government is to change planning guidance for local authorities, making it easier to reject applications to build on land liable to flooding.

Andrew Bennett, the Labour chairman of the environment select committee, claimed the government's housing policies were partly responsible for the flooding.

He said the vast extension of house building meant water drained off the land into rivers far more quickly, increasing the likelihood of flooding.

A 13-year-old boy died on Saturday after slipping on rain-sodden cliffs and plunging 60 feet onto rocks at Sharkham Point, near Brixham, South Devon.

Although the weather was good at the time of the accident, the cliff tops were muddy and slippery after days of torrential rain and the rocks were treacherous.

webTitle: Left high but far from dry as new flood threatens

fields.headline: Left high but far from dry as new flood threatens
fields.standfirst:
Bewilderment follows order to quit homes

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Bewilderment follows order to quit homes.
fields.body:
Michael Gascoigne, out of work for more than two years, sat glumly yesterday afternoon in the fifth-form common room at Brayton high school in Selby, north Yorkshire. He was hoping the rain would not come again.

"I'm due to start work at a packing factory on Wednesday," he said. "I need two days to sort the paperwork out, but this is going to hold all that back. I've had depression and panic attacks but getting this job was a real tonic."

He wanted to get home to get the papers he needs. But his home is opposite the Olympia pub in Barlby, just north of Selby's famous abbey, and the village is under threat from the fast-flowing waters of the muddy Ouse.

The packing factory is also in Barlby: Mr Gascoigne's daughter Kirsty works there but won't be able to clock on today.

As everyone waited to see if the forecast rain would send water levels rising again, Kirsty and her father, plus her mother Sharon and brother Christopher, prepared to spend another uncomfortable night at the school while rockets shot into the sky from local bonfire parties.

The four, all wearing string necklaces with identity tags, were given 15 minutes to evacuate their home on Friday night. "We took five minutes to to shift some furniture and then left," said Mr Gascoigne. "We had to leave our two cats behind. We spent the first night at Selby leisure centre and then came here. We've had no sleep and don't know what is going on. We'd like to go home - there's no electricity but we have gas heating."

Three quarters of Selby lost power on Saturday, with a sub-station now reported to be 10ft under water.

Up to 6,000 residents were warned that they might have to leave their homes; Barlby and the Flaxby Road estate were worst affected.

Police prevented tourists from crossing the swing bridge into Barlby yesterday. The village, with about 200 mainly terraced houses, is protected from the river by a high bank.

But the river bank has already been breached in three places and troops from the King's Own Regiment toiled yesterday to plug the gaps with a number of sandbags.

Barlby was a ghost village. The pedestrian crossing was out of action and there was no one around to buy Sunday papers at Barlby Bridge News.

But one house was occupied. Lilias and Andrew Sutton had heard - incorrectly as it turned out - that they could not take their collie dog, Jasper, to the high school evacuation centre.

So they had cleared the downstairs rooms, leaving just a print on the dining room wall, put a chicken in the oven for lunch and prepared to hoist the sofa on to a table if the water started rising in the hall. "We came down on Saturday and we've done our best. It's freezing cold and we've had to wash in cold water. But we're getting on with it. What else can you do?" said Mrs Sutton.

fields.headline: The end is nigh, perhaps
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Typical, isn't it? Scientists have pinpointed the day when Earth is in danger of being hit by an asteroid the size of an office block. And it has to be at the weekend.
fields.body:
Typical, isn't it? Scientists have pinpointed the day when Earth is in danger of being hit by an asteroid the size of an office block. And it has to be at the weekend.

Put the date in your diary - Saturday, September 21 2030. Forget about the lie-in, that boozy lunch with friends down the pub - if pubs still exist - and that shopping trip.

Instead, prepare for the arrival of the unromantically-named 2000 SG344, which astronomers believe could hit Earth with a force 100 times greater than that released by the atom bomb which destroyed Hiroshima.

The gloomy announcement was posted on Saturday on the internet by the International Astronomical Union. The object was spotted some time ago but the chance that it could hit us was not realised until last week when Nasa began studying its orbit.

Though it is possible the object is a discarded rocket booster, most experts believe it is an asteroid with a diameter of 230ft.

If, like many asteroids and meteorites, it is made of stone and iron, SG344 would cost millions of lives, but probably would not end civilisation.

Though the risk is small - about one in 500 - that SG344's orbit and Earth's will collide, it is nonetheless being seen as a possibility.

In the 10-point Torino scale for grading objects which could hit Earth, the object gets a rating of only one. But it is the first astronomical object to get on to the scale, meaning that it merits careful monitoring.

David Morrison, chairman of the Astronomical Union committee at Nasa's Ames research center, said: "We have never had a prediction at this high level of probability. In the past we have talked about one in 10,000 or one in a million."

On average an asteroid strikes our planet every 100 years, the last resulting in a blast in the forests of central Siberia in 1908.

A glance at the history books shows that September 21 has been a disaster date in the past - in 1974 more than 8,000 people died in Honduras in floods caused by hurricanes.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

James Dyson the high profile inventor, has threatened to expand his operations in Malaysia instead of creating new jobs at home if Britain refuses to join the euro. Mr Dyson is increasing staff numbers to build his new washing machine which was unveiled last week.

Abbey National faces humiliating defeat in its ambition to woo the City into backing a hostile £10bn bid for Bank of Scotland.

Sunday Times

Lord Tugendhat, chairman of Abbey National, flew back from the Far East over the weekend in an attempt to revive the former building society's merger talks with Bank of Scotland. He is likely to offer a series of concessions including the promise of a top role of either chairman or chief executive to Peter Burt, chief executive of Bank of Scotland.

Gordon Brown is set to announce a big shake-up of VAT for small and medium-sized firms in his pre-Budget report on Wednesday. The move is intended to re-establish the government's business reputation.

Sunday Telegraph

Nomura, the Japanese bank, is preparing a bid worth up to £1.8bn for Welsh Water just days after a group of Welsh investors, Glas Cymru, agreed to buy the company. The move comes six months after Nomura first tried to buy Hyder, the multi-utility which includes Welsh Water.

Sir Ian Robinson is to step down as chief executive of Scottish Power. He is expected to do so within the next six months and is likely be replaced by deputy chief executive Ian Russell.

Mail on Sunday

ScottishPower will give up to £4m worth of shares to its 16,000 employees next month.

Aeroflot, the Russian airline, is planning to list its shares on the London Stock Exchange. Equity will be made available to investors in the form of global depository receipts.

Sunday Express

The Confederation of British Industry is demanding tax cuts of £3bn and accusing the government of weighing businesses down with too much red tape.

Sunday Business

Trinity Mirror is talking to the billionaire Hinduja brothers about cooperating over its bid for Express Newspapers. Discussions so far have centered on developing a commercial arrangement between the two sides with the possibility that Trinity Mirror would handle the distribution of the newspapers for the Hindujas.

German media group Bertelsmann would like to merge with EMI after its alliance with controversial online music-swapping website Napster.

BT is expected to announce on Thursday that it intends to divide its retail and wholesale businesses into separate legal entities, taking the group a step closer to demerger.

IoS

British Airways is planning to abandon its provincial UK services in a move which reflects the airline's increasing focus on Heathrow. The decision is a key part of chief executive Rod Eddington's attempt to revive BA. Short-haul services lose the airline about £300m a year.

Parties interested in entering the exclusive stage of negotiations to buy Express Newspapers are being asked to produce a non-refundable deposit of up to £60m. City advisers to United News & Media, which owns the Express, are thought to have come up with the idea as a means of keeping the bidding process under control.

Reports out this week

Today

Interims Ashanti Goldfields (Q3), British Airways, Carphone Warehouse, Focus Solutions, Infobank International Holdings, Netstore (Q1), Stockbourne. Finals Terence Chapman, Wescol Group. AGMs Paterson Zochonis. EGMs ITE Group, New Capital Investments.

Tuesday

Interims BP Amoco (Q3), Bright Station, Cadcentre Group, Colt Telecom, FirstGroup, GWR Group, Maelor, Marks & Spencer, Robert Wiseman Dairies. Finals None scheduled. AGMs Freeport, Henderson Eurotrust, ICM Computer Group, A&J Mucklow. EGMs None scheduled.

Wednesday

Interims Associated British Foods, Baltimore Technologies (Q3), Bookham Technology (Q3), British Energy, CGNU (Q3), Electrocomponents, Peacock Group, Radstone Technology, Thus, Umeco, Volex Group. Finals Fenner, McCarthy & Stone, Minorplanet Systems. AGMs Groupe Chez Gerard, Jos Holdings, William Sinclair. EGMs None scheduled.

Thursday

Interims BT, Chamberlin & Hills, P&O Princess Cruises (Q3), Royal & Sun Alliance (9 mths), Scottish Power, Thomson Corporation, Tate & Lyle, Yates Group. Finals Capital Radio, Dimension Data Holdings, MMT Computing, Superscape AGMs Community Hospitals, Diageo, IAF Group, Frank Usher. EGMs Frank Usher.

Friday

Interims Express Dairies. Finals None scheduled.

AGMs Northamber. EGMs None scheduled.

UK IDS pay settlements analysis. UK Industrial output (Sep). UK Manufacturing output (Sep). UK Final M0 (Oct). UK REC labour market survey. UK SMMT new car registrations (Oct).

JP Leading index (Sep). EU Euro-zone services PMI.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Vodafone eyes Swisscom
fields.body:
Vodafone eyes Swisscom

Vodafone is reportedly considering taking a stake in the mobile phone business of Swiss telecoms company Swisscom. Reports in the Swiss press suggested that Vodafone is poised to take a 25% stake in the business and fill in one of the few gaps in the company's European network.

Swisscom is 65.5% owned by the Swiss government and the reports said the cabinet will meet to approve the deal on Wednesday.

BCC chooses Prudential

The British Chambers of Commerce, which represents 126,000 firms, has chosen the Prudential as its preferred provider of a stakeholder pension scheme. The agreement follows the announcement in July that Prudential had been selected as the commercial partner for the TUC scheme, making it one of the largest affinity stakeholder providers in the country.

Web firms to float

Two more internet businesses announced their intention to float on the stock market yesterday undeterred by the continued volatility.

NRX Global, which sells spare parts for heavy industry, will be valued at £40m. It hopes to raise £15m in the float to help finance the development of the website. It will place 12m shares.

Meanwhile Cyberes, a company which has built an online reservation system for independent travel agents, is raising £8.5m through a placement of shares and will be valued at about £30m.

New jobs at Asda

Asda yesterday announced plans to create up to 4,500 new jobs over the next two years through the expansion of its home shopping service outside the M25.

The supermarket chain is also launching a home shopping website, asda.com, which will allow customers to order online for the first time.

fields.headline: Allied bids for vodka
fields.trailText: Allied Domecq is hoping to secure the lucrative American distribution rights for Stolichnaya, the world's best selling vodka brand.
fields.body:
Allied Domecq is hoping to secure the lucrative American distribution rights for Stolichnaya, the world's best selling vodka brand.

The company is understood to have held discussions with the spirit brand's Russian owner in anticipation of the existing distribution deal with Diageo coming apart. Reports at the weekend suggested that privately owned Bacardi has also entered the fray.

Diageo is unlikely to renew its US distribution contract when it expires in the next few weeks. The company said this summer that it intended to focus its business on eight global brands, and that its efforts in the vodka market would be centered on Smirnoff.

Stolichnaya is seen as a premium imported vodka in the US, where it sells some 1.2m cases a year. Internationally it sells 55m cases. Allied is still in the running for the drinks business being spun out of Canadian group Seagram in what has become a messy and protracted auction.

The division, which is valued at around £4.8bn, brings with it brands including Chivas Regal and Martel brandy.

Competition for the business is fierce. Allied faces rival bids from an alliance of Diageo and Pernod Ricard of France and, again, Bacardi which has made an approach alongside Brown Forman of the US.

Stolichnaya may be seen as consolation for the group that loses its bid for Seagram, which also has the rights to distribute Absolut vodka.

It remains uncertain whether Allied would distribute Absolut even if it wins the Seagram bid battle.

There has been some suggestion that Sweden's state-owned Vin & Sprit, producer of Absolut, has already given its backing to Bacardi.

fields.headline: BoS and Abbey try conciliation
fields.trailText: Bank of Scotland is ready to hold "talks about talks" with its putative merger partner, Abbey National, within the next few days following frantic moves over the weekend aimed at rescuing a deal between the two banks.
fields.body:
Bank of Scotland is ready to hold "talks about talks" with its putative merger partner, Abbey National, within the next few days following frantic moves over the weekend aimed at rescuing a deal between the two banks.

Sir John Shaw, BoS's governor, is awaiting a call from his counterpart at Abbey, chairman Lord Tugendhat, who returned from business in Hong Kong on Saturday and who is said to be ready to offer concessions to the Scottish bank's management team in order to restart negotiations.

Informal discussions between Credit Suisse First Boston, BoS's investment bank advisers, and Lehman Brothers, working alongside UBS Warburg for Abbey National, took place on Saturday before Peter Burt, BoS's chief executive, returned from a private trip to New York that evening.

The sides last met on Thursday morning before news of the discussions leaked and BoS subsequently revealed that while it had discussed a merger of equals during the summer, Abbey's more recent suggestion of a full-blown takeover of the Scottish bank was of no interest.

"There are no meetings scheduled, but if they are ready to flesh out their proposals and want to discuss it we would be duty bound to listen," a BoS spokesman said yesterday.

The chance to re-present their case will come as a relief to the Abbey camp, which has been thrown into disarray by the sharp rebuff it received last week from the Scottish bank. But both sides last night conceded that the chances of an amicable deal had deteriorated markedly now that negotiations were being conducted in the full glare of publicity.

"We have had a very public exchange of views. I think most people agree this is not the best way of going about things, sitting in a goldfish bowl," one adviser said.

Abbey was taking a conciliatory line over the weekend, suggesting that since both sides accepted the commercial and strategic logic in bringing the two businesses together, there should now be room to work on issues such as the structure of any transaction and the division of management. "Shareholders in both banks will not let us walk away from this now," one insider said.

But the BoS camp was still insisting it does not "need to do a deal for a deal's sake".

One adviser said: "A nil-premium merger made firm economic sense. But shifting the goal posts - moving from a merger to a takeover - and suddenly there is not much left in it for shareholders. There is not enough to justify a big premium."

It is now widely assumed that Abbey will have to offer a swath of top jobs to BoS executives if it is to stand any chance of success.

Analysts have speculated that if amicable terms cannot be agreed, one or other side might be goaded into a pre-emptive hostile bid. Although both sides played down the prospect last night, Abbey and BoS are acutely aware of potential predators.

fields.headline: David Wheeler
fields.standfirst:
Mathematician and educationist who was a classroom innovator
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: David Wheeler, who has died of cancer aged 75, was a pioneer of mathematics education. As editor of what became the Association of Teachers in Mathematics journal, Mathematics Teaching, he developed its international reputation.
fields.body:
David Wheeler, who has died of cancer aged 75, was a pioneer of mathematics education. As editor of what became the Association of Teachers in Mathematics journal, Mathematics Teaching, he developed its international reputation.

David maintained that the detailed content of the curriculum could not possibly be of the first importance. He also said that contemporary beliefs - that each teacher could only teach in his own way, or that good teachers were born and not made, or that a teacher's personality was an important part of his equipment - precluded the possibility that teaching could be scientific. "It seems to me to be one of the grossest educational errors of recent times," he wrote in Mathematics Teaching in 1970, "that we have managed - for the best of reasons, of course - to construct situations in the classroom which make it difficult or impossible for the teacher to have much choice of ways to act."

Wheeler developed the idea of mathematics as an activity rather than a body of knowledge. He saw children as embryo mathematicians rather than mere learners of techniques. "Because mathematics is made by men and exists only in their minds, it must be made or re-made in the mind of each person who learns it. In this sense, mathematics can only be learned by being created."

Born and brought up in Swindon, he studied mathematics at King's College, London University. After teaching at Willesden county and Acton grammar schools, he became a lecturer in education at Leicester University in 1959.

David was a prominent member of the ATM, which had begun in 1951 as the Association for Teaching Aids in Mathematics. As secretary from 1959-64, he did more than anyone to make it influential.

He edited the ATM book, Notes On Mathematics In Primary Schools (1967). This continued the ATM's tradition of group writing by teachers, started by Some Lessons In Mathematics (1964). In David's hands, the originality of the result spoke for itself; it was a new, informal style of writing for teachers that included children's work and lesson descriptions. David's lectures combined thoughtfulness, humour, inspiration and provocation. He was awe-inspiring, yet always kind to younger ATM members.

A sabbatical year spent with Caleb Gattegno - founder of the ATM - in New York in 1969-70 led him to move to the US. He worked with Gattegno from 1973-75 and then moved to Concordia University in Montreal. In 1980 he launched For the Learning of Mathematics journal.

David's retirement to Vancouver in 1990 was interrupted by organising the seventh International Congress on Mathematical Education in Quebec in 1992. He devoted his increasingly immobile time to reading, crosswords, and music.

His wife, Brenda, died in 1989.

 David Wheeler, mathematics teacher, born February 16 1925; died October 7 2000.

fields.headline: The tributes continue
fields.trailText:
I pause in the middle of a wild dance of glee at the news of Chris Woodhead's departure to express my astonishment that he has already been replaced by a Mr Tomlinson (Blunkett limits damage by promoting deputy, November 4). I am stunned at the government's ability to advertise openly for applicants, send out information, receive applications, shortlist, interview and appoint, all in the space of half an hour. Normal equal opportunities procedure, as followed by all other organisations in receipt of public funds, demands, after all, no less.
Catherine Rose
Olney, Bucks
abzx31@dial.pipex.com

Anne McCormack
Wigan

 The releases of Brian Keenan and John McCarthy; the defeat of Portillo at the last election; Royal Athlete's Grand National win (£5 each way at 40-1) are the only occasions that I can remember spontaneously cheering at a TV screen. Add to that select list the announcement of the departure of Chris Woodhead.
Greg Hetherton
Hove

 I have had a wonderful weekend, despite flu, listening to Ian Dury's album Laughter to celebrate Chris Blockhead's move to the Torygraph. Track three, Delusions of Grandeur, seems particularly apt.
Gary Cornford
London

 Chris Woodhead in public relations?
James Wilson
Banbury, Oxon

 Now that he's gone, what on earth am I going to write letters to the Guardian about?
Simon Midgley
Bacup, Lancs

fields.headline: Robert Cormier
fields.standfirst: American novelist whose work was a hotline to the hearts and minds of teenagers all over the world
fields.trailText: From the moment The Chocolate War, a coruscating attack on intimidation and corruption in an American catholic school, was published in 1974, the author Robert Cormier, who has died aged 75, was continually raising the stakes about what could be written about for young readers.
fields.body:
From the moment The Chocolate War, a coruscating attack on intimidation and corruption in an American catholic school, was published in 1974, the author Robert Cormier, who has died aged 75, was continually raising the stakes about what could be written about for young readers.

His position was simple: “There are no taboos,” he told the Guardian this summer in what was to be one of his final interviews. “Every topic is open, however shocking. It is the way that the topics are handled that’s important, and that applies whether it is a 15-year-old who is reading your book or someone who is 55.”

Cormier’s books were as good as his word: Tenderness charted a promiscuous young girl’s fixation with a serial killer; The Bumblebee Flies Anyway, set among the terminally ill teenage inmates of an experimental medical institution, was a bleak portrayal of dying despair lit by tiny moments of joy, and his psychological thrillers such as We All Fall Down and I Am Cheese never flinched at the cruelties that humans inflict upon each other.

Not surprisingly, his grim realism and stories that ignored the conventions of the teenage novel by telling it like it really was - with no happy endings and no adults prepared to lend a helping hand - brought him into conflict with parents’ groups in the US, who believed that it was unsuitable material for sensitive adolescents. There were frequent attempts to ban his work in schools and libraries in America.

Speaking at a conference on censorship earlier this year, Cormier declared: “I have my own standards. Tenderness is a very tough book. But it’s written in a minor key. When you’re dealing with a serial killer and a sexually precocious girl, it’s easy to let the blood flow and the sex roll. The harder part is to contain it and suggest it. So my conscience is clear. As to that sensitive child out there, I know they exist, but maybe a good dose of the truth would be a warning for what’s waiting. You seldom get a censorship attempt from a 14-year-old boy. It’s the adults who get upset.”

Cormier was born into a large family in French Hill, a French-Canadian neighbourhood of Leominster, Massachusetts. The second of eight children, he showed an early flair for writing. He never lived further than three miles from the house where he was born and, for almost 30 years, he worked as a journalist on the local paper, covering everything from the police news to births, deaths and weddings. “All the stories I’ll ever need are right here on Main Street,” he said.

It wasn’t until he was in his late 40s that he produced his first novel for teenagers. Thereafter, in his 13 books, Leominster became fictionalised as Monument and French Hill as Frenchtown, the latter most memorably in Cormier’s last book, Frenchtown Summer, an elegiac account of a paperboy’s journey to self-awareness as he walks the streets of his home town 50 years ago. As in all of Cormier’s books there was a darkness lurking beneath the sunlit surface. As Cormier’s editor was to note, the book might be hauntingly beautiful, but Cormier still managed to get a dead body into it. In the strongly autobiographical world of Cormier’s novels, that was because there really had been one: when Cromier was a boy the town had been traumatised by a local murder.

One of Cormier’s greatest strengths as a writer, besides a rhythmic flow and brilliant use of simile and metaphor, was his ability to take ordinary American suburban life and show it from the perspective of the child who sees all the things that the adults have missed or prefer to ignore. Cormier’s adults are often rather complacent, blissfully unaware of their offsprings angst or the dangers they are facing.

The loneliness and sense of being an outsider that Cormier had experienced as a bookish child, who was picked upon in the street, became translated into a series of main characters who were all loners. “I have always had a sense that we are all pretty much alone in life, particularly in adolescence,” he said.

Despite this, Cormier, a genial man with a birdlike inquisitiveness, had a long and happy marriage to his wife Connie and raised four children. It was the experiences of one of his teenage sons, who refused as a matter of principle to take part in his school’s annual fund-raising sale, that was to inspire The Chocolate War.

When Cormier sent the novel to his agent he was surprised to be informed that he had written a book for teenagers. It was an approach that was to stand him in good stead. “I simply write with an intelligent reader in mind. I don’t think about how old they are.”

The result was a rare writer who appeared to have a direct line to the hearts and minds of his young audience and made sure that they also had one to him. In a typically Cormier touch, he included his own telephone number as that of Amy Hertz’s in I Am Cheese. The resulting thousands of calls became his personal hotline to contemporary teenagers.

Cormier’s adults are often rather complacent, blissfully unaware of their offsprings angst or the dangers they are facing. The loneliness and sense of being an outsider that Cormier had experienced as a bookish child, who was picked upon in the street, became translated into a series of main characters who were all loners. “I have always had a sense that we are all pretty much alone in life, particularly in adolescence,” he said. Despite this, Cormier, a genial man with a birdlike inquisitiveness, had a long and happy marriage to his wife Connie and raised four children. It was the experiences of one of his teenage sons, who refused as a matter of principle to take part in his school’s annual fund-raising sale, that was to inspire The Chocolate War. When Cormier sent the novel to his agent he was surprised to be informed that he had written a book for teenagers. It was an approach that was to stand him in good stead. “I simply write with an intelligent reader in mind. I don’t think about how old they are.” The result was a rare writer who appeared to have a direct line to the hearts and minds of his young audience and made sure that they also had one to him. In a typically Cormier touch, he included his own telephone number as that of Amy Hertz’s in I Am Cheese. The resulting thousands of calls became his personal hotline to contemporary teenagers. • Robert Edmund Cormier, author, born January 17 1925; died November 2 2000.

fields.headline: Steve Allen
fields.standfirst: Star of America's Tonight show and inventor of the television chat format
fields.trailText: New York in the early 1950s was an artistic maelstrom, and it was in that city, in 1953, that Steve Allen, who has died aged 78, made his debut as host on NBC's Tonight show. Allen and Tonight created the talk-show genre, and set the creative bar at a height that has never been equalled.
fields.body:
New York in the early 1950s was an artistic maelstrom, and it was in that city, in 1953, that Steve Allen, who has died aged 78, made his debut as host on NBC's Tonight show. Allen and Tonight created the talk-show genre, and set the creative bar at a height that has never been equalled.

Allen was a multi-talented comedian and musician-cum-middlebrow renaissance man, who abandoned the talk-show format while he was still defining it. His idea of middle-brow would seem elevated today - in 1956, he was improvising jazz piano while Jack Kerouac read from On The Road. When Allen asked why he had written the book, Kerouac replied: "I wrote it because we're all going to die."

Allen was already a New York television personality when the local NBC station offered him a 90-minute show five nights a week. In September 1954, Tonight moved to the network, where it was an instant success. The key to Allen's appeal was his spontaneity: he engineered absurd skits in the streets outside the studio, prowled the audience with his microphone, or simply read the evening papers on air, ad libbing as he went.

NBC soon created the Steve Allen Show, a prime-time challenger to Sunday's Ed Sullivan variety programme on CBS and the slick western, Maverick, on ABC. After he left Tonight, the programme floundered until the producers followed his suggestion and hired Jack Paar as host. Paar would be followed by Johnny Carson, who fixed the show in a comic format which continues today under Jay Leno.

Allen's work ranged from game shows, such as What's My Line, to straight acting. He played the title role in the film The Benny Goodman Story (1955), and 40 years later gave a memorable performance on television's Homicide: Life On The Street, as well as playing The Mikado on the New York stage.

He wrote film scores and Broadway musicals, and was once cited by the Guinness Book Of Records as the world's most prolific songwriter, producing some 8,000 titles, the most famous of which is This Could Be The Start Of Something Big.

Working as a disc jockey in Los Angeles, he won a $1,000 bet with the singer Frankie Laine by writing 50 songs each day for a week. He composed them in the window of a music shop. He recorded nearly 50 albums, both music and comedy.

Allen was proudest of his serious television, creating the Emmy award-winning series Meeting of the Minds for the Public Broadcasting System.

Allen's parents were a vaudeville team: Allen & Montrose. His father, Carroll "Billy" Allen, the straight man, died before Steve was two. His mother, Belle, raised him alternately on the road or by leaving him with her family in Chicago. He claimed to have attended 18 schools.

Asthma led to a wartime army discharge and Allen began disc-jockeying in Phoenix, Arizona, soon moving to Los Angeles. There, by 1947, his live broadcasts attracted overflow crowds, enchanted by his mix of talk, interviews and records. In 1950, CBS gave him his start in television in New York, where he met the actress and game-show personality Jayne Meadows, whose sister, Audrey, was another television icon, playing Jackie Gleason's wife on The Honeymooners. Jayne became Allen's second wife in 1954.

The night before his death, Allen did a solo show before a sell-out crowd at a local college. He is survived by Jayne and four sons.

 Stephen Valentine Patrick William Allen, entertainer, born December 26 1921; died October 30 2000.

fields.headline: Stephanie Lawrence
fields.standfirst: Glamorous leading lady of the British stage musical
fields.trailText: Stephanie Lawrence, who has died suddenly at the age of 50, was a musical actress of rare glamour, which made her natural casting for a show about Marilyn Monroe. But, although she was a pillar of British musical theatre over the past 20 years and played lead roles in Cats, Evita, Starlight Express and Blood Brothers, she never fully achieved the 40-carat stardom that came to her no-more talented peers.
fields.body:
Stephanie Lawrence, who has died suddenly at the age of 50, was a musical actress of rare glamour, which made her natural casting for a show about Marilyn Monroe. But, although she was a pillar of British musical theatre over the past 20 years and played lead roles in Cats, Evita, Starlight Express and Blood Brothers, she never fully achieved the 40-carat stardom that came to her no-more talented peers.

She was born in Hayling Island, Hampshire, into a performing background. Her father was a musician and her mother, Gladys Kent, was a classically trained dancer who later formed a children's dance troupe, the Kent Babes. The young Stephanie went to the Arts Educational School in Hertfordshire and made her West End debut as a roller-skating tap-dancer in Peter Nichols's Forget-Me-Not Lane (1971): a prophetic move since she spent a good part of her later musical career on skates.

It was hard to miss her in the Nichols play since she embodied the adolescent sexual fantasies of the play's autobiographical hero.

Her stunning looks were accompanied by a fine voice and a dedicated professionalism and it was no surprise when she took over the lead role in Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice's Evita in 1981 and made no less an impression than Elaine Page as the Argentinian icon.

The choreographer on that show, Larry Fuller, was also the director of a musical called Marilyn which opened two years later at the Adelphi Theatre. The show was intended as a tribute to another popular icon who died young, but it failed to capture the public imagination. The one person who emerged with credit was Stephanie Lawrence. She not only captured the externals of Marilyn Monroe - the wiggle, the walk, the passionate pout, the vocal breathiness - but conveyed the carmined innocence and soft vulnerability within. It should have been her passport to fame but the show failed to live up to its star.

Undaunted, she picked herself up and got on with it. In 1983 she played the reformed prostitute, Mary Magdalene, in an ITV play called Doubting Thomas. In 1984, she was back on roller-skates in Lloyd Webber's Starlight Express at the Apollo Victoria Theatre. Amid the hi-tech efficiency of Trevor Nunn's over-busy production, she once again caught the eye. As I wrote in my review: "The first number to really grab me was He Whistled At Me which worked because Stephanie Lawrence, as a pink-suited steam-buff, was allowed to stand centre-stage and communicate a recognisable human emotion: unfulfilled longing."

Lawrence remained a popular figure on the musical scene. Succeeding Barbara Dickson and Angela Richards, she spent four years in Willy Russell's Blood Brothers. As well as appearing at the Phoenix Theatre, she also led the cast of the company that took the production to New York in 1993 where, thanks to the determination of producer Bill Kenwright, it survived mixed reviews.

She was a renowned animal lover and someone who put her career before long-term relationships although she married Laurie Sautereau only this year. She also brought to the West End musical stage a luminous glamour that has been extinguished cruelly early.

 Stephanie Lawrence, actress, born December 16 1949; died November 4 2000.

webTitle: Letters: Nader could be zenith for vote reform

fields.headline: Nader could be a zenith for vote reform
fields.trailText:
I was sorry to see that the websites set up to allow Gore and Nader supporters to trade votes tactically have been stamped on (Vote-trading websites close, November 2). However, I wonder if the idea might catch on here. Living where the only challenger to the sitting Tory MP will be a Liberal Democrat, I would happily swap my Labour vote with a Lib Dem living in a seat where it might count. I'd have to trust my "pair" to keep their word, but then what have I to lose but a redundant vote? If enough people used such a site, maybe the parties would have to look again at the options for PR.
Michael Jenner
Oborne, Dorset
m.jenner@virgin.net
fields.body:
I was sorry to see that the websites set up to allow Gore and Nader supporters to trade votes tactically have been stamped on (Vote-trading websites close, November 2). However, I wonder if the idea might catch on here. Living where the only challenger to the sitting Tory MP will be a Liberal Democrat, I would happily swap my Labour vote with a Lib Dem living in a seat where it might count. I'd have to trust my "pair" to keep their word, but then what have I to lose but a redundant vote? If enough people used such a site, maybe the parties would have to look again at the options for PR.
Michael Jenner
Oborne, Dorset
m.jenner@virgin.net

 So Downing Street is discreetly backing calls for anti-Tory tactical voting (Report, November 3). But Labour should be wary of taking Liberal Democrat support for granted. An ICM poll, carried out for Make Votes Count in June, showed that nearly one in four (23%) of Lib Dem voters say they would be less likely to vote Labour at the election if it decided not to hold the referendum on voting reform. With the recent volatility in the polls, tactical voting could prove decisive. Perhaps those in the Labour party and the unions who have campaigned for Labour to ditch this promise will reflect on whether their all-out opposition to a more proportional voting system is really serving the party's best interests - let alone the country's.
Nina Temple
Director, Make Votes Count
nina@makevotescount.org.uk

 Advocating tactical voting is doing nothing more than asking people to use their votes as sensibly as they can. The difficulty is that we do not have a sensible voting system. With first past the post, rather than voting for the person they most want, voters may choose to vote for the candidate who can defeat the person they least want. This could easily be remedied by allowing voters to rank their preferences. The AV+ system, as recommended by the Jenkins commission, would eliminate the need for most tactical voting, as would the single transferable vote system, which also offers the benefits of a more proportional result.
Dr Ken Ritchie
Chief executive, Electoral Reform Society
ken.ritchie@lineone.net

fields.headline: End of the beginning
fields.standfirst:
The death of Donald Dewar has made the Scots realise that their parliament matters a great deal.
Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: The death of Donald Dewar has made the Scots realise that their parliament matters a great deal.
fields.body:
It is amazing what effect mortality can have on political fortunes. As a living, breathing and campaigning candidate for senator of Missouri, Mel Carnahan was narrowly behind in the polls. Then he died. The rules dictated that his name had to remain on the ballot. Now he is in the lead.

Donald Dewar's much lamented departure is now having a similar effect on the Scottish parliament. While he was alive, the governing body he had done so much to create had been embraced by Scots in principle but was struggling to inspire confidence in practice.

Rightly or wrongly, the new administration was regarded as profligate (the building for the new parliament ran six times over budget), irrelevant (paralysed by rows about fox hunting and sex education in schools) and besieged. In March, Labour not only lost a byelection in Ayr to the Tories, it slumped to third place; the Liberal Democrats, Labour's coalition partner, came fifth, behind the Scottish Socialist Party.

The administration was assailed by populists on the left (the Scottish National party and former Labour party dissidents such as Tommy Sheridan and Dennis Canavan) and the right (the millionaire owner of Stagecoach, Brian Souter, ploughed thousands into keeping section 28, which discriminated against lesbians and gay men). Worse still, since at least the aforementioned difficulties were of the administration's own doing, it also started to look like a magnet for bad luck. While the rest of Britain's economy was booming, Scotland's started to contract slightly. Then in August came the exam fiasco, in which thousands of university hopefuls received the wrong grades.

In the referendum on devolution in 1997, 74.3% of Scots voted for a Scottish parliament. Two years later, one poll showed 72% believed the parliament was either doing a bad job or didn't care how it was doing.

But less than a month after Dewar's death, things are starting to look up. The Scottish executive has just announced that the elderly will now get free long-term nursing home care, unlike their counterparts in England and Wales. Canavan, a life-long Labour party member who stood and won against Labour after he was not selected to stand for the Scottish parliament, has embarked on a process of reconciliation with the party. Dewar's successor, Henry McLeish, has conducted a thorough and deft reshuffle. The entire Scottish Qualifications Association, which was responsible for the exam debacle, has been persuaded to resign. The economy is showing signs of growth. As England and Wales wade through muddy flood waters, even the sun is shining on Edinburgh.

This does not mean that Dewar was a failure or that McLeish is a success. Far from it. Dewar, one of Labour's unspun heroes, had a genuine personal following in Scotland; very few Scottish people have much of an opinion about McLeish one way or another. It is more a sign of the times. For Dewar is not the only person Scottish politics has lost suddenly and recently. Shortly before he died, Alex Salmond resigned as leader of the SNP. Within a month, Scottish politics lost the two men who, together, have dominated the landscape for the past decade and oversaw the transition from Westminster to Holyrood.

When Salmond became leader of the SNP, in 1990, the Tories were using Scotland to test-drive the poll tax and the SNP, the smallest party in Scotland, had branded Labour's Scottish MPs "the feeble 50" because of their inability to do anything about it. By the time Dewar died, Scotland had a parliament that had voted to abolish poindings and warrant sales and Salmond was the leader of the opposition.

But while both Dewar and Salmond were synonymous with Scotland, they bore the indelible imprimatur of Westminster. It was on Westminster's terms that they made their names - for there were no other terms - and fought their battles. They came to Holyrood gladly, but they did not come from there. Their successors are a different story altogether. Both are virtually unknown outside Scotland; indeed most Scots would struggle to pick out John Swinney, the new leader of the SNP, in an identity parade. Their performance at the despatch box this week - the first time they have duelled togther - was dire.

Undoubtedly they will grow into their respective jobs, although it is too early to tell in what direction they will take their parties. McLeish seems to be heading for a more populist agenda. His principal achievement so far is changing the name of the culture and sports portfolio to sports and culture - less Puccini and Bach, more pies and Bovril. He has said he wants to concentrate on "core issues", such as health and education, rather than gay rights and fox hunting. It is true that he has not travelled as far as Dewar, but that also means he is carrying less baggage. He could persuade Canavan not to resign his Westminster seat and force a byelection that Labour would probably have lost. Dewar could not because he and Canavan had a long-standing feud.

Swinney, meanwhile, has declared himself more of a gradualist. He wants to show that the SNP is fit to govern on bread-and-butter issues in Holyrood before he moves on to the big prize of independence by referendum.

But their low profile south of the border and scarcely developed agendas are no bad thing. For it is less important where they are going than where they have come from. Their big chance has come not in Westminster but Holyrood. Their success or failure will be defined in terms of how they fare in Edinburgh, not London. As the past 18 months have demonstrated, the terms of debate are very different up here. Scottish politics is more religious and less rural than that of Britain as a whole; the indications so far are that Scotland is likely to be less socially progressive but more economically redistributive. To hold its own here Labour must look to its left not its right.

The parliament has a higher proportion of women than the Commons but no ethnic minorities. Scottish backbench MPs in Westminster have taken to complaining that they cannot get their voice heard here because the media are too busy covering Holyrood. That is the way it should be. "Devolution creates institutions whose leaders have to have the confidence of those institutions rather than Westminster," says John Curtice, a politics professor at Strathclyde university.

It is a truism Tony Blair has had to learn the hard way; the consequences go beyond Scotland. Now that McLeish is in charge in Holyrood the four men Blair wished to carry his mantle during the first wave of devolution have all gone. Their careers have been cut short - by disgrace (Ron Davies), death (Dewar), defeat at the polls (Frank Dobson) and defeat in an assembly (Alun Michael). The two men the Labour machine fought hard, and at times dirtily, to deny the top jobs in Wales (Rhodri Morgan) and London (Ken Livingstone) are both in place. And, despite dire warnings to the contrary, the sky has not fallen in. The political institutions are in place: now the political cultures must flourish. The transition period is over. Like Dewar, may it rest in peace.

It is a truism Tony Blair has had to learn the hard way; the consequences go beyond Scotland. Now that McLeish is in charge in Holyrood the four men Blair wished to carry his mantle during the first wave of devolution have all gone. Their careers have been cut short - by disgrace (Ron Davies), death (Dewar), defeat at the polls (Frank Dobson) and defeat in an assembly (Alun Michael). The two men the Labour machine fought hard, and at times dirtily, to deny the top jobs in Wales (Rhodri Morgan) and London (Ken Livingstone) are both in place. And, despite dire warnings to the contrary, the sky has not fallen in. The political institutions are in place: now the political cultures must flourish. The transition period is over. Like Dewar, may it rest in peace. gary.younge@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Greek hijacker plunges to death
fields.trailText: An investigation began last night into why a man under arrest for holding a bus full of Japanese tourists hostage in Greece was able to hurl himself to death from the seventh floor of a police station in Athens.
fields.body:
An investigation began last night into why a man under arrest for holding a bus full of Japanese tourists hostage in Greece was able to hurl himself to death from the seventh floor of a police station in Athens.

"This was an unlucky moment for the Greek police, especially after the successful operation to safeguard the lives of the hostages," the general secretary of the public order ministry, Dimitris Efstathiadis, said.

But a conservative opposition MP, Fani Palli-Petralia, demanded further clarification, saying: "There is a big question marking hanging over this incident."

The hijacker, Christos Kendiras, in his late 40s, dived through a window at the central Athens police headquarters as he was being prepared for transfer to a public prosecutor in Piraeus, ending a bizarre two-day drama of murder and hostage-taking, some of which was broadcast live on television.

He bolted when his handcuffs were removed for him to be fingerprinted and photographed, ran into a nearby office and jumped through a window, the police said. He died when he hit a concrete overhang above the station's main entrance.

Kendiras threatened to kill himself while he held 35 people, mainly elderly Japanese tourists, at gunpoint for nine hours on Saturday.

He faced charges of killing his mother-in-law and a man he suspected of having an affair with his wife in his home town, Galatas.
Reuters

webTitle: Vital relic of artist who stamped indelible mark on visual imagination

fields.headline: Vital relic of artist who stamped indelible mark on visual imagination
fields.trailText: A playing card-sized scrap of copper has given scholars unique insights into the engraving process invented by William Blake, which allowed him to produce his extraordinary illustrated books.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A playing card-sized scrap of copper has given scholars unique insights into the engraving process invented by William Blake, which allowed him to produce his extraordinary illustrated books.

The author of two of the most popular poems in the English language, Tyger Tyger and Jerusalem, was also an artist, visionary and mystic, who saw and spoke with angels while walking through Covent Garden in London.

The fragment of copper printing plate is the only surviving example of Blake's relief etching technique, which allowed him to produce etchings as delicate and subtle as water colours.

Robin Hamlyn, curator of the largest ever Blake exhibition, which opens at Tate Britain on Thursday, explained that the artist, never rich and often penniless, used and reused his etching plates, and on his death in 1827 those remaining in his studio were sold as scrap metal.

"This little piece of metal is of unique importance," he said. "It is the only surviving piece in which we can actually see the hand of Blake at work on a relief etching, and watch how he achieved his effects."

The plate, which has never been displayed in Britain, and is a loan from the National Gallery of Art in Washington, only survived by chance. Blake had etched a frontispiece for his America a Prophecy on it, but did not use it.

He then cut up the plate, and gave a piece of it to his pupil, Thomas Butts junior, who cut an unimpressive bearded figure on the blank back.

It survived in his family's possessions, and its true significance was only realised long after master and pupil were dead.

When Blake died aged 70 in 1827, he was almost penniless. He invented the engraving process, ironically, to allow him to mass produce his illustrated books and make his fortune. It proved so labour intensive, even with his wife Catherine colouring the plates and stitching the volumes, that he lost money on every rare occasion that he sold a book for 10s 6d.

"This is the largest Blake exhibition there has ever been," Christine Riding, co-curator, said. "The Tate has borrowed from museums and private collectors all over the world - people have been extraordinarily generous."

Of the 12 drawings for his first prophetic book, Tiriel, only nine are believed to survive, and the Tate curators have managed to borrow them all from six different owners: the Fitzwilliam and British museums, Yale, and three private collectors.

All 100 plates from his last book, Jerusalem, now owned by Yale, are also on display together for the first time.

Blake, son of a hosier, who never went to school and earned a living as a jobbing engraver, had a few devoted friends and passionate admirers, but was generally regarded as a fool or a madman.

Today his work is revered by a remarkable range of artists, including Maurice Sendak, whose children's book, Where the Wild Things Are, has strikingly Blakeian bearded and hoofed figures; Thomas Harris, author of The Silence of the Lambs, whose anti-hero Hannibal Lecter actually devours a Blake engraving; Alex James of the band Blur; and American singer songwriter Patti Smith, who will give a rare London concert during the exhibition.

webTitle: Kindness by families 'puts elderly at risk'

fields.headline: Kindness by families 'puts elderly at risk'
fields.trailText: Pensioners' health is being put in jeopardy by well-meaning relatives and social services telling them to put their feet up, an expert in ageing reports.
fields.body:
Pensioners' health is being put in jeopardy by well-meaning relatives and social services telling them to put their feet up, an expert in ageing reports.

Families and local authority workers who do the household chores for elderly people may be depriving them of their main exercise of the week, said Marion McMurdo of Dundee university.

She also criticised public campaigns urging healthy lifestyles for concentrating on the "hi-tech lycra image" of physical fitness instead of embracing broader concepts, such as walking, dancing, bowling and gardening.

"Part of the problem is the common misconception that to reap health benefits, continuous vigorous exercise - athletics, jogging or squash - is required", she said.

But more moderate activity, such as brisk walking, would give most of the same health benefits.

There was substantial evidence that lost fitness could be regained with regular physical activity even in old age. Professor McMurdo, who is to speak on the issue at a conference organised by the British Medical Association in London today, suggested balance training and t'ai chi could make falls less likely, and regular exercise could help ease depression.

Towns should be made safer and more attractive so that old people felt encouraged to take their own chosen exercise.

In addition, they should be helped to regain lost skills. In most cases, the benefits of activity outweighed the risks. "Laying to rest the pervasive misconception that all the ills of old age are 'just your age' would represent a major breakthrough for health care of older people."

webTitle: MoD flattens hills to smooth airfield sale

fields.headline: MoD flattens hills to smooth airfield sale
fields.standfirst: Environment groups protest as woods face axe at Farnborough and ministry uses crown immunity to avoid need for planning permission
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence is to flatten two hills and cut down 150 acres of environmentally sensitive woods so it can sell an historic airfield for use by private executive jets.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence is to flatten two hills and cut down 150 acres of environmentally sensitive woods so it can sell an historic airfield for use by private executive jets.

The MoD is using crown immunity to avoid seeking planning permission to make the airfield at Farnborough, famous for its international air show, attractive to a potential buyer.

The airfield is being sold off as surplus to military requirements. But is not thought safe enough by the civil aviation authority unless the hills and trees are removed from the flight path.

Local environment groups are alarmed because the area contains sites of special scientific interest, home to some of Britain's rarest birds - the nightjar, dartford warbler and woodlark - although the MoD said the site would be improved by its works.

The MoD has already sold a former research station at the airfield for £57m for the area to be used as a science park but has negotiated a much larger sale with the multi-national company TAG Aviation for the airfield itself. This sale, for an undisclosed sum of more than £100m, was on condition that the CAA was prepared to grant a licence for its use as an airport for executive jets.

TAG is investing an additional £80m in new airport buildings while the MoD demolishes the nearby Eelmoor and Miles hills. The sale of a 99-year lease on the airfield is expected to be finalised in 2002.

Rick Kimber, spokesman for the Blackwater Valley Friends of the Earth, said that in addition to rare birds, the site contains a number of spiders and beetles which are endangered as well as grass snakes and lizards which are becoming increasingly rare.

"This kind of activity by the MoD shows why we need a countryside and rights of way bill. Under the new legislation the MoD would not be able to get away with this sort of behaviour. They realise that if they had to apply for planning permission they would have a lot of trouble persuading people that destroying the habitat of these species was necessary."

One hill is losing seven metres (21 feet) and the second two metres, and Mr Kimber claimed a third small rise called Norris hill was also "being scalped" as part of a plan to flatten out the whole area. The 50,000 cubic metres of earth being moved will be dumped in the natural hollows between the hills.

In 1996 the MoD decided it no longer needed the establishment and began the search for a buyer. One condition of the sale is that the biennial air show, which is used to sell civil and military aircaft, should continue.

Keith Holland, chief planning officer for Rushmoor council, said it supported the MoD's wish to sell off the airport for use of executive jets and TAG was granted outline planning permission last month.

The MoD allows executive jets to use the airport along side military aircraft but under the plan, permitted aircraft movements would double to a maximum of 28,000 a year.

"Clearly the MoD is entitled to go ahead without planning permission for its works to make flights safer. They did ask us if there were any objections as they are obliged to do. We consulted various bodies and there were no objections so they are going ahead."

Katherine Chatters, for English Nature, the government's statutory watchdog, said she had not objected because if the work was carried out properly the removal of scrub and trees would restore the site to lowland heath which would provide improved habitat.

An MoD spokesman said that the decision to "remodel" the hills and cut the trees down was taken on safety grounds for military and civilian aircraft and was not made specifically to satisfy the CAA and facilitate the sale to TAG Aviation.

fields.headline: Shelter attacks anti-begging campaign
fields.trailText: The government risks labelling all homeless people as cheats and drug addicts with its "misjudged" campaign urging the public not to give to beggars, Shelter warns today.
fields.body:
The government risks labelling all homeless people as cheats and drug addicts with its "misjudged" campaign urging the public not to give to beggars, Shelter warns today.

A £240,000 advertising blitz will be launched today by the Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam, and Louise Casey, director of the Rough Sleepers Unit, which argues that pennies given to beggars may "go towards the fiver needed for the next heroin hit".

National newspaper and magazine adverts will call on the public to "change a life" by donating to homeless charities in the run-up to Christmas.

But in a forthright attack on the initiative, Britain's biggest homeless charity warned that it would send out the wrong message.

Chris Holmes, Shelter's director, said: "We agree that we must tackle the problems of begging and street culture. However, in this instance we feel unable to support the strategy, which we believe is misjudged.

"Some of the headlines already generated by this campaign risk over-simplifying the issues at the expense of vulnerable people on the street."

The charity warns that the government risks intensifying hostility to rough sleepers, who already live in a "very dangerous environment ... They are more likely to be attacked and abused."

Ms Casey, who was formerly deputy director of Shelter, is concerned that giving change to beggars fuels drug and drink addiction.

But Shelter warns that while there are gaps in services to treat homeless drug addicts, drinkers and the mentally ill, withdrawing money from beggars will simply leave a vulnerable group of people with no money and no escape route.

"If people are forced to find other ways to maintain a drugs habit, they may be forced into more serious crime, or working for drug dealers. Any messages which deter the public from giving to beggars, however subtle, will compound the existing stigmatisation."

In Brighton, which has a high concentration of rough sleepers, the local newspaper has conducted a campaign against beggars. The Evening Argus has been praised for its campaign by Ms Casey and by the Home Office minister, Lord Bassam.

The anti-begging campaign has come under fire from social policy academics, who protested to Tony Blair that it was "potentially harmful". Dons, including Ruth Lister of Loughborough University, warned it was likely to lead to an increase in crime and prostitution.

The latest government figure for the number of rough sleepers is 1,180. Shelter says this is likely to be an under-estimate.

Shelter is urging the government to draw up a task force bringing together voluntary agencies, the Rough Sleepers Unit, the Home Office, police, DSS, and psychiatric experts to develop long-term strategy.
