webTitle: DPP inquiry into collapse of drugs case

fields.headline: DPP inquiry into collapse of drugs case
fields.trailText: The director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, has ordered an inquiry into a drugs and police corruption trial which collapsed after the judge identified serious improprieties by the prosecution team.
fields.byline: Michael Sean Gillard  and Laurie Flynn
fields.body:
The director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, has ordered an inquiry into a drugs and police corruption trial which collapsed after the judge identified serious improprieties by the prosecution team.

The Guardian has learned that the inquiry will examine the actions of senior crown prosecution service officials, Kent police officers and the complaints investigation bureau, which was a Metropolitan police anti-corruption squad.

The police squads masterminded a complex and expensive operation codenamed Nectarine lasting more than two years. It ended in humiliation last January at Maidstone crown court in Kent, when Judge Harvey Crush stopped proceedings against eight defendants, including a serving Met detective, accused of conspiracy to supply£12m of cannabis.

Two weeks later, Judge Crush returned to outline his reasons for stopping the case. His 42-page judgment was a scathing attack on the CPS and the police operation. Two months later, the DPP appointed two members of his personal staff to conduct an internal inquiry. Its existence is known only to a few officials.

But the report, which is expected to land on Mr Calvert-Smith's desk next month, could have implications for the conduct of future prosecutions, especially those involving supergrasses.

The DPP also took the unusual step of asking Stephen Wooler, the head of the CPS Inspectorate which investigates prosecution misconduct, to oversee the internal inquiry for thoroughness, integrity and independence.

Mr Wooler said: "There is no precedent for this situation. The review of this case is to see what lessons are to be learned. We are looking at all the issues Judge Crush raised." One of the defendants caught in Operation Nectarine was a drug trafficker, Richard Price, who after his arrest turned supergrass and implicated Met detective, John Bull.

But Judge Crush discovered there were illegalities in the way the anti-corruption unit and Kent police officers had debriefed Price to obtain his evidence.

It emerged during 11 weeks of legal argument - mainly about Price - that the police had offered him a "sweetening deal" worth £37,000 which they kept secret.

Judge Crush's judgment identified five key issues:

 "Wholesale breaches" of three laws governing police investigation, preparation of evidence and conduct of trials.

 "Prosecution misbehaviour" symptomatic of "a culture of non disclosure".

 1,700 pages of "significant" police documents not disclosed to the defence.

 A failure to record and retain police interviews with Price leading to doubts about the veracity of his written statement.

 "Pressure" by police officers when debriefing Mr Price and a suggestion of financial inducements to implicate detective sergeant John Bull and other defendants.

Judge Crush ordered that the defendants' costs should be paid from public funds. Philip Kelly, a defence solicitor in the case, last month made a substantial civil claim against Kent police for compensation on behalf of one of the defendants who had spent 13 months in custody.

Mr Kelly said he hoped the DPP would make the report public.

Mr Bull is still suspended on full pay pending a disciplinary hearing. He denies the charge.

In a statement, the CPS said Judge Crush's criticisms were taken "very seriously". It continued: "Naturally we are disappointed that none of the vast amount of evidence was ever tested before a jury."

fields.headline: Rome blocks regional poll on devolution
fields.trailText: The Italian government has tried to shore up its constitutional authority by blocking a referendum in Veneto, the region that includes Venice, on greater independence from Rome.
fields.body:
The Italian government has tried to shore up its constitutional authority by blocking a referendum in Veneto, the region that includes Venice, on greater independence from Rome.

The president of Veneto, Giancarlo Galan, vowed to press ahead with the referendum on the constitution that the wealthy region proposed last week, a draft which some described as near secession.

Mr Galan, who belongs to the centre-right coalition which is expected to win next year's general election, wants to keep two-thirds of the tax revenues raised in Veneto and to control health, education, immigration, law and order, and elements of foreign policy.

Francesco Rutelli, the centre-left's candidate for prime minister, denounced the plan as a recipe for a Yugoslavian-type disintegration.

A cabinet meeting decided that a referendum could be called only by the central government.

It would interfere with the devolution bill which it aims to push through the senate this week.

webTitle: Peckham outsider wins top design award

fields.headline: Peckham outsider wins top design award
fields.standfirst: But choice of library revives row over south-east 'bias'
fields.trailText: But choice of library revives row over south-east 'bias'.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The "building with the beret", Will Alsop's jaunty public library for the south London suburb of Peckham, has beaten the odds and a string of higher profile buildings to win British architecture's top award, the £20,000 Stirling prize.

Within minutes of being presented with his prize Mr Alsop, who was on the shortlist for the fourth successive year but was seen as an outside chance, decided to give the money away. Half will go to the Architects Association, half to throw a party for his team and the library and council staff involved in the project. "And all those sad people on the shortlist can come too," he promised. The sad people include the rival peers of the architecture world, Lords Rogers and Foster, and Denis Marks and Julia Barfield, who designed the London Eye.

The library was trailing in the betting on the competition, for which the favourites were Caruso St John's spectacular canal-side arts centre in Walsall, and the soaring spaces of Lord Foster's Canary Wharf tube station.

Mr Alsop was a popular winner, but his triumph revived the argument about the perceived south-eastern bias of the judges. Four of the five judges, who included artist Tracey Emin, are based in London, and four of the six shortlisted projects are in London.

The list was bitterly criticised by architects in Wales, the north of England and Scotland. Sebastian Tombs, of the Royal Institute of Scottish Architects, said: "Peckham is probably the most positive on the list to win, a building, like Walsall, which can have a real impact on an area where you would not expect people to go the extra mile in commissioning such a quality building.

"However, I very much regret that the judges, like Nelson, had a patch over one eye, a blind spot which blotted out all of Wales and Scotland. I am sad that viewers of the Channel 4 programme will get the impression that there is no good architecture north of Walsall."

Mr Alsop robustly dismissed this argument: "If you begin thinking like that, then next year the jury is going to have to say we must not forget Scotland, or Wales, we must have a woman, oh and we must have a building by a black man, and that's got nothing to do with the quality of the architecture. The jury happened to think that these buildings were the best architecture, and they happened to be in the south-east, and that's it."

The library, with its brilliant colours and extraordinary profile - the beret is a sunshade for the glass front - was much admired by critics and the public, but was seen as an outside chance. It has been hugely popular with local people and has increased the number of regular library users by more than 3,000 in less than a year. It was praised by Marco Goldschmied, president of the Royal Institute of British Architects, as "a building to make you smile - more architecture should do that".

The library cost £4.5m, peanuts compared with many of the other projects: Lord Foster's tube station cost £32.5m, Lord Rogers' Wood Street office block in the City £55m, and the lottery-backed Walsall gallery £21m.

Mr Alsop and his young team punched the air and shouted "Yes!" when their triumph was announced, to a distinctly over-emotional crowd of their peers, at the Science Museum. The announcement of the prize was delayed for hours. Architect Piers Gough, MC for the night, at one point appealed to the audience: "Please go away, get yourselves a drink and have a chat to your friends ... and then come back very slowly".

Excited rumours of a pitched battle among the judges between Walsall and Peckham supporters proved wide of the mark: the delays were caused by technical problems of the Channel 4 crew, which abandoned plans for a live broadcast and instead showed highlights of the ceremony last night.

A stainless steel folly in a forest near Kielder Water in Northumberland, designed by Softroom Architects, which cost £35,000, won the Stephen Lawrence prize, set up in memory of the murdered London student who had hoped to study architecture. Mr Goldschmied called the structure astounding, and noted that no planning permission was required for the folly: "Such are keyholes of opportunity through which strong innovative architecture has to squeeze in the nanny society."

webTitle: Archaeologist digs himself into a hole

fields.headline: Archaeologist digs himself into a hole
fields.trailText: It was uncanny the way Shinichi Fujimura knew just where to look for important historic artefacts. In fact, he was so good at tracking down Japan's paleolithic treasures, he was dubbed "God's hands".
fields.body:
It was uncanny the way Shinichi Fujimura knew just where to look for important historic artefacts. In fact, he was so good at tracking down Japan's paleolithic treasures, he was dubbed "God's hands".

But now it has been discovered his success was due to something a little less divine.

Mr Fujimura's reputation, like the ancient civilisations he investigated, is in ruins after he was caught burying artefacts in the early hours so that he could later stage their "discovery".

He was photographed by a newspaper burying 61 ancient stone items from his personal collection in an area that was thought to be home to one of the oldest settlements ever discovered. Mr Fujimura made a contrite appearance at a press conference following the front-page publication of the photographic evidence of his activities.

"I did something I shouldn't have done," said Mr Fujimura, who remained in a deep bow throughout the conference in a traditional sign of humility.

He has offered to resign as vice-chairman of the Tohoku Paleolithic Institute which, in the face of incontrovertible evidence, accepted full blame for his shenanigans.

"He's right there in the photos, digging holes and putting stones in them. There's nothing more you can say," said Toshiaki Kamata, chairman of the institute. "It was such a foolish thing to do."

The national newspaper Mainichi Shimbun took the pictures in secret and before publishing yesterday got Fujimura to confess to fraudulently burying the items in a layer of earth about 600,000 years old.

The incident took place in the Miyagi prefecture about 186 miles north-east of the capital, Tokyo, at a site which had drawn international attention because of the apparent "finds" made by Mr Fujimura and his research team.

They claimed to have unearthed "holes" which appeared to have been the footings for pillars to support primitive dwellings. If true, they would have been among the oldest houses ever discovered.

But all but four of the 65 stone items dug up at the site were from the errant archaeologist's own collection from earlier excavations.

Mr Kamata blamed the incident on Mr Fujimura's perfectionism and drive to find ever-older and more plentiful artefacts from Japan's prehistoric past.

It may have been that his previous, legitimate discoveries spurred him on to fake even more finds in a bid for extra glory, he said.

In a country where important archaeological finds often make the front pages and the population is deeply interested in its ancient history, the scandal is bound to have repercussions.

It is expected to tarnish not only the institute but also other researchers and work at the Miyagi site.

webTitle: Post office closures at record high

fields.headline: Post office closures at record high
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The rate of closure of sub-post offices is accelerating rapidly, despite promises by the government to find them new business and reverse their collapse.
fields.body:
The rate of closure of sub-post offices is accelerating rapidly, despite promises by the government to find them new business and reverse their collapse.

Figures for the first two quarters of this financial year show 333 post offices have shut, only 49 fewer than closed in the whole of the previous financial year, in itself a record. If the trend continues, more than 600 net closures will take place this year.

The figures, released by the Department of Trade and Industry, show 145 closures in the first three months of this financial year and 188 in the second quarter.

At the beginning of the year the Post Office could claim a network of 18,000 branches, the biggest single commercial network of outlets in Europe.

In a new worrying twist for the government, the number of rural closures at the half-year stage has declined, but there has been a rapid increase in the number of post offices in towns shutting down, especially in poorer areas.

The government is in large part responsible for the problem, as a result of its decision to switch payment of benefits from cash via post offices to automated payments direct into bank accounts.

The Post Office has calculated it will lose £400m of business annually as a result of the move. The switch, which is taking place in stages, has removed one of the most profitable lines of business of local post offices - many derive more than 40% of their total income from benefit payments.

Alan Johnson, the industry minister, is conducting research to discover the reasons behind the dramatic increase in urban closures.

The Liberal Democrat treasury spokesman, Vincent Cable, said: "These figures are very worrying. We are getting pretty close to a collapse. Sub-post offices are voting with their feet and if the government does not act soon, the whole network will crumble."

Many of the closures are due to sub-postmasters and mistresses either retiring or dying. The Post Office has then been unable to recruit replacements, leading to the enforced closures of the local post offices.

The government has tried to plot a new future for the Post Office through its proposals for a universal bank. The bank, run jointly by the high-street banks and the Post Office, would offer accounts for the 5m British people who do not have an account, the so-called socially excluded.

The Post Office has asked the banks for £130m to help set up this basic form of banking through its outlets. The new account would not provide overdraft facilities, a cheque book or direct payments except for utility bills. In addition, the banks would be expected to put cash machines in the local post offices.

The government is trying to ensure a response from the banks by the end of the year. The speed-up in the rate of closures will be putting extra pressure on the government to deliver.

But many of the high-street banks regard the proposed £130m payment as unfair and amounting to a voluntary tax. However, many of them know that they are politically vulnerable on the issue as a result of the rapid rate of closures of rural banks and the need to provide some form of alternative banking through post offices.

The Cabinet Office published a report in the summer suggesting the rural post offices could also develop a role as one-stop shops for government services and as a distribution point for goods bought over the internet.

fields.headline: Presidential Bush goes on defensive
fields.standfirst:
Bush on defensive despite assuming presidential air

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Bush on defensive despite assuming presidential air.
fields.body:
The arrival of the man who would be president is heralded by the sudden appearance of men in charcoal-grey suits and clear plastic wires protruding from their ears. It is one in the morning in the most important swing state in the country, and every minute is measured out and accounted for.

With hours to go, George W Bush and his immaculately disciplined battalions have already taken on a presidential air. When the Bush motorcade, flanked by police outriders, swarms into the hotel car park, the men in charcoal whisk the candidate and his wife to a top-floor suite, leaving behind a crowd of aides, handlers and journalists dizzy from high-speed visits to three states in eight hours.

Yesterday the Bush team spent the entire day in Florida. His rallies in West Palm Beach, Miami, Tampa and Orlando were a reflection of the importance of the state (with 25 votes in the electoral college which ultimately chooses the president) and a rare, if tacit, admission of vulnerability.

Only a month ago, Florida was in the Texas governor's pocket. It is a traditionally conservative state and Mr Bush's brother, Jeb, is its popular governor. But the latest Florida poll, published by Reuters and the MSNBC television network, showed vice president Al Gore four points ahead. That represented a statistical tie, given the poll's 4% margin of error, but coupled with Thursday's revelations about Mr Bush's 24-year-old drink-driving arrest, it is enough to put the campaign momentarily on the defensive.

Snap weekend polls suggested the news of the driving incident at the Bush family retreat in Kennebunkport, Maine, and the governor's failure to own up to it had only a marginal influence on public opinion, and national polls last night put Mr Bush between 2% and 5% ahead. But at this stage in a tight race, marginal tilts are all important.

The Bush campaign, which has been aggressively upbeat in recent weeks, was uncharacteristically tetchy. His spokeswoman, Karen Hughes, stepped in on at least one occasion at the weekend to stop an interview on the subject.

"This is the problem with Washington, this kind of 'gotcha' politics," Ms Hughes said, presenting the issue as one of Democratic party ethics, and directing attention to Mr Gore's portrayal of the contest as a battle between good and evil. "The American people are going to find it inappropriate and plain wrong."

Jeb Bush was sent out to the television studios to dismiss the problem. "People have discounted this. They've looked at it and they've decided it's not important," the candidate's younger brother said. "My brother has transformed himself since then."

The campaign started the day confident that it had put the matter behind it with no discernible damage in Florida. Soon after dawn, Mr Bush and his wife, Laura, went to church in downtown Jacksonville, the governor telling reporters that it was "a great day to start off the stretch run. No politics - just prayer and reflection".

After the service, Mr Bush drove to a breakfast meeting with the veteran evangelical preacher Billy Graham, the man he credits with leading him to his born-again Christianity. The meeting was also good politics. The revivalist has been filling 70,000-seat stadiums in Florida as part of his Billy Graham crusade, pulling in large numbers of voting-age youth in the conservative heart of the state. In the Jacksonville newspapers, the crusade has been given equal front-page billing with the campaign.

In its closing days, the Bush campaign has fallen back on its core message - that the Texas governor will purge the US of the sense of betrayal and moral discomfort of the Clinton era. At one rally after another, the central campaign slogan, "return dignity and honour to the White House" earns more cheers than any policy proposal.

At West Palm Beach yesterday, Mr Bush pointedly used the language of catharsis. "We have the opportunity on November 7 to purge this country of the old-style politics, the old way of doing politics," he said to a roaring crowd. By contrast, the promise of an across-the-board tax-cut was received with a restrained cheer.

Warm-up acts for Bush campaign rallies almost always use jokes focusing on Mr Gore's reputation for making up stories, such as: "How does Al Gore sleep? He lies on one side, and then he lies on the other side".

At a rally on Saturday on the outskirts of Philadelphia, the candidate was introduced by the Republican party's icon of integrity, General Colin Powell, the former national security adviser and putative secretary of state.

"It boils down to leadership," he told the crowd. "GI's [US troops] around the world need help" - echoing a favourite Bush slogan in the closing days: "Be patient. After eight years, help is on the way."

Alongside Gen Powell, there were several blacks on the podium, as is standard in Mr Bush's image-conscious campaign. The warm-up speaker, a black Republican official, Renee Amour, shouted to the crowd in urban slang unintelligible for much of the overwhelmingly white middle-class crowd. She referred to a local school's marching band, as "some brothers from Glenside".

The crowd's enthusiasm was undimmed and its desire for revenge against Bill Clinton was palpable. The Bush camp will be seeking to build on that anti-Clinton emotion today with an aggressive final sweep through Tennessee and Arkansas, the vice president's and president's home states, which now look vulnerable to the Republicans.

Mr Bush will fly more than 3,000 miles in the last frenetic 12 hours of his campaign and will also visit Wisconsin and Iowa, two more states which voted for Mr Clinton in 1992 and 1996 but which are now evenly balanced.

The strategy is intended to convey a sense of confidence. None of the four states Mr Bush will visit represent large voting blocs in the electoral college, but the Bush staff opted not to return to the bigger states like Pennsylvania and Michigan, arguing that their candidate's appearance in his adversaries' heartland will reinforce the campaign's central theme, squashing the Clinton legacy.

Mingling with the press corps in Philadelphia was Luis Rosero, another phenomenon of the campaign's closing stages. Mr Rosero held a manila file emblazoned with a Bush-Cheney sticker, but he was in fact a Democratic party operative, sent to listen to the Republican candidate, and whenever possible influence the press.

He questioned the Republican turnout figures and gleefully drew attention to Mr Bush's late arrival. "Every time they're late, they lose votes," he argued, distributing details of a Democratic press conference immediately after the rally, aimed at rebutting Mr Bush's claims. But much of what he had to say was drowned out by the band's martial music and the chanting crowd.

fields.headline: Storm brings more misery
fields.standfirst:
Once more unto the breach ... Britain braced for new deluge

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Flood-stricken areas of Britain were preparing for more misery and disruption last night as strong winds and torrential rain blew in from the Atlantic.
fields.body:
Flood-stricken areas of Britain were preparing for more misery and disruption last night as strong winds and torrential rain blew in from the Atlantic.

The new band of heavy rain and wind sweeping across Britain meant some areas were facing up to 50mm of rain overnight, and the worst-hit regions were bracing themselves for renewed flooding.

The storm dumped 34mm of rain in the south-west yesterday and was due to move across southern England and the Midlands, reaching Scotland today and tomorrow.

As Sir John Harman, chairman of the environment agency, warned "we are by no means out of the woods yet", the agency said it was monitoring the situation minute-by-minute.

A spokeswoman said that although rain falling in the hills would take a couple of days to reach the flood zone, any heavy rain would cause localised flooding because the drains were full.

Last night 21 severe flood warnings were in force on five rivers in Yorkshire, the Midlands and Wales, with a further 66 flood warnings across the country.

In the Midlands, the river Severn had peaked at Gloucester by midnight on Saturday, with the city escaping further damage. But the environment agency said the predicted rainfall could return the Severn to critical levels over the next few days.

In Yorkshire, the river Ouse peaked in York at more than five metres on Saturday - the highest levels since records began - but had started to drop yesterday.

However, flood defences at Barlby and Selby were overwhelmed and around 200 properties flooded. Work was being undertaken to shore up the bank but a further high tide was expected yesterday.

The storms are expected to last into Tuesday, while the swollen rivers could take many days to return to normal levels.

Deputy prime minister John Prescott's weekend announcement of £51m to shore up flood defences over the next four years was described as "finger-in-the-dyke stuff" by Friends of the Earth.

Mr Prescott, who visited Selby and surrounding villages early yesterday, reiterated his message that more robust planning of emergency services was required.

"People tend to think this is going to come every 20 or 30 years," he said. "Climate change is making a fundamental difference. Since 1987, there have been three major floodings and they are becoming more frequent."

Homeowners were facing a new threat as springs which have lain dormant for hundreds of years began leaking thousands of gallons of water into low-lying areas.

fields.headline: Iraq resumes domestic flights
fields.standfirst:
Decision increases pressure on sanctions
Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Iraqi Airways, grounded since the Gulf war, resumed regular domestic flights through the western-imposed no-fly zones yesterday, striking a further psychological blow against British-backed sanctions.
fields.body:
Iraqi Airways, grounded since the Gulf war, resumed regular domestic flights through the western-imposed no-fly zones yesterday, striking a further psychological blow against British-backed sanctions.

Two Russian-built aircraft took off from Saddam International airport in Baghdad for Basra, in the southern no-fly zone, and Mosul, in the northern zone.

An Iraqi official said the airline had started with one flight a week to each destination by plane, but added that there would be extra flights by helicopter.

The US and Britain imposed the no-fly zones in 1991 to protect Kurds in the north and Shia Muslims in the south from possible attack by Iraqi forces. Since then, both countries have led Iraq to believe that the ban on flights extended to civilian as well as military aircraft.

As recently as last September, when the Guardian disclosed Iraq's plans for a resumption of civilian flights, western diplomatic sources maintained they would be an infringement of the zones. Britain and the US now say that they have no objection to the flights.

Saddam's decision to resume domestic flights comes as the whole policy of sanctions is under unprecedented pressure. Although commercial flights to and from Iraq are still forbidden, thinly disguised "humanitarian" flights are now almost routine. One day last week, seven arrived from Turkey, Lebanon, Russia and the United Arab Emirates, all carrying officials and business delegations.

In addition, high oil prices mean that Iraq now has more money to spend than at any time since the 1991 war. A total of 1,554 companies from 45 countries have sent delegations to the Baghdad trade fair, which continues until Friday. The biggest delegations are from France, Russia and China - all permanent members of the UN security council.

A Ministry of Defence spokesman said that the RAF would continue to enforce the no-fly zones, but "if civil aircraft are flying in them it will be a factor we will take into account".

The US state department has said that, for safety reasons, it wants at least 48 hours' advance notice from Baghdad for each flight. But Iraqi officials refuse to give a warning because that would imply recognition of the no-fly zones.

This means that western aircraft patrolling the zones will have to rely on their own "friend or foe" technology to distinguish between civilian and military flights. According to one military expert, these methods are not infallible.

A further complication is that at least one of yesterday's civilian flights reportedly used a military aircraft.

With Britain and the US already under pressure over Iraq's allegations of civilian casualties caused by bombing in the no-fly zones, the accidental shooting down of a passenger aircraft would be a disaster for western policy.

Britain is also concerned about plans to reopen the oil pipeline between Iraq and Syria later this month. Diplomats say that Iraq intends illegally to export 200,000 barrels of oil a day through the pipeline, more than doubling the volume of the country's illegal oil sales.

A Foreign Office spokesman said the proposed exports to Syria would deprive ordinary Iraqis of humanitarian support if they were conducted outside the UN oil-for-food programme.

fields.headline: Patten law
fields.trailText: You argue that the Patten report should be implemented "neat" (Leaders, November 4), asserting that the inquiry was a "fair-minded study". How fair-minded is a matter of opinion. What is not in doubt is that if Patten is implemented neat, that will be unacceptable to the great majority of the unionist community and will give further ammunition to the anti-agreement faction of the Ulster Unionist party at the party's council in January.
fields.body:
You argue that the Patten report should be implemented "neat" (Leaders, November 4), asserting that the inquiry was a "fair-minded study". How fair-minded is a matter of opinion. What is not in doubt is that if Patten is implemented neat, that will be unacceptable to the great majority of the unionist community and will give further ammunition to the anti-agreement faction of the Ulster Unionist party at the party's council in January.

Even assuming the British government could coerce unionists into accepting Patten undiluted, it would inevitably lead to the downfall of David Trimble, the leader of moderate unionism. Unless there is some give on the republican side, the Belfast agreement is doomed. In which case, since there will be no northern ministers, no north-south council nor a Council of the Isles, there will be no prospects of a united Ireland, the goal of republicans.
Simon Partridge
London

fields.headline: Giveaway gamble by Brown
fields.standfirst:
Chancellor to hand out billions to soothe fuel discontent

Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Chancellor to hand out billions to soothe fuel discontent.
fields.body:
The chancellor Gordon Brown will this week hand out billions of pounds in his pre-budget statement in an attempt to quell growing popular discontent over fuel prices, pensions and the rising tax burden.

In what has been described as the most delicate political judgment of his career, Mr Brown will offer a number of concessions in an effort to remove the increasing perception of arrogance and incompetence surrounding the government.

He will hope to assuage some public anger over high fuel prices by targeting tax cuts for low and middle income families. And he will also give away millions to homebuyers willing to move into deprived inner city areas by announcing the targeted scrapping of stamp duty.

Mr Brown's statement on Wednesday has been designed to counteract Tory plans to reduce income tax. He hopes to define the election battleground, pledging to increase the value of the new children's tax credit and making the working families tax credit - the tax break for the working poor - more generous.

Although there are expected to be some concessions to hauliers and farmers, who have been pressing for huge cuts in fuel tax, the help offered is unlikely to be on anything like the scale demanded.

In a speech to the CBI today Mr Brown will insist that the planned concessions will not require plundering his budget surplus, so jeopardising his overall economic strategy.

"Even when tested by events like rising oil prices, our resolve will be constant," the chancellor will say.

The prime minister Tony Blair highlighted the dilemma, saying yesterday that he could easily win a reputation for listening, but lose his reputation for economic competence if the government gave in to the fuel protesters' demands.

However, in the first clear sign that the road haulage industry will gain some respite, Lord MacDonald, the transport minister, said the chancellor will do what he can to ease pressures on the industry.

He conceded that British industry was facing growing competition from foreign hauliers. The likely solution is the so-called Britdisc, a tax to be paid by all hauliers, including foreigners, operating inthe UK. However, British hauliers would be compensated for the cost of the disc through parallel cuts in Vehicle Excise Duty.

The package is also likely to include help for rural petrol stations.

The official haulage industry associations are still pinning their hopes on a 15p cut in diesel duty for hauliers - costing £1.5bn. A refusal to cut diesel duty for hauliers could reunite a politically fractured industry by pushing the more moderate association leaders into the hands of the rank and file protestors.

But the associations concede that ministers, previously reluctant to make the politically difficult environmental case for high fuel duty, have been emboldened by claims that floods hitting large swaths of Britain have been caused by global warming.

In a sign that the protesters recognise their position is weakening, they have slashed their demand for a 26p cut in general fuel duty down to 12p. Brynle Williams, the more moderate figure in the People's Fuel Lobby, may make further "negotiating concessions" when he meets Lord Macdonald today. Popular support for further protests over fuel has fallen to 58%, in line with Labour's private polls.

The protesters also issued a statement promising not to stage a go-slow down the motorway if they go ahead with plans for a convoy from Jarrow to London next week.

The move came after Lord Macdonald predicted that police would arrest anyone breaching the Highways Act.

The shadow environment secretary Archie Norman also spurned disruptive tactics, saying he did not wish the convoy to take place. "We're saying don't do anything which is going to inconvenience the general public, which is going to break the law."

In a move designed to underline the competing pressures on the Treasury, Mr Brown is expected to meet Lady Castle on Tuesday following a pensioners' rally in London.

Treasury sources promised that there would be above inflation increases in the basic state pension as well as other transitional arrangements before the introduction of the new pensioner credit in three years time.

Although attention in advance of the announcement has focused on the fuel protests, the chancellor's themes will be encouraging entrepreneurship, safeguarding the environment and reducing poverty.

webTitle: Victory is in the blood for 'aristocratic' Republican

fields.headline: Victory is in the blood for 'aristocratic' Republican
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The Republican George W Bush will be elected US president on November 7 because he has more royal blood than his opponent, it was claimed today.
fields.body:
The Republican George W Bush will be elected US president on November 7 because he has more royal blood than his opponent, it was claimed today.

The Texas governor has twice as many ties with aristocrats than his Democrat rival Al Gore, according to Burke's Peerage.

The company, which publishes books on ancestry, aristocracy and history, has predicted the outcome of the presidential race for almost 200 years. It says the candidate with the most royal blood has always been the victor.

Mr Bush has direct descents from William the Conqueror, Henry II and Charles II, according to Burke's Peerage.

He also scores better than his father, who lost the office of president to Bill Clinton, because of his mother's well-to-do ancestors. Barbara Pierce Bush's royal connections include French Bourbon and several Scandinavian monarchs, as well as members of the Russian, Spanish and German monarchies.

In contrast, Mr Gore can only boast roots that include a few b-list central European royals including three German dukes and two Holy Roman Emperors from the middle ages.

"Although never in the history of the United States have two presidential candidates been endowed with so many royal connections, our final research proves that governor Bush will become president," said a spokesman for Harold Brooks-Baker, publishing director of Burke's Peerage.

webTitle: Cod fishermen could be banned from North Sea

fields.headline: Cod fishermen could be banned from North Sea
fields.trailText: The government is to consider closing off vast areas of the North Sea to cod fishing as scientists warn of a drastic drop in stocks of the fish.
fields.body:
The government is to consider closing off vast areas of the North Sea to cod fishing as scientists warn of a drastic drop in stocks of the fish.

Cod numbers in the sea have slumped so low that the European Union is being advised to close areas to trawlers for the first time in the history of European fishing policy.

The British government has indicated that it would follow scientific advice in order to ensure the industry can survive.

The International Commission for Exploration of the Sea (ICES), meeting this weekend in Copenhagen, is concerned that the drop in numbers is so severe it may mean the end to commercial fishing for cod.

Scientists on the ICES advisory committee on fisheries management believe drastic action is needed and are recommending that spawning grounds be protected at all costs. They want large areas closed for three months in spring to give the few adult fish there a chance to breed.

EU fisheries ministers will meet to discuss the advice in December when they fix fishing quotas for next year, but they said at their June meeting that they will closely follow the advice of scientists.

ICES fears another Grand Banks fiasco, which occurred off Newfoundland, Canada, 10 years ago. Repeated scientific warnings about the imminent collapse of cod stocks were ignored and the vast shoals that once made this the most productive sea in the world vanished and have not recovered.

The scientific advice will not be disclosed until Thursday when EU governments are informed of the ICES recommendations but closure of large areas is the favoured option. There are other management suggestions such as a reduction of fishing but these alone are not thought to be enough.

The crisis has unfolded over years. Annual cod catches in the North Sea were routinely more than 350,000 tonnes, but the last time this figure was exceeded was in 1970. Numbers have fluctuated since then, with scientists warning that stocks might crash. Last year the quota was 132,000, tonnes but only 128,000 tonnes were caught by one of the most hi-tech fleets in the world.

Most of the shoals found in 1999 were undersized fish below breeding age. As a result much of the breeding stock was wiped out and scientists recommended a 40% cut to 81,000 tonnes this year. By the middle of October only 62 % of this quota had been caught - the fishermen simply could not find the shoals.

Joe Horwood, deputy director of the Centre for Environment, Fisheries and Aquaculture Science in Lowestoft, said: "I do not know what the recommendations are but the research shows the state of the cod stocks is very severe. Our work shows there are very few cod, and far fewer small ones for future years."

Last year, for the first time, parts of the Irish Sea were closed to all fishing during the cod breeding season from February to April. A known cod-breeding area round the Isle of Man was declared off limits. The success of the policy was based on the cooperation of local fishermen who believed it was the only way to safeguard their jobs in the long term.

Dr Euan Dunn, a marine policy officer for the RSPB, said: "With most of the old mature fish fished out, the age structure of the North Sea cod is highly imbalanced. In short we have a spiral of diminishing returns which affects not just numbers of fish but also their size and market value."

A spokesman for Elliott Morely, the fisheries minister, said he was aware of the problems of North Sea cod. "The minister would not be averse to closing part of the North Sea if that is what is needed to ensure the long term survival of the industry," he said.

When the Canadian stocks failed to recover, one explanation given was that the number of breeding adults was reduced so much that all their eggs were eaten by predators and their place in the ecosystem was taken by other fish.

Another was that global warming had increased the water temperature and cod were no longer able to breed so successfully. Scientists have already warned that the North Sea is warmer and that cod survival is threatened for that reason alone.

fields.headline: Garden pesticide link to Parkinson's
fields.trailText: It was only ever a matter of time before scientists pointed to one of the toxic agrochemicals pervading the world and linked it to a major disease of unknown cause.
fields.body:
It was only ever a matter of time before scientists pointed to one of the toxic agrochemicals pervading the world and linked it to a major disease of unknown cause.

Today, Professor Tim Greenamyre, of Emory University in Atlanta, Georgia, will do just that - suggesting at a conference in the US that exposure to rotenone could cause Parkinson's disease, the crippling brain illness which brings suffering to 120,000 Britons.

But, ironically, it is a connection that will shake some of the most ardent opponents of the use of synthetic pesticides in farming. For rotenone is no post-war insect killer cooked up in a corporate lab, but a natural product, extracted from the derris plant, and a mainstay of organic farms and gardens.

The findings of Prof Greenamyre and his team, to be published next month in the journal Nature Neuroscience, show that rats repeatedly given rotenone not only develop the symptoms of Parkinson's - trembling and loss of muscle control - but acquire the distinctive microscopic lumps in the brain, known as Lewy bodies, that are a sure sign of the disease.

"These results," the scientists write, "indicate that chronic exposure to a common pesticide can reproduce the anatomical, neurochemical, behavioural and neuropathological features of Parkinson's disease."

A link between pesticides and Parkinson's, which affects the Pope, Michael J Fox and Muhammad Ali, has been suspected for some time.

A review of 19 different studies over the past decade, carried out at the Ohio Medical College last year, reported that most found exposure to pesticides increased the risk of contracting Parkinson's.

Critics of the pesticide theory point out that the mass use of man-made chemicals to control pests only began in the latter half of the last century, whereas James Parkinson first identified the symptoms of what he called "the shaking palsy" back in 1817, and there is evidence that the disease goes back much further.

But rotenone, in the form of the powdered root of the derris plant, was used on a large scale in the industrial world from the mid-19th century onwards. In some countries, it has an even longer history.

Derris-based pesticides are on sale in garden centres across Britain. Rotenone is sometimes used to control populations of fish, for which it is highly toxic.

One bottle of rotenone pesticide on the shelf of a garden shop yesterday was labelled as "a traditional insecticide" and "a natural plant extract."

A spokeswoman for the Ministry of Agriculture said yesterday: "It's too early to say what the safety implications of this study might be. It will be put forward to our pesticide safety directorate toxicologists who will decide whether a review of this particular pesticide needs to take place."

Although the Atlanta scientists have pinpointed rotenone, they make it clear that they believe other pesticides which work in the same way could be equally dangerous.

Benoit Gaisson and Virginia Lee, Parkinson's researchers at Pennsylvania University, said the work did raise questions about rotenone's safety.

"Rotenone is a naturally occurring substance that is eventually degraded in the environment, and as such it is considered to be benign compared to many other pesticides," they wrote in Nature Neuroscience. "Whether rotenone exposure contributes to the incidence of Parkinson's disease remains to be determined. Nevertheless, the effects of chronic rotenone administration observed here may be representative of the possible effects of exposure to low amounts of other environmental toxins, yet to be identified."

One theory is that exposure to one or several pesticides combines with an individual's genetic makeup to cause Parkinson's. The Pennsylvania researchers said the fact that the risk of getting Parkinson's rose sharply with age fitted in with the notion of the drip-drip effect of environmental toxins over time.

In Parkinson's, cells in the brain that produce dopamine, which carries signals between nerve cells, begin to die. The reasons are not understood, but a major clue came in the 1980s, when an attempt to create an illegal designer drug went spectacularly wrong. The guinea pigs who took the drug, MPTP, were struck down with a rapid-onset version of Parkinson's.

MPTP interfered with a key component of the dopamine-producing brain cells, the mitochondria, the "power stations" of cells. Rotenone and other pesticides have a similar effect, although rotenone appears to produce symptoms much closer to typical Parkinson's disease than MPTP.

The Atlanta team believes that at the heart of the problem lies a kind of toxic waste produced by the mitrochondria as they generate energy. This waste comes in the form of rogue molecules called free radicals, which barge around the body, damaging vital functions. One theory holds free radicals responsible for normal ageing.

Even in healthy people, the mitochondria in dopamine-producing cells are thought to produce a high level of these free radicals. The Parkinson's-causing effect of pesticides may be to increase the amount of "waste" the mitochondria produce, causing the death of the cells.


'You tell your body to move - and it doesn't'

It seemed trivial yet it was troubling. The instructor at the toddlers' gym where Maureen McHugh had taken her son asked the parents, as part of an exercise, to wiggle their fingers. Her brain responded, but her fingers didn't.

"I couldn't wiggle the fingers in my left hand," said Dr McHugh, 44, a soil scientist from Aberdeenshire. "I started to lose mobility on my left side. Everyday tasks became difficult."

That was in 1996. Despite signs that something was badly wrong, she did not consult a doctor until 1998, when she was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease.

"Your brain tells your body to move and it does not," she said. "It's going to get steadily worse. It's not supposed to shorten your life - it just makes life a complete misery."

Since being diagnosed, Dr McHugh has been taking the drug L-dopa, which relieves Parkinson's symptoms. It does nothing to treat the cause, and can itself lead to serious disability after long use. But for the time being it enables her to carry out everyday tasks such as driving and helping her partner David Mills with their children.

"I'm fairly incapable at times," she said. "Before I went on the medicine, I was virtually unable to do anything. Now I can do most normal things in a limited way, although I have to plan in advance."

Dr McHugh has spent hours studying research into Parkinson's. She believes the evidence of a link between the illness and chemicals in the environment is strong. Over the years she has been exposed to different toxic chemicals in her work, but doubts that a single chemical such as rotenone is to blame.

With hopes high that a treatment to end Parkinson's may be on the horizon, Dr McHugh is campaigning with other members of the Special Parkinson's Research Interest Group (Spring) to persuade the government to relax restrictions on scientists who believe the best hope of a cure lies in the using human stem cells to create new nerve cells to replace damaged ones.

The only source of human stem cells is surplus human embryos donated by couples undergoing IVF treatment and at present scientists are barred from using these for research into anything other than fertility problems.

"It's vital that the government make these changes," said Dr McHugh. "The embryos in question are very early. An individual being hasn't been established at that point."

webTitle: Weller's call for rape trial rights

fields.headline: Weller's call for rape trial rights
fields.standfirst: Marcel Berlins on: Anonymity in sex crimes * Press Freedom * Jobs in the judiciary
fields.trailText: Two weeks ago the singer Paul Weller, once of the Jam, was arrested in connection with the rape of a 36-year-old woman, four years ago. It made the front pages of some of the tabloids. Last week the police announced that he would not face any charges. Needless to say, that decision didn't get the same coverage.
fields.body:
Two weeks ago the singer Paul Weller, once of the Jam, was arrested in connection with the rape of a 36-year-old woman, four years ago. It made the front pages of some of the tabloids. Last week the police announced that he would not face any charges. Needless to say, that decision didn't get the same coverage.

Weller, understandably miffed, has called for the law to grant male rape suspects the same anonymity as that given to their alleged victims. His case is all the stronger because he was not even charged. There is nothing new in his demand, of course. Celebrities (such as Craig Charles of Red Dwarf) and non-celebrities (Austen Donnellan, accused of the date rape of a fellow student) who have gone through the ordeal of a highly publicised trial before being acquitted, have made similar points. Why should the name of the accused be, as it is always put, dragged through the mud when he is innocent, while the woman complainant who has told a pack of lies keeps her name secret?

There is a superficial attraction in the equality argument: either do not reveal the rapist's name unless and until he is convicted (which is the practice in some countries) or, if his name is public, disclose the woman's identity if he is acquitted.

It is a flawed argument. First, the fact that the man is acquitted does not necessarily mean that the woman is lying. It could be that the jury thought he had probably done it, but there was not enough evidence to be sure, beyond a reasonable doubt. Second, the reason for allowing rape complainants anonymity is to persuade women to report rapes; without that concession the reporting rate would be even lower than it is now. But if women knew their names would be revealed if their attackers were - perhaps wrongly - acquitted, they would surely think twice before reporting sexual attacks.

This leaves one argument: why not keep an alleged rapist's identity secret until his conviction? We have a system of open justice in this country which, we rightly believe, is one of the hallmarks of a democratic society. Open justice means that the identities of those accused of crime are publicly known. Many of them will be innocent. Having their names bandied about will be embarrassing and sometimes devastating, whether they are charged with theft, murder, fraud or rape. But there is no reason for treating the alleged rapist more favourably than the alleged thief or fraudster. Unwelcome publicity is the price we pay for democracy.

I'm impressed by a robust House of Lords ruling the other day on the freedom of the press. If this is a portent of the future attitude of the law lords, and of their leader, Lord Bingham, it is good news indeed.

The case was about whether or not a journalist could be successfully sued for libel for his report of a press conference at which defamatory comments were made about the Belfast solicitors' firm that had represented the paratrooper Lee Clegg. The Northern Ireland appeal court had ruled that the press conference was not a "public meeting" and therefore reporting it didn't attract the "qualified privilege" that protects the reporter from a libel claim. The five law lords unanimously decided otherwise - it was a public meeting, with the reporters acting as "the eyes and ears of the public"; they therefore couldn't be sued for providing a fair and accurate account of it.

Lord Bingham stressed the "cardinal importance of press freedom" and added: "The proper functioning of a modern partici- patory democracy requires that the media be free, active, professional and inquiring." We're not accustomed to such talk from our judges.

The result of the American presidential election could have a profound effect on future decisions of the US supreme court. The president appoints the judges and he chooses people likely to support his own agenda. And because the judges take decisions over such a wide range of issues with social consequences - the right to abortion is just one - it is no exaggeration to say that the make-up of the supreme court can influence the very fabric of American life.

The astonishing thing about the court is that its judges are appointed for life (it used to be so here, but now law lords have to retire at 70) so that a new appointment can only be made when a judge decides to retire or dies. Two judges may be close to going, the 80-year-old Justice Stevens and the 76-year-old Chief Justice Rehnquist. At the moment, the nine-person court (including two women) is - just - weighted towards a "liberal" stance.

But if Bush gets in and the liberal Stevens leaves, he will almost certainly be replaced by a "conservative", which would immediately tilt the balance. One of the consequences will be an attempt to claw back the abortion rights given to women by the momentous decision in Roe versus Wade. If Bush does win, the liberal (usually Democrat), hope will be that the conservative Rehnquist goes first. If he is replaced by a like-minded judge, it won't alter the balance. I look forward to the day when I'll be writing such analytical items about our judges in their new UK supreme court identities. It won't be long.

Just a gentle reminder to the many thousands of broadcasters, journalists, politicians, famous people and members of the public who have, in the past few weeks, informed me, through the various media and on a variety of subjects, that the "law is an ass" - Charles Dickens wrote no such thing. "If the law supposes that," said Mr Bumble in Oliver Twist, "the law is a ass, a idiot."

fields.trailText: When AS Roma last won the Scudetto in 1983, long hair was the fashion and the samba skills of Falcão, the crosses of Conti and the goal-scoring exploits of Pruzzo sent the red half of the Eternal City wild.
fields.body:
When AS Roma last won the Scudetto in 1983, long hair was the fashion and the samba skills of Falcão, the crosses of Conti and the goal-scoring exploits of Pruzzo sent the red half of the Eternal City wild.

Since then the I Lupi have struggled in the shadow of Juventus, Internazionale, AC Milan and even their hated city rivals Lazio. But 17 years after their last Serie A triumph Roma have returned. And with Totti's trickery, Cafu's incisions, and Gabriel Omar Batistuta goals (and hair) reviving memories of the 1983 side, they are - for the first time in a decade - being talked up as serious title contenders.

Yesterday Roma's ripe start to the season continued with a 4-2 victory away at Brescia. Despite somehow falling 2-1 behind at half-time, a brilliant second half hat-trick from Batistuta (he's now scored a phenomenal 158 goals in 249 Serie A matches) turned things round, leaving Brescia coach Carlo Mazzone - the Big Ron of Italian football - mightily impressed.

"If Roma don't win the league this season I don't know when they ever will," the ex-coach of Roma gushed, before quickly remembering himself: "I say that like a Roma fan but it must be made clear that we didn't gift them the win today," he continued.

Roma coach Fabio Capello, however, was much more downbeat. "Today we must not boast," he insisted. "We must remain calm and keep our concentration."

Despite their impressive victory, Roma stay behind shock Serie A leaders Udinese, who were much too strong for Lecce. After a drab first half, Italian international Stefano Fiore began to strut his stuff, and two goals within five minutes from Sosa and Margiotta sealed a comfortable 2-0 win.

After the game Udinese coach Luigi De Canio - like Capello - refused to get carried away. "It was very difficult today because Lecce are a good team and we didn't play well for the first half an hour," he admitted. "We have to stay humble and keep concentrating."

Meanwhile another of this season's surprise packages - new promoted Atalanta - continued their excellent start with a 3-3 draw away at AC Milan. But despite a creditable result, Atlanta's two-goal hero Christiano Doni - who is currently facing a five-year ban for match-fixing - wasn't satisfied, claiming his side should never have thrown away their 3-1 half-time lead.

"I am actually not that happy with the result because I believed right up until the final whistle that we could get the three points," he insisted. Even so, fans of new-promoted Atlanta won't be too disappointed to find themselves in third place.

The same can't be said about the attitude of ever-volatile Napoli supporters, however. Yesterday one particularly irate supporter followed the Azzurri's 2-1 home defeat by Vincenza by hurling a Molotov cocktail into the villa of co-owner Corrado Ferlaino.

The home-made device bounced off the wall of the house and exploded in the garden, setting fire to two cars (a Renault and a Nissan if you're interested) that were parked outside. Fortunately a policeman on duty at the house extinguished the blaze - although the cars were destroyed.

But Ferlaino couldn't say he wasn't warned. He later told police that he had received an anonymous call on Sunday morning telling him that his villa would be set alight if Napoli failed to win. Worse still, later on that morning, two men had spookily forewarned one of Ferlaino's cleaners: "Watch out. There's going to be one hell of a fire here tonight."

However despite the result - and the fire-bombing - under-pressure Napoli coach Zdenek Zemen today survived a board meeting - and so he keeps his job, for now at least.

Elsewhere Juventus moved into fourth after David Trezeguet scored twice in their 2-0 win away at Massimo Tiabi's Reggina. Parma won 1-0 at Bari with an 87th minute Patrick Mboma goal. And Hakan Sukur - reportedly rumoured to be going back to Turkey last month - scored his second goal in as many games as Internazionale scrambled a late draw at Verona.

But spare a thought for the plucky home side - they were forced to play the whole of the second half with ten men after Vincenzo Italiano was given a second yellow card for an "over-the-top goal celebration" after he put Verona 2-1 ahead. It could have been worse though - with seven minutes to go (and with Inter throwing four forwards into the attack: Pirlo, Vieri, Sukur and Recoba) the Turkish striker was presented with an inch perfect Recoba cross, just three yards out, but sliced it over the bar.

webTitle: Stewart claims turn up heat on MacLaurin

fields.headline: Stewart claims turn up heat on MacLaurin
fields.trailText: Alec Stewart has revealed that, far from being thorough, investigations by the England management into his alleged dealings with a bookmaker amounted to just a brief phone call.
fields.body:
The thoroughness of the England management's investigation into allegations that Alec Stewart received money from a bookmaker was thrown into doubt yesterday when the former Test captain revealed he had only a brief phone conversation with the chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board Lord MacLaurin.

Writing in his newspaper column, Stewart said the decision not to send him home from the Pakistan tour was made after he had a short conference-style conversation with MacLaurin and the ECB chief executive Tim Lamb.

Stewart said yesterday that he was asked three questions. Were the allegations in the Indian Central Bureau of Investigation's match-rigging report true? Did he know the bookmaker Mukesh Gupta? And had he ever accepted money from anyone in relation to match-fixing or providing information?

"I gave three nos," Stewart explained, "and said I was willing to help in any way that I was able. It was not a long conversation."

In fact, it is believed the whole thing lasted no more than 10 minutes, the bulk of which was spent discussing a strategy for handling the media and associated issues.

Stewart added: "Once I had satisfied them MacLaurin said words to the effect of: 'Right, that's fine, you have cooperated. You can stay on the tour.' I don't think there was ever any question of my going home."

In other words, what was seen as a serious attempt by the ECB to investigate the allegations was, in fact, fleeting.

It is also at odds with MacLaurin's insistence in a BBC radio interview that he had "a very long conference call" with Stewart. The only interpretation, other than that MacLaurin has a different idea of "long" to Stewart, is that the ECB is embarrassed by the obvious lack of depth behind its decision to keep Stewart on the tour and is trying to get off the hook.

MacLaurin's already battered image in Pakistan will only be worsened by the news that he will not be attending any of the three Test matches. Nor is he going to an International Cricket Council finance board meeting in Lahore, where the new ICC president Malcolm Gray will be present. Lamb is going instead.

This will be the first time that MacLaurin, who is about to embark on a further two-year term as chairman, has missed an England tour since he was appointed to the job.

The reasons, as far as they go, are legitimate enough. As chancellor of the University of Hertfordshire he has some unavoidable commitments, although they surely do not extend to all three Tests.

To Pakistan it will look suspiciously as if he is ducking out of being seen here, especially in the light of the Stewart affair and his recent comments - misconstrued or otherwise - that players under investigation in match-rigging inquiries should be suspended (the ECB was keen to explain that this view applied only to anyone who refused to cooperate).

The England team, meanwhile, have arrived in Peshawar for their final warm-up match before the first Test in Lahore. It will also be their last chance to sort out the make-up of the side.

According to the coach Duncan Fletcher yesterday there is certain to be a change in last summer's strategy of four seamers, and it is still possible that they might employ not one but two spinners if the pitches look conducive. Ideally, Ashley Giles and Ian Salisbury will both play in the forthcoming match, which starts on Wednesday, and slug it out from there.

The first-class aspect to the tour got off to an excellent start here on Saturday, with Matthew Hoggard and the spinners wrapping up an innings victory by bowling out the Patron's XI second time round for 169. It is something to be savoured: England wins of any description in Pakistan are rare enough to warrant protected-species status.

Once more Hoggard did the damage, finishing with figures of four for 40 for the innings and nine for 102 for the match. His experience with Free State in South Africa last winter - using the same Kookaburra ball as is used here, and bowling a similar length and line - has clearly stood him in good stead.

The chances of him gaining a Test place on merit are still not good, but Fletcher is rightly delighted. Quality back-up for Darren Gough and Andy Caddick, neither in the first flush and each subject to sudden and long-term injury in the past, is vital.

fields.headline: Police to investigate county games 'fix'
fields.trailText: The ECB may ask police to investigate claims that two matches between Essex and Lancashire in 1991 were fixed.
fields.body:
England's cricket authorities, shocked out of their stance of moral righteousness over the match-fixing affair, are likely to invite police to consider a criminal investigation into the most controversial county match of the past decade.

Long-standing allegations by the former Essex bowler, Don Topley, that two matches between Essex and Lancashire in 1991 were rigged were met for many years with a dismissive response by the England and Wales Cricket Board, and led to Topley being widely ostracised throughout the game.

However, the ECB had little choice but to reopen investigations last summer after supportive allegations that the matches were fiddled. Nearly a decade on, the police are now likely to be asked to examine the conduct of the matches played under two stand-in captains, Lancashire's Neil Fairbrother and Essex's Neil Foster.

Topley claimed that two desired results between Essex and Lancashire in August 1991 were conveniently achieved in a shoddy deal that suited both counties' ambitions.

Essex beat Lancashire by eight wickets after what Wisden called "a generous declaration" and went on to win the County Championship. In the middle of the fixture, a Sunday League match was won by Lancashire by five wickets with five balls to spare, in a season in which they finished runners-up.

Topley has always maintained that he bowled badly in the Sunday game under instructions, stating: "I was told 'you know what you've got to do', and I deliberately bowled so that Neil Fairbrother could milk my bowling." Guy Lovell, a former Essex spinner, has always supported Topley's claim that the matches were fixed.

Wasim Akram and Salim Malik, two Pakistan players censured in the Qayyum Report into match-fixing, were overseas professionals at Lancashire and Essex at the time. Topley has never accused them of involvement.

Topley said he was relieved by the promise of Lord MacLaurin, the ECB chairman, that his evidence was at last "being pursued".

Such a fiddle, if proved, predates by more than a year the wave of match-fixing scandals involving Indian bookmakers. England, after pronouncing itself free from dishonest cricket, might be presented as its birthplace.

fields.headline: Ibsen for five-year-olds
fields.standfirst:
A Doll's House
New Ambassadors Theatre, London
**
fields.trailText:
A Doll's House

New Ambassadors Theatre, London
**
fields.body:
You can never completely destroy Ibsen's masterpiece. But Shared Experience's new production, directed by Polly Teale with Yvonne McDevitt, has a damn good try. It is labelled "expressionistic". What struck me was its mindnumbing literalness. Every-thing that is unspoken in Ibsen's text is acted out as if for an audience of five-year-olds.

It starts with Nora emerging from a real doll's house. Meanwhile the home that she and Torvald inhabit is full of cracked walls presumably to indicate a rotting bourgeois marriage. It gets worse. Every time Nora mentions her father, Pip Donaghy appears dangling a bag of macaroons in front of her as if she were a domestic pet. And, when Nora is haunted by Krogstad's revelation of her forgery, the tattered blackmailer appears on stage writhing at her feet.

The intention is to remind us that Ibsen was not a purely naturalistic dramatist. But whoever supposed that he was? Ibsen himself supplies all the symbolism you need. The tarantella, for instance, represents Nora's repressed demonism so that you don't need, as here, for her to whirl around clutching the doll's house roof.

What you lose, by the intrusion of shadow-characters, is the autonomy of the individual actors. It hinders rather than helps Anne-Marie Duff's Nora for us to be constantly reminded that she has been the victim of domineering men. Her performance comes into its own only when she is left alone with Torvald and confronts him, with unaffected downrightness, with her lifelong dependence. But even in this scene Paterson Joseph's Torvald is so heavy handedly patronising that the crucial point that the play is about his self-realisation as well as Nora's is obscured.

The best work comes from Jude Akuwudike, who overcomes Krogstad's melodramatic writhing to suggest a guilt-handed blackmailer, and from Eileen O'Brien, who makes something unexpectedly moving out of the nurse's revelation that she has farmed out her own illegitmate daughter. A moment that normally goes for nothing is suddenly thrown into sharp relief, which proves that the best way to play Ibsen is to excavate the text, here given in Michael Meyer's excellent translation, rather than to treat is a source of child's picturebook illustration.

Until December 9. Box office: 020-7369 1761.

fields.headline: Halifax eases account transfer
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Halifax will announce a plan this week which could eventually halve the time it takes to swap accounts between banks.
fields.body:
The Halifax will announce a plan this week which could eventually halve the time it takes to swap accounts between banks.

The bank's move to introduce computer switching of direct debits comes days before the launch of a Department of Trade and Industry drive aimed at encouraging industries to ease the transfer between banks and utility providers such as gas and phone companies.

The major banks already exchange customers' direct debits on paper, but Halifax will become the first of the high street banks to introduce computers into the process. The bank claims the average period for switching current accounts could be cut to three weeks from the present six weeks.

All the banking groups have agreed to roll out the automated services towards the end of the year. Halifax, however, will start a pilot scheme in 100 branches between now and the end of the year.

The bank hopes to offer automatic "switching" at all its 800 branches by early January, when its new 4% interest rate on current account is introduced.

David Fisher, general manager of banking and consumer credit at Halifax, said: "Altering direct debits has always been a nuisance for the customer and our aim is to put things right with this new system."

An NOP survey commissioned by the Halifax showed that 59% of adults are deterred from moving their current accounts by "hassle" factors like direct debit transfers. Also 60% of customers considering a move would go ahead if a rival bank offered them a "switching" service.

Despite attempts by Halifax to inject competition into the current account market, some industry sources believe that its attempt to win business by paying 4% on current accounts - compared with the 0.25% offered by the big four - may be fruitless. Customers looking for high interest would probably rather transfer their money into savings accounts.

The DTI is expected to announce an initiative this week following research commissioned by trade secretary Stephen Byers into what motivates consumers to switch service providers from banks to utilities and what deters them. Industry sources had expected the DTI to publish "best buy" tables, but senior sources believe the department has decided against such measures and will refrain from "naming and shaming".

webTitle: The rise of the individual worker

fields.headline: People power
fields.standfirst:
Why are employers willing to pay for flamenco dancing and pottery lessons? Bill Saunders on the rise of the individual worker - including the temp.

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Why are employers willing to pay for flamenco dancing and pottery lessons? Bill Saunders on the rise of the individual worker - including the temp.
fields.body:
What is the point of leaving parties? Why do we all pile into a wine bar on a wet Friday night to get to know somebody we will never see again? Professor Alec Reed, founder of the Academy of Enterprise, but better known as the chairman of Reed Employment, raised this simple question recently at a personnel conference in Harrogate as an illustration of how the relationship between employers and employees has changed.

We supposedly live in an age of insecurity, of short-term contracts and temporary assignments. The trend took off during the recession at the start of the 1990s, but it has continued to grow as we near what statisticians count as full employment. The fly-by-night nature of temporary assignments makes it hard to estimate how many people are temping, but the best guess is that it is about 1.2m on any given day, and rising. About a quarter of these temps will be in secretarial or admin positions. But, argues Reed, it is employers who should feel insecure over this arrangement.

As competition for staff increases, it is employers who will have to be more flexible in understanding what workers want. Reed cites the example of a senior manager in his own organisation who quit to train as a ballet dancer in Moscow. People at all levels have aspirations and unless employers learn to cultivate these they will lose their best workers.

The old model of exemplary staff relations is gone - "such traditonal employee champions as Marks & Spencer are crumbling before our eyes," says Reed. Instead of paternalism, Reed advocates maternalism. "In our maternal approach, we offer an interest-free loan to co-workers [Reed's term for employees], a home computer scheme, confidential counselling and free training. Co-members may take any non-vocational lessons they please, whether they be tennis lessons, pottery classes or flamenco dancing, and we will pay half the cost."

The switch from paternal to maternal is not a temporary reflection of the strength of the labour market, however. It is not the case that, come the next recession, we must brace ourselves to hang up our ballet shoes and be grateful for the free white wine at the Christmas party. Indeed, most temps would probably be astonished at the idea that they are the shock troops of a new economic order.

Yet Reed is adamant that a fundamental change has taken place in the economy. "It is people," he says, "who determine the strength of a business venture." His arguments hinge on the most basic economic principle of supply and demand. There is a glut of goods, there is a glut of investment capital; what is in short supply are talented people who can create the added value which will persuade a jaded and sophisticated public to buy. But since creative people are in short supply, the cost of employing them shrinks the profit margins. The individual is more powerful than the organisation.

So the theory goes, and it is convincing enough to persuade one of the merits of becoming a creative person. If you are a temp, however, you might already be more creative than you realise. Because it is temps who are probably best adapted to an environment in which, in Reed's words, "we work where we want, for whom we want, when we want".

Reed dates his belief in what he calls "peoplism" to 1994. It is certainly the case that, in 1996, Reed Employment released some interesting research into the state of morale in the office. It was found that permanent workers felt far more insecure than the temps they increasingly found themselves working alongside. It appeared to the permament workers that they had only one asset - their knowledge of their own particular job - which they had every reason to suppose might disappear at any time. Temps, by contrast, had a wide range of experience.

There is no doubt that the new world of peoplism is not always as stable as one would like. The notorious Kelvin McKenzie reportedly used to greet recruits to L!ve TV by shaking hands twice "in case I'm not in the office when you're fired". Reed's suggestion that employers should learn to hold joining parties, as opposed to leaving parties, sounds altogether more pleasant.
